comment: I would definitely say that Spence is a super engaging professor, and I loved going to class with him. Compared to other professors, his grading is a little hard because he does not give out as much extra credit.
Professor Spence was Amazing. Truely caring individual and always wanted to see his students succeed. You have to put in the work; however if you do so micro will be a breeze.
Hilarious lecturer, but the work assigned outside of class isn't enough to be prepared for tests, especially  if you have no prior econ experience.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Spence is the man. Light homework and entertaining lectures. If you go to lectures and put in a little effort you will get an A pretty easily. Understanding and really fun dude.

Honestly such a bad professor. His class will single-handedly crash your GPA. I will not be taking any more of his classes if I can avoid it. I don't care if he's 'nice', I care about the quality of his teaching which is of very poor quality.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Spence is simply incredible. He makes a sincere effort to learn every student's name, despite lectures being >100 people. He provides modern context to concepts and has an engaging, hilarious lectures. There was extra credit on every test, and he truly provides the resources to do well. My own mediocre grade is a reflection of me, not him.

He is an amazing guy and def take him. He canceled class a lot and we left early for most of the classes too. The workload is not too bad with around 1 assignment per week. A lot of resources for the midterm and he sometimes reuse questions from the practice exams. You can tell he is passionate about economics and really cares about his students!
This guy rocks.

He's a great guy, at times the concepts were hard to understand as someone with no prior knowledge of economics. Very engaging lectures and truly cares that his students learn the content. Tests can be difficult and are worth a large portion of your grade, so be prepared to study a lot. About 1 assignment a week sometimes none.

Prof. Spence gave great lectures, though sometimes I struggled to understand the concepts since I did not take AP Micro in high school, and it seems like most students in the class did. However, he gave lots of resources to study and was always willing to meet and go over concepts or give study advice.
Professor Spence is a great teacher. Super good lecturer and honestly made me more interested in economics. Some of the tests can be a bit tricky but he is overall a great teacher and a great guy.

The professor made me study the most I ever had and I still gave him a 5 based on his teaching style and personality. He is an amazing guy and he always updates his slides based on current events going on, such as the election.
Wow! What a great guy! He has great TAs too. Make sure to take him for microeconomics!
Fell in love with Spence, fell in love with the graphs, and flirted with economics.

W/O econ background this will be a harder class, but an A is still doable. Taking the abundance of practice tests provided is the best way to study imo. Spence has a great sense of humor and is a wholesome professor overall. Also, lectures and HW are often related to modern events which I love. You will need to put work in, but great class.

Spence is a great teacher if you put in the work. A couple hours of work each week on problem sets/writing assignments are more for practice than points, and the two midterms + final make up 75% of the grade. Info is mostly based on lectures and notes drawn on chalkboard, and class is very easy if you have taken micro before.
Spence is an awesome dude, he's young and gets being in college. Taking good notes is essential. His huge amount of homework takes away a lot of the stress of exams.

Definitely better for micro than stats, but still absolute GOAT. Biggest thing is he's funny and cares/understands college students. Lectures may be a little confusing, but he does pretty good job of explaining it. Don't need prior knowledge of stats, but it is definitely helpful. Pay attention in lecture and do LOTS of practice problems to do well

I have never taken a stats course and it was hard! If you put the work in you will be satisfied. The exams are straightforward but still difficult. I think Spence is a great professor. Everything he gives you if useful.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He moves extremely slowly in this class. He understands his students well, but he is not a great teacher of this material. It is his first time teaching this class which might be why. He seems very sloppy in his teaching style.
LOOOOVE PROF SPENCE!! So accessible outside of class. If you put in the work you will succeed. No busy work. Every assignment matters. Made microeconomics very interesting.

Prof Spence is a good professor and I loved his class. His class consists of problem sets, writing assignments, economic puzzles, and at times extra credit. Midterms 1 and 2 and the final are so hard. He's super fast-paced at times not thoroughly going through material. TBH... just glad I passed this class.

I loved Professor Spence for micro! He's a very engaging lecturer and his office hours were super helpful for solving the weekly problem set and reinforcing concepts. If you like application more than memorization, take this class because you can use a "cheat sheet" for every test and three for the final! Would highly recommend!

Spence is AMAZING. One of the "must take" professors in my opinion. Lectures are very engaging. Not a lot of homework either. Problem sets due every 3-4 classes that take around 35 minutes. Two midterms, one final. Does a great job explaining concepts and gets you to think about real world implications. Cannot recommend you take his class enough.

I had absolutely 0 prior experience with ECON prior to taking this class, so it was difficult at first. However, Spence did a really good job of being available and providing extra opportunities to learn. There is only one homework assignment a week that isn't super time consuming. Less math focus and more conceptual. Definitely suggest taking him.

Spence is a caring and enthusiastic professor. I had previously taken Micro early my sophomore year in highschool and had AP credit, but chose to retake it for a better foundation for my econ major. I got a bit bored during his lectures, but I think that may be because I was familiar with the material. Not much work outside of class.

Professor Spence is great. Awsome guy who truly makes an effort to get to know students. Lectures are fun, but can be a bit confusing. To do well on exams go over practice tests and problem sets repeatedly and exams should be easy. Also going to his office hours was very helpful to doing well in the class.

Professor Spence can sometimes be unclear in his lectures but for the most part, uses relatable analogies and stories that apply to microeconomics. His value comes from his willingness to meet with underclassmen to give them guidance on majors and overall direction. He went on a thirty-minute walk around campus with me when I needed some advice.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: People love Spence and rightfully so, he's an engaging and fun lecturer. Sometimes micro content wasn't always explained in the best way but he's open for questions. HW is problem sets and your grade is basically boosted by the economic puzzles -- never got less than full credit. Tests aren't too far off from the problem sets.

Absolutely GOATed professor and DUS, possibly my best at ND. Truly caring and amicable. Foremost in his mind is remembering he is there to teach you not torture you (surprisingly rare!). Very funny! Non-Econ majors seem to have a tougher time extracting the intuition from his lectures, per reviews, but he is super accessible! Love this guy!

spence was an amazing lecturer and I absolutely loved going to class. However, the fun lectures came at a price- he would barely explain concepts in class and kinda just skimmed across info. You would leave class thinking u knew it but then fail the exams. I am pre-med stem major and micro was my lowest grade. hard tests, easy course load.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dropped the class lol. If you have no prior experience in micro, don't take the class (as he is used to teaching people with more experience). Never really went in depth on a topic, barely explained the material. Felt fast-paced. He was good at cracking jokes every now and again but his class made me reconsider my Econ major.

Lazy professor, moved too fast and did not properly explain things to students. The structure of the class was not conducive to learning- poll everywhere is not a clear way of teaching topics. Prof. Spence is not a very fair teacher and there are many better microeconomics professors to take.

Spence is one of my favorite professors/teachers of all time. This class finally convinced me to become an economics major. He's a funny guy and takes the time to learn the names of his students, even with almost 200 people in each lecture.

Final exam was nothing like the review materials given. The average on the final was 78.5%, not a great reflection of his instruction. My grade went from an A to a B- based solely on the final and after, he sent a snarky email to all. I took AP Micro and had a solid base but came out of classes feeling more confused about topics I already mastered.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Spence was an enjoyable professor. Expectations were minimal other than showing up and doing a little reading. He enjoyed parroting free market talking points while individuals in the class pushed back against him. His goal was to convince us that economics is not the "dismal science." I don't know if he's succeeded.

Professor Spence was a fantastic lecturer and made me grasp the concepts of economics and change the way I view the world. However, his problem sets are rigorous (but there are TA sessions to help) and his tests are hard so be warned (not the easiest Econ professor at ND).

Principles of Micro is not an easy class by any means, but Spence makes the class extremely comprehensible and is probably the best professor I have ever had. Take this class for principles of micro and don't look back.

Spence shows genuine interest in getting to know his students and emphasizes that he is here for us personally. He makes Moreau something to look forward to. Not a harsh grader at all, just meet the requirements and you'll get 100s. He also brings bagels and coffee every week which made my Friday morning class a lot more enjoyable.

Your average Joe. Some might say the homework is excessive. He really loves to stress the importance of group work/collaboration sessions. However, I did not ever attend any group HW sessions, and I ended up doing well, so they are not necessary.

Such a nice guy and he is pretty accessible if you time it ahead of time. He shades liberal when he discusses politics, but otherwise very knowledgeable and fair. Weekly homework can be a lot but he grades very easily and you can have cheat sheets for tests.

He simply assumes that the students already know all the material and teaches concepts in an unnecessarily difficult manner. I feel as confused as ever, even though I took IB HL economics. His tests are the opposite of the practice tests and he only explains the materials through Panopto videos that are impossible to understand.

If you can take Spence for a class, especially Moreau, take him. He makes you want to show up to class and really keeps people engaged. He gave us bagels and coffee every week in Moreau. As long as you turned in your assignments, you will pretty much always get full credit.
Einstein's bagels and coffee every class. Great sense of humor and is extremely laid back. Easy A too - turn in your stuff, make it look like you tried and you get full credit.

Spence is awesome. His lectures were funny and helpful to understanding the material. Problem sets were not bad because they were collaborative, and it was easy to get an A on them if you go to the group problem solving sessions. Exams could be rough, but Spence was a great professor and I would definitely take again.

Professor Spence was great; his Moreau class actually made me look forward to Moreau. Not only did he usually bring bagels and coffee, but he also seemed to genuinely care about us. He just seems like such a nice guy, and if I ever take an Econ class, I know where to look.
Super funny and helpful. This is who you want for any micro class

Goated professor. I only got the grade I did because of my own lack of effort. He genuinely cares about his students and the content he teaches. He makes sure there are plenty of opportunities to get help outside of class. I always looked forward to his class and would definitely take him again if given the option.

He is such an amazing lecturer but the material is hard to grasp. It was a difficult class and even though I understood his lectures, the homework was difficult and the tests were even worse. Overall, the course itself is very difficult but it's possible to succeed if you put in the effort and ask for help. He truly is an amazing teacher overall.

Professor Spence is quite amazing. The class is a large step up from principles, but he really makes the lectures and content engaging. The HW is sometimes very very time consuming and difficult, but he encourages group work to help students. Exams are also very tough. He has inspired me to continue Econ for graduate work, and is my favorite prof.

Professor Spence is a great lecturer and made the content interesting, but his tests are very difficult. I did genuinely retain a lot of information from his class and really enjoyed every lecture he gave.

Such a caring professor, he takes the time to learn all 120 students' names. His only downside is the format at which he teaches the course. He goes out of order and makes the way you learn it confusing. Drones on at times about Econ topics and there is a fair amount of hw compared to other Econ 10010 courses.

Professor Spence was the best teacher Ive ever had in my life. His class was difficult not because of his teaching, but because the curriculum itself is hard. This class is problem sets and tests and the tests are exactly the same as the practice we do. Overall, I felt that I learned a lot and had a good experience and highly recommend Spence.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: This class is tricky but he's a great professor. One of the best in the Econ department.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Very difficult to understand because he talks super quickly and the PowerPoint slides are a mess. He's a nice enough person but the homework and exams are super frustrating.
Hard class but made me enjoy it.

Professor Spence set my standards for college professors through the roof. Everything after him has been a disappointment. Interesting and engaging lectures, genuine care for his students and their mental health, truly wants you to succeed. Exams were straightforward and he didn't try to trick you. If you have the chance to take Spence please do!

The best professor, and person, I've had here at my time at Notre Dame. Very rarely will you find as compassionate of a person who'll go out of their way to check up on their students. "how's your day going; how's life". From an academic standpoint: by putting effort in, you'll do well because there's tons of resources.

Most of my friends thought their Moreau classes were boring and pointless, but I looked forward to my moreau (which is saying a lot because I got stuck in a friday 8am). Forrest is thoughtful and his class was a chill convo/discussion in the sdh while we ate breakfast. My friends in his econ also love him!!! so kind

Absolute gem. Lectures were clear and interesting, he is available for office hours frequently, responds to emails insanely quickly, and manages to guide you to the answers when you need help without making you feel frustrated or stupid. He made me feel like he cared about my individual success in a 200+ person class. Please take his class.

Incredibly caring, this guy was the highlight of my semester. Really worried about our mental health, wanted us to do well in his class, and offered several opportunities to earn extra credit. Exams exactly like homework, really straightforward and interesting material.
As others have said, great professor. Problem sets were a little challenging, but he's a fantastic teacher and truly motivated to see students succeed. One of the Econ department's best
The absolute man. very interesting guy and class

Prof Spence is easily my favorite professor I have ever had. Micro was the only class that I was actually excited to go to everyday so that I could watch him lecture. He really cares about his students and makes an effort to learn everyones name. I promise you will not regret taking his class, everyone loves him.
Prof Spence is a gem

Genius, nothing more to say, he is a really good teacher that gives great feedback and makes lectures entertaining and worth going to. You will have to do some homework but it is made in such a way that you will be more than prepared to ace the class. Overall, a fantastic experience taking a subject that is not even in my major.

He's a nice enough person, but his class sucks. He talks a million miles per hour and lectures for an hour and fifteen minutes straight. Then, he likes to give extremely difficult homework, which is fine, except the examples he gives in class are so basic that they do not help with the hw. Be prepared to spend HOURS on it. Exams are exactly like hw

This was the first econ I ever took, but he is very clear when he teaches and is great at getting the concepts across. Lots of assignments, but they are all purposeful in helping learn the material. Even though he had hundreds of students he knew my name and always promptly answered my emails. Would highly recommend!

Professor Spence has got to be one of the best econ professors out there. He cares about his students, and somehow manages to remember quite a few names in a class of over 100 students. He keeps his lectures entertaining, and is a very relatable, down to earth guy. I also respect him for teaching econ without partisan bias.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Spence is a great professor. The class is focused heavily on the lectures, so although attendance isn't required, it is highly encouraged. There is a lot of weekly homework. However, Professor Spence is very accessible outside of class and is willing to help everyone understand economics.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Spence is one of the best professors at Notre Dame. He makes an effort to learn every student's name and regularly gives personal feedback on graded assignments. He genuinely cares about your success in this class. There is a decent amount of homework per week, and exams are pretty difficult, but he has lots of extra credit opportunity

I had Spence for both principles of micro and intermediate micro. While principles was super easy with him, intermediate micro was much more difficult. I still really like him as a professor because he gives interesting lectures and is accessible outside of class. Spence has lots of charisma, and everyone who's taken his class loves him.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: He is very knowledgeable in economics. His lectures are focused around explaining and walking through the topics so it is really important to go. The class is fairly difficult but if you put in the effort you will be fine. Also definitely go to the collaboration sessions he sets up because those are very helpful.

Prof. Spence is easily the best professor I've had in my life. He is incredibly passionate about what he's teaching, and makes abstract and complex topics interesting through his very engaging classes. He does assign a lot of homework; yet it is quite fun and out-of-the-box. If you are taking Microeconomics, Prof. Spence is a MUST!

This was my favorite class I've taken so far. Although there was a lot of homework assigned, it really helped to grasp the material. I thought his lectures were incredible; he is very funny, easy to understand, and makes an effort to learn everyone in the classes name and face. He made an introductory class meaningful for me.

Spence has been my favorite teacher so far. The class itself is very interesting, and Spence does a good job of communicating concepts that a lot of people have never seen before. While there is a lot of homework, it is very helpful in understanding the concepts. He is very accessible if you have any questions.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Spence is an awesome guy. He makes you do a lot of homework outside of class and the homework impacts your grade significantly so you have to do it well. Spence really cares about the class and is very funny.

While Spence was passionate about economics, he assigned an overwhelming amount of homework. The writing assignments were lengthy and vaguely worded, while the puzzles were just confusing. The problem sets often had material we never covered. Don't take him if you don't want to spend upwards of 6 or 7 hours on pointless econ homework every week.
Great teacher, easy to learn in the class
Great professor. Took a subject that I did not expect to enjoy and make it fascinating every lecture. Fantastic class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: BEST PROFESSOR EVER But really, this guy was one of the best professors I have ever had. His class can sometimes be challenging, but it was intriguing nonetheless. Try to take his micro class at least once in your life, you will not regret it.

Really works with you to make sure you understand the material. Posts solutions to every problem discussed in lecture or on the homework, with a video where he talks through how to solve each and every problem. Great guy overall! Emailed me personally to congratulate me on improving from one exam to the next.
He is great. He cares about the students, teaches exactly what is on the exams, and is a very nice guy.
Hard not to love Sevov.  Very sweet and funny guy. Class difficulty is very manageable. Would highly recommend.

Sevov is one of the best professors in for gen chem, so if you can get him, DO IT! He explains in a simple way, but somethings aren't as clear as others so make sure you're focused and attentive in the lectures.

Sevov is a true character and really cared about his teaching even for a 300-student lecture. I love him as a person but just a warning the lectures are basically copying the notes he's writing down. Not a lot of demonstration or visual aid. And know that the lab is typically not correlated to the class which makes it slightly more difficult.
He is an amazing lecturer and an even better professor. His lectures are more conceptual-based, so tutorial worksheets may be confusing at first, but everything becomes clear easily.

Sevov is a great guy who evidently cares about the subject he teaches. The material could have been a little more organized and some subjects felt more rushed than others, but he overall does a good job explaining eveything that will appear on exams.

Mr. Sevov is good about not giving unnecessary information. His lectures only cover what you actually need to know. He mostly runs through examples of how to do problems in class. Paying attention to these prepare you well for the exams. When answering questions he sounds harsh, but he is not mean.
Goated Chem prof
Very knowledgeable guy with funny stories. Can sometimes be a little critical of people who ask questions during class, and his notes are a little messy.

Clear and concise lectures as he does all lectures by hand, so it feels as if you are discovering chemistry with him. He is truly caring and wants everyone to do well, and he never fails to crack a joke or to tell us one of his many stories. Great professor, great class.
Great professor that will teach using many examples.
Sevov is a great professor but lectures and notes are kind of difficult to understand.

Sevov doesn't overcomplicate the topics we cover unlike other profs teaching the course. He only focuses on things that actually show up on the test. Do the practice test and review the tutorial worksheets and you'll do just fine.
Professor Sevov made my semester w/ his class :)
Hard class, great prof
Sevov has a interesting sense of humor that makes chemistry bearable. His notes are hard to read, but he explains things in a clear way.

Sevov is a very great prof, his lectures are very example-heavy. the only downside is his handwriting, and he can be passive aggressive when you ask questions so sometimes you feel stupid. He is prob the best gen chem professor you can get
Lecture are to-the-point, cover material that shows up on exams, lots of clarity and not boring at all because he is so funny. Content is overall doable.
Sevov is generally a good professor and he tries to make the content as clear as possible.

Chemistry is a hard subject no matter what teacher you take, but Professor Sevov does his best to help you. His lectures and extremely clear and easy to follow. Highly recommend for anybody taking Chemistry.

Very knowledgeable on the subject, but somewhat impatient when it comes to answering honest questions.  Notes are oftentimes hard to follow, I have since learned that other professors' notes are easier to follow and better prepare you for the exam content.  However, I do appreciate how he tells dad jokes and stories at the start of his lectures.

Decent lecturer that also provided lecture notes in case you miss a lecture, but there were a few instances during lecture where I would just zone out for half of it. Easy HW and tests except for the last midterm. My only A- out of rest As due to this class requiring a good amount of memorization that I can't be bothered to do :(
Professor Sevov is a very good lecturer. He is well organized and makes sure all the material is taught in the most straight-forward and understandable way possible.

Slavi Sevov is a great professor, has a nice dry humor, and carefully explains to the students what will be on the exams. He'll make some mistakes, but it's all worth it because you get to learn about Bulgaria.

Sevov is a great guy and very funny. He is very knowledgeable on the topic but that sometimes means he forgets we are not. He explains things very well in class but I recommend finding your own way of taking notes during lectures as his notes are not easy to understand when studying or reviewing for tests. Other Profs notes are easier to understand

Slavi makes every class so much fun--he has a great sense of humor! He goes over the material without covering any unnecessary stuff, which is really helpful. I always felt prepared for every test. Just make sure you do the practice tests and you'll do great.
He is great in office hours, you should try to go often.

If you have no knowledge about chem, his style of lecture might be slightly harder to grasp. But if you know the subject, I would recommend him a million times.  He was a great guy, good at communicating, and more than willing to help after class / during office hours ALWAYS!
Was able to communicate the material well with handwritten notes and examples. He's a great guy and could always raise the atmosphere in the room with his funny anecdotes and stories.
Very concise and clear with him lectured but also cared for his students deeply
Absolutely adore him, so kind to students and very understanding. Doing hand written notes rather than slides that are very helpful and easy to follow.

Slavi Sevov is incredible. I took Intro to Chem with him last semester and myself and many others still talk about how amazing he was. Not only was he an efficient lecturer, but he extremely caring, and made our lecture of 200-300 kids all feel loved and cared about.

SLAVI. MF. SEVOV. If you have to take gen chem 1, take it with Slavi. Even if you're not in his section, go to his lectures. Genuinely so nice and gives amazing dad energy. Will roast you but it's always in the name of good fun. You can tell that he wants students to love chemistry as much as he does. Long story short, Slavi is the only answer.

I loved learning from Prof. Sevov. He has great "Dad" vibes, sharing a bit about his personal life throughout the semester which made lectures about Chemistry a bit more bearable. I did not take AP chem in high school, only went to lecture and took notes, and did perfectly fine in the course. Go to class and do the work and you'll be fine.

Professor Sevov gives very good lectures. He makes what you need to know clear and does not clutter the lectures with extra information. He walks through examples with simple step-by-step instructions. He occasionally starts class with a personal story or funny life lesson.

Gen Chem is hard in general, but he did a great job teaching it. No need to read the textbook because he covers everything in class. His teaching style is a little different, but it really helped me. Really helpful at office hours. 10/10 recommend for gen chem.

Professor Sevov is a great person and truly cares about his students, but if you need organized and clear notes his teaching style is difficult to follow. He goes through the material really fast and doesn't clearly answer questions. However, the TA's are VERY helpful during office hours and that is how I learned the most.

Professor Sevov is amazing! I cannot rave about him enough. His lectures were engaging and the exams were very similar to the material covered in lecture. His notes are just words on a blank piece of paper, which I prefer, but if you are someone who prefers powerpoints he might not be the teacher for you.

Sevov is definitely the best chem lecture to have. I had a lot of friends in other sections that came to his section because he was the best at teaching the material. He never keeps you late and always asks how every is doing. Also, he shared his life wisdom and experiences with the class in order to inspire. Overall, a very good man and professor.

Sevov is the best. He cares so much about his students and wants them all to be successful. Lectures moved fast but were extremely clear. He's great at answering questions and is willing to stick around a bit after class. If you take good notes and study, the class will be no problem.

Prof Sevov is the beloved teacher of gen chem. He explains concepts clearly and gives examples. He cares about his students, gives good life advice, is willing to work with you outside of class, and is usually ahead of the other classes which gives him time to answer questions before exams. Come to class and take notes--he prepares you well.
Professor Sevov is certainly a fun teacher. Makes concepts clear and uses plenty of examples throughout his lectures. Definitely have him as your professor for gen chem.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Sevov is undeniably the GOAT. Attend lectures, pay attention, do the homework, and you will succeed.

Easily the best Gen Chem professor. Goes through lots of examples in class, makes the material easy to understand, and is a super nice and funny guy. If possible, Sevov is the professor you'll want to have for gen chem.
Sevov is the Gen Chem 1 professor to have. He teaches only the stuff that you have to know. Great at explaining the information and giving example problems.

Please take Gen Chem with Professor Sevov. Without a doubt one of the greatest professors I will probably have during my time here. He is always straightforward and clear about the content during lectures, and always includes practices problems within them to apply the material we learned. 10/10 no matter what your background in chemistry is.
beloved professor. if you have to take chem 10171 take sevov he's the best of the four.
Chem is a boring, strict class and not very useful for most, but Sevov makes it fun.

Professor Sevov is probably the best professor to have for Chem. He goes through lots of examples in class compared to the other professors. He knows what he is talking about and his notes are very clear, so even if you miss class it is not difficult to follow what happened in class. I would highly recommend him, he just gives off good vibes.
The Lectures are good mostly easy to understand. If you miss some classes it will be harder but you can still catch up, however, tutorials and exams are hard but they don't depend on the professor.
so sweet
30x more personality than any of the other chem teachers, gotta be honest I kind of enjoy the class
Literally the best. Dad energy is off the charts, he explains concepts concisely and memorably. He's hilarious and we all love him. Easily the best chem professor at ND.
He's simply the GOAT.
What a nice and engaging professor! He's Bulgarian but his accent is not hard to understand. He sometimes speeds through topics that are hard to understand, but if you ask questions he'll slow down!

We *literally* cheered when Slavi came back after being substituted by another professor. Cares about students, and is the best of the University's Intro Chem Professors at communicating material effectively.

Great professor! Basically a write-and-talk lecture. Very light-hearted and fun, cracks good jokes and gives off dad energy. Explains the material pretty well but the class can go fast at times and if you did not take AP Chem/have a good background in chem you might struggle a little. His accent is pretty fun to listen to. Had a good time in class!

Favorite prof of the semester, would 100% recommend. His lectures are clear and straightforward and he has a great sense of humor. He tells you everything you need to know and nothing you don't.  Some other profs have unnecessary info in their lectures that arent on the tests. Cares about students and answers questions.
The class is pretty boring but sevov is so nice and funny and really cares about his students. He has the best lecture notes and is very clear.
Absolute gem. so funny, so easy going. posted notes online, went through examples in class, definitely the best chem teacher out there

LOVED HIM! My favorite professor this semester! I've heard gen chem is very tough but his lectures are very straight forward and easy to follow. He gives you the material you need to know for tests with applicable examples. He's funny and cares about his students.

Sevov was one of my favorite profs this semester, his lectures can be a little dry sometimes but they're easy to follow. Just copy the notes that he writes down and you'll be good. He gives enough time to copy them which is nice. Really wants the students to do well. Says some of the funniest stuff sometimes.

A GEM. One of my favorite professors this semester. Uses class time efficiently, and explains concepts so well that students from other classes often skip their classes to come to ours. Hilarious without even trying. Truly cares about his students and willing to help you understand things you're confused about. Protect him at all costs!

Cuts to the chase and says things to the point. Copy his notes and listen to his explanations and that's all you need to do well in the class. He can lack engagement at times but he has a good sense of humor and is good at explaining the important concepts and problem examples that will be on tests.

Amazing professor. I cannot tell you how much content I truly learned. This was the first class where I didn't care about the grade I got— I really just wanted to truly learn the content. However, this class is a lot of work. Be prepared for this class to take up a lot of your time. If you put in the work, you'll get an A.

Professor Brown is a great teacher. I would have given him a 5 had I gotten an A (I was less than a half point below the cut-off). Nonetheless, it is a lot of work and pretty difficult. Try to get practice tests from previous years because he only gives you one per exam to study from.

The class was tough and concepts were taught with few examples, but it's necessary for the amount of content this class covers. Although Wednesday mornings seemed like torture at times (be prepared to get cold called to explain questions from the problem set), overall loved Professor Brown for chem!! More than anything, this class builds character.

This class is a weeder! Homework/tests are difficult due to them being application-based. He's a great lecturer, but you MUST go to office hours weekly to understand the problems. If you put in a huge amount of work, you'll be successful. Also, Seth Brown just doesn't get that people are dumber than him; sometimes his explanations aren't helpful.
Super difficult, but a great lecturer. Love the class, but if you're worried about your grades more than the content you're learning, don't take the class.

I loved having professor brown, I personally think he made chemistry for fun for me. To each their own, it is a tough class but it is very interesting. He is very smart professor so at times you may feel overwhelmed but you'll get through it. It kind of is a weeder class so enter with caution.

The people that think Dr. Brown is anything less than a 5 either didn't go to office hours and complaining about the difficulty or just don't pay attention. He is one of the BEST chem professors you can have. If you go to office hours and find a good group to study with, the tests and problem sets are really eye opening. don't complain, do the work
Run. Do not take. Beware.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Seth is an absolute genius, but also a gifted communicator that allows him to explain concepts well. Office hours are a NECESSARY part of the class; going once a week is enough. I took an easy semester, this was where more than 80% of my effort went. Seth is a great person and TAs are super helpful. Only take this class if you really love chemistry

If you are a biochem major and didn't take AP Chem in high school, beware of this class. Will probably take up 90% of your time. If you have social anxiety/problems with criticism also do not take and opt for an easier chem, as weekly you will have the chance of being called up to the board for tough problems and being placed on the chopping block.

Seth Brown is an AMAZING professor. He is an engaging lecturer and truly cares about his students, offering many hours of office hours every week. However, this class is as BEAST. The exams and problem sets are extremely hard; however, the curve is great. If you do not like chemistry, don't take, but if you do, this class is amazing!

Dr Seth Brown is not only too smart to be teaching this class, but very rude at times. Upon asking to speak with him one on one (his office hours were basically a repeat of lecture - too crowded), he told me that he was simply too busy. If you are premed... do not take his class. Do not major in chemistry or biochemistry unless you want a PHD.

I really enjoyed this class and honestly did not think it was as much work as people say (no easy A though). AP experience helped a lot but not necessary. The only thing that WAS necessary: LOVE chemistry. If you don't, run as far as you can from Seth Brown. But if you do, he is a great lecturer who is very dedicated to his students.

Professor Brown is one of the most helpful professors there are. He is very willing to help any student outside of class and provides excellent explanations; however, this class will consume your life. This class was where 90% of my effort from the semester went. The problem sets and exams are ridiculously hard. CHEM10181 is not easy.

Professor Brown puts so much effort into getting to know his students and is super accessible outside of class (highly recommend going to office hours for problem sets!) That being said, the class is insanely difficult and requires way too much time and effort (problem sets are impossible). The generous curve and lab grade carried my course grade.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Lecturer for the "for-major" chemistry Gen Chem 1 courses. Walking into this, you may think your 5 in ap chemistry will get you easily through this class, but this is simply not the case. Hard, lots of homework, but a very rewarding class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Brown is one of the best lecturers I know, but this class is not for the faint of heart as it dives deep outside of the scope of a gen chem curriculum. My honest advice: DO NOT TAKE if you are not planning on getting a phd in chem or biochem. I don't care who you are and how smart you think you are, don't take if that is not your plan.

Seth Brown is an amazing lecturer and made sure to learn everyone's name in our class. That being said, if you are not dead set on getting a phd in chem or biochem don't take this class. It is not worth it for premed and most people end up switching. It is completely different from non majors chem. Awful problem sets and tests. Ridiculously hard.

Dr. Brown is a great prof., but this class is VERY DIFFICULT. It is much harder than the non-chem major chem, so I highly suggest that any premed students stay clear of the chem/biochem major; your GPA will struggle.The amount of hours you'll put into this class for a mediocre grade is ridiculous. More than half of students switch to easier major.

Brown is required for chem and biochem majors. If you want a decent chem grade, get out of there. That said, really knowledgeable guy and awesome lecturer with tough tests. Makes problem sets only doable if you go to office hours. Wouldn't take again but this class isn't the nightmare some people might say it is.

I think he is a wonderful professor that will help very much when you ask him questions outside of class and is always there to meet one on one. That being said, DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS!! Especially if you want a good GPA. You might think you know chem, but trust me, you do not. This is a completely different level than chem for non-chem majors.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: He was great in lectures, but you would quickly realize that he did not teach you everything you needed to know for lectures. Exams were more difficult than the practice exams. There were questions on the exams that I never seen on the practice problems. He also takes unnecessary pts off. Still recovering for the number he did on my gpa

Professor Brown made an effort to learn everyone's name in this large lecture. However, he left information out of the lectures that was needed for the difficult problem sets and exams. You have to go to office hours and ask questions to gain this necessary information and to be successful in this class. TAs were impatient and unhelpful at times.

Seth Brown's class is extremely difficult and challenging; however, he makes it light hearted and interesting. His lectures are amazing and you can tell he truly cares about his students and Chemistry. He applies everything to real world applications and is lighthearted. Problem sets are hard, so MAKE SURE YOU GO TO OFFICE HOURS!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Brown is very smart and gives really in-depth lectures that can be hard to understand at some points. You have really hard problem sets that you have to go to office hours 4 hours a week. If you are not dead set on being a Chem or Biochem major I would not take this course. He does however give a really high curve because the class is so hard.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Professor Brown is truly amazing. His lectures are instructive and his sense of humor will keep you engaged. While the problem sets are quite hard, he is more than willing to help (both in office hours and outside them), and he genuinely cares about his students. He makes an effort to get to know all of us. Highly recommend (neuro major as well)!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Still trying to recover from the absolute number this did on my GPA over a year later. His problem sets were so unnecessarily hard.

Dr. Brown is one of the best teachers I have ever had. He is very quirky and makes his lectures interesting and easy to follow. However, the class itself is very difficult. The only way to understand the problem sets is to go the office hours. Get ready to not understand all of the content completely

Seth Brown is great! This is definitely the hardest chem class I have ever taken, but he does so much to help outside of class and it is apparent that he cares about his students and their progress. I would recommend him because he has great lectures and keeps the class interesting and lighthearted.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Very funny guy, he made his lectures entertaining and you can tell he put effort into teaching. He is the smartest guy in the entire chemistry department, which means he is very knowledgeable, but sometimes it can be confusing to understand. Office hours are a must. Made an effort to know everyone, especially in office hours, despite 120 class.

This class is tough, and if you've asked anyone who's taken it they will agree. Seth Brown is a great lecturer and class was always very interesting, however the problem sets that you have to do every weekend are WAY more difficult than lecture and require office hours. The tests are rough, but he sets the grading scale accordingly.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Brown is a wonderful professor although his class is quite difficult. His lectures are entertaining and informative, and he is also extremely accessible outside of class. Office hours are must if you want to get a decent grade. Be prepared for his difficult tests and problem sets. Although his class is tough, I absolutely love him.
Wants to see his students not succeed. Does not teach everything necessary for the class

His lectures are quite entertaining. He jokes a lot and is very engaging, explaining concepts clearly the first time with relevant analogies and examples. The problem sets were difficult, and there were not enough office hours (four weekend hours with 120 students all needing help). Tests were difficult but manageable.

One of the best lecturers that I had and will ever have. That said, it was one of the most difficult classes I have been in. He is a great man and will explain everything to the fullest. The problem sets are really hard, but if you go to office hours you should be fine. The exams get increasingly more difficult. Overall would take again.
Very rude professor. Does not know how to teach organic chemistry. Leaves out a lot of information needed for examinations. I do not recommend him!

Great guy- funny person. Very accessible outside of class. His class is probably the most difficult class I've ever taken. Material on problem sets and exams is much harder than anything learned in class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: One of the best professors I've had so far at Notre Dame. Organic chemistry is not an easy subject to teach or learn, but his lectures are really well prepared and his office hours are some of the most helpful homework sessions I've ever had.

Seth Brown, Great person, not a great teacher. Is extremely brilliant and holds his students to the same standard. His lectures are clear and concise but the exams are at a level entirely different from any material learned in class. Don't get discouraged by any bad grades, Gen chem is a weed out class, you'll be fine.

Gen Chem is hard af, no way around it. But Prof. Brown's lectures and his willingness to chat with you about anything Chem makes it bearable. He writes everything important on the board. All you have to do in this class is record exactly what he puts down because it'll be on the exam. Super bright guy and funny, awesome teacher.
Real good professor, class is just very hard, definitely a weed out class.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Gen Chem's a rough class, but Brown makes it bearable. He's funny, organized, and his lectures (though sometimes a lot less in-depth than the tutorial questions) make the material easy to understand. Take SUPER good notes during lecturesmy notes were probably my most useful study tool.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Brown is a great lecturer, but not a good guy to talk to one-on-one. He can be condescending. Gen Chem is a tough class, though, and I think he's the best person to teach it.

Really smart guy. His lectures are very well-planned and helpful, and occasionally hilarious. He makes he expectations pretty clear, though, and he grades pretty unforgivingly if you don't put in the effort to reach them.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof. Brown is almost too smart to teach. He gets way too in depth for a Gen Chem course in my opinion, and doesn't give examples in class, which is annoying. He also was always a lecture or two behind the material that we needed for the homework, which was super frustrating. He was funny at times but also used too much lofty language for my taste.
Somehow he manages to make chemistry which is hard, fun and interesting
Best teacher ever period.

Brown is widely known as the best professor at ND.  He knows all the material like the back of his hand and makes 300 person lecture halls all understand it.  He is absolutely hilarious but he is also very clear when teaching and conveys what we need to know and how we will be evaluated on our knowledge.  Only grades are tests.

Seth Brown. Words cannot describe him. Even if you despise chem with every fiber of your being, it is factually impossible to hate Seth Brown. Chem is hard regardless of what professor you have. Seth Brown makes it manageable, personable, and fun- you couldn't ask for anything more.

Seth Brown is THE MAN. His problem sets are difficult, but class is awesome and engaging (Shakespeare+Chem anyone?). Tests aren't nearly as hard as the homework, but still make you earn your grade. If you can take a class with Seth, do it.

Amazing professor. Definitely take him if you can... I was not a chemistry major but enjoyed his class and learned a LOT. He made lecture interesting and is just a very unique person everyone should meet at some point in their lives. A year and a half after taking his class, he still said hi to me by name on the way to DeBartolo.

This class is HARD, but Seth Brown is amazing! His practice problem sets made me cry on more than one occasion, but they prepare you really well for the tests. And Dr Brown is always there to help you if you need it. He's one of the smartest people I've ever met and he really cares about his students-he'll know everyone's name in a 100-person class
No Comments

Seth Brown is pure genious.  This class is extremely difficult, and would be almost unbearable without Seth Brown, but because Pro. Brown is teaching it, it is one of my favorite classes this semester.  This professor is hilarious and literally makes quantum physics fun. This is one professor you need to have had in your liftime.

Wietstock gets a bad rap, but he has a tough job. He's not the most enthusiastic professor in the world but if you bring the right attitude, he's friendly and helpful. That said, it's a lot of work- as much as some 3 credit classes if you don't have much chem experience.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: The lab largely falls on TAs, with Dr. Wietstock's only real contribution being mini lectures. His explanations are boring, monotone, disengaging, which was particularly emphasized when Dr. Horgen took over for a day. He is knowledgeable, though, and the lab itself isn't that hard, with write-ups rarely relying on accuracy of data. You'll survive.

This class is pretty awful, but the reviews here are mostly overreactions. It's relatively easy with almost all students getting either an A or A-. Wietstock is generally apathetic towards the students, though, and his lectures were not engaging whatsoever.

Overall, Dr. Wietstock is a fairly nice guy. However, he was never present in the lab to answer questions or help out. He lazily sits in the classroom and fully relies on young TAs. Other professors who filled in for him while he was gone were in the lab helping us constantly. Strangely enough, he always openly ate Arby's while we did the lab...
He is very knowledgeable and a good person overall, however, he does not really engage in the lab. He is not very helpful in answering questions and makes the TA's do a lot of the work.

Chem lab is one credit, but it feels like three. Chem lab is the worst part of everyone's week, regardless of the teacher. However, Wietstock is one of the least charismatic university professors I have seen, and is a hard ass for no reason. Take Dana Horgen, who is more organized, better in prelab lecture, and also a stunningly beautiful woman.
No major issues with him, however the other chem lab professors are much more involved and helpful in answering questions to develop your understanding.
Great professor who will show you the same effort you put in. Just show up to his office hours and show that you care.

Professor Wietstock demonstrates complete apathy towards his students. I don't think he learned a single name in our entire lab section. He begins each class with an extensive lecture, and then when the actual lab gets started, he is nowhere to be seen. Good grades are guaranteed if you do the work, but it's a lot of work for just a 1 credit class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment:
In the lecture hall where knowledge seeks,
A Jabba-like professor, sluggish speaks.
The class, a puzzle, not perfectly aligned,
Yet through the academic night, we find.

I'd buy my TA flowers, a gesture sweet,
Gratitude blooms, sentiments meet.
In this journey of knowledge and strife,
Grace colors our academic life.

Professor Wietstock's organization skills are severly lacking. The way that the lab is set up makes absolutely no sense. Students must complete a pre-lab writeup before class, take a quiz in class, and then be taught the material in a lecture. The order is inane. This, of course, eats into lab time, of which there is hardly ever enough.

Dr. Wietstock is a nice guy, but this class caused me unnecessary pain. I can put in the same effort of work and get an A or C on the lab, depending on the grader. Lectures were boring and those quizzes were unnecessarily difficult. Lab instructions are unclear (and equipment is often broke) so I recommend befriending your TA; they are lifesavers.

Professor Wietstock is very monotone and his lab is very boring. The TA's are the ones who actually help the students through the class and with the prelab and write-ups. Prepare to spend a bit of time with this class, but it's not unmanageable.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment:
Does not explain lab content well at all. Never in sync with lecture. Not willing to help outside of class.
Doesn't even help in lab, just sits at his desk. TAs are very helpful !

Of all the talk there was about Wietstock at the beginning of the semester, he is not that exaggeratedly bad. He still is bad, but he is not the worst lab professor to have in the world. While his lectures go by extremely slowly and he has weird quirks, the class is so easy to get an A in. All you have to do is the work, which is admittedly boring.
Quite snarky. Passive agressive. Denies making mistakes. Asks to buy his textbook which has multiple errors in them as well as not being original (The experiments are all online).

Bro literally does not care a single ounce about any of the students in his class. Any questions get shut down. Most of the time during post quiz talks, he is the single most boring human being that has ever existed. He does not care if you have anything going on, or if you are experiencing issues that legitimately are not your fault. 
L teacher.
Would never do it again

Worst professor at Notre Dame by far. Beyond difficult to comprehend and merciless when it comes to asking for questions, extensions, broken lab materials, etc. I have seen first hand TAs have to recollect themselves in the corners of the lab with the amount of stress, panic, and broken materials surrounding each week of lab. Quizzes very hard.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: The absolute worst professor at Notre Dame.

Wietstock's lab felt to me like a waste of time. Long, dry, and useless lectures preceding every lab on material already covered in the main class. Required to copy lab instructions in our notebooks before lab(why???), and then went over them again before lab. This left limited time to complete the lab. Some nice TAs but Weitstock is useless.

Boring teacher. Grading rubric is so bad. Says the class is supposed to "teach you how to be in lab" and yet there is no teaching. You just learn from getting terrible grades until you understand what they want. Every lab after this is fine. Sadly, it is required. Find a good TA to ask for help with the reports and that will help.

Contrary to popular opinion, I didn't hate chem lab as much as most of my classmates. As long as you read the pre-lab textbook you will be fine on the quizzes and if you email a TA about a question on the write-up they will provide helpful feedback. I will say it is a somewhat stressful environment, but if you follow directions you will be fine.

Professor Wietstock does not care about his students and created a very stressful environment in lab. Students who were even a minute late were given a zero even if they were taking another exam. He was not helpful or supportive and the TA's did all the grading, which was often graded very hard.

Prof Wietstock essentially didn't do anything in lab so hope you have a good TA. Very strict on attendance. Labs (that he wrote and makes us pay for) make no sense and writeups are tedious. Prelab quizzes are hard but not worth many points. He is fairly pleasant outside lab but did deny my friend disability accommodations which I think is illegal.

Professor is not very involved in the lab. Definitely get to know your TA and ask him any questions you have. Lab and content are not difficult, although the class is out of sync with the lecture. Quiz questions are very specific, so make sure to review the material.

Wietstock is the worst. I'm actually surprised the University keeps him around. Shows no kindness or sympathy - don't even bother emailing him with any questions; he won't respond. Overall chem lab sucks but to be fair it's a pretty easy A if you do the work.

Steve Wietstock does not care about his students or their grades. He sat in the back of my class every day and ate fast food while we were in the lab. The pre-lab quizzes were difficult and it was rare to get a 5/5. The work itself was not too bad, there were just times when the lab itself would take longer than the allotted class time (3 hours).
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: he has you do long division by hand because that is for some reason indicative of your knowledge of chemistry.
Odious, odious man. Goes out of his way to make the class a pain for students.

This man is terrible at his job. He does absolutely nothing. If you have a bad TA, good luck. His pre-lab lectures will put you to sleep. You have to be to class on time because there's quizzes at the beginning of each class. I have seen him  give zeros to students who are late with valid excuses. He shows no mercy.
This man is not good at his job.

Arrive early to lab because he gives quizzes at the beginning of every class that require a code to get in...he will not give you the code if you come in late. Instead, he will give you a zero. He is not very compassionate and he only ever sits in his chair. The TA's most (all) of the work, so hopefully you get a good TA.

This professor does not care about his class. The curriculum he teaches is poor and unrelated to the chemistry lessons.  his own TAs rant about him to the students because of how unreasonable he is.  This man does not understand empathy, one of my friends got the flu and had to go to the emergency room, and asked for an extension but was denied.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment:
Arrive early to lab! Prof. Wietstock has clear rules, and he's strict about some things, but it's all of necessity. He's a nice guy that has a lot of responsibility placed on him by the university so he's strict about some stuff: don't forget your lab notebook, or your lab equipment!

TAs are your friends!! Get to know them, and how they grade!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: What an absolutely terrible professor to have lab with. To start off, he writes the book that you will use in this lab, so he is getting a percentage of the ~$15 it costs for every student. He is NOT a nice person when it comes to answering emails and the system he has to turn in papers is incredibly confusing+unforgiving. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: The most universally dreaded class in the College of Science. Professor disdainful at students, entirely unresponsive, unnecessary and long lecture/prelab. Equipment never works, or enough of it. Hope that you don't get sick over a lab, or injure yourself trying to go regardless. Lab is out of sync with lecture, so it's on content you don't know.

I did not have a bad experience with him but I had a friend who was in the emergency room and missed a lab - Wietstock was not very forgiving in giving her a chance to make it up. Your grade for each post-lab is dependent on the TA grading it. Wietstock doesn't really do anything in the class. The post-labs are often pretty confusing.

Some people dislike Prof. W's teaching style because he takes time explaining what to pay attention to. However, he would give hints during his explanations, so PAY ATTENTION. He talks slowly enough for everyone to understand (v helpful), and if you try, he notices and is more likely to respond to you outside of class. Just keep asking questions!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Overall, this course was not too bad. The one thing that makes the course difficult is the amount of work associated with the post labs. Make sure that you record all of the numbers and statistics you need before leaving the lab and make sure to not procrastinate the post lab (they are worth a large portion of your grade and take considerable time)
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: He has the worst attitude but in all honesty the labs aren't difficult if you just follow instructions. If you need help just ask one of the TA's; asking Wietstock will get you nowhere
This lab makes me so miserable every week and Professor Wietstock isn't helpful.

Wietstock is as understanding as a gas station, and is as available outside of class as a Target after 11pm. Be prepared to read cranky, snarky emails on a weekly basis. Don't even think about sending him emails with questions. That's the equivalent of throwing your socks into a black holes. His TAs will be the only help you would ever receive.

He is very dismissive and rude. He either won't respond to emails or will yell at you for bothering him without answering your question. During our first day of lab, he literally told us he didn't want us to ask him any questions or send him any emails regarding anything in the class.

'Nuff said about his teaching style. It's all already been said. So long as you follow the instructions (do your labs online so people can read them, trust me) and make sure to double check your lab work with someone else, the course is honestly pretty easy. I got a 98 by just doing the work assigned to me.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Wietstock has the personality of a damp paper towel. Don't expect to get any help from him. If you read the e-book and utilize the help of your TAs, lab shouldn't be too bad. Just avoid Wietstock and let the TAs teach you.
Does not do anything. Just sits there and reads off a slide. Also, he never wants to answer questions

During the lab itself, I am not sure what Wietstock does. He lectures a little in the beginning of class and then is essentially done and the TAs take over. Lab is chaos. He is snarky and impolite for no reason. I honestly think he just enjoys deducting points.

Gives unclear instructions, changes the structure of assignments midway through the semester, does very little for the class, sends snarky and sometimes cryptic emails, takes himself too seriously, etc. The TA's tend to be more competent than him. Ultimately, be prepared for a lab course frustrating at best and completely infuriating at worst.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: The class usually involves him lecturing for a little bit before you do the lab, where you're in groups guided by TAs. His lectures are pretty good, but he's inflexible due to the class size. Also, if you're even a minute late he'll give a zero on the quiz he gives at the beginning of class. It's 2.5 hours, but you could usually get out early.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Lim gives no easy examples to start, jumps right into theory on the first day and makes you feel like you don't belong at Notre Dame. Took him my freshman year, and couldn't have felt like I belonged less because of him. He's passive aggressive and made me question Notre Dames reputation of its amazing people as soon as I stepped on campus.

Professor Lim is better than his reputation. All of the exams contain pretty similar questions to the homework, lectures, and tutorials. The class its self requires a lot of work and a lot of practice, but is definitely manageable. The worst part of the class is the mobius homeworks because they take a long time and have very hard numbers.

Found the lectures to be rather redundant, far too much time spent on theory, not enough on simpler examples. Left little class time for explaining efficient means by which we would be expected to solve problems on exams. Did'nt enjoy a second of the lectures. By the time you're done w/ Mobius hw you have no time/energy left to study independently.

Professor Lim is a great and hilarious lecturer. It takes a few classes to get used to his accent, but I didn't find it difficult after that. I enjoyed the way he lectures, except sometimes he would go way too far into theory and leave us with little to no examples. Mobius is very tedious and annoying, but it prepares you for the test well.
Professor Lim, overall, is a good professor. He is clearly brilliant at what he does, but he can occasionally be hard to follow.

The lectures can be challenging to follow as he goes quite fast and often prioritizes proving the methods over showing how to do the method, but he posts all the lecture videos and extra help videos explaining everything. The online homework program, Mobius, is the worst and often very challenging/time consuming but the tests are super easy.

I'm shocked at how many reviews are exaggerating how bad Lim's teaching is. Things he could've done better is covering the material in class time and covering more examples than concepts. However, this class is definitely not undoable. Lim teaches you everything you need to succeed. He is also open to feedback and cares for his students.

Lim is a good person who cares about the students he teaches. As a professor though, he is not always the best. I found he often went too fast in class for me to both copy and understand what he was writing in his notes. Also, he spends a lot of time covering conceptual material that is not important for the exams.

Professor Lim is the best of the calculus A/B profs. He likes to see students do well, and is willing to help if you don't understand a concept. The textbook and tutorials are useless, and the best thing is to do practice problems. The homework will give you a headache. The exams are fair, but the course requires a ton of effort/work.

I prayed every morning a FedEx truck would hit me on my way to class to avoid seeing this man's face. He does not care about helping you and will respond to emails informing you that you do not belong at ND. The HW will be enough to make you question your decision of school. If not, the 3 additional lectures he expects you to watch will be.

Degrading, passive-aggressive, and takes pride in failing students. Prepare for 10+ hours of useless HW due every football Saturday. Instead of altering exams to account for his lack of ability to get through the material, he expects you to watch extra lectures he posts. Tutorials are also pointless and used as additional lectures and more HW.

The content on Lim's exams couldn't be further from what he actually "teaches" in class. He shows a bunch of proofs and then the test questions are completely different applications of concepts. You also spend an absurd amount of time on homework. Completely miserable class. I cried tears of joy when I was finally out of that hell.

Unfortunately this devil of a person runs the Calc department so you're screwed whether he teaches your lecture or not. This is less a review to dissuade you from the course as you most likely have to take it no matter what. It is more so in hopes this graces the eyes of the man himself and he reflects on the hell he has inflicted upon this school

It is clear that he knows the content very well, but his class is very difficult, especially with minimal calculus experience. LOTS of online homework due Tuesday, Thursday, and Saturday at midnight, and while practice can be helpful there is so much that you will begin to prioritize just getting it done on time rather than actually learning it.
He is very knowledgeable and puts in a lot of work to organize the homework, notes, and review sheets. The class has a lot of homework that generally takes a pretty good amount of time.
Arthur Lim is the worst professor I have had during my time at ND

The lack of understanding I had the displeasure to experience in this lame excuse for a class is hitherto undreamt of. Everyday I lie awake at night in a petrifying sweat as I nearly bombed my Mobius homework assignment for the week, writhing in agony in my twin size bed at the thought of having to hit the monotonous grindstone again tomorrow. HELL
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Mixed feelings. He's passionate about his work, but can often be condescending and cold. Will make you doubt your ability to succeed in your future career. People say to take his class because he's the *best*, but I would recommend a DIFFERENT instructor. Use his resources (i.e. recorded lectures) if you need them, but it's not worth the 8:20.

This class is so unnecessarily difficult and you are provided with literally no help. The lectures make absolutely zero sense and are filled with useless crap that isn't helpful on tutorials (which are also, btw, pointless). And get ready to spend 49 hours a night doing Mobius problems that end up being worth a whopping 6% of your grade.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Prof Lim was a terrible professor. If you didn't have any prior experience with calculus you're left in the dust. He is unapproachable + harsh. If you're not doing well in the class he does not encourage you but rather makes you feel less because you're struggling. DON'T take this class if you dont have a strong background in calculus.

Professor Lim is the strongest Calc B professor. He has an attendance sheet but posts his lectures and extra practice that you can watch on your own. The homework is long but very similar to test questions. He doesn't surprise you with questions on exams and tells you what to expect. Utilize TA office hours. Never read the textbook and did well.

Lim's class is very hard if you have not taken calculus before. He expects prior knowledge in the subject and can be rude when you ask for help. He isn't super accessible. He is good at simplifying complex concepts, but spends too much time on proofs that are not on the exams rather than working through examples. His class is not worth the 8am.
Goes super fast and is so hard to understand. Would never take again. Expect to put in 12+ hours a week of work for this one class.

Such a good teacher. Goes fast, but once you get the hang of his pace, you learn so much. If you need to take Calc B, I would try to get Professor Lim bc he's the course head. Tests are easier than the homework so most students get good scores.
Focuses on learning math for your career, rather than memorizing formulas. Overall, my fave teacher.

Most degrading professor ever. If you do bad, rather than him working thorgh where you went wrong, he questions your career choice and ask whether or not you're capable of pursing that said career for yourself. I'm sturggling in the class due to me having no experience of Calc in high school. He made me cry and I'm never taking him again.

One of worst classes I've ever had; way too much homework, so time consuming and so much harder then tests. Teacher who is bad at teaching; very smart guy but cannot teach an intro course. Please don't take this class with Lim, it's so time consuming and not easy to understand even if you took BC in high school.
He's just great. Love the accent
Best math professor at Notre Dame!!

Professor Lim is very knowledgable about calculus. He also tries to add in humor to his lectures. Be ready to spend a significant amount of time on Mobius homework. But, if you can do the homework with no problem, then you will be fine on tests. The tests are very similar to the review sheets done in class.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Arthur Lim was the only reason that got me to do calculus at 8am in the morning. He tends to go through lectures very fast, and learning is dependent on notes. There's a lot of homework assigned in Mobius which you should do ahead of time. He does his best to explain things. Also, he has an attendance sheet and will notice if you aren't showing up.
While sometimes tough, Lim is very good at explaining hard topics.

Professor Lim is very knowledgable about Calculus. I had him for Calc B. He brings lots of energy to class each day. The tests are pretty much straightforward. The homework can get annoying quickly. But, just do it, because it will help in the long run. This class if difficult, so it is important to review material outside of class.

Lim is hilarious! Love this man! Lots of homework, but it helps so much if you do it. Tests are straightforward and EXACTLY like the in-class review that he does. This man explained calculus so well. You'll do well in this class if you do all the homework and ask for help when you need it.

Professor Lim is the course chair for Calculus A meaning he assigns/ creates all the homework and tests for the course. The Mobius homework is absurd. They take me a minimum of 2-3 hours (for ten questions), and talking to other peers in the class, this is pretty standard. The questions are extremely difficult, unrelated, and incredibly frustrating
Brings the energy to class. Explains difficult topics well. Difficulty score is just because it's calculus which is hard no matter who you have. Good grading system.

I switched from the Calc I-II track to the Calc A-B track. It is essential to complete the review sheets and practice problems as soon as Lim sends them. I found this class especially frustrating because there are many mistakes on the solution sets and practice exams. Class times are also not long enough. Overall, I would recommend taking Calc II.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Lim was always honest with the class. He started off saying that Calc B would be a lot of work, and he was 100% right. You have lots of practice problems for homework, but I thought it was always useful in prep. for exams. Do the summary sheets and go to office hours! He really wants you to understand and master concepts rather than memorize.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Lim is the best Calc A/B professor at ND. He's knowledgeable, super funny in lecture, and really cares about his students. He set up extra tutoring specifically for Calc B this semester and is very helpful in office hours. If you are struggling, reach out and he is happy to help. Show up to his class and engage if you can and you will be ok.
SO hard to communicate with and disregards any concerns you bring to him. Crazy Crazy amount of homework - impossible to do it all. terrible, never ever again never
Tons of homework.  Lectures have mistakes and very few practice problems.

Very good at explaining difficult material and an amazing communicator. Attendance is mandatory and he takes it almost every class but a very nice professor and knows how to teach very well. Cares about his students and the subject. Take his class if you have the chance.

Funniest professor I've ever had. He often goes off on tangents about proofs that you don't need to know but the exams are fair and don't cover the proofs. Challenging class but the drop policy is very helpful.

Class is set up very poorly for an introductory calc class required by social science majors. As someone who did well in high school calc the math in this class is much harder and much of the difficulty in this course comes from the insane amount of homework. My tip to anyone: study the reviews heavily because they are similar to how the tests are.

Was a pretty decent teacher. Not really that great if you dont have a background in calculus tho. The midterms were pretty straightforward if you paid attention in class. However, he made the final ridiculously hard compared to the midterms so beware of some curveballs

Homework had absolutely no relation to class material or tests and quizzes, I had a TA who made errors in every practice problem, and Lim did not teach any sections. If you dont have to take this class for your major DO NOT TAKE IT!!!
