He was not my actual professor, but was the course head for Calc B. The main issue was the construction of the lectures. There were barely any practice problems in the lectures. This means u learn a concept, but u dont actually learn how to apply it. By the end of the semester I was only going to the tutorial because the lectures were useless.

Prof. Lim brings lots of energy and passion to the lectures, and at the time of writing this review is definitely the professor you want to have for Calc A. Even if he's only teaching an 8AM, his passion for and familiarity with the material more than makes up for the early class time. I advise doing everything you can to get Lim's Calc A section.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Very energetic and makes morning lectures enjoyable. If you are taking Calculus A or B, this is the teacher you want.

Very organized but overrated. His teaching style didn't match mine too well but I understand why so many people like him. I often had to teach myself the material because the lectures didn't help me that much. Would still recommend because not all students learn the same way.
Professor Lim is a gem at 8 am in the morning. Most of the time I wouldn't go to lecture, but the days I did go, it was because I knew that he would be happy to have a fuller class!
Cares a lot and is willing to help students outside of class. Can take you through a proof or long way at times instead of just teaching the "how to." Very funny!
Professor Lim is by far the best calculus A teacher- he is very passionate about math and is very willing to help students who need it.
Amazing math teacher, lots of homework, really funny guy. Definitely hope for him if you're taking Calc
THE BEST PROFESSOR EVER. SO KIND AND ENGAGING AND HAS A LOT OF LOVE FOR HIS STUDENTS. AN A IS MORE THAN ATTAINABLE IF YOU SIMPLY LISTEN DURING CLASS, and take good notes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: Such a compassionate teacher and he really cares about students well being. The class is definitely a lot of work and more reading than I expected but you get used to the work load. Fr. Kevin and the TAs are fairly easy graders and as long as you follow word count/rubric and do all the work, its a guaranteed A. Stressful workload, rewarding class.

Fr. Kevin Grove is a class act.  His class definitely lives up to the hype, with engaging lectures that incorporate the ND student experience.  More importantly, Fr. Kevin is very kind-hearted and genuine, radiating the light of Christ inside and outside the class.  This class is a must for any ND freshman, especially if you attended a Catholic HS.

Fr. Kevin's class is a lot of work, and all the students in the class complain about this in the beginning. However, he truly cares about each student, makes an effort to get to know them, and conveys the concepts in an engaging fashion. As the course progresses, I found that each student had a true appreciation for the content.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Such an engaging lecturer. This class is a lot of work, but it is well worth it. Fr. Grove is amazing at connecting various concepts together and making it all make perfect sense. Would highly recommend.
Very engaging lectures. There is a lot of homework and reading, but assignments are not graded harshly. I wasn't expecting to enjoy the course as much as I did.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lots of homework

comment: Couldn't recommend enough.

A detailed, but difficult introduction to theology although the grading is very forgiving (even a full letter grade boost if you go to weekly discussion groups). Fr. Grove is very engaging and sharp with his words. He introduces theological topics from multiple perspectives, meaning lots of writing and reading for homework from the Bible, etc.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: He is an excellent theology teacher, just gives insane amounts of homework.

There are often a couple hours of reading/writing before class, but this is true for most other theo classes. The good news is basically everyone does well, as grading is usually generous. If you go to the discussion group meetings, he will bump up your grade one notch (Ex. A- becomes an A). He gives all test questions before tests.

Extremely knowledgable, so much work though. Go to convos of purpose and pray you get a good TA and you will be fine though. Just be ready to read and be ready to dedicate a crazy amount of time to this intro class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Definitely one of the best professors I have had. His lectures are great - you can tell he understands the content and relays the information in a way that is easy for students to understand. His class is great and you dive deep into material. Highly recommend taking him if you can, you can get so much out of his class.

Fr. Kevin is probably the best teacher I have ever had, both by pedagogical skill and ability to get me invested in the subject. He made the story of the bible into an academic action movie. It was great; take his class!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Accessible outside class

comment: Father Kevin is a great professor and very kind and helpful to students. The course is a bit work-heavy, but it is graded pretty easily and you can get an A without too much trouble. The first two weeks are kind of brutal, but after that it is enjoyable--would highly recommend.

Fr. Kevin is a fantastic lecturer who truly cares about each one of his students. He makes frequent jokes about things that are happening around campus, and he truly understands the Notre Dame undergrad experience like few other professors do. If you can, I would absolutely 1000% take Fr. Kevin's Intro to Theology class.

Grove was about as good of a theo prof as you can get. Taught the class well both for those who were Catholic and those merely there because it was required. Made an effort to learn everyone's names and talk to them despite it being a 300 person class. Lots of work but graded easily, tries to scare people early with difficult first homework.

Fr. Kevin was a W mans. The mandatory 'textbooks' just refer to the catholic reading bible that is required for everyone in the class to have, and two other short stories but tbh you could just find pdf versions online and have them printed out (not the bible though). He made great hummus for office hours, and the TAs were great as well

Lots of reading and homework due for every class, but if you do the work you'll get the A. The TA's aren't harsh graders and the 2 exams we did in class we get before hand, and he answers all the questions during office hours. He also took the time to learn everyone's names in our lecture. 100% recommend for an easy A to knock out the requirement.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lots of homework

comment: Amazing professor and learned a lot about the catholic faith in this class. At first it might seem like a lot of work but the grading is fairly easy as long as you showed effort. There are only 2 tests and they are very easy he gives you them ahead of time. I would recommend this class, everyone I know enjoyed it and ended up with a high grade.

As long as you do the work you will probably get an A, especially with the grade boost from the discussions with purpose. The TAs do not grade tough at all. Attendance is mandatory. The readings are long but doable and the papers and exams are not that hard. Lectures are not too boring and can be fun at select times.

There is a lot of homework for this class but if you do even the bare minimum you'll probably get an A. He is not a tough grader and the class isn't super hard. He kind of plays favorites between the dorms
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Caring

comment: The readings were long but if you do then you will get an A. He is not a tough grader as long as you do the work.  Also if you go to the office hours before the test he will give you the exact answer. He is a fantastic professor and learned the names of almost the whole class despite it being over 200 people.

People hate on Fr. Kev, but don't listen to them. Genuinely such a caring guy. He knew probably every student's name after the first month and lecture had about 200 kids in it (which is mad impressive). Yes, there is a lot of reading, do not get discouraged. His lectures are very clear and his class is truly you get out of it what you put into it.

Great and engaging class and lectures! There is about 1 page of writing for each class (2 per week) but it is graded easily. Exams questions are all given in advance. Massive extra credit opportunity given to boost grade. Worth it!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Amazing lectures

comment: Great professor, one of my favorites at ND. Very genuine person who cares about your success and understanding in his class. Perfect fit to teach this class in an engaging way!

It's true that Fr. Kevin's class is a lot of reading and homework - it can be frustrating and overwhelming at times. However, once you fall into the rhythm, it's not awful. I didn't find interest in Theo so lectures were boring, but I know others who enjoyed them. Overall, he is genuine and willing to go to great measures to help you do well.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Fr. Kevin is an amazing man, and his class will change your life.

Fr. Kevin is one of the best professors I've ever had. He gives fantastic lectures, and, though his class is reading and writing heavy, the TAs grade fairly. Hard work pays off. His tests aren't bad. Taking his class has been an essential part of my experience at Notre Dame. His class has changed the way I view myself and those around me.

I really enjoyed this class: each class feels genuine and actually reached me, compared to a lot of my other profs. I would 100% recommend, but as a forewarning there is a decent bit of reading and writing. The TAs grade very generously (everyone I know has an A- or A), but it should be known that there is a decent amount of work to get the A.

Do NOT take Fr. Kevin Grove unless you want all of your time to be spent doing long readings and writing papers. This class has an absurdly unnecessary amount of work and is NOT an intro class like it says. Unless theo is your favorite thing ever SAVE YOURSELF

Super nice guy and interesting/thought-provoking material. That said, if you're not in a major somewhat related to Theo/Philo it's probably not worth taking. Very time-consuming overall with papers due every class accompanied by long and at times tiresome readings. Easy A if you do the work and show up, but a lot of work for a required class
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Amazing class, 10/10 would recommend. Lots of reading/writing but graded really easy. Fr Kevin is an amazing lecturer and an amazing human being who cares about his students so much. Wouldn't recommend if you aren't willing to be interested in the subject, but if you go in with an open mind it could change your life.

Every lecture was like listening to a Ted Talk. The 1st paper of the semester is the worst, but it gets much better from there. Basically impossible to not get an A in the class if you show up and do the HW. Gives out the tests in advance and the office hours tell you exactly what to study. Would recommend to take care of your THEO credit.

You can't go to Notre Dame and not take a class with Fr. Kevin. By far, one of my favorite professors I have ever had. He assigns reading for every class period (and a small response) but it's graded easy. A truly inspirational, and entertaining, lecturer and guy who genuinely cares and wants to get to know his students. You won't regret having him

Fr. Kevin is an amazing guy who genuinely cares so much about his students.  He knows how to connect with the class, and he is a very talented lecturer.  While there is a lot of homework, it is not graded harshly at all, and the purpose of the homework is really just to help you understand theology.  I would definitely recommend Fr. Kevin's class!

He's a great guy and his lectures are pretty engaging but the homework is a little obnoxious. If you are planning to major or minor in theology, I absolutely recommend this class, otherwise it is more work than it is worth.

Really nice guy but terrible class. Long and boring lectures in uncomfortable and crammed auditorium seating. Papers due ever class with sizable readings needed to complete them. Homework overload. Avoid the foundations of theology class he has at all costs

Father Grove is a SUPER kind and knowledgeable guy. Clearly knows his stuff and is thoughtful about lectures. He's also very forgiving with grading and absences and such. HOWEVER this class will take up your whole week. It should not be the size it is (250-ish kids) and all of your interactions will mainly be with TAs.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS PROFESSOR. WAY TOO MUCH READING AND HOMEWORK ESPECIALLY FOR AN INTRODUCTORY CLASS THAT IS REQUIRED. LECTURES ARE LONG, BORING, & REQUIRED. EVERY POINT IS A PERCENT OF YOUR OVERALL GRADE. FIND ANOTHER PROFESSOR, OR YOU WILL WASTE HOURS OF YOUR WEEK (DOESN'T MATTER HOW SMART YOU ARE IT CAN TAKE 4 HRS FR 1 ASSIGNMENT). bless up
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Let me begin by saying that Father Kevin is a great guy who cares about his students and is very passionate and knowledgeable about what he teaches. That said, his class is VERY homework intensive. 40+ page readings with essays every class is a heavy burden that honestly was not worth the insight I gained from taking the class. Look elsewhere.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: He's a really engaging and caring Professor. There is a lot of work, but it's not particularly difficult work - and his grading reflects that it is an intro-level class. He chooses interesting areas in theology to study, class moves at a good pace, and he's very talented in lecturing. I think I learned a lot about Catholic theology.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--So many papers

comment: Yes, there is a lot of work but no, it is not graded strictly. If you do the work and show up you will get an A. That being said, Father Kevin is the best teacher I have ever had. He cared about his students, he was informative and interesting with his lectures, he loves what he does. I love this man with my whole heart. Please take his class.

Kevin Grove assigns way too much work for a university-required class. All of the homework or first exposures as he calls them require a lot of effort and are graded on correctness despite them being due before the material is taught. His lectures are extremely long tedious and boring, and he often comes across as condescending during them
rating_tags: Lots of homework--So many papers--Lecture heavy

comment:
Interesting class, definitely learn a lot about theology if not religious; but there is so much work: readings and a one page paper every class due and occasionally a 3 page paper
once you get the hang of it, it doesn't take too long, just annoying
lectures are all class and mandatory, but going to office hours before the test is all u need
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Lecture heavy

comment: I was somewhat disappointed by Fr Kevin's class after hearing how life changing it was supposed to be. It was interesting, but sometimes points made were trite. Way too much homework.

I had very low expectations but I loved this class so much. Fr. Kevin was an amazing professor and made me enjoy theology. He always knew how to bring you into the content and help you understand. His foundations class was a bit over average work wise but so worth it.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Life changing class, truly. He was so clear about what he wanted us to learn and why. I felt like I learned a lot about myself and the world from him. He was readily available outside of class and the work we needed to do for him, while extensive and not always easy, related directly to our learning in an impactful way. 100% recommend him
A really good guy and will learn something you can take with you forever. But beware, a lot of work.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Don't let Anre/his reviews scare you! I was terrified of him and wanted to drop on day one. Looking back, his half was way better than GA's (he was good too). He acts scary in class but was genuinely helpful and caring one-on-one. His lectures are well structured as opposed to summarizing the textbook (which you just need to skim to do well!).
He is a fun teacher and very knowledgeable. Although the way he presents information on the slides is not the best in my opinion, it is still "follow-able" and complements the textbook well.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Historically, Anre has sworn like a sailor in class; however, this semester, someone must have complained or something because he cleaned up his act and never cussed (or apologized if he accidentally did).  Regardless, his disorganized and hard to follow lectures were very opinionated, filled with liberal, anti-Catholic, and anti-U.S. commentary.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Venter is a great Intro Psych professor, despite what you may hear. While he can be intense, he is funny and does care about his students. The complaints you hear are mainly from conservative students who cannot deal with the critical thinking Anre presents. Review daily and stay up to date on the lectures and you'll be fine!

Anre can be very abrasive sometimes but if you have a good sense of humor then you just think it's funny. Makes the class more interesting and he's actually a really good guy if you get to know him. The course itself isn't that bad, just pay attention in lecture (very lecture heavy) and make sure to do all the readings. Lots of extra credit too.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy

comment: Anre's a great guy, especially if you get to know him. He's INCREDIBLY intelligent and challenges his students to be the best version of themselves, and is not afraid to express the harsh truth. Those who don't like him either don't like their beliefs being challenged by critical thought or didn't take the time to get to know him. Awesome person.

Anre had a bad attitude every day in class. He was rude to all students and couldn't care less if someone misunderstood a concept. His lectures were very unorganized and hard to follow. His thoughts were all over the place, and he would jump from topic to topic. He was very opinionated, and just an overall unpleasant professor.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Anre was insufferable. He expressed his displeasure of being at Notre Dame along with the students and his disliking for them. His teaching is hard to follow and his PowerPoints are hard to follow and gave unclear instruction most of the time. He was not shy to express his opinions and often villainized Catholics as well as any conservative person.

Anre is very rude to students and uses lecture time to share his beliefs, many of which express anti-Catholic sentiments. He also has made disrespectful comments about psychiatric medication use, which is absurd as a psychology professor. Additionally, he refers to his students as being in a "necrophiliac relationship" with him.
Anre's lectures are very confusing, and he seems to jump from topic to topic, sometimes without finishing his thoughts. He is very opinionated.
Anre is an odd man. He just gives me the creeps. Go to lecture and study!! You'll be fine. Take advantage of the extra credit.

If you fall asleep in class, Anre will throw the chalkboard eraser at you. If you walk in late, he might single you out in front of everyone. Just arrive on time, take good notes, DO NOT sit in the back 3 rows and you'll be fine.

Professor Venter was very disorganized. He would start a thought and move on to his following sentence before finishing the last one. He was sometimes hard to understand. He would do more ranting and complaining than teaching. He used lots of profanity for no reason.

Look, some people love Anre, some don't. Dude swears a ton. In general though, I believe that he cares for his students. In class he has coarse humor, but he is a kind and helpful person. The class has a curve, you can't skip and not study and expect an A. However it isn't that bad if you try. I loved the course, others won't. Anre is a meme.Period

Anre loves to use profanity...lots of it. He is very disorganized, and he puts his opinions into just about every lecture. The content is not difficult if you review the notes and textbook before exams. Find someone to send you old exams, because those are a huge difference-maker!
Class is interesting. Anre is unorganized af. But he is funny. Get practice tests. Slay.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Venter is a great professor. While his PPT slides organization wasn't my favorite, the lectures are great and he is 'unhinged' in a funny and entertaining way. Do exactly what he and GA recommend (go to class, review consistently over time - not cram, textbook reading, etc.) and you will have no problem with the class despite its notorious rep.

Prof. Anre's part of intro psych was more digestible and less "hard-fact" memorization. Just like Radvansky, the class is graded on the six multiple-choice exams, which are mainly pulled from lectures. Take good notes and read from the textbook if you want to. He cracks dry humor jokes and takes little digs during class which can be entertaining.

Do not be fooled by Anre on the first day!! He is not that scary. He has a strange sense of humor, but he is also very passionate about the subject. His notes are more scattered than GA's, but if you form a study group it will all be okay. He offers availability for asking clarifications and questions.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Anre yelled at me on the first day of class, so I kept a low profile for the rest of the semester. However, he was hilarious and made me grasp the content very well. Tests are hard, but most of the material is from his lectures, so go to class and take notes.
Easy, interesting, helpful for preparation for after college.
Anre is a funny guy and makes the class more interesting. The tests are kinda hard but the curve helps a lot. Most of the stuff from the exams are from lecture material so show up to class.

Professor Venter is a character and makes the class very interesting in a good way. His classes were less structured than GA's, which sometimes made the material confusing. A mixture of in-class notes and textbook reading is the key to doing alright in the class. Also, be sure to study, like, a lot. Overall, a pretty cool professor.

One of those eccentric professors. Lectures were funny if you have a certain sense of humor and agree with his political positions, but at times tended towards derogatory. He looks down on students, and isn't very available outside of class. But the class is also entirely memorization, so if you sit down and grind it's pretty straightforward.

This class is fine, but Anre is not a good prof. His notes are not clear and he speaks about things that don't matter, he thinks he's edgy and hilarious but it really just comes off as desperate. The best part of him being a psych prof is that you can do a pretty interesting case study on him. Lectures got me nothing.

Anre gives good examples, can be funny at times, and can be strict. He acts tough but is always willing to help. His tests are super detail oriented, though, so you'll have to memorize everything from lectures and the textbook which kinda sucks. He says some life changing stuff sometimes so that made class worth it.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: I had Prof. Venter for Drunk on Film, and he is incredible! So knowledgeable and hilarious. If I could recommend one ND class to anyone, it would be Drunk on Film. He adds a very interesting perspective from the neuroscience and psychology standpoint and is ale to answer any questions. He and Ted Mandell work very well together.

Honestly an amazing prof. Those who dislike him just are turned off by his humor and attitude, but I believe that's what keeps people so engaged in his class. I really admire his passion and his tests are easier than GA. Loved this!

Many might find his unusual demeanor funny or humorous At the surface level but in reality its just a cover for him to be completely disrespectful and carefree. I honestly do not find him funny or insightful anyway, and his view on society is not original and tries desperately to pass off as wise or knowledgeable

Best prof I have had. His humor should not be taken seriously. You can tell he really cares about his students and about them truly understanding and actually thinking about it more than its required. He makes you love psychology, especially social psych. Such an interesting and inspirational professor.

He was extremely unhelpful and rude. His lectures werent helpful-hed talk fast, get made if you were writing things down instead of answering his questions, and wouldnt keep the slides up for long enough.
Great
Anre is incredibly engaging and will make sure that students know about what he is teaching. He has somewhat unorthodox ways of getting you to pay attention but his class is really good.

Participated in Notre Dame Summer Scholars programme and Anre was in charge of the psych track. Amazing guy. Truly inspirational, gives great advice. Also very straightforward and funny, I love this guy
He is hilarious and politically incorrect in the best way! Honestly the life advice I got in this class can't even compare.
Fascinating lectures. He's hilarious, and really cares about his students.

Any and every Notre Dame student deserves to take Anre for Intro to Psych. It's a tough course if you don't put the time into it, but Anre's accent, crass humor, and foul language make it enjoyable and overall worth taking.
Incredibly insightful man who will open your mind and eyes to so much. May not get an A but well worth taking his class nonetheless- without a doubt the best professor I have ever had.
His personality makes the class and course material fun! If you don't like foul language, avoid this class!!!

You have to have a certain attitude to deal with Anre, but if you can take his "out there" comments with a grain of salt and really listen to what he has to say on the subjects at hand, you will learn a ton. Also, read the book. Seriously, I don't know why people think required textbooks are optional in a psychology class.
Anre teaches the second half of Introduction to Psychology.  He is very captivating.
He is a very helpful professor, even though his class is difficult, he will help you succeed as long as you make the effort to ask him for help.

Really funny. Sometimes a little rough around the edges with his humor. You have to have a sense of humor or else you won't enjoy him. Wanted to go to class even though it wasn't mandatory. Learned a lot.
Anre is an awesome professor! He might come off as rude and indiffrent during class but during office hours and as the undergrad advisor he does everything possible to help his students.
His sarcastic humor made this class bearable...but besides this he really does try to make sure that everyone is following what is going on in class
No Comments

She gives a lot of homework, but you get unlimited attempts, and it's relevant to course content. She gives soo many (optional) practice problems (3-4 practice exams on her website) which make her exams less surprising, unlike other econ professors. I HIGHLY recommend taking her for prin of micro (especially over the other popular professors).
Decent amount of homework, but prepares you for exams. Practice exams on her website reflect the material she tests you on. Implemented generous curve.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: Do all practice tests on her website, go to all lectures, and look at the solution explanations for the Pearson homework problems for problems you're even slightly fuzzy about after you work through him. She's stern but probably has the best organized Microecon class. You can get to know her well by asking questions/sitting closer to the front.

Do the practice exams!!!! and you will be completely fine, go to class, office hours and you'll find she's actually a chill, caring professor. can be passive aggressive but its kind of funny, overall i think the easiest mircoecon prof just because if you put in the work and do the practice exams you will get an A

She doesn't allow cheat sheet on the exams like other teachers and gives a lot of homework that is due Sunday evenings. Homework/quizzes usually includes material that isn't covered in class, but you can usually figure it out without reading the book. Exams are challenging but are similar enough to the practice exams and problem sets.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Gives a lot of homework that are all due Sunday night. Massive lecture halls but cares for her students. Moves through content quickly. Tests are difficult but manageable if you do the practice exams since they are very similar to the real thing.

The class is overall pretty easy if you are good at micro. If you have no prior knowledge or are not confident in your ability to learn it DO NOT TAKE HER. Her lectures are not structured whatsoever. They consist of her scribbling on her ipad and talking the entire time. She also does not do a great job preparing you for exams

Prof D was a very nice person, but sometimes there was a lack of connection between the homework/exams and lectures. Really hard to keep a good grade if you bomb a test or two, but other than that was pretty good. Lectures can sometimes feel redundant or not helpful in the moment, but will come back to bite you on an exam.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Course is very hit or miss. You will either end up w/ a good or a bad grade no in-between. "Tough mom" energy (double-edged sword). LOTS of homework (always due Sun). Fast-paced lectures. Practice exams tend not to match up w/ actual exams. Does take the time to get to know her students in lectures + coffee appts. Nice person, tougher of a prof.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: A terrific option for Intro to Micro. The lectures can get a bit monotonous but she does a great job keeping them interesting. Take notes and class and engage with what she's saying. Homework is a bit time consuming but pretty straightforward. Use the practice exams on her website and you will be more than prepared for the exams.
IF YOU WANT A GOOD GRADE DO NOT TAKE HER! YOU WILL REGRET IT!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: if you take your students to Mexico you should hire a translator and not capitalize off of the unpaid labor of your Latino students.

DONT TAKE FOR PRINCIPLES OF MICRO, ignore the other reviews!!!. Notes and lectures are extremely unorganized and final exam was nothing like the practice exams/notes. Take Spence instead. Every other class with different professors got a cheat sheet besides our class. I like her as a person outside of class, but not as a teacher.
I had already taken the class in high school, so it wasn't that difficult. That being said, she did a good job of explaining things, and, especially if you try, she is a very good professor.
Pretty engaging lectures and generally does a good job explaining concepts. As long as you do the online homework, it shouldn't be an overly challenging course.

Definition of a no-nonsense professor. Gets straight to the point every class and you can tell she's really good at what she does. Some might even find her intimidating. That being said, she teaches very clearly and is great at answering questions so you should be able to get a good grade

Loved Professor D! Her personality outside of class was A1. She is very caring of her students but can be a bit passive-aggressive sometimes. She gives out a lot of homework that is very time-consuming, the exams progress in difficulty but she has old exams to help you study! Her lectures can be engaging & interesting, but at the same time dull. :)

Fun teacher, but posted a lot of meaningless assignments during the week. Classes were lecture heavy and even though it was a big class, she knows if you skipped. Each of her exams has practice ones online that mirror the real one, so easy to prep for. The final was quite terrible though and tanked my high A to a B, so prepare extra for final.

She wants to know your name (which I didn't really like) but it shows she cares. Class is easy if you just take the practice exams on her website. They're the exact same as the ones you take in class. Three exams, homework due every Sunday. Econ is easy if you make it easy.

I was a fan overall and walked away with a high A, but I could definitely see how a few small mistakes could tank your grade in one of her classes. So make sure to be super detail-oriented and follow any rubrics for projects closely or she will take considerable points off. The same goes for tests. She sometimes asks very hyperspecific questions.

Prof. Dziadula is a wonderful professor. I took her for Macro, but I have heard she is great for micro as well. Very strict, but explains topics well and gives ample resources to prepare for exams. I really enjoyed her class and teaching style, especially compared to other Econ professors I have had.

LOVE Prof. D! Had her for principles of macro. Great lecturer and has a clear set of standards for students. Counts attendance randomly a handful of times throughout the semester. She's always there to answer questions and is one of the econ dept. advisors so definitely enjoys getting to know more about the students.

Absolutely awful. By far my least favorite teacher ever. Doesn't care about her students. Isn't just not polite but is downright rude to her students. Gives good lectures, but that is the only good thing about her. Highly recommend not having anything to do with her. Will never take her again.

AMAZING PROF who cares so much about her students (makes an effort to learn everyones name). Decent amount of HW and quizzes but overall manageable (use textbook for help). Practice tests are helpful for the exams which are generally easy. Attend class or you'll fall behind!

*always remember to put the dollar sign on tests and problem sets :)
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Dziadula is a wonderful professor. You be successful in this course if you go to class, take notes, and ask questions. Her lectures are simply excellent, and her expectations are clear. I would definitely take her again, and I highly recommend for anyone looking to take Principles of Macroeconomics.

Dr. Dziadula is the best professor I have had at the University of Notre Dame. She clearly cares about all of her students by learning their names and offers tons of resources to succeed. Her lectures are interactive and she makes sure to tie in lots of relevant information. 10/10 recommend Eva Dziadula for Micro.

Great professor with excellent lectures. Relatively easy tests. Available outside of class for extra help. Very friendly but strict with rules/syllabus. Just show up, take notes, ask questions, and participate, and you will get a good grade.

Biggest thing, do not mess up submission times, page order or literally anything because she is very very strict about no exceptions to anyone no matter the circumstance. Very funny in class though and lectures are hugely important and helpful to understanding the material so go to class.

Professor D is my favorite. She is an absolute girlboss and is to the point. Pay attention in class, ask questions, go to office hours, do the practice tests and it will be fine. Doing the practice tests over until you get the problems all right is a good strategy. She is a really cool professor and I absolutely love her.
Had her for principles of micro. if you attend class and take notes, you will pass. it's as simple as that.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Professor D's made lectures interesting, even at 8am. The tests are rather easy as she takes problems right from the practice tests. Do the practice tests and you'll be golden for exams. Minimal homework compared to other profs. Beware of final, it is cumulative and she will pull from even the smallest of topics. Respectable professor overall.

Every other micro professor except Dziadula will let you take a cheat sheet into the midterms and final exam. She'll give the least amount of homework, shortest problem sets, no papers or projects, and least midterms. You will not have a ton of work. But it's a tough class and not being able to have a cheat sheet like other students will break you.

Prof D is organized, fair, efficient, and caring. She won't waste your time inside or outside class, and puts a lot of effort into getting to know her students. The class does require a bit of effort, but if you attend class and follow Prof D's HW instructions and exam prep recommendations, you'll learn a lot and will earn a good grade.

Microecon. Very little homework... only had problem sets due the class before each exam. Quite a bit of extra credit. She goes around the class quizzing you but it's easy stuff. I never read the textbook (only learned from her lectures), and I got an A. By far one of the easiest classes I ever took.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes--Amazing lectures

comment: When I think back about great profs I've had at ND, she'll be at the top of the list. Take her class. It's not a breeze, but having her as a prof is worth it. Funny, intelligent, and cares about you as a student. Great teacher. Will be in ND teaching Hall of Fame when it's all said and done.
she gives out clear guidelines and shes a good teacher. class can be hard to keep up so you have to pay attention. but overall good experience and engaged me with econ.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Clear grading criteria--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Good lecturer; class not very difficult. Put in the work.

If you go to class you will do fine. She is very helpful and tries to help everyone's grades the best she can. She drops multiple online quiz scores. She also has two possible grade calculations and gives you the better grade at the end of the semester. She has no empathy for those who don't come to class, though, and she does notice.

As much fun as "Easy A" classes are, sometimes you have to take the punch and work your butt off. You have to read the textbook and you have to take good notes. Attendance is not graded, but you definitely want to show up. If you work hard, ask questions, and do the homework/readings, you'll do great and have a great recommendation by the end.

Make sure you go to class. Exams are on a difficult side and could be a bit overwhelming for a bunch of first-years who have no idea what college is about. No PPT slides or anything, so the only things you can rely on are your notes, and her lectures tend to be a bit boring. So if you don't go to class or start daydreaming, welp good luck
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: She is very clear, talks quickly, and discusses the details of the topic very thoroughly. She is funny and caring but isn't afraid to put her foot down if she knows you don't come to class. Tests are relatively easy and if you fail one of the two midterms, that midterm will only count as 5% of your grade and more weight will be on the final.
Love Dziadula- her lectures are very entertaining and she is always willing to answer questions

One of my best profs this semester. Clear, concise, easy to understand. Cares about you  if your alarm doesn't go off for an 8am exam and you talk to her afterward, she will give you extra time. As long as you pay attention in class and take notes, you will be fine. Have not used my textbook (except for assignments) and still have an A.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Really good teacher. Class is tough but she is really understanding and even more helpful. If you bomb a test the grading criteria is set up to discount the bad grades and upgrade the good grades.

I don't know why the other reviews on here are so negative. I'm a science major so Econ has never been my strong suit, but as long as you pay attention in class and take accurate notes, you'll do just fine. She's the tough love type, but if you participate in class or see her at office hours, she's really nice and will make sure to help you.
She ad libs her lectures and strays from the course outline sometimes.  The textbook is much clearer.
moves to fast, not very clear, hard tests

Professor is a kind and funny guy but not a good professor. Spends more time making jokes in class than teaching. You will have to spend a lot of time self-teaching. Exams are also very hard. His class is arguably the hardest Mendoza foundation class.
Carl is incredible. He is very caring and hilarious and really wants his students to do well. Arguably the best professor at this school.

Never imagined a professor with 500 students could be so compassionate. Carl's a great motivator and genuinely wants the best for his students. He has a fun teaching style and takes breaks in lecture. Tests are difficult - get quizlets from upper classmen for the theoretical material and practice the math a ton and you will be fine. Curves nicely.

Carl is one of if not the most exciting and nicest teachers at ND. He is a ton of fun in class and gets to know everybody even though he teaches 500 kids. The content can be fairly challenging with some very random conceptual questions on the exams (which make up almost the whole grade), but the math is easy once you get the hang of it.

Amazing professor and really cares about all his students. Exams are very hard. You need to know how to do every problem you've seen for the exams. You also need to read every assigned book reading and know everything from the book for the few very specific questions from the book. He makes lectures very fun, and I looked forward to class every day
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Test heavy

comment: Awesome guy, awesome professor, but it is a weed out class so be weary. Lowest grade I've received in my life - would not recommend taking him freshman year. Get the hang of college classes first before you tackle his.

Carl is by far the most caring and personable professor I've ever had. His lectures, if you pay close attention, are very helpful in learning the material, and he always keeps things interesting by engaging students with candy or funny pictures of his old students. The content itself is definitely not easy, but  Carl is very motivating!

One of the best people I know. The class can be boring,more practice problems in class would help. Grades: two midterms and a cumulative final, which is math-heavy and requires knowing a lot of formulas. Even with careful reading, answering correctly isn't guaranteed. Still, he's very understanding, caring, and has amazing knowledge of finance.Take
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Carl is great! He is kind and genuinely cares about his students. In terms of the class, it can be difficult to get an A, but it is doable. I've found that if I keep up with readings, do the homework, and study hard for a few days before the exam, I do well. Overall, the class is enjoyable and was a great introduction to finance!
This guy is the GOAT. Would definitely take him if you can. He truly cares about his job. Tests are challenging but if you know how to do the problems on the practice test you will be fine.

Carl is a great man and truly cares. He teaches the important stuff in class. Read the textbook and do optional homework problems. 90% of your grade comes from 3 tests. While most test questions come from class, some are randomly pulled from anywhere in the relevant part of the book and others are "How many of these are true?". Remember the curve.

Carl is an amazing lecturer and makes class fun and entertaining although sometimes he speaks fast. There are only 3 exams and they are weighted very heavily along with no graded homework to buffer your grade. The exams are incredibly in depth so you need to understand everything WELL and study 10 days in advance!!!!

Carl is a caring and passionate professor dedicated to his students' success. There are only three exams that demand lots of studying, and no graded homework adds to the pressure. While his engaging lectures are filled with distracting jokes and anecdotes, Professor Carl offers an excellent introduction to finance for those who can stay focused.

Carl is a great guy don't get me wrong but every 5 min we took a break to look at photos with old students and their finance textbook or to play the beverage game. Exams are pretty tough and he pulls a few random questions straight from the textbook which even if you read you may not get right. Wish we spent more time doing more examples.

Carl genuinely cares about his students. His lectures are entertaining, but he takes a "short break" every 5 minutes, and it is quite distracting. Could benefit from a few more examples instead. You HAVE to do the reading, and still may miss questions about small details. Exams are challenging but doable, and he is generous with the curve.

Carl exemplifies Mendoza's dedication to growing the good in business. He might have 400 students, but it feels like you know him personally. He also cares about using money for good. Engaging, funny lecturer. Beware that your entire grade is based on 3 exams with minute details from the textbook and you have to self-teach a fair amount.

Carl is amazing. A very personable and funny guy. His class is meant to weed you out, though. Three exams, with questions from the most random textbook sections. It's very annoying. But if you study the basic formulas and know how to do every question he assigns, it makes the course much easier.

Carl is a fantastic man, but his class should definitely be taken seriously. The course is graded entirely based on three increasingly-weighted exams (90%) and participation plus a "case project" (10%). He spends a large part of class time showing you photos of people in past years with his textbook at parties or in other unconventional locations.

LOVE Carl, but his class is a weed-out course. The first exam is all math, and the second exam is mostly concepts. You won't do well on exams if you don't fully understand material so keep up with the readings. The curve mostly helps. Carl makes class so entertaining and is the only reason I wake up at 9:30. Best prof at ND.
rating_tags: Hilarious--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Carl Ackermann is overhyped, he wastes half of the class playing the beverage game or throwing candy at you. He makes the class seem like a show and does not get straight to the point. I was able to get an A in honors corporate finance, which is harder than fundamentals which I got a B in due to his absurd teaching style and lack of clarity.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Carl was the best professor I took in my freshman year. His class is very rigorous but everything he assigns is crucial to success in the course. There is tons of support available so take advantage of it and you will be successful.

Carl is amazing! He goes above and beyond to learn every student's name and he's hilarious. 90% of your grade is based on 3 exams - which are math-heavy -  but he gives you the materials and additional help needed to succeed. He has your best interests at heart and I cannot recommend him enough. Just be prepared to study quite a bit before exams.

Fantastic guy. Really cares about the success of his students. Makes lectures fun. Class is hard but not any harder than any other professor teaching the same class. Really good at accessibility out of class. Will go above and beyond to help you if you're struggling. Best professor and class I've taken at ND so far.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: I can not say enough about Carl. He is the best professor at ND.

Carl is quite amazing. The class is definitely difficult and time consuming, but Carl does a spectacular job at making the content interesting and engaging students. He is willing to go the extra mile to help people who need it, and he is very invested in every single student. Exams are pretty difficult, but he does a lot to help students prepare.

amazing professor; goes out of his way to help, gets to know students, adds fun elements. However, your grade depends on 3 exams that require a lot math, attention to detail, and conceptual understanding (he does provide practice exams and practice problems that set you up to do really well on the exams if you are willing to put in the effort).

Carl is great as a person, but his class (fundamentals of finance) is incredibly difficult. I enjoyed his as a professor because he was always enthusiastic, but it felt like his lectures only touched the surface of finance. You definitely have to teach yourself the class, and its not an easy subject to learn. Hes great to have convos with though

Prof. Ackermann is a wonderful man but his class was pretty difficult. He does a lot to help his students, but the fact that your entire grade depends upon only 3 exams is tough. If you aren't good at math or conceptual things, make sure you get a tutor. However, I enjoyed Carl's class a lot, even though it was difficult.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Professor Ackermann makes what is otherwise relatively boring material fun through his lectures. He has a great reputation and genuinely cares about his students. However, the course grade is entirely dependent upon three tests each worth 30% of the course grade.
Carl Ackermann is the man, plain and simple. He is incredibly nice, and his funny shenanigans make the lectures much more interesting. 10/10 would recommend.

Carl genuinely seems to care about his students, but his positive reviews are a bit misleading. He claims not to believe in grades, yet gives 3 exams worth 90% of the grade- all of which are multiple-choice with no partial credit (even though most require multi-step math). And the exams are absurdly difficult for an intro course.
Ackerman seems to really care about his students and wants them to succeed. While the material he teaches may not be the most exciting in the world, he tries to make it exciting.
Incredible professor and human being. He is the man.

Ackermann is very funny, but his jokes sometimes detract from the learning. Ackermann seems to care about his students and tries to be supportive when people don't do great on tests. Ackermann's class was very difficult for me personally because I didn't understand the concept questions well, but I was able to solve the math problems.

Ackerman is known as the man, and the reputation is spot on.  Boring material, but he does his best to make it interesting, so class is generally pretty fun.  Attendance not at all required.  Tests are exactly like the practice tests- no excuse to not know what is coming on his tests.  Could not give a higher recommendation
Best professor I've ever had. Genuinely cares about his students and goes out of his was to help them in any way he can. Keeps class entertaining, very knowledgeable, and overall great teacher.
excellent
Best prof I've ever had! Challenging but very helpful.
BEST TEACHER I'VE EVER HAD. CARL'S THE MAN!
the epitome of what every teacher should aspire to be.
strong to quite strong
Best prof. I ever had.
No Comments
No Comments
Pizza, gorilla suits, house calls and a Prof. that knows his stuff.  What more could you want?!
Best prof I have ever had
Best teacher I had in my 4 years
No Comments

Justin was an AMAZING lecturer often running around the 200 person lecture hall during discussions to meet/engage with as many students as possible. LOVED the Dialogue Group set-up: it made such a larger class feel way smaller. TAs were tough at first and there was a LOT of busy work but they offered good feedback/came around in the end!

Great class! I loved my dialogue group; I'm pretty good friends with most of the group. Grade in the class is very dependent on your TA. Christy has interesting lectures which involves a lot of class and group discussions. Material is very interesting, and there's isn't too much homework

Loved GAGL with him; any review under 4 on this page was made by someone with a rival lecturer. Justin and I formed a 14-year common law marriage that produced 11 children, 3 of which are tenured professors at Ivy League universities. Now that he has shaved his luscious beard I cannot bear the sight of him.

Annoying how the class was divided into grading by two different TAs and had clear grade distinctions between these TAs. Other than this, he is excited about the class and the dialogue sections were fun.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment:
In the wisdom winds, Justin Christy's ballad weaves profound philosophy,
Morality, epistemology, religion's flings echo, virtuoso in sound.
His ballad navigates the vast canvas, each verse a thoughtful stroke,
A tapestry of insights, where wisdom's echo and melodies evoke.

In the halls of wisdom, where thoughts take flight,
There stands a beacon, a guiding light.
His name is Justin, a sage so rare,
Whose lectures spark with wit and flair.

With laughter as his tool, and wisdom as his guide,
He takes us on a journey, with intellect as our ride.
In every jest, in every jest,
Lies a kernel of truth, put to the test.

Yo, meet Professor Christy,
Spittin' philosophy so crispy,
Droppin' wisdom, vibes so risky.
Justin was great! He really cares about his students!
Great!

Professor Christy lets students ask whatever questions they want, which are often very distracting. With the grading system, one poor grade can tank your average, and the TAs give poor/late feedback. Dialogue group is a huge pain to have to attend every week, and they always contributed nothing to my understanding while taking up my weeknights.

Lots of busy work but if you put in the time you will get an A. TAs are tough graders on graded reflections but not bad on longer papers. Lecture can be boring and attendance is taken. 8pm dialogue is the best part of the class so don't let the time scare you.

relatively easy class like not that hard to get an A but his lectures are super boring and i zoned out a lot. the topics are interesting but really drawn out because people ask weird questions that take a while. make sure you have a good dialogue group or its really boring but the dialogue leaders are usually good. busy work but not hard work.

Dr. Christy made Moreau class interesting, which is an impressive feat. There is a general dislike for the course, but Dr. Christy added his own spin to it and made it enjoyable. It is a participation heavy class and the discussions are always engaging. He is also a reasonable grader that leaves comments on our assignments.

The TAs basically graded everything and it was so hard to get an A for no reason. Tbh, you don't have to go to class to pass (attendance is a part of your grade though). Sometimes the lectures were confusing but Christy as a person was so amazing and friendly, and overall just a happy guy. Best part about the course were the GGL dialogue groups.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: The grade breakdown was weird so one small thing could tank your grade and it would be hard to bring it up. The concepts themselves weren't hard to grasp, but the assignments sometimes didn't accurately reflect your understanding of concepts. The lectures could sometimes get boring. TAs also grade pretty harshly.

Prof. Christy is incredible! He cares so much about his students and wants everyone to succeed! I gained a real appreciation and love for philosophy in his class and would highly recommend any class he teaches! He also encourages exploration of philosophies that we may not have time to cover in class!! 11/10 Prof! CTY

Around like 5 pages to read a night for homework. Honestly not too many written assignments either. There is just one big paper at the end. The TA's grade pretty hard though. It's easy to get a B+ but to get an A requires top-notch work. Christy is just an average prof. Lectures every class. They aren't super engaging but also not horrible either

I was so disappointed by this class! Lectures were extremely boring and the content was never taught in a way that made it feel meaningful or relevant. Christy seems like a nice guy but he honestly ruined philosophy for me because of his impersonal and un-engaging teaching styles. Also, be prepared for busy work. Would not recommend this class.

Professor Christy takes an incredibly impersonal approach to philosophy where he lectures on complicated topics and does not get to know any of his students. Your entire grade depends on an undergraduate TA who decides a majority of your grades. Avoid this class at all costs if you intend on pursuing something that relies on GPA. DO NOT TAKE
I didn't find the content in the class to be very meaningful but it was pretty easy.

GGL has gone through some changes so it depends on the semester and prof how the class will be structured. Take Megan Sullivan if you want to take GGL, her class is much easier. Following the course changes, Christy has a lot of unnecessary work and reading that's just a waste. He's great though, very energetic just the course was made "harder".

Honestly, never really had a problem with Prof. Christy. Gave millennial english teacher vibes in the best way possible. This class really depends on your TA. If you have a great TA, congrats. If you don't, good luck. Dialogue was really fun, but the TA really makes or breaks the experience of GGL. Prof. Christy is fine, just hope you like your TA.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: His lectures were fairly engaging, and the dialogue group discussions were phenomenal. Most of the tough grading is done by your TA. Christy as a professor was good, couldn't ask for much more and same with GGL as a class. Definitely not a guaranteed A anymore, it's not too hard to get a B+ or A- but cutoff at 95 for A is tough.

Professor Christy was a great lecturer overall in my opinion. His style of speaking was easy to follow, and you could tell he wanted to ensure his audience understood the material being covered. I would recommend Christy as a professor, but GGL as a class itself can be very tedious work.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Respected

comment: Professor Christy is fun and has an uplifting personality. His lectures are easy to follow and he enjoys audience participation. He is passionate about the topics he teaches. The downside of GGL in general is that the TAs are notoriously difficult graders and it is hard to get an A. If you are looking for an easy philosophy credit, this is not it.

Justin is the goat -> Gives great feedback and willing to help; Treats everyone as equals so everyone becomes good friends; Very smart, respectful, caring, easy to approach, and funny...Also a goat class -> Deeply interesting philosophies explored; Students can self or group lead class; Work is never overloaded or stress inducing; Best Midterm Ever

Be careful with GGL, they constantly change how hard stuff should be graded to avoid grade inflation/deflation. One semester could be much harder than another. That being said, Christy is very helpful and unbiased, no complaints here.

Relatively a lot of homework for each class. Lecture is usually large so it's easy to get distracted. However, he's is very willing to put in extra time with students outside of class, a diligent email responder, as well as sympathetic in extreme cases. The TAs are rlly who grade papers VERY rough.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: I love Justin so much. He created a perfect in-class environment and I met some great friends because of the way he treated us. We were all equals in his classroom and felt safe saying whatever was on our minds. The work was not graded strictly; that does not mean people were not engaged. We all thought hard and cared about the class because of him

This class used to be a free A. Now its a free A- since they raised the A requirement to a 95. Not that much work required compared to other Philosophy classes. Prof Christy is very nice and keeps things modern and tries his best to engage with a large lecture.

GGL with Professor Christy will be one of the easiest classes you take. He is a great lecturer and if you pay attention you will walk away smarter every class period. There is also barely any work for this class. If you are into philosophy, you may be slightly disappointed at how watered-down the material is, but definitely still worth taking!!

Ive taken Justins classes at both the intro (GGL) and advanced level and hes been great for both Super nice and understanding. Extremely easy grader (as long as he grades and not a TA). He does take a long time to grade things though, but its ok because he is very generous.
Always friendly, ethusiastic in lectures, knowledgable.

Prof. Christy is a good lecturer and definitely tries to get his students invested in philosophy. GGL is overall an extremely easy course though, so you can't really go wrong with what professor you choose. Also, your TAs grade a lot of your work, but they tend to go easy as well.
He is an easy intro philosophy professor. Very kind and energetic. Wants to get students interested in philosophy.

If you're taking GGL, I'd avoid him. The class is graded (and is the same easy A) no matter which prof you take. With that being said, he's really, really nice, but kind of a boring lecturer. I didn't think he was all that well prepared and kind of stumbled through the lectures. Calls on same 2-3 kids in a 200 person class... just gets old quick.
This man is absolutely hilarious. Keeps us engaged during lecture. 4 tests, but lowest one is dropped.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The class was very easy. There were barely any assignments and only 3 short exams. However, this professor makes tons of inappropriate comments that genuinely make it awkward for students. PREPARE YOURSELF that there will be weird and borderline creepy conversations every day.

Reading the comments it seems people like Filchak, but honestly the guy was so inappropriate and would ramble a lot about things not related to genetics. The class is so easy just read the powerpoints and skim the textbook. I never went to class and got almost a perfect grade. The guy is intolerable though. And the class is very outdated.

Professor Filchak does a great job of keeping his lectures engaging and interesting. Pretty much all the content comes directly off his PowerPoint slides, so if study the lectures before the exam, you will be fine. The only homework was a few selected readings from the textbook. Definitely would take again - very funny lectures.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Filchak keeps his lectures interesting and does care about his students. However, he makes sometimes inappropriate comments during class and does not have a ton of resources to help with the learning of the material. He explains stuff well. However, your only grade is 3 exams with no homework so there is a lot of pressure.

Dr. Filchak is a good professor. Lectures and tests focus on the details. There is a textbook, however, he will tell you what specific sections will be on the test. Course has no other homework, so the tests are what determine your final grade. Do not skip class.

He is a funny guy and has a great sense of humor. Just make sure to study EVERY SINGLE DETAIL on the PowerPoints. His tests will sometimes include information that was in the tiniest font on the slides. As long as you do this you will ace the class.
he really cares about students and focuses on lectures

Prof. Filchak is a nice guy that cares about his students. Asks for ways to improve, and his powerpoints boil down the necessary details for the course. Must read textbook as well, as some test questions are from the book only
the man, the myth the legend, great lecturer and an even better looking guy!
I loved this professor! His class is the best one I took this year.
Prof is difficult but fair. Tells you from day 1 the class will be challenging and it was. Go to every class and take good notes and you should be fine.

He's an engaging lecturer and explains everything well. However, your final grade is determined by three tests. There isn't much work outside of studying and the material is incredibly interesting, but you will have to prepare quite a bit to do well on the tests.

Professor Filchak is one of the best lecturers I have had so far at Notre Dame. The content of the class is also super interesting. Make sure to read the book and be ready for class. It's not too difficult but will have to definitely work for it.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Kenneth Filchak is singlehandedly the best lecturer that I have ever had. Though going to class is not mandatory, don't expect anything above a B- if you don't consistently go. 3 tests determine your grade; half of each test is based on 3 chapters of a book and the other half is based on the lecture. Would 100% take this class again.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Amazing lectures

comment: Anyone who thinks Prof. Filchak wants you to fail just didn't do the reading. There's one book you read throughout the whole semester, doesn't overload you but you have to know it well. Nice guy and wants to get to know you, pretty funny. Like someone else said, he does a Socratic question asking but always makes sure you understand. Go to class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: Great professor and interesting class. Gives great lectures and can be hilarious. Overall nice guy, but does a poor job answering questions. Class is very interesting but certainly difficult. You MUST do the Red Queen readings he assigns or you won't pass.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Not an easy A, but a really good class.
Wants students to fail, very hard class. He's an ass to his students and hopes that they will fail the class so they will learn from their mistakes in the future/
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Filchak will tell you what you need to do to do well, if you follow this you will be fine.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Great Professor, a ND favorite.

On the first/second day of class he will say to drop this class if you want an easy Topical Science. That's not a scare tactic, it's the truth. A lot of hard work and prep for the tests which are all multiple choice and mostly memorization. It's a rite of passage , but if you don't want the challenge don't take this class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He's somewhat rude to students, but in a sort of Socratic way that is conducive to learning. Amazing lectures. Relatively easy class.
He has interesting lectures but makes you thoroughly read a novel called "The Red Queen." It's a good read if you can get into it but the test will make you earn your grade.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Great prof!
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Very strict and somewhat rude  professor. BUT lectures were amazing and so interesting. Loved going to his class. Tests were challenging but not extremely hard

Current topics in environmental science - hard to say because he didn't really teach, other professors gave presentations the whole time, but at least it was a very easy class despite the large workload.

not good, not horrific, but his tests were very difficult and often he tested on topics that he spent very little time on. for example, the 3rd test, he had 8 questions on worms out of the 50 on the test. why? i dont know
Filchak is pretty funny and a cool guy.  Class is fun and not too challenging.  The subject is also pretty interesting.
Coolest teacher I've had yet. Highly recommend.
No Comments

He literally reads off slides that are uncorrelated with the class. not like says things like what is on the slides, but literally READS them. He once insulted me in class. Completely unavailable outside of classes. In the engineering department he is the legendarily bad professor to get for math. dont do this.

If I could give you one piece of advice in my life it would be do not take this teacher. He the absolute worst. Truly the most terrible teaching experience I have ever had. He makes it impossible to do well in the class, and has a singular office hour during the entire week, in the most inconvenient time possible. Whatever you do, avoid this man.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I got stuck with Taylor bc I was a freshman with a bad time slot - for Calc III attendance isn't take so i highly recommend going to another lecture that doesn't take attendance. Overall, class tests have retakes which help but final was unbelievably difficult and the avg was a 68 so do well on the other tests.
TERRIBLE JUST TERRIBLE
ALL WRITTEN EXAMS AND HIS TEACHING IS ATROCIOUS. WORST PROFESSOR EVER

Whatever you do DO NOT TAKE HIM.  Way too old to be teaching.  He mumbles and doesn't explain anything.  No one shows up to class because it is a waste of time and the ones who do just do their homework and don't pay attention to him.  It is overall just awful because this should be a super easy class if we have already taken calc but its not.

DO NOT TAKE. Take any other professor but Taylor. He mumbles in class and makes no sense. If you go to office hours he doesn't help you. The practice exams are nothing like the real exams. He is a harder grader than the other professors. If you get stuck with him, go to another professors lecture. He doesn't take attendance.

I went to class the first 2 weeks of school and then stopped going because I would just sit in lecture and do the homework. He didn't explain anything well and was hard to understand. If you are in Calc III just skip the lectures and watch the online videos because the lectures are a complete waste of time
I would not look both ways when I walked to class because I would pray a car would hit me before I had to go to this class

This is the worst professor I have ever had. He has no idea what is going on and is frequently confused by his own words. He creates his own problems that have nothing to do with the material on the tests, gets confused, mumbles and grumbles to himself, then goes "ughhh ahhh mmmm you guys can solve this you're all smart." Like NO??? WE CANT

Easily the worst Calculus 3 teacher. He speaks softly and often gets lost in his lectures, very hard to follow. Will get his examples wrong and send emails later with corrections. After 2 classes I decided to teach myself the material with chatGPT which was honestly way better. I recommend attending another section if you have to take one of his.

When looking at the reviews I knew I had to do everything I could to avoid this class, unfortunately, it was not enough. I was tragically forced to take the only remaining math section, his section 1 class at 9:25 AM. Despite the 75 students that could fill the lecture hall, only 25 were forced to enroll and just 10 came to the lackluster lectures.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: AVOID AT ALL COSTS. He is very difficult to understand, mumbles under his breath when teaching. He rushes through the basic concepts and skips to very complicated examples that are hard to follow. Stops halfway through problems and just assumes you can finish it because "you've seen it before." Ended up switching lectures and saw major improvement.
Very hard
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Taylor's class was an absolute waste of 3 hrs/wk I could have spent studying the diff eqs on which he mumbled. I already had 85% of the material in the class at another uni, and still only received a C because I came out of his classes more confused than before. If you have no other option, find one, or take it another semester w/ someone else.

Good guy but do not at all recommend his class. He's very confusing, makes far too many mistakes, and generally seems a bit lost. Attending his class is typically a waste of time (so either skip or do other homework during). If you end up with him, go to the math help room, pay attention/ask questions during tutorial, and do all the Mobius homework

DO NOT TAKE UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES. If you have no other choice, find one. Taylor's idea of "teaching" is not explaining anything, finding the most complicated problem possible, and then doing it wrong while mumbling to himself. If you're like me and thought you could deal with a bad professor, just know this is a whole new level of bad.

Professor Taylor is very poorly equipped to handle technology (even a microphone) to make himself decipherable during the pandemic. He does not speak well to engage students, and the material for this course is very challenging, but he does not do a great job engaging students or helping outside of class. One of the worst Profs I have ever had.
Bad, bad lecturer. Confusing, and almost hostile when asked to explain his convoluted statements. I don't think he's a bad guy, I just highly recommend he retire.

Do not take Laurence Taylor under any circumstances. Or if you are forced to take his class, do what everyone else does and go to another professor's lecture. You will not learn anything. There's a reason 38% was *passing* on the midterm.
cannot communicate well. He knows the material, but does not put it into terms that students understand. Also does not answer questions well and regularly makes mistakes in lecture without noticing.

His lectures are confusing and unhelpful. He uses a "flipped classroom" which just means you teach yourself and he does examples in class (except he often gets example problems wrong). I don't recommend going to lectures - just watch videos and teach yourself the material.

He sometimes explains things that only make sense if you are really proficient in math. Office hours aren't always helpful. Really watch and take notes on all the videos and do all the homework before class cause otherwise you'll be lost. Study the homework for tests. Remember your grade is very dependent on the individual work you put in.
Professor Taylor is a horrible professor. Do not attend his lectures as you will be more confused than when you started. Attend a different section and pray you don't have him for calc
Half the class didn't bother showing to his section. Find another professor or teach yourself with the book.

if you didn't take this class in high school, good luck. If you did, it is still hard unless you saved your notes because he is awful at explaining a topic if you have trouble with it. If you took it in high school, you're better off not going to class and just reading the online powerpoints since you're a better a teacher for yourself than he is
Drones on. I took his calc class after taking calc in high school, so I passed easily. But if I hadn't I would have failed. My notes from high school were more useful than he was.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Awful lectures. Just reads off a powerpoint for a calc III lecture. Very difficult to follow along in class.
Lectures are terrible, does not explain anything well, and is not helpful at all when you go to his office hours.
He is very theoretical and very hard to understand in basic terms. He does not so examples, making tests and homework difficult.
Definitely a person destined to be a teacher. She goes through all material in a very understandable way. She is also probably one of the nicest professors I have ever had.

Dr. K was a fantastic start to chemistry at Notre Dame! She had fill in the blank power points she'd fill out live with lots of problems/examples to keep students engaged. She was so nice too! She always remembered my name and I LOVED when she'd SPRINT around the 200 person lecture hall to ask if the problems made sense/anyone needed help!

Her notes were formatted really well. Definitely best notes out of all the professors. I really liked her lectures, and they prepared me really well for exams. She is a good lecturer as well. Especially helpful for conceptual questions and also good for calculation questions. Also, the class isn't nearly as hard as people say. Just study.

Really caring professor. Floored me when she remembered my name on exam day- she had spoken to me once in a class of hundreds! Lectures can get dry but they're especially good for strugglers. The other chem lecturers are good too but I heard very few complaints on Kessler.

Kessler was overall a great teacher. One slight issue is that she explains concepts in very simple terms and does not go that deep into the topics. This makes studying for the test difficult because you sort of have to teach yourself the material.

Prof Kessler had super straightforward notes that made studying a lot easier. I had a very solid understanding of chem before I took her but I thought that her lectures were good. I don't know if I would go out of the way to sign up for her 8 am but she was super kind, accessible outside of class, and easy to understand.

All of the chem profs are good (Kessler, Sevov, Del Valle) in their own way, but I think that Kessler is probably the one you want if you are shaky on chem. She's the only one that uses slide decks; the others just scribble stuff on a blank notebook and project it to the board. Her style makes notetaking easier and helps lectures feel organized.

the epitome of controversy in the Chemistry sphere of ND. Your ears will be falling off 35 min into the lecture as her words bore into your skull but at least she has good penmanship.
