In all seriousness, could do a lot worse with profs but she is amicable, cares about students more than one would think. Hope you took an ounce of chem in HS.

Gen Chem 2 with Dr. Kessler was a challenging class. Contrary to the content from Gen Chem 1, this class focuses a lot on proving why certain trends exists, which often requires paragraph-long responses on exams. Overall, Dr. Kessler did a good job with this course. Doing the optional tutorial problem sets is crucial to your success in this course.

Kessler is fine as a person but not great at teaching. She spends time on random stuff that won't appear on exams then tests on completely different concepts. She refuses to record lectures after many people requested. She ghosted me when I asked her to clarify an exam question. Basically need to rely on prior knowledge in chem to do remotely ok.

If you can, please stay away from any class this woman teaches. She speeds up lectures towards the end while starting off slow. She does not record lectures while that would have helped. She can get pretty sassy at times. I had her for both Gen Chem 1 and Gen Chem 2. The sad part is she is a really good person, but a bad teacher. I would say more.
Just has no idea how to teach. Bad grader and bad teacher.
just terrible

Julie is the goat. A lot of people were hating on Julie, but she proved the haters wrong. This was her first semester teaching the course, and, given the circumstances, she did a fantastic job. If you focus on the tutorials before the test, you will do, well.

Professor Kessler was not clear about what was expected on tests and was not helpful when explaining concepts. Her lectures would start slow and then she would speed up at the end of the lecture to cover all of the slides. She is the only professor for this class, so she will be inevitable for many.

This class would be much more manageable if it had an associated textbook. Relying on Dr. Kessler solely for material is challenging as the lectures sometimes are not sufficient. A good euphemism for this is being taught to swim in the shallow end and being thrown in the deep end on the tests.
I think the class was super easy but she's a slow lecturer.

The perfect teacher if you prefer organized notes. Her guided notes were extremely helpful and in line with textbook. Her one weakness is she is a slower lecturer and the other classes are usually 1/2+ lecture ahead. This can make homework difficult because she has not taught it yet and it can cause her to have to fly through some topics.

Kessler is very kind and approachable. I only got a B- in the class because I am bad at chemistry, not because of Kessler at all. She explains content clearly and lays out class material on slides to take notes. She answers emails quickly. I also appreciated the extra office hours and study sessions she hosted before exams.
Uses a guided notes/PowerPoint notetaking format, which makes it easy to organize content, especially when reviewing for midterms.
Love the slide-style lecture notes. Very accessible outside of office hours. Boring class, but good professor.

Provides slides to work through.
The problems on the slides are an accurate representation of the questions you will receive on the exam.
She works through every problem diligently.
Very accomodating with office hours and will provide extra with the harder concepts, often to suit the student's time schedules (ie Sundays).

She sometimes skips over important material in lecture. If asked about it, she tells you to come to office hours. All-in-all, going to lecture was useless as you might as well just stay home and teach yourself.

She seems very nice, but she is not a great teacher. She constantly skips over material, makes mistakes in lecture that cause people to lose points on tests, and skips over doing examples in class when examples would be extremely helpful for everyone. She expects everyone to come to her office hours if they want the answers to in-class problems.

While we were often behind in lectures compared to other sections, Professor Kessler was a great teacher. I liked the powerpoint-style notes and the interactive lectures. Gen Chem I was made much easier with Kessler's help!

While she sometimes moved fast, I liked the powerpoint format of the class and thought she was very organized. I feel like that is somewhat of an unpopular opinion but I learned a lot from her course.

Professor Kessler is a bit slow in lecture. She is oftentimes behind in content compared to the other professors. She also doesn't give a lot of examples in class. If you want lots of in class practice and examples, I would recommend Professor Sevov instead.

Prof. Kessler definitely made having an 8 am class worth it. She has great lecture style and offers plenty of options for office hours and review sessions, especially around exams. I advise anyone taking her class to attend every lecture- the content moves hyper-fast- and put honest effort into the homework.

Julie is Awesome! A little fast but super cool. Exams are kind of tough and a large portion of the grade, however Julie is really willing to help out and go the extra mile to help us learn the material, if you will. 

Obviously really cares about her students and is very knowledgable of the subject

Professor Kessler's lectures were informational and helpful. Her teaching method revolves around fill-in-the-blank slideshow presentations. These are concise, but she tends to go faster though the slides than a student can write. I recommend downloading the slides before each lecture so that you could fill in the blanks rather than rewriting slides

She is a really good professor and I like how she dives into conceptual things because it really helps to actually understand the content when it comes to the quizzes. Her only fault is that she talks extremely fast so be prepared to whiz through notes
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Kessler is a really nice person, but she felt inexperienced as a teacher at times. She often skipped important points in the lecture because the class fell behind, and she wasn't great with explanations in lecture. She's great in office hours though. Great person overall though. If you did AP Chem in high school, you'll be just fine in this class

Dr. Vaughan is not a great professor by any means. She is always disinterested in her lectures, which are just her reading powerpoints. For the other half of class you just watch a video. Your only grades are 4 tests throughout the semester. The tests always contain questions are very specific, you either know it or you don't. Don't take this class

Zero homework for this class, but the exams are very hard. You have to memorize ~150 slides and ~50 questions on videos shown in class per exam. Class would be a lot easier if you had taken AP Bio. Lectures are sooo boring, and buying the textbook is waste of $200. Grade is only based on 4 exams, so you can't mess up on any if you want a good grade

Whole grade is based on 4 tests. If you're good at memorization this is an easy class. I'm personally not as good so I find it a little more difficult. Lectures are really boring, not necessary to attend since she posts the slides and videos. Do astronomy/cosmology instead if possible. Last exam brought from B+ to A.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I wanted to take the time out of my day to write that Professor Vaughan is one of the worst teachers/professors I've ever had in my life. I'm assuming the only reason she still has a job is because of tenure. I strongly advise that no one takes Microbes and Man. I wouldn't wish the boredom, pain, and suffering of her class on my worst enemy.

I wish I had never taken microbes. This class is awful; she is so boring. The exams are based on pure memorization, and they are all multiple-choice, so there is no extra credit. Her class is one boring lecture where she reads off slides. Her questions are extremely picky, and her multiple-choice answers are worded weirdly.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Do NOT take this class! Patricia Vaughan is a terrible teacher - only lectures and there are 4 exams. The exams are based on a TON of information that is pure memorization, but it is nearly IMPOSSIBLE to memorize all of it. I studied for 4 hours a day for an exam and still only received a D. DO NOT TAKE!
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I decided to take Microbes and Man because I was told it was an easy science class for non-science majors. Boy was I wrong! She brushes over things in class then asks the most specific questions ever. The whole grade is 4 exams so study hard for the exams and try not to get tricked with her wording (easier said than done). She is also sooo boring.

Honestly, this class depends on how good of memory you have. 3/4 of the class stops showing up after the 1st week because she is extremely boring and posts all the material online. If you can memorize all the slides (about 150 an exam) you never have to go to class and its an easy A. It is only graded on 4 equally weighted exams
VERY HARD CLASS. DO NOT TAKE IT!!!! YOU HAVE TO MEMORIZE 10 SLIDES ABOUT AN EXAM AND SHE ASKS THE MOST SPECIFIC QUESTIONS EVER.
Way too heavy with her tests. Brush through content and makes us take exam.

she is just an awful teacher. i somewhat feel bad writing this review because she is not a bad person, but my goodness she is a horrible teacher. she thinks she is connecting with the class when 8 people have passed out during lectures about why it is important to use soap. she is also not as easy as she likes to think, this is just a rough class
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Like literally all you have to do is review the notes and be semi conscious in class and you'll do well. The only people who don't do well are people who don't know how college courses work.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Used to be if you didnt have something nice to say dont say anything… I have nothing nice to say and I will say it…. she STINKS

just awful. i dont know why notre dame thinks she is capable of teaching science because she goes up in the front of the room and rambles on about hand washing techniques. this was the class I was looking forward to most and I couldn't even make it through class without falling asleep. she is just a brutal teacher to be honest
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Horrible. the worst teacher and worst attitude. she seems to really dislike teaching, her students and doing anything remotely helpful for her class
literally the worst class and professor ever. ruins a cool topic and is just a really mean person
AWFUL!!!!! THE WORST AND MEANEST PROFESSOR IVE HAD IN 4 YEARS. JUST A REALLY MEAN PERSON WHO ENJOYED SEEING STUDENTS STRUGGLE

I honestly can't believe anyone didn't enjoy Professor Vaughan! It was alot of fun learning all the diseases caused by different microbes and we watched like 4 docu style movies. As long as you study like actual ND student, you should be fine. Ngl, her lab was my favorite one I have ever taken, never stayed more than an hour.

I am not quite sure why there are so many negative reviews because she is amazing. I found the material to be very interesting, but also not complex at all. I also really enjoyed the videos. Sometimes the class is a little boring, but I found it to be a good way to learn about biology. She also gives some slack with grading.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: HORRENDOUS TEACHER. My friends and I could not believe how boring she made a cool subject. We are in a pandemic!!! How could Microbes and man not be interesting? Well, if Professor Vaughan teaches it!!! She is truly awful. One of the most self-centered, my road or the high road people Ive ever met. Do yourself a favor and avoid her at all costs.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: scale is not low enough for me because she deserves negative ratings.
avoid. here is your warning. tests are nothing like she says in class and really doesn't care about helping you learn.

Very easy A if you put in some effort. You just need to memorize the slides bc that's the entire test. you can find video answers on quizlet which is cool. you don't have to go to class, but it will make the class easier. your grade is 4 exams and your lowest score is 1/2 the weight
just a truly awful professor. if i could go back and take a different class with a more caring and interesting professor I would.
Pretty easy class but terrible professor.
awful teacher. really poor at lecturing and tests are nothing like class. Just makes a really interesting topic very unenjoyable
terrible. arrogant and bad at teaching. avoid and thank me later.

terrible professor. she acts like the class is super easy and if you show up you will do well. Nope. Doesn't explain anything and the exams are nothing like the textbook or class. Do not take if you want an A, really overrated professor.

This woman is goated. The class has no HW, only four tests that are all multiple choice with no trickery--she tells you what you need to know. Half the class is basic note-taking and the other is videos. This woman is legendary. I took her in 2018 and even then we were watching Contagion and she was calling out a pandemic. Goated

Microbes and Man is a great class.. The topics are interesting and she helps you understand while knowing that many who take this class don't want to be science majors. The tests aren't hard and she always does review and gives hints before them so listen to those. She also lectures for 50 mins and shows videos for the remaining 25 which is nice.

GGL is one of the easiest classes you will take, and I highly recommend taking it with Blaschko. He gives out extra credit all the time and gives engaging lectures about philosophy. Most of your grade consists of showing up to class, completing a thinker analytix course outside of class, and going to your group discussion. Super easy.

Professor Blaschko was an amazing individual. He spent time out of class and office hours to help me sort out any problems I had with the material. His lectures are incredibly interesting and funny. The workload is very reasonable and the TA's are also happy to help. Would recommend 100%.
Great Guy. Definitely recommend for first years.

Highly recommend GGL with Blaschko for your first philo requirement! Interesting topics for what can in other cases be a boring subject and definitely a reasonable workload for an intro class. Go to class and take notes and you're guaranteed to do well. Blaschko is also very funny and always has a good story to tell, so I honestly enjoyed lectures.
Super easy and manageable class. One long essay but otherwise not much work associated with this class. Definitely recommend for an intro to philosophy class.

Prof. Blaschko expertly assembles lectures that relate philosophical concepts to daily life, such as his presentation on William James, Elizabeth Holmes, and Steve Jobs. You will learn as much about the world around you as you do philosophies of the past. Available to meet outside of class. Excellent professor.
Goat. Nuff said

Paul Blaschko is genuinely one of the best teachers I've ever had. His material is engaging, he explains complex concepts with humor and simplicity, he is incredibly organized and clear, he is kind and understanding, and he makes us laugh. I wish I could take a class of his every semester. Awesome guy.

This professor really cares about your learning and little about your grade. He wants everyone to do well and gives extra credit if everyone does poorly on quiz (when the grade wasn't an A average). I got over a 100% in this class and learned so much from the course and found all the lectures interesting.

Very entertaining and funny lecturer, makes philosophy bearable and even interesting for those who can't stand the subject.  Go to lecture (attendance is sometimes taken indirectly via handwritten exit tickets) and take good notes.  Hope for a good TA because they are the ones grading your apology and mainly determining your final course grade.
Super easy class. Prof is really into what he teaches so that makes it bearable even for someone who has no in philosophy.

Blaschko is a gifted lecturer, very funny guy. The GGL class is a (good) cult at ND, and his personality certainly justifies it. The class was easy, just make sure to take good notes and DO THE READING, or else the apology essay is extremely difficult. Take advantage of the TAs.

Professor Blaschko is a great GGL professor. I hated philo before coming to ND but he completely changed that perspective. He's super funny and relatable. When Blaschko is lecturing, it feels like he's talking to you as a friend. For grades, it really depends on your TA. I had a tough one and barely got an A. If you have a tough TA be ready to work

Made sure all that was graded by TA's is done so fairly and you can tell he is constantly improving this class. Lectures cover the main points of the readings. ThinkerAnalytix platform can get tedious, its purpose is to build skills in argumentation. The professor clearly has a passion for what he is teaching.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Blaschko made lectures engaging and interesting. Although TA's can be harsh graders, they are always open to help outside of class. The coursework for this class was relatively light and all assessments were open notes so be sure to take notes on the homework readings.

Professor Blaschko is both hilarious and gives really good lectures. The content for the class is very well structured and easily broken down on the website. Because quizzes and assignments are open-note, if you take good notes on the readings, you will do well. I highly recommend GGL with Professor Blaschko for a 1st Philosophy at ND.

Extremely engaging, I learned a ton about philosophy and it changed my outlook on life. Easier than other philosophy classes but still has challenging assignments. A few papers and quizzes, all graded by TAs. The TAs grade fairly and give good feedback. They are accessible for office hours too.

Good lectures- he includes personal examples and is entertaining. But the lectures were exactly the same as the daily readings, which made them repetitive. Daily readings, quizzes, and application article annotations become busywork. The final apology paper is long but interesting. TAs can be hard graders. Dialogue meetings are fun though!
Good professor with fun lectures- grades are very dependent on your TA though.  Attendance was not mandatory and the homework was pretty light most of the time.
Professor Blaschko is very smart and teaches the class very well. However, he is very hard to reach out of class and your only contact will be your TA who also does all of your grading.

Professor Blaschko is very interesting and engaging during lecture. There are quizzes before every class that require a lot of reading and he doesn't go over the answers during class. However, he truly cares about his students and is accessible outside of class if you need him, but the TA's do all of the grading.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Good class and professor to take for intro philosophy. Blashko makes the lectures interesting and easy to understand. Lots of busy work which can get annoying. The class is harder than it needs to be but overall not terribly difficult. TAs grade the apology pretty strictly.

Professor Blaschko is passionate about what he teaches and I could tell that he wants his students to have a good understanding of the material he presents in class. You will receive an A in this class if you show up, do your work, and have a positive mindset. If you are thinking about taking GGL as your first philosophy requirement, do it!!

The class is a pretty straightforward intro to philosophy that doesn't dive too deeply into any individual topic. Daily reading quizzes are tough but not weighted heavily. Most important grades are done by TAs, who are pretty tough/aggravating graders. You need a 95 for an A but an A- is pretty easily achievable.

Great lecturer but the class is tougher than you think. Your grade is pretty much dictated by your TA. The reading quizzes are actually quite difficult but don't make up too much of your grade. Reading/homework isn't too bad, just busy work. Your apology makes up a lot of your grade so work hard on it and go to your TA, they are generally helpful.
The apology draft is graded with as much scrutiny as if it were the final paper. My TA was nice but was a tough grader.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: God and the Good Life is the perfect introductory philosophy class, and Professor Blaschko makes his lectures very engaging. There is work before every class but it doesn't take more than 30 minutes if you pay attention.

Prof. Blaschko really wants you to learn about philosophy in a relatable way. It's just that the class itself is a decent amount of work. I find his lectures to be fascinating. Also heads up: the TAs do all of the gradings, but I'd still recommend office hours with him.

While I think that Professor Blaschko is a great professor, I think that GGL has become a class of busy work. Whether it be through Perusall or the reading quizzes before every class, I think the work is excessive and somewhat pointless. I often took nothing away from the lectures because the readings and quizzes before class covered everything.

Deceptive teacher. Seems to care about you a lot but lets the TAs decide your grade. If you end up with an unreasonable TA, oh well, he DOES NOT CARE because he needs some students to have poorer grades in order for the course to seem like it's difficult. Do not be fooled by his seemingly optimistic character. If you want an A, it's a toss up.

The weekly quiz answers could be found in the practice quizzes. Many of my peers complained about getting terrible grades on the written work because some of the TAs are tough graders. I had an 95 in the class before my 82% on the final tanked my grade to a B+. The TAs were sometimes such hard graders.
Amazing lecturer and great personality. For his class it is easy to receive a good grade if you do your work on a regular basis, and this takes a total of 30 minutes a week.
One of the best professors I had this semester. 10/10

Del Valle is super caring and really supports freshman in gen chem. Homework is manageable and lectures are way easier if you put in the time to do reading. The course in general can be challenging but she does a good job of explaining concepts and is always accessible. Best professor in my opinion for the course, also does lots of demos!

I love Del valle. Shes super nice and really makes an effort to get to know her students. My best advice would be to go to her office hours and take good notes. The homework isnt bad and if you grind the practice tests/ tutorials you should do just fine on the exams.

Dr. Del Valle cares about her students understanding content and ensures there are no questions before moving on. Although she can make errors in her notes, if she notices them or is called out, she always fixes them. She is high energy and actually cares about chemistry and her students learning.

Del Valle is very thorough in her explanations and cares about her students retaining the material. Her notes are very clear and stops if there are questions/confusion. She does tend to make a few mistakes but she always corrects them when noticed.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Del Valle is often in her own world, but she is amazing at what she teaches. The course itself is designed to cover a lot of content, so that explains why some lectures are often more rushed than detailed. Yet, if you stay on top of the lectures and the homework, you should be fine for the majority of the exams. You need to put in a lot of work.
rating_tags: So many papers--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She cares a lot about the material and a lot about students. You could access her notes and notes from other profs online which helped to understand the material.

Professor Del Valle has very engaging lectures and she is willing to meet with you outside of class. She makes mistakes often in her lectures, but chemistry is going to be a hard class regardless of the professor, so be prepared.
del valle has very organized notes. if you prefer morning classes, TAKE HER LECTURE! she also gives typical test questions in lecture which are helpful to practice.
She is very passionate and excited about what she is teaching. She also truly wants her students to succeed and is very approachable.
Lectures are okay and cover all of the material you need to know for exams, she can be a bit much at times though.

Professor del Valle was a wonderful professor. In the beginning, it was kind of hard to follow as it felt like she went super fast, but it gets better the longer you go on in the class. Her notes are also super organized! She was always accessible outside of class as well, so many opportunities, and she takes so much time to explain!

Professor Del Valle is the best. She cares so much about students and genuinely wants to make sure everyone learns the material, and will do whatever you need to help you get there. Explains things well and does several examples, but does make mistakes fairly often (just make sure you're on guard for that.)

I recommend taking advantage of office hours, doing extra practice problems and getting to know the TAs; use the resources at your disposal. Exams are moderately difficult but are doable if you take good notes and study. Dr. Del Valle wasn't perfect (she makes mistakes frequently), but she was a good teacher who made chemistry enjoyable.

Del Valle is awesome! She's very accessible to students and works to connect with them despite the large lecture size. Gen Chem 1 is a difficult course, especially if your high school chemistry background is not very extensive, but her clear notes and organized slides are easy to follow. She makes lectures interesting by doing lots of demos.

I absolutely adore Professor Del Valle. She has a strong, relentless commitment to her students and cares about them so deeply. I sat in on other lectures at time and none are nearly as good of a teacher as her. She writes her notes very clearly and organizes them, providing high-quality explanations of the material.

Cannot recommend Prof. Del Valle enough. Truly cares about the success of all of her students, whether or not you actually have her for lecture. She's extremely helpful in office hours and promptly answers emails. Always enthusiastic and positive. Lectures are thorough without being redundant, and we often got ahead of the course schedule.
She is really nice
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Caring

comment: If you like to have organized, written notes, this is the best gen chem professor imo. I had no AP chem background going into the class, and she was very accommodating for people like me. Her lectures felt less rushed than the other profs, but we always got through the same material.

CHEM 10122 was BioChem for EG students. Prof. DelValle does a great job leading the class with detailed notes that she planned ahead, and often uploaded online. Tutorials for this class varied based on TA, but lectures were structured and she respected your time. Friendly and not a harsh grader.

Overall, she was a good teacher for Gen Chem. There were only a few moments that I felt I was falling behind friends with other teachers. Attendance is not technically mandatory, but the slides she posted don't help if you miss class.
Dr. Del Valle is incompetent. She has woefully underprepared students for their first class of organic chemistry.

She's very sweet and would bring another professor in to show my class demos which other chem professors wouldn't do. She teaches well but you definitely need to read the textbook along with her lectures to understand everything well. If you attend lectures and make sure to learn the material well outside of class you should have a good grade.

Professor Del Valle always seemed a little frantic and frazzled during lectures. She'd make mistakes and sometimes not understand why an equation wasn't working out the way it was. In comparison to other gen chem teachers, though, I think she was good. She has a good teaching style.

While I did well in the class and learned everything I needed to know, I often came away from Professor Del Valle's lectures feeling like one crucial piece of information was missing. This was slightly frustrating, but I overall it didn't affect my ability to perform well in the class.

She's okay. She's really sweet and I have no problem with her class but based on how some other students describe their professors it seems that there's some better options. However I can always do the online homework after lessons, but sometimes her examples don't fully reflect the homework so it can be confusing.
Del Valle was very nice and willing to help students. While her lectures weren't boring, they weren't very helpful because she tended to ramble.

A professor who really cares about her class despite the sheer amount of people. Unfortunately, there are strange things to note, like how she records lectures but doesn't say where they went and her refusal to share notes with the students. Just pay attention and study, and you should be able to get an A if you are studious enough.

Prof. Del Valle is such an awesome professor that I actually didn't mind morning lectures. Definitely attend class if you're confused, but if you know chemistry (like AP Chemistry) then the class shouldn't be bad. She actually cares about the students, so if you email her about a question, you can feel the passion in her response. 10/10 professor.
She was pretty good for gen chem. Very nice and wanted her students to do well.

Awesome guy, moved a bit fast through his lectures (if you missed one, it would really hold you back) but overall gave very fair exams and minimal homework. Really great lecturer too, made a 100+ class very engaging!
Gave great lectures every class that clearly explained everything. Genuinely cares about his students. Exams are all multiple choice.

By far the best micro professor. His exams are based on memorization, rather than professors like Spence who have make students apply material to outside situations. Never really read the online material and breezed through online "homework." What really matters is if you can do his in-class problems, they are almost identical to exam questions
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Doran was an amazing lecturer which made econ a lot of fun. As someone who didn't take any form of econ in high school, I was definitely challenged. I got a B+ but that's a result of me not trying enough. If you study, you'll get an A. Doran is a great option for micro!

Lectures with Prof. Doran were fast-paced. He emphasized the important points by repeating them and would "test" students while giving the lecture with a fill-in-the-blank style. Great class, and what appeared in the quizzes was pretty expected from the practices.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Amazing guy with really fun lectures. Attendance is "mandatory", but it's only taken by submitting an in-class-problem. Homework is very simple and only due at the end of semester.

Doran was a really good teacher but he moves super fast. Very lenient on homework deadlines. There are 3 non-cumulative exams plus a cumulative final exam. Class attendance is not required but very important otherwise you will fall behind. TA office hours are very helpful in studying for the test since Doran moves quickly in lectures.

I took the Economy: Divine and Human course, and it is the best class I have taken at ND. Amazing lectures with profound insights, minimal homework (mostly reading and written 0.5 page reflections), and two very easy exams. The class is easy and edifying at the same time. Every class should be like this, and every professor should be like Doran!

Professor Doran is supposedly the hardest Econ professor but I found the course to be very easy. He is super caring and makes it very clear what he wants from you on the tests. The tests are all multiple choice, and very math heavy but the math is simple applied algebra. His lectures are very entertaining and he can be very funny.

Doran is one of the more challenging micro professors and has a very fast paced teaching style. However, if you put in a lot of effort and studying, you will be able to do well in his class. He is a nice guy but sometimes seems annoyed by student questions. Overall, I would recommend his class but be ready to work hard.

I couldn't have asked for a better Micro teacher, his classes had the perfect balance of math and real life applications, he even brought out some cool economic studies near the end of the semester. Make sure you go along and work out the problems with him in class and you'll be set.

Professor Doran is a great character and just a great person overall. He emphasizes the importance of knowing which practices to master for exams (setting up equations, reasoning behind scenarios, etc.) which was super helpful. I would definitely take Doran again and would highly recommend him to anyone thinking about taking him.
Kirk Doran was the best professor I have had so far. If I could take his class again I would. He effectively highlights what information will be on tests and makes sure you know it.

Doran is known to be one of the harder econ professors, but I thought he was super engaging and really enjoyed his teaching style. The test material was always covered in class or on practice problems, they never try to trick you. It was definitely fast paced but between him and the TAs there were always many opportunities for extra help.
Principles of Microeconomics has a lot of good professors but I loved Doran and he is the reason I switched to the Econ major.

The homework for this class is on Cengage and due before class but it was only mentioned in syllabus week so not sure if it really counts, its not graded on correctness anyway. This class has more exams than the average Micro class around 5 or 6 in total including the final, TA's make the exam and some were slightly harder than others.

Very nice guy but BEWARE TA's make all the tests so they are very unpredictable and hard to study for. One of the hardest Econ professors. Attendance is optional but if you miss one class you will be lost. Review sheets don't really help.

Doran is extremely well-prepared for each class. He is willing to go over problems multiple times at office hours until you understand the concept. Lectures move very fast and it can be hard to keep up with the pace. Class is more math-heavy than other econ sections. Exams are slightly unpredictable. He is one of the harder econ professors.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Doran is a really good professor. He teaches more of a calculus-based economics class, so if you don't understand math you will be in trouble, but if you do you will find it easy. His office hours are extremely helpful as he is a really nice guy and will appreciate you putting in the effort.

Doran is the best professor I've had at ND. His lectures were super interesting! I recommend this class for students that need Econ for their careers (it is on the more difficult side). Homework and participation are graded on completion. He also curves the exams and has office hours. If you are willing to push yourself, definitely a must-take!

Doran knows the material well and moves quickly. He doesn't take attendance, but if you miss class, you'll be pretty lost. Your homework and participation in class factors into your final grade, so it's pretty well balanced. This was my hardest class; you really need to study. Prob the hardest microecon professor but he cares abt his students a lot
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Professor Doran is really kind and really cares for the students to learn the material. But, I would say compared to the other Microeconomics classes its definitely a bit harder. He moves pretty quick, like if you miss one class you'll end up pretty lost. But, if you do the homework and pay attention in class you can easily get an A.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment: Had Doran for microeconomics fall semester freshman year (2020). Solid professor who is very personable and knows the material like the back of his hand. Truly cares about his students dearly. Super kind. 3 midterms and a final-- the work load isn't a blowoff class but isn't terrible. Book used for HW. Understanding of speed-bumps caused by COVID.

He is an amazing lecturer and a very engaing professor. He knows the topic so well that he can answer any question on the spot. He takes participation and effort into consideration when giving you your grade.
Professor Doran is one of the smartest profs you'll meet. He genuinely cares about all his students and his office hours are extremely helpful to drive home the material.

Great lecturer, always helpful, knows microeconomics like the back of his hand, and cares about students understanding the material. Wish more professors were like him.  Sometimes in-class problems become too ubiquitous, but they are helpful.
Rosato is a kind professor and an amazing lecturer. She makes formats of exams clear and never tries to trick students. She also shows empathy for students and is super funny.

Professor Rosato is the best! The lectures were very engaging and informative. As long as you take good notes and attend lectures regularly you will do great. She is super accessible for extra help and so are the TA's. Exams are mostly memorization and application of main ideas from the readings. Could not recommend taking this class enough!

Took her for intro to intl relations and the best way I can describe the class is this -- they want you to succeed (Rosato and the TA's!) Tests quite easy and based on memorization, I would recommend taking VERY detailed notes on the lectures and reviewing those. Paper graded leniently. Madeline is an amazing TA, you're very lucky if you get her!

Professor Rosato is the best. Final is just a third midterm and all three of the midterms are very doable if you pay attention and know information from a couple of the readings. Discussion can drag your grade down if you have a bad TA but all of them during my year were great.

All the information is given through lectures so you have to attend each lecture. She is engaged and knowledgeable in everything she discusses, so she keeps the class interesting with her examples and jokes. There's a lot of reading, but I didn't do any of them and still passed with an A as she discusses all the readings/concepts in class.

Prof. Rosato's International Relations course is amazing. The material is very interesting, and she does a great job of explaining each concept. The class is very easy and the only homework is doing some readings. Her lectures are also very fun as she tells a lot of jokes and provides good examples of each concepts.

Great Lecturer and very friendly professor. She is captivating and I enjoyed going to class even if it wasn't mandatory. The grading was only three exams and an essay so just study and you will do fine.
Rosato is one of my favorite professors at Notre Dame. Her lectures are fun and exciting and also very informative. As long as you do the readings you will do very well in the class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Rosato is an amazing Professor all around. She is super kind and funny; it is clear that she cares about her students and wants to make the class enjoyable. Also, her lectures are entirely understandable and always engaged and interested me. One more thing-Rasheed (TA) is amazing. I will miss Professor Rosato and her class a lot!

cannot recommend a better professor to start with for poli sci reqs. literally, ND give her a raise, make her department head, in fact, give her Jenkins ' job. 1000/10. straight forward tests and lectures in a way that makes complicated theories simple. also Madeline best TA ever. loved this class.

Professor Rosato is seriously the gem of the polisci department! Her lectures are amazing and she makes sure that everything you need to know for her exams is covered. She is also eager to help her students by meeting outside of class to discuss major considerations, giving course recommendations, etc. By far the best intro polisci class!!!

This woman is seriously one of the best professors at Notre Dame. Political Science students looking to get their breadth requirement - take IR with Susan Rosato. Her class is lecture-based but they are seriously so interesting and funny; you have 3 tests which are all memorization and based on the lectures. She goes over the homework readings too.

Professor Rosato was great for IR. She makes the lectures fun and the content easy to learn. Her class has 3 exams (which cover a lot of info, so be sure to study) and 1 paper (5pg). For the discussion session, make sure you do the readings (or at least know the basic ideas of the readings). The workload is very manageable. I would 100% recommend.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Rosato is a gem within Political Science department. While her lectures aren't mandatory, her lectures are interesting enough to want to come. The reading is dense, but the discussion sections help to understand. Ultimately, if you come to the lectures, take notes, and do the reading, you are essentially guaranteed some sort of A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Rosato is a fantastic professor. She is incredibly knowledgeable, willing to talk to her students and is a funny person. I would absolutely recommend taking her class. The course is based entirely off of the lectures, so make sure that you go to class. The tests are all memorization; however, if you take the time to study, you'll get an A

Professor Rosato is one of the best in the Poli Sci department. This was my first class in the major and it was great. The tests are mostly memorization, and the readings directly correlate to the lectures.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Rosato is amazing. The class was super easy, but also so interesting. It was a great intro class - the content wasn't too difficult and she's always available to clear up questions. Mostly tested based on memorization. 10/10/.

Professor Rosato is great. She gives good lectures and does a great job at being clear and concise in delivering content. Class should be a pretty easy A as long as you do the readings, take notes, and show up to class. Tests are heavily based on memorization (definitions, significance). Good intro class.

Professor Rosato is an AMAZING lecturer. She is funny, approachable, and will talk with you before class and just be very open. However, her class is very memorization centered. The tests are VERY memorization oriented, but if you pay more attention than I did you'll hopefully get an A but I don't personally know anyone who did. She's cool though!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Amazing lectures

comment: She used to wait 3 minutes every morning because I'd show up late (it was an 8:20). Looked me in the eyes on multiple occasions to tell me she was proud of me for showing up. Easy tests, minimal studying necessary, definitely should read the readings or attend the lectures. Everything on the test is in the lectures and she doesn't want to trick you

She's a hilarious teacher who made learning the material interesting and engaging. There is a lot of assigned reading but I would just skim over them and I did just fine. Only the discussion sections have mandatory attendance. There are only three midterms (which aren't too hard) and no final which is always nice
Makes an effort to give good lectures, which end up being hilarious. She is also very kind and helpful. She does however give a ton of reading, tho I didn't do most of them and still got an A.

Great professor. Only gives three exams over the entire semester that were straightforward. As long as you know the readings, participate in the discussions, and make a moderate effort in the class, you will be fine. She is also super funny.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Hilarious--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: She was awesome! Very funny and relatable and not overly difficult if you pay attention and make an effort. Would definitely take her classes in the future.

excellent teacher! No final exam, just 3 midterms that were really straightforward (ID, short answer, essay) and a short final paper. Very approachable, and her lectures are always interesting and relevant!

Good professor! She's funny and crazy smart. The readings don't always need to be read because discussion sections each Friday tell you everything you need to know. She's a really nice person as well. I would recommend her for sure, just be careful, subjective grading can screw you.

Love Dr. Whaley, she makes herself very accessible outside of lab and is more than happy to help you and your lab partner throughout the research and paper writing process.  She gives really good and helpful feedback during these meetings, highly recommend meeting with her and your grad TA to produce an A-grade paper.  Intense but rewarding lab!
She cares about the students a lot. The material you learn in lab might be difficult to understand but the grading is very lenient.
LOVE Dr. Whaley. She genuinely cares for her students and makes so much effort to be there for them.
So far the best professor I have had. She is very knowledgeable, is super good at teaching, and has lots of outside class time to help anyone.
Professor Whaley is a wonderful professor. She is always very organized and does a very good job preparing her students for the standardized bio tests across all professors.

Dr. Whaley is such an amazing professor. The genetics lab had lots of work required outside of class, but in the end, it was worth it. She is always willing to do whatever she can to help you succeed!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Whaley is fantastic, and she truly wants each student to learn about the material and research! Her passion comes through, and she is ready to meet with you about any questions. This is the most academically challenging class I've ever taken, but I grew a lot as a student and I made a great connection with Dr. Whaley. I recommend the lab!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: She is literally the best. She cares intensely about each student's success and is always available to meet up. She even does review sessions every week. Definitely the best professor I have ever had.

My favorite professor yet! Dr. Whaley is super knowledgeable and eager to help students understand subjects. Had very good TAs who along with Dr. Whaley, were super accessible outside of class. Fun atmosphere in class and clear grading rubric for tests. It felt like she cared about each student's success. Highly recommend.

Dr. Whaley was an excellent professor. Very thorough lectures and made sure to answer questions in class and extremely accessible through email. Super nice and happy person. Peers confirmed she was the best lecturer for Bio II (M2E).

Amazing for Biology II! She was knowledgable of the material and incredibly kind to all students. Whaley hosted review sessions multiple times a week and was always available after class/over email. She has great TAs and has been the best prof so far at ND.

Professor Whaley really cares about every single student understanding the material. She is always available for questions and help. She makes sure that no one gets left behind. Best professor I have had thus far.

Professor Whaley is very enthusiastic and overall a fantastic teacher. The genetics lab is certainly a tough course, but so long as you attend office hours and ask questions you should receive a good grade. Exams are very detail heavy and there is a final lab paper. Plenty of opportunities to ask questions and write in class.

Dr. Whaley is an angel. Her lectures are very straightforward and she does well at explaining the materials so that it is understandable. She's very approachable and easy to talk to. Definitely a professor I would recommend to take for intro bio.

Whaley is the GOAT there's no doubt about it. The genetics lab was by far my hardest course thus far but Professor Whaley makes an effort to make sure you understand everything. As long as you ask questions, attend office hours/reviews, you will do just fine! Whaley makes sure no one gets left behind
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Dr. Whaley was a fantastic professor. Besides giving clear, well-explained lectures, she was available outside of class to host review sessions and answer questions. She made a genuine effort to get to know everyone in this 60+ person lecture and helped students get into undergraduate research labs. She is my favorite ND professor thus far.

Dr. Whaley is the best professor I have ever had. She is extremely dedicated to her students and cares deeply about their learning and development. Her genetics lab is one of the most challenging courses I have taken, but it was also the course in which I learned the most. She is exceptional at getting her students to do the best work  they can.

Professor Whaley was an amazing professor. She added extra details in her slides that make it easy to follow along and had all the material needed to do well on tests. She made sure to be available outside of class and did a fantastic job at keeping lectures interesting.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Accessible outside class

comment: Shes the absolute BEST PROFESSOR ND has. Please take her. It is challenging, but you will get an A if you study and meet with her to discuss any questions. She makes an effort to know all the students, so a great prof for recommendations. I love her. GOAT
Amazing professor

Professor Whaley is truly a gem! She's always willing to help whether it's about Biology or about research. She is very passionate, inspirational, kind and caring! She really does care greatly about what she is teaching and her students, so I HIGHLY recommend taking Professor Whaley's lecture! :)
the absolute QUEEN of the biology department. expect to work hard in genetics lab but also expect it to be worth it

GA's lectures are based on his slideshows, which are very organized compared to Anre's slides.  While the class is pure lecture and very wrist cramp-inducing, the material is interesting.  GA always leaves room for questions and answers in a concise and often funny manner.  No office hours or review sessions, so daily independent study is crucial.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Go to class and take notes…be prepared to write fast and be concise and clear when asking questions. He's a funny guy, but he covers a LOT

Professor Radvansky is an excellent and engaging professor, who makes Intro Psych more fun and exciting to attend. While I did find his exams to be harder than Professor Venter's, you'll be fine if you stay on top of the material and review daily. Attending class isn't mandatory, but you'll need to get notes from someone and do the quiz anyways.
ga is funny. he is a good lecturer and approachable by students for questions. he did a good job explaining the material. the class is just hard.

Such a great professor. Lectures were very easy to understand, hilarious professor, and overall brought a sense of joy while he lectured for psychology. I can envision similar energy in his PSY 30430 course which I plan to take sometime throughout the next years or so. Overall, a great professor, highly recommend him.
I love this man with all my heart. Take learning & memory with GA if you can, you won't regret it.
This class was so stressful. Everyone thinks GA is the nicer professor for Intro to Psych, but definitely not. Good luck with the biweekly exams.

At the beginning of the year I didn't like GA at all, but as the year goes on he gets nicer and nicer and I liked him by the time his half of the semester ended. His lectures are quick, but very informative and the exams are about 90% from the lectures and 10% from the book, but overall they are fair and not too bad.

GA is an entertaining professor. His class is straight forward: attend lecture, read the textbook, take exams. Reading the textbook is definitely important as lectures do not cover all of the content. That being said, the amount of reading per exam is very manageable.

GA is awesome and really fun to listen to, but I will admit his Learning & Memory class suffers from textbook-itis to an extent; you could probably never show up to lecture and get an A just reading the textbook if he didn't require you to. Course content is super interesting though and GA is a good and fair professor.

The way that intro psych is set up makes it purposefully tough, but I still found the material really interesting. Definitely a very self-focused course (you get what you put in). G.A. was funny and you definitely have to study EVERY DAY in order to do well. Don't leave it the night before the test.

Prof. Radvansky is very straightforward in his lectures. You could probably get away with just going to lecture without reading the textbook and end up with a decent grade. All six exams are multiple-choice, and the curve is somewhat lenient. Ask questions during class. If you take good notes in class and can cram a lot of material, you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Radvansky may not be the nicest guy, but his lectures are clear and he gives you a good outline of notes. His half of Intro Psych requires more reading from the book. He does not offer many resources besides lectures and the textbook. Overall, not a very helpful professor but fine.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: GA is a good professor and explains all the material clearly. Not as crazy as Anre, but he is funny and makes the class interesting. You should show up to class and read the book because the tests are 50/50 reliant on each part. The curve helps. Do extra credit.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Test heavy

comment: Professor Radvansky made Intro Psych very fun. He gave excellent studying tips (which are vital for this class). There is a lot of info to memorize, but as long as you read the textbook and pay attention during lectures, you will be fine. There were also opportunities for extra credit (and a curve), so do not stress. Overall, a great professor.
G.A. is chill, just read the textbook and you'll be fine. If you also go to lecture that's a bonus, but it's not 100% necessary.

GA was a great professor, for both introductory psychology and learning & memory. He relies a lot on the textbook, and although his lectures are basically just a summary of the textbook, the way he phrases things helps you maximize your understanding. You must read the textbook AND attend class to do well.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: I really enjoyed GA. He explained ideas very well, and he kept the class engaged. While attendance does not count, attending every class is the only way to do well. Also, you need to read the textbook but its only around 100 pages for each test (not bad). Overall, he was a great and entertaining professor.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Radvansky is a great lecturer but not very approachable. The exams are manageable if you study but often involve questions which could have more than one answer. Much more approachable during his office hours, don't miss them.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Hilarious teacher, I wanted to go to class even though it wasn't mandatory. I learned a ton, and remember a lot of it too.

Hilarious teacher... really gets the stuff across in an interesting way.  All I had to do to get an A was go to the test review sessions (there are a ton of tests, but they take no time at all... for example, I got a 58/60 on the Final Exam after finishing in 13 minutes).  The TAs at these reviews pretty much give you the answers.
Radvansky was a great prof.  He made class interesting and it was always entertaining to go.  He's also writing his own text book so you don't have to buy it yet - woo hoo.
Radvansky made me want to go to class. He has a great sense of humor! This class is very interesting and easy to understand.
No Comments
thsi dude is funny, he makes fun of the stupid kids that ask dumb questions!
great prof. great guy

As a CS major, I found this class manageable. If you have a decent grasp of Lagrangian and differential calculus, you should be well-prepared for the material covered. The key to succeeding in this course is consistent practice and challenging yourself with harder questions. Aim to stay on top of the practice problems, and you'll be set for an A.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: As a CS major, I found this class manageable. If you have a decent grasp of Lagrangian and differential calculus, you should be well-prepared for the material covered. The key to succeeding in this course is consistent practice and challenging yourself with harder questions.  . Aim to stay on top of the practice problems, and you'll be set for an A
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Only option for Int Micro. Pretty good though. It is a tough class, but he does good job covering material during lectures. Homeworks are difficult but going to collab sessions is VERY helpful -- almost a must for this class.
He is great at teaching. He makes Intermediate Microeconomics easy to understand. He puts a LOT of effort into the class, and he understands his students well.
The GOAT. Simplifies complex topics with real world examples and gives you a document on how to do well in the class. Follow it an you'll be just fine.

Professor Cronin is the man. His lectures are engaging and he gives students tons of resources. Students are given homework, practice homework, and practice exams to help them learn the material. On top of all of this, every single problem on all practice exams, homework, and practice homework is accompanied by walk-through video lectures. 10/10

Lectures are fast paced and engaging, which forces students to actually learn and think instead of just writing down notes. Homework is hard but that forces students to get to know other people and actually know the material before a much easier midterm. Grading is forgiving but not easy which only allows students that know the material to get A.

This class is definitely super tough, but it is only so because of how much outside work that you have to put in for studying for exams. The exams are difficult, but Cronin offers all the resources necessary to succeed. If you have the time and work ethic, you can get an A in this class. Cronin is better than the other professors for this class.

This class is a lot of work, but Professor Cronin gives you ample resources to succeed. He is extremely knowledgable on the subject matter and explains topics extremely well. If you are motivated and seek out help, you will do well. This is going to be a hard class no matter what professor you have, but Professor Cronin makes  succeeding easier.

Professor Cronin is one of the best professors I have had at Notre Dame. His classes are interactive and he allows you to actually learn and not just take notes. While the content is difficult he is always accessible for questions. Take his class and you will not be disappointed.

Mr. Cronin provided good and organized materials and resources but didn't care a lot outside of that. Nice guy, but he has very few office hours for the amount of homework he assigns. Particularly during finals and midterms, he does not offer extra hours. Not an overly bad experience, but not particularly pleasant either.
Brutal class. The lectures and PowerPoints are not helpful. The textbook is a disaster. Homeworks are extremely difficult. I would not take this class again. However, he seems like a nice guy.

I loved my time in Professor Cronin's class. His class is not easy, with challenging homework and slightly less challenging tests, but I learned a ton and his class inspired me to add an Economics major.

Professor Cronin is a great professor and is always there to help. The material is really tough, but Cronin does a good job at explaining it and clarifying. He has a great sense of humor and makes class interesting each day!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: Difficult class but Cronin lays out what you need to do to be successful from day one. The homework is difficult and time consuming but it is rewarding to understand the nuances of the material. Tests are also difficult but practice exams help with that. Solution videos posted online are a a great study resource. Put in effort on the lecture polls
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Do homework assignments on your own at first, then talk to a group. Don't just study the night before an exam. You can drop your lowest exam grade.

I would say I liked Cronin overall, to the point that I was disappointed by how much love Spence gets relatively. Cronin was funny and helpful, always aware of the intensity and length of his problem sets. He blocked the two hours before they were due on Fridays to be available for drop in office hours (life saver). Class is hard, but Cronin isn't

Professor Cronin is the real deal. I think he sometimes gets overlooked by students who really want to take Professor Spence's class (rightfully so, Spence is amazing). But Cronin is very strong as well. He is extremely thorough, organized, and clear with his expectations. He makes a tough subject more understandable and applicable.

Yes, this class wasn't an easy A and his problem sets are tricky, but he organizes sessions where you can work with your peers on them. His exams were easier than his homework sets and straightforward, so you feel well prepared. He is a really amazing, smart, funny, and engaging lecturer and learned everyone's name even in the huge lecture hall.

I don't really agree with the previous rater, Dr. Cronin was a very tough grader and had a difficult class with difficult problems sets but it was definitely worth it.  He gave pretty good lectures and I learned a lot in his class, and I'm performing better in Macro than my peers who took the other Micro teacher
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria

comment: An absolute, without a doubt, in every sense of the phrase, "must-avoid teacher." Makes the class far harder than it needs to be- the sections with other teachers had no idea how to do the work we were doing.  He is impossible, self-righteous, and downright unbearable.  Take him at your own risk.
Do all of the homework assignments, take notes, go to extra credit opportunities. YOU WILL BE FINE!! Pag is a professor that wants his students to do well.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria

comment: The best. Pags got to know every single name in a class of 200, need I say more? His lectures are extremely engaging and meaningful. While not too difficult, homework is due every class along with occasional papers - you will be reading and writing a lot. 3 exams are very manageable and extra credit for final grade is available. Highly recommend!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lots of homework

comment: I loved Pagliarini, he cares about every single one of his students and learned the names of all 200 students in the lecture hall. Grading depends on the TA but he tries to make it fair for all by giving points for students for the grading discrepancy. However, there is SO much homework and a lot of reading.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Lots of homework

comment: Class is super tedious and an abnormal amount of busy work. Grading depends on TA and attendance is mandatory. He makes it so everyone gets an A if they do the work correctly but the work is still hard.

Pagliarini makes a lecture of 200 people feel like a class of 20 by making sure that everyone can participate. He is so approachable and memorized the names of everyone in our 200-person class. He makes the information relatable and you really get to know him too. I was intimidated by the name of the class and there's lots of work but it's amazing!

Pag is a great teacher with super engaging lectures. It seems like an overwhelming amount of work off the bat but gets much more manageable as time goes on. He is definitely the best theo 101 professor. Highly recommend
He is a great teacher. Take his class. He wants you to do well and is extremely reasonable. The homework can be very tedious, but in the end it's difficult not to get an A. Calm class, clam teacher.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Amazing lectures

comment: Anthony is my favorite. Very funny. Makes Theo 1 entertaining. You might be falling asleep in some of the other lecturer's theo classes, but not Anthony's! He's just a chill dad.

Take for Foundations of Theology. Cares about students. Available outside of class. Homework is very straightforward. A few bigger papers but they are very doable. For exams just take good notes and pay attention in lectures. Best professor at Notre Dame.

THE GOAT. Take for Foundations of Theo. Homework is pretty straight forward and you should do well if you put in effort. Lectures are great. He is hilarious and dynamic and no lecture feels boring. Exams are very manageable as long as you attend lectures and take decent notes.

Likely the best and most entertaining lecturer I've ever had.  Very knowledgable about all things theology, making it easy for him to present a plethora of information in interesting, memorable, and hilarious ways.  Homework is easy yet arduous, but as long as you put genuine effort into it and attend lecture, you should get an A.  100% recommend!

Professor Pagliarini is probably the best lecturer I've had so far at ND. His class is super interesting and he cares SO much for his students. It's really a life changing class. There is a lot of reading and writing, but it makes you think. The difficulty is also based on your TA. I have a tough one and I'm working hard to get an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lots of homework

comment: 100% best theo 1 teacher out there. His consistent analogies made lectures both fun and easy to understanding. Amazing sense of humor. Plus attendance at weekly dialogues with your dorm gets you a letter grade boost at the end of the semester so taking one of the giant lecture theos is a huge plus.
Kept lecture fun and engaging. This is a great class to take with friends from your dorm. Anthony is my absolute favorite man on campus and seems like he'd be a great dad.
He is an awesome professor, and his lectures are very engaging. There is a lot of homework, but if you do it all you will get an A.

Pagliarini was a God-send for my first semester. You have to show up to class, but I never found myself dreading it. He mixes between lectures and discussions, repeats his main points clearly, and goes through material for exams so no one is ever stuck. He will never try to trick you on an exam or homework question. Pags is awesome. 11/10.
A fantastic lecturer and very knowledgeable. I found his tests to be well-written, and he curves generously.

Pagliarini has very engaging and deep discussions on the Old Testament and the overall interpretation/context of religion. Very respectful and a down-to-earth person. Most participation happens in tutorials/breakouts, and the difficulty of the course is mostly affected by how TAs run group discussions.  A few papers/exams but not too bad.

Passionate professor, makes lectures fun with lots of analogies for the material. Learned all the students names and knew when someone wasn't in class, so best not to skip. Reading assignments and short analyses were due before each class, and tests are mostly memorization.
Wish I had put more time into the class, it was interesting and well-taught.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: A great first introduction to theology. Professor Pagliarini really cares about his students and that shows in the way he lectures. There is a lot of confusing reading, but the lectures help clear a lot of it up. Go to class and pay attention and he will set you up great!
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: His lectures are interesting and hakes attendance for each lecture. There's a test every other week, but he gives you the questions beforehand. He's probably one of the best professors for 1st Theo. Sometimes the topics are unclear and he won't answer your questions. The one time I talked to him, he was rude, so I just don't interact with him.

I enjoyed Pagliarinis lectures, but I always felt like he wasnt specific about what was going to be on the exam. Theres an exam every 1-2 weeks, and the grading is somewhat unfair due to different TAs grading each students work. He is a good professor and has entertaining lectures, but its difficult to get an A.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: As I teacher, I really like Pagliarini. He always goes on informative and funny tangents, and his lectures are actually interesting. However, there is a lot of reading for the class, and sometimes, the content is very difficult to understand. I really liked the teacher, but not the class so much.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Pagliarini is absolutely PHENOMENAL. I was never religious and dreaded the idea of taking a theology course, but his perspectives, ideas, and lectures were some of the most interesting and engaging aspects of the semester. You will definitely appreciate theology after taking his course. While he may not be the easiest, the quality is worth it.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof. Pagliarini breathes life into his lectures and does a great job of communicating the main points. He is very clear about what is expected in each paper/exam. For an introductory course in theology, Pagliarini is your guy.

He is a great professor that knows his stuff extremely well.  Son-in-law of the former head of the theology department.  There is a lot of reading so prepare to do 30 or so pages a night and summarize those pages in a blog post.  The class is a pretty good size but participation counts.  Plenty of opportunity for that though.

My queen. Literally loved her- her lectures were interesting/clear, what she writes on the board is nearly all you need for notes. Minimal homework. Just do all of the practice problems, (not just practice exams, but the optional individual practice problems per unit) make sure you know how to do them, and you will be great!
interesting, clear and engaging lectures. make sure to do the additional practice she gives for each individual unit to prepare for the test!

Prof. Bennett is honestly so cool and relatable. She is good at explaining concepts, but lectures can get heavy. Her exams are not the easiest and she does not give a lot of material to practice (1 practice exam per midterm and practice homeworks) however, it is a doable class. If you can take stats with Bennett, do it. She's worth it.

Not as bad as all the other reviews say. She's very funny and relatable and while at times she is slightly disorganized during lectures, it's an overall manageable class. The problem sets and tests are reasonable and you will succeed if you study. Office hours are also very accessible and good for problem-set help. Overall a good class!
Barely knows what she's talking about. Exams are absolute BS. TAKE SPENCE!!!

Class is relatively easy. Participation grade is based on putting an answer to PollEverywhere questions. It can get a little boring at times, but the tests are very fair and if you take good notes you will succeed. A cheat sheet is allowed for all 3 exams. Small assignments weekly, but overall a very low and easy workload.

disorganized professor. Kept me in the dark the whole semester because she only bothered to look for my midterm exam from the testing center at the end of the semester, having assumed I skipped it and making no effort to inform me. Botched the final for students with accommodations by getting them the equation sheet 2 hours into the exam.
Idk. I just didn't like the vibe of her course it felt more like a class in middle school where kids in middle just shout the answers. That's the kinda atmosphere she actively allows and creates

Prof Bennet made the subject of stats much more interesting by being a relatable and cool professor. She was good at explaining the concepts, but the class could have benefitted from more examples. She is open to questions during lecture and cares about her students. Class is not impossible if you pay attention and work hard on the homework.

Do not take her for Stats. Confusing lectures that rarely helped with homework sets or tests, I felt like I learned most of the class material outside of class. The exams are very difficult, study hard or you will do poorly.

Professor Bennett is super sweet and approachable, and genuinely cares about her students. Homework load isn't bad and exams are fair. Classes are sometimes a little rushed and can be confusing, but you can get the help you need from her or the TAs. Tutorial is like a third class (not revision of material). Data project at the end is super easy!

Professor Bennett is great. Her lectures are entertaining, and as a non-econ major, I found her class to be highly informative. The problem sets were generally not too hard, and the writing assignments were easy. While the exams were difficult, her grading system allows you to still do well even if you mess up on a midterm. Definitely recommend.

Professor Bennett is great for principles of microeconomics! Her lectures were pretty entertaining, always filled with lots of examples, and the homework load was pretty light. The tests are hard, but there are plenty of practice questions and opportunities to succeed in the class. Highly recommend!

She tries to be a good professor but falls behind in so many aspects. Tough grader; does not let you ask her questions during exams but rather you must write what you were confused on and debate with her; not accessible at all, she only hosts office hrs once a week; HER ANSWER KEYS, EXAMS, AND HOMEWORKS ALL HAVE TYPOS, EVERY SINGLE TIME

Easily the best principles of micro professor from what I've heard about the others. Her class is far easier than other professors and although she doesn't really care about meeting the needs of students her lectures are great.

She does expect a lot out of incoming freshmen, but if you spend the time to actually study you'll do perfectly fine. I went into the final with a B- and came out with an A due to her lenient final grade scaling as well. She also is quite entertaining. My only issue is that she does not post her slideshow/lectures online so class is required.

Professor Bennett was a great principles of micro professor. She communicated things in a very understandable way, helping make sense of complicated topics. Midterms were more conceptual than the problem sets and practice midterms, so make sure you have a thorough understanding. Overall, if you are engaged and take good notes, you will get an A.

This is for ECON 30340 which is Stats for Economics. I heard her principles class is really good, but I only had her for stats and it was awful. This was her first time teaching stats, so maybe that's a contributing factor. She just would constantly mess up the material and examples, confusing everyone in class. Her office hours are also unhelpful.

Prof Bennett's intro classes are probably the easiest in the department. She grades pretty easily and really only one of the mid terms matters towards your final grade. Just study for all exams and you'll be fine

She is so bad. Never take her if you love your life. She will never be satisfied. If you expect an A, you are going to get a B. Worst grader and lecturer. Messes up her own problems. Gets them off of chegg. Even if you chegg the HW, you will never get full marks. THIS IS FOR THE STATISTICS FOR ECONOMICS CLASS.

I loved having Professor Bennett as she made the class very enjoyable. I also really enjoyed our writing assignments because she chose relevant subject matter and made the assignment relate to current events.

Prof Bennett is a good professor. Class is heavily reliant on PollEverywhere questions and can be somewhat painfully slow paced at times. Exams are of moderate difficulty. You'll be fine if you study and attend each lecture. She includes assignments designed to provoke interest in the subject matter, which I liked.
Great professor, but the grading criteria (possibly more the fault of the Grad TAs) is a little more on the tough side.

If you like philosophy, then this class is for you. If you hate philosophy, avoid at all costs. While Speaks is a good lecturer, many of the concepts were way outside the grasp of an intro student. The small group discussion days were certainly the highlight! Also the size of the class was wayyy too big for a philo class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Speaks is a very intelligent man with a gift for making lectures interesting and engaging. Philosophy can be hard to understand at times, but he is very kind and willing to help. The TA's are also very helpful.

For my first philosophy class at Notre Dame I took Speaks Epistemology and Metaphysics, and it was honestly the best class in my entire schedule. He is an unbelievable professor who truly cares about his students, and you see this through his TAs and lecture effort. We also had to watch movies/shows for class, and only 2/3 papers are graded.

Professor Speaks's class was AMAZING! "Myphilo," his website, is your midterm and final grades, and with only the highest two out of three papers considered.
