Discussion days watching "Black Mirror" and "Inception" with your peers, all while grades are handled by Teaching Assistants. TAKE THIS CLASS!

Speaks was a good professor. He just lectured, and his TAs did all the grading...so PRAY that you get a decent TA that doesn't grade you like a philosopher. I hated philosophy going into the course, and I came out hating it even more. Such a worthless subject. I recommend speaks if you want a course with a reasonable courseload, PRAY for a TA.
Such an interesting class!

Incredible lectures. He really makes you think. Grading is based on three papers (lowest of the three is dropped) and completion of "My Philosophy," a program he wrote that involves answering philosophical questions after each class. There is one paragraph of reading per class, but you don't actually have to do it. No exams.

Your grade is pretty dependent on your TA, but it usually works out well if you put enough effort into your writing. From my own personal experience, as well as from what I understand from my peers, it is easy to get an A- in the class, but relatively difficult to get an A.

You're able to suggest songs for extra credit so make sure to take advantage of that. Grading is 100% reliant on TAs so make sure that you ask for help when needed. Take advantage of the chance for TAs to give feedback on your papers before turning them in.

Dependent on which TA you get for the papers, grade us like grad students. The class is all lectures on logic arguments that are incredibly boring. There isn't much work to do until the midterm and final as those projects take an enormous amount of time and are graded incredibly hard. Speaks is very knowledgeable but it's torture to listen to him.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Very interesting, doesn't assign much reading but wants you to really think about class questions.

Professor Speaks is a great lecturer. His class can be confusing sometimes but that is strictly because of the material being covered. You dont have to attend every class but it would be wise to because it makes your My Philosophy work much easier. Youre grade is dependent on your TA so utilize office hours to check over papers. No exams.
SO. SMART. Take any class of his you can. He knows what he's talking about and he was super kind/accommodating when I had to go into rona isolation.

Prof Speaks does a wonderful job explaining complex concepts by using everyday examples. If you have any confusion, he posts all of his lectures on his class website. Students can also submit songs that relate to the class topic for extra credit. Shorter papers and less reading than God and the Good Life class. 100% recommend!

Professor Speaks is a great teacher. He takes very complex philosophical ideas and breaks them down so that they are easy to understand. There is no homework besides a light reading before class (about a paragraph) and three papers. He cares about his students. I had him during corona, and he cancelled our final to try and help us have less stress
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Clear grading criteria

comment: I really love professor Speaks!!! Amazing lectures and sometimes hilarious. Always a pleasure listening to his reasoning. He knows so many things about Philosophy that he can answer everyone's question or opposition very quickly. So sad that he just teaches this course. However, the grading mainly depends on your TA.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Inspirational--Amazing lectures

comment: Excellent professor! He is a brilliant and very approachable guy. Workload is not bad at all, exams not too bad. Tough course, but keeps lectures pretty interesting. Performance does depend on your TA, though
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Brilliant professor. Don't be afraid to ask for help, because you'll probably need it.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Really great at answering questions and making things understandable
Very smart professor and good lectures.

His genetics course is very intense, much more so than the other (more pre-prof geared) genetics. I struggled with the material and flipped classroom format; however, Dr. Hyde is very kind and patient and willing to work with you outside of class to master the material (a resource I should have utilized sooner). BIG time sink (lecture + studying).

Dr. Hyde's Blindness module is by far the most fascinating class I've ever taken. However, his lectures can be fast paced and it is sometimes difficult to get down all of the information, especially because there are zero outside resources for the class, only the lecture content. Quizzes are take home and can be difficult, but the final was good.

I loved Dr. Hyde's bio module, as I found it to be fascinating and felt he was very knowledgeable about the topic.  This is a difficult course without prior bio experience, but the concept checks strictly follow what is taught in class and the assignments aren't bad.
David Hyde is a great professor who is clearly very knowledgeable. His biology module on blindness is extremely interesting, but it's also very difficult.

Definitely one of the most difficult classes I've taken here but simultaneously one of the best. Class is >75% problem solving based rather than memorization. This class does take up a lot of time though (double lecture, study groups, and flipped classroom) but I found it pretty rewarding. Lots of opportunities to get help. Don't buy the textbook.

I really enjoyed Dr. Hyde's genetics class...despite the grade. His course is very difficult, but definitely doable. Looking back, I've learned so much from Dr. Hyde. Don't bother buying his textbook. He will show you figures from the book in class. Overall, Dr. Hyde is a great professor, but his class definitely is not easy.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Hyde is a great person who cares about his students...BUT it is not worth the time and stress you will have while taking his course. He expects so much work to be done, and it seems like he doesn't understand that students are taking other courses and are involved in other activities besides his course. Not worth is to buy his textbook.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Don't buy his book. It is unnecessary and he rarely references it for the hefty price of over $300. If you are good at problem solving the class isn't that hard. I just found him to be extremely arrogant and insincere. Additionally, the flipped classroom makes easy material difficult as you are expected to tackle it without guidance.

Professor Hyde is so engaging and fun to listen to. I loved learning about his research during the module and his organized power points along with the TA review sessions helped me so much. His lectures are very fast paced but the material was so engaging that the time flew by. I loved his teaching style and would definitely take his class again.

Dr. Hyde is a great lecturer and is super entertaining. He doesn't post notes or ppts so take good notes (I recommend voice recording every lecture.) Highly recommend attending the TAs review sessions (she has good ppts and summarizes material well). Quizzes were sometimes difficult but the final was quite easy. The 2 papers were graded generously.

Dr. Hyde's blindness module is very interesting. Tells great stories and is engaging. Material is difficult, but he is obviously very knowledgeable. Hard to take notes on paper because his powerpoints are just unlabelled pictures. He does not write notes and doesn't specify what you need to know, but TA does good job clarifying in review sessions.

Hyde is amazing. He cares about students and will make the effort to help us review outside of class. He's also funny and engaging during lectures, so it's easy to pay attention.

The flipped classroom is great for learning, but it's easy for students to not watch the videos (so many and very long) or do the wksts. 

Highly recommend the class!

Hyde is probably one of the most caring and knowledgeable dudes I've met. While his module is very hard, it's really not that bad as long as you go to the weekly review sessions with the TA. Also, recording his lectures will help a lot.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Hyde was a great professor and his engagement with students made the learning environment much richer. He genuinely cares about students understanding concepts and is easy to access outside of class. What makes this class hard was the weekly quizzes which, for only being multiple choice, are fairly difficult.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: I took his module on neurodegenerative diseases and blindness. Everyone warned me not to take it because of the high level of difficulty, but it was super interesting so I say take it anyway if you enjoy neuroscience! I find his way of lecturing to be quite disorganized, but his TA held weekly review sessions that were really helpful

Dr. Hyde's genetics course is extremely challenging but also a great experience. The flipped classroom style takes getting used to, but the effort is worth it in the end. Dr. Hyde really cares about his students, and he promptly responds to office hours requests. It's a huge time commitment, but you will learn more than in any other class.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Test heavy

comment: I took Dr. Hydes biology I module on blindness and it was honestly one of the most interesting subjects I have studied so far. His module is notorious for being the hardest and perhaps the most hated but I somewhat enjoyed learning about his research as it is somewhat connected to my major: neuroscience. Definitely be sure to work hard in class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: He did a "flipped classroom" setting, which wasn't very helpful. If you go to him during office hours, he will definitely express concern for whatever you need. He genuinely cares, but I don't think he understood how much work it was. I did not like how the quizzes before class were graded - he basically expected us to teach ourselves on our own.
you will learn a lot in this class, but be ready for tests with no partial credit, 25+ hours of outside class work a week, and a prof who believes his class is the only priority in your life.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Tests are tough

comment: Even though Dr. Hyde's genetics course was the hardest course I have ever taken, I thought that he was a fantastic teacher. The flipped classroom style of his genetics course was hard to adjust to, but at the end I realized how much I learned because of it.
Arrogant and unhelpful.
People who say he is a good professor are just autistically smart and will glaze any professor who gives them a decent grade. This guy doesn't actually teach.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. Miller is a good orgo prof, probably the best option at ND, yet he can be condescending and somewhat rude when you ask him for help. Definitely utilize the TAs, they are amazing and much more understanding. Miller's class is so organized, which was very helpful for learning. Orgo 2 is HARD, and even though he can be a lot, Miller is the best.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Blah blah don't listen to Smilly's bad reviews. Best prof at ND. Orgo 2 is HARD, thats just a fact. Smilly makes it possible. He answers emails almost immediately and is super available to meet and discuss how you performed on exams etc. Just go to class or listen to the recorded lectures and study A WEEK IN ADVANCE for the exams. Ask for help.

Professor Miller had very good and clear lectures, and the overall organization of the course was stellar. However, be prepared for his speed and difficulty to insanely ramp up from Orgo I to Orgo II. He also wasn't the most understanding or considerate of the students regarding scheduling and grading, so don't expect any leniency.

Orgo II with Prof Miller was probably the hardest and worst course I have ever taken. The exam questions and grading were so incredibly picky that you needed to absolutely master the concepts, knowing the basics and every little rule about them. Don't overestimate what your grade will be. I got an A in Orgo I, but a C+ in II.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: There's not a lot of actual teaching happening in this class. When you ask for help you are simply told to "read the book" or "do end of chapter problems" but in reality, navigating a 1000 page book to teach yourself complex reactions is about as easy as teaching yourself Calc 2 through a textbook. If you aren't inherently good at it you're screwed

I love this man with all my heart. He is a fantastic lecturer, incredibly articulate and sets up the course in such a way that it genuinely could not be any easier for students. Orgo is very hard but he makes it bearable and enjoyable. You can never go wrong with taking his lectures.

Miller takes an already difficult course and makes it impossible. With hundreds of slides and a new mechanism on each, you never have a chance to actually understand what is being taught and you are left scrambling to memorize new topics given the day before. Terrible teacher who talks faster than a four-year-old after 5 cups of coffee.
Shawn, I know you're reading this. Get a life and learn how to teach

Shawn is great at setting up orgo, but I don't love him as a prof. He talks so quickly and uses such an expansive chemistry vocabulary that I don't understand half of the stuff he's saying. I'm never asking him questions again because I end up just feeling awful about myself. The recorded lectures are great, but if you get behind you are cooked.
Best teacher I've had at Notre Dame! 10/10

Miller is fantastic. He records his lectures which is super helpful for review or if you miss a class. He is very approachable for questions and makes time for questions DURING lecture, which is really appreciated. He knows his stuff and can explain the concepts exceptionally. Taking him again for orgo 2.
If you can't handle a lot of energy at 8:20am, then don't take him then. Great professor, loves what he teaches, and is good at it even though orgo is miserable.

Miller is the best. I wasn't even in his lecture time but I started going to his instead. He works VERY hard to make the content digestible. His lectures are so helpful and he records them so students can rewatch. He uses technology and writes out his work as he goes so it is so much easier to understand. I RECOMMEND HIM TO ANYONE!
really good professor. Miller will prepare you for anything you have in the future (mcat, dat etc.) Make sure you read the book and its a guaranteed A.

Professor Miller wants you to succeed and posts many resources, but the class is very difficult. He has a good attitude and records his lectures. You need to do all of the actual learning on your own, so read the textbook and practice daily. The exam questions are hard and there is no grade rounding! Killed my mental health, would never take again.
Really hard class with very little helpful outside resources. Do well on exams and you'll be okay. Study well and with other people
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Miller is undoubtedly the best professor I've had at Notre Dame. Although I struggled immensely with Orgo I, I utilized the Canvas resources much more efficiently in Orgo 2. Reading before lecture AND doing the in-chapter problems helps A LOT. Spacing out your studying before exams (~1 week) also helps. 100% recommend Professor Miller!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class--Online Savvy

comment: Professor Miller is a great instructor, and I would 100% recommend for both orgo 1 and orgo 2. His lectures are really good, but I highly, highly recommend reading the book along with the lecture. Miller is also great during one-on-one meetings and office hours, and he wants to help you succeed. Stick it out in orgo 1 and 2!

He really cares about everyone doing well. He is also super energetic in class. If you have an ipad, he makes it really easy to take notes with his slides he posts ahead of class to annotate and follow along with him. This class is hard, but he makes the hard material much easier to understand.

Amazing, amazing professor. He really understands what students need and how they learn best. He repeats questions that were asked before answering them so the entire lecture class can hear. He responds to emails at all hours of the day and is very helpful with his feed back.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: This is the professor you want to take if you are taking organic chem. Lots of worked-out examples in class and available outside of class and office hours. The material is difficult, that's just the subject, but from what I've seen, he is the best at explaining the concepts out of all of the professors that currently teach the course.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Miller is a skilled lecturer and coordinates the Organic Chemistry I course, so his notes are streamlined. He offers quite a few examples and always tries to connect with his students. Always available to make 1 on 1 appointments to nail down concepts. Definitely taking Organic Chemistry II with Miller.

Organic Chemistry Two is one of the hardest classes you will take in college. However, Professor Miller was also the best possible teacher for it. He truly cared about his students and the material. He did a fantastic job teaching. Although it was a hard class, he made it bearable. I would highly recommend, one of the best professor I have had.

I am going to miss her sm. Literal angel and from my experience the TAs are not hard graders. Willing to meet during office hours to discuss any questions too, and explains everything thoroughly if you ask. Don't stress too much about the end of semester synthesis project, but just be thorough and write a lot in the write up.

Professor West is a fantastic Orgo 1 and 2 lab teacher, and very helpful whenever you are struggling or need help in/outside of lab. Stay on top of the pre-lab and post-lab assignments, and you'll be fine. Make sure to communicate with her about any discrepancies because she'll definitely work with you!
Orgo Lab and gen Chem 1 Lab are like night and day difference. this class was lovely in comparison

Very energetic and passionate about organic chemistry.  Presents information very clearly and efficiently during pre-lab lectures and connects the labs to the topics we are currently learning in our organic chemistry lecture.  Walks around during lab and is always happy to help and patient while responding to any questions or problems!
super sweet and manageable labs, connected to orgo lectures and helped w/ understanding. post labs were not overwhelming compared to the ones from gen chem lab.

Mrs. West is so sweet. While I didn't "love" Orgo lab, it was a huge improvement from general chemistry. She is energetic and the TAs are all very helpful. You'll be fine in this lab, so don't sweat it!

You don't realize how great lab with Prof. West is until you're in it. She's incredibly kind and the lab feels so laid-back compared to Gen Chem (yet you still get way more done and learn a ton more). Labs are super interesting and prelabs are relevant and helpful. Not at all a class you need to stress over.
Love Dr. West! So sad I can't take chem lab with her, only orgo

Do not worry about this lab. Mrs. West is the best. If you show up and complete the labs you'll be fine. The TAs have office hours almost every day if you ever have any questions and they grade the assignments very easily. The prelabs also have very clear instructions on what you need to include in the assignments.

Professor West is truly the best. Always available to help students understand the materials and assignments. Grading comes down to the TA (they switch graders every time so it's fair), but overall much more manageable than General Chemistry Lab I. Utilize her office hours to ask questions about Post-Labs!
Amazing professor! She really, really cares about her students and even moves her tougher labs around to not overlap with the Orgo tests. She will go out of her way to help you if you ask for it.
All love for Prof. West. Will never forget the look on her face when I showed her everything that went wrong during lab. Don't stress about the final writing project, they're pretty chill on grading.

Prof. West is like a breath of fresh air after taking gen chem lab with Wietstock. She seems to genuinely care about her students, and her TAs are less jaded prob due to this. Do the pre and post-labs decently, and you'll get a good grade. Make friends with your lab TAs.

Prof. West is AMAZING! She teaches both of the orgo 1 and 2 labs. The pre- and postlabs can be a little time consuming, but the assignments are fair for course material. Both she and her TAs are accessible outside of class if you need help on the lab reports, and she is really helpful and patient if you have trouble with the procedure during lab.

Professor West is truly one in a million. She cares about every student in the course and will take the time to address any issues regarding the course, course material, or student grade. The difficulty of the course, as per pretty much any Notre Dame lab, lies on the TA assigned randomly at the beginning of the semester. I would 100% recommend!
Prof. West was always available outside of class for help on the lab reports. Also, she always has a welcoming and positive attitude in the lab.
LITERAL QUEEN. the grading of labs is so fair. not a hard class literally just follow the procedures and do the post/pre labs and you'll be perfect

Had Prof West for orgo 2 lab and she is one of the nicest professors I've ever had! She isn't the one actually grading your lab reports (your TA does) but she's very helpful in lab and gives clear instructions.
Very nice!! Allows you to ask questions
She's very helpful in chem lab and the reports are very straightforward.
Very good at working through examples and understanding the how the class feels towards the material. Very accessible outside of class.

Professor Walsh is supper nice and really accommodating. Her lectures are really good at teaching you the material and attendance is never required, so if you can teach yourself the material you never need to go to class. There is a group project but it's not too difficult. Would def take again and would recommend you take it
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: No notecard, don't be fooled. She may be sweet, but the test isn't. Good luck!
rating_tags: Group projects--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Honestly, Molly Walsh may be a sweetheart but the class is not easy. Attendance isn't mandatory, but even if it was, her lectures are boring and not very constructive. I would not believe what everyone else says because it's just an average class and her exams are tough. Again, Walsh is super sweet, but the class is not as easy as people claim.

there's 2 tests, a project, & a final. all pretty easy. not at all hard to get an A in the class. u only have to go to 1/3 classes a week for attendance. DEF take the class its super easy and shes really nice and sweet. super accessible and willing to help. love her
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: TAKE HER. she's super accessible outside of class and just overall is very sweet and caring. you get graded on 2 exams, 1 cumulative final exam, a group project, and some homework/quizzing/participation stuff. hw and quizzing is based on multiple choice canvas quizzes that you can retake up to 4 total attempts. you get a notecard on exams!

Great professor who cares about her students. I wish it wasn't a lecture so that I could've gotten to know her more but she was very kind to all her students. Very easy class that requires studying for exams, but they are not very difficult. Mainly averages of 80-90%. Would recommend!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Very good at explaining the information, always supportive and helpful.

Professor Walsh's lectures weren't the most clear explanations of the material, but she gave you every possible material you need to succeed. In-class notes, chapter summaries, video recaps of lectures, and more are all available to the students. Take advantage of those support systems and you'll do well.

Amazing experience in Elements of Statistics. Clear lectures and organized notes which help greatly with the concepts. Always accessible before and after class. Exams are not too bad and you get a notecard on them. Knows how to use technology very effectively as well. Reading/HW quizzes somewhat difficult but multiple attempts offered.

Dont need to attend class if you watch her lectures online but class offers many more helpful examples/explanations. Very helpful in explaining different concepts or going over questions. The concepts will get you, not the math, but 3/4 exams are fairly easy. I attended about half the classes and relied on her online lectures, turned out fine

Professor Walsh did a great job of making statistics accessible to the mostly engineering students in her class. Everything was heavily example based in class, and she allowed stuff like a notecard on tests so that it wasn't just a memorization exam. If you can do the homework, you can probably do the quizzes and then the tests with some studying.
She's a nice professor. I found myself drifting off a lot during her lectures. You really need to make sure you understand the content on your own. I don't have too many complaints
Such a great stats professor. Lecture videos are posted in case you miss class and she does a great job of giving thorough explanations and step-by-step examples. Would definitely recommend!

Professor Walsh was a very knowledgeable, kind and dedicated teacher. It was evident that she cared about her students. The lectures in class followed guided notes which made it easy to follow along, and she tried her best to engage students in class. If given the option, I definitely recommend taking her.
She's a good teacher, stats just isn't my thing personally. She teaches the material relatively well and the tests are fair. If you are required to take a stats class, she is not a bad option.

Incredibly easy class. She is also a saint and a gem. The lecture itself is kind of boring and the structure is always the same, but she is the best for Business Stats and Engineering Stats. Free A. Guided notes for every chapter. Online tests (at least during 2020-2021 year) - except an in-person, 20% final. Take her if you can.

Professor Walsh is an amazing teacher. She truly cares about her students and learns all of their names. Her guided notes are very clear and easy to understand, and she's always willing to help her students understand. Your grade is mostly comprised of your three midterm exam and final exam grades.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Caring

comment: Professor Walsh explains concepts well in lecture and is careful not to take too much/too little time on individual topics. Easy class.

Great Theo1, good balance between tests/papers. Daily reading guides are tedious but mostly completion grades and not too much time. Grades fairly, but makes you a better writer (yes, actually). Full of energy/passion in lecture, and makes things very palatable even for those with no theo background. Likely one of the better 1st theos out there.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: Took this class this past semester and would not recommend it. Gerdon is a great lecturer and class is always interesting, but hard work doesn't yield good grades. There are really long reading for every class in which you can choose to write responses to instead of writing the final argument paper, but a lot of work. Do NOT take if you want an A.

Dr. Gerdon's Writing and Rhetoric class was my favorite class this semester.

It was undoubtedly a difficult class that pushed me. However, each class was engaging and I liked how he took time to get to know us.

He is a tough grader, but let's you rewrite papers; he makes you a better writer. My advice would be to participate as much as possible.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: Don't take this class if you are looking for an easy A. Gerdon is an outstanding person and lecturer, but this comes at the cost of a more difficult and thorough understanding of theology. I greatly enjoyed the class and deepened my understanding of theology, and it set me up for future theology classes well. Great availability away from class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: As a pre-med, I thought this class was more difficult than organic chemistry. He's a good lecturer but the long readings, tedious assignments due each class, and the various essays graded on no clear criteria made this class a massive headache. However, he's accessible outside of class and very willing to help, especially with essays.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: VERY knowledgeable professor. I have taken Theo my whole life and was worried I would be bored, but he gave a lot of new insight to the class. Definitely take this class if you want a great understanding of theology. But if you want an EASY A, DO NOT take this class. He grades fairly hard and you need to know a lot of information for exams.

Strict and intense but you will definitely be engaged in his lectures. Tough grader but good feedback, allows you to redo the first three. Tough to get an A but should get a B at the bare minimum. Would stay away from the class if you are looking for the easy A or just to fulfill the requirement. 
GRADES YOUR PAPERS DURING AN INDIVIDUAL MEETING

I have never been a big writing/English person, but I loved Dr. Gerdon's class. He is a tough grader, but he gives really good feedback and lets you redo papers. He is a very engaging lecturer and ties everything together really well. Even though I didn't get an A in the class, he made me a much better writer and I learned a lot.

I've never had a lecturer as good as him. Asked students lots of questions, no slides no notes. He'd just weave everything together in his head and make it a cohesive story that covered a pretty rigorous breadth of theology. It's not an easy intro to theo, but it sets a great foundation. Tough but fair. You'll have to be a good writer to do well.

I like Professor Gerdon a lot, his class is just a lot more than I needed out of a basic university requirement for all freshmen. He requires participation and encourages you to think much more than other profs that my friends took did. If you are just trying to take this to get a requirement out of the way, I do not recommend.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Amazing. I never really liked writing/English classes, and I have never had more fun and learned so much in one before Dr. Gerdon. I will definitely take one of his courses again.

I'm sitting in this guy's class right now. Gerdon is so smart and clearly loves his job. The only problem is homework readings are ridiculously long so if you don't have time to read 100 pages and write a response on them before class then you will be lost during lecture because he talks fast and flows through ideas quickly.
He really challenged his students to work hard in foundations of theo. There are a lot of papers. I think it helped me in the end, but it was a lot of work.

Bad teacher. I would avoid if I were you. I learned nothing but Aristotle over and over again. He should remain a theo professor and nothing else. I'm sad because I genuinely wanted to improve my writing. He graded the entire into 30 points. An A- on one paper is minus one point and a 29/30 is a ready a 96% in the class, 2 A- and you can forget it

He is the worst teacher I have EVER had! I was one of the most talkative students in his Writing and Rhetoric class and yet he would tell me that I did not get full participation credit. We had 5+ papers and it took half a semester for him to grade the 1st paper. He says that there are regrades but that's only true for the first 3. Learned nothing.
GREAT professor, kind of a lot of work. Easy A if you try.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: All-time favorite professor. I took him for foundations of theo. Perfect choice. His class was more than just a religion class - he explained the history behind everything. He's always very nicely dressed and calls everyone by their last name. He seems overly formal, but you can mess with him. And he would quote lotr all the time! Best prof ever.

Amazing teacher who really cares about the class as a whole! Each individual matters to him and will do whatever he can to help each person understand. Definitely take this class if you want an overall great professor who doesnt make it easy but not hard. A professor that is fair in every way he teaches.

I had Dr. Squires at Notre Dame where he taught my Ethics course. Class was always so fun and such a great discussion. He makes Kant, Nietzsche, and Plato as accessible to students as reading the New York Times

Professor Squires was an excellent Professor who taught philosophy in a respectful, engaging, and relatable manner. He was challenging, yet forgiving. I learned so much in his class that it has inspired future endeavors in philosophy.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Great lecturer. Broke down complex topics into things that are more accessible. Super helpful outside of class. Great teacher overall. Do what is asked of you and you will get out of the class so much more.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: Very chill professor who cares about you learning the material rather than focusing only on the grades. Really enjoyed my first philosophy class and highly recommend as a professor.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: I took a philosophy class with Prof. Squires. He chose interesting, challenging primary texts for us to read. He did not tell us what to think or have us just memorize what the authors were saying. Instead, he helped us wrestle with the ideas themselves. I always left class with a lot to think about. He pushed us to think and to write clearly.

Prof. Squires is always available outside class and held office hours every weekday while I was taking his course. He is always willing to discuss just about any topic in Philosophy, and is very steadfast in his positions. He is extremely receptive to active students, and will give back to the students as much as they're willing to put in and more.

Professor Squires is brilliant, and he makes complicated topics easily understandable to non-majors in his field. He is an engaging lecturer, always available and interested to talk outside of class, and attentive to detail but not scrupulously harsh. It's evident he really cares about his students.

Professor Squires was very good at teaching this introductory philosophy class many of that basic logical structures of language and argumentation, in addition to having us read interesting texts from classical Greece to modern Europe. He's great to talk to outside of class as well. Super interesting, recommend him.

Professor Squires' class was focused around group discussion of materials read outside of class. In my opinion, most of my learning came from the discussion of these readings, not the readings themselves. Squires likes to add humor to class, and is always happy to meet to discuss class, or whatever else might be on your mind. Well worth taking.

Professor Squires is a great guy. He took what was some pretty esoteric subject matter and made it into a class that was consistently engaging and interesting. He gives excellent feedback and facilitated great discussion during class. I would recommend to any student looking to dive deeper into a philosophy class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Squires is awesome. He made class super interesting and was very reasonable about the workload. Definitely take anything he teaches!

Squires gives great feedback! Any question will be answered with a thoughtful and thorough response. He provides excellent instruction and critique of papers. You can tell he goes to great lengths to make his classes intellectually stimulating and fun for students. Professor Squires was the best philo prof I have had. Certainly, recommend.

Professor Squires' Ancient Philosophy class was the first exposure I had to real, unfiltered philosophy, and even a year after finishing the course I find myself still considering those major topics we discussed. The course content was given in full and explained with great thoroughness; his challenges demanded serious philosophical engagement.

Amazing professor! Super smart and very approachable. He makes tough material easy to understand and organizes his class well. Talk to him after class! He is always willing to discuss philosophy with students. Even when sometimes you only have a limited understanding of a topic, he listens to you with respect. Workload and papers not bad at all.

Prof. Squires class was perhaps the most meaningful of my time at university. He built his ethics class around a few different texts, and though the reading was sometimes hard, it was all worth it for the high quality of in-class discussion that he cultivates. He conveys philosophical concepts accessibly, and quite honestly changed my life.

Prof. Squires is a professor with deep knowledge of philosophy and a great willingness to share it with others. Although the course was difficult content-wise (Aristotle is never easy to read), he always made himself available to help with any difficulties. He taught me a variety useful skills that have carried into other philosophy course.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: Griffith was an amazing teacher. His job experience is unparalleled in Mendoza. The three exams have EXTREMELY subjective and open-ended questions, and Griffith will use them to punish you. If you're a bad writer or take lots of time on short answer questions, the class isn't for you. The group projects were fun. Super great guy.

Classes are very dynamic with student presentations, lectures, videos, and some games every now and then. Material is kind of repetitive but knowing all the terms matters. Picky grader in the group case studies, and student presentations. I get excited to go to class and see what he has to say the next time.

Your whole grade depends on the case studies and exams. Participation is also an important part of your grade, but Griffith keeps the class engaging and easy to participate in. He is a difficult grader on the case studies, and if your group is lazy or bad, youre kinda screwed. Exams are complete memorization.

Professor Griffith is one of the best professors at Notre Dame. Extremely funny and engaging speaker who combines his professional knowledge in a way that is still accessible to a first-semester freshman. The class itself has a few case studies that are a little onerous but other than that the exams are pretty straightforward.

I'm really happy I had Griffith for marketing! He is a tough grader on case studies and the presentation, but his entertaining and passionate lectures, and industry experience, make up for it. He also discusses companies that are relevant to us (Chick fil A, Amazon, Disney), connecting the content to our lives and making the class more engaging.

Makes the class really entertaining with humor & personal anecdotes. Tries hard to make even the dull material fun. You have to participate once per class but he provides a lot of easy chances. The tests are pure memorization from the slides, but not too hard if you are diligent about it. Tough grader with presentations and case studies but fair.

Genuinely nice guy.  Showed compassion for my situation and helped me through it.  Fair but tough grader on papers.  Lecture heavy, but sense of humor helps make class interesting.  Brings years of industry experience to the classroom.  Was planning a career in another discipline, but this course made me reconsider and switch to marketing.

Griffith is a wonderful professor who makes sure all of his lectures are engaging. He pulls excellent examples for all of the topics he is talking about, and is truly an expert in his field.
For this class, keep in mind that participation matters (but he makes it really easy to do so!) and the tests are mostly memorization.

Tries to engage the class with humor and real world anecdotes.  Seems to enjoy what he does.  Lecture-heavy class that covers A LOT of material.  Has high standards for grading, especially on the case study projects.  If you're willing to work hard, you can learn a lot about marketing from Professor Griffith.
Fantastic at answering questions.  Genuinely funny.  I'm not a marketing major, but I enjoyed this course much more than I expected, largely because of him.

Professor Griffith is a swell guy, but the class was definitely tough with him. The midterms were pretty much just memorization, and he can sometimes fly through lectures. The group projects felt out of my control, as my grade usually fell a bit due to the other members. I wouldn't say to not take this class, but be prepared to work

Wow, I really loved Professor Griffith. He was a tough grader at certain points, and his exams required a lot of studying, but I learned more in this class than I have in any other class at ND so far. I loved his lecture style and use of personal anecdotes and visual/auditory examples to increase understanding. Great class and professor. Take him.

Each class was just one lecture after the next. Midterms are solely memorization. Ur only other grades are group projects and a final exam. So if you get a bad group you're screwed. I worked really hard for this class and got my first B. The amount of effort you put into this class is not reflected by ur grade. I highly DO NOT RECOMMEND taking him.

Griffith is a good choice if you are INTERESTED in marketing, but he is one of the harder professors. In a typical class, he gives a lecture for the entirety of the period. Make sure you ask questions. There are 4 case studies done in groups worth 20% (graded toughly) and teammates are randomly assigned. Lastly, the final is only application based.

Exams are heavily based on memorization. The final exam is application-based, but a cheat sheet is allowed. There are about 4 case study group projects which are not bad. He has a lot of real-world experience and he integrates that into the course which is really nice. Lectures consist of going over the textbook chapter he asks you to read.

Scott was entertaining and funny. Nice guy. For tests, you will have to memorize 400 slides or 1000 for the final. Lots of memorizing lists. 2 midterms and a final. Also, 4 fairly large group projects and an individual presentation. Projects will be a pain if your assigned group is lazy. More work than other marketing classes.

Professor Griffith is a very entertaining lecturer and really is able to engage his students in class. Although he is not necessarily easier than the other principles of marketing professors, he is a great option for people who want to major in marketing. He worked in marketing for decades and has a lot of stories and insight to give.

I have a conspiracy theory that every English teacher is the same person, and Professor Shumake definitely supports that theory. She is very nice and grades easy but loves to hear herself talk. Sometimes annoying but means well. If you've ever met an English teacher you have a pretty good idea of what to expect here.

I haven't encountered an english professor who is more kind and helpful. Approachable too and I always felt comfortable asking for what I needed. My learning was celebrated and my learning style a perfect fit here.

Professor Shumake definitely cares about all of her students. She makes an effort to get to know each of them. Professor Shumake is a tough grader, but her expectations are clearly outlined at the beginning of the semester. As long as you do the work, you should have no problem passing her class.

I do not recommend taking this class. Her classes are disorganized as she often rambles on about some confusing tangent. There's tons of reading and videos to watch outside of class. Her feedback on assignments is often confusing and unhelpful.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: A good class to develop critical thinking skills and learn to develop your own ideas. Fair grader who keeps class interesting by including movies and videos and relating them to the topic of study. Peer review is mandatory, which was my least favorite part of the course. Definitely recommend the class.
Nicest professor. If you make an effort in your work, she will love you. She makes class interesting, which is challenging and she grades reasonably. Super helpful during office hours. I LOVE HER!
Her class is interesting and kind of philosophical. Work load wasn't too bad. Definitely manageable. She's approachable, nice, and helpful. Fantastic class. :)
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: It is a drag to have to attend her class, because it is always so dull and random. There is so much reading to do before class, and extra assignments that feel unnecessary, such self-assessment quizzes every week. She is very unclear in lectures, and very disorganized during class time. She rambles often and it is hard to pay attention.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Very good english professor. Really teaches you how to be a better writer, very helpful when it comes to writers block, grades on if something is actually a good paper. Class itself was not difficult. Shumake is super helpful. I would definitely take her again.

She was awesome! She's down to earth and easy to get along with. She's nice but she's not a push over. If you pay attention and honestly try all the assignments you won't die trying to maintain your gpa. I would recommend her! She makes the awfulness of this required course a little less painful.

Her class is not easy but your writing will improve. I appreciate her helping me on writing concepts and overall have improved my writing. Personable and wants everyone to succeed. Course is well organized.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Learning was such an enjoyable experience with this professor. We did a lot of work (it's a writing class), but grades are based on rubrics which means read them and you're good. Good balance of individual and group work in writing groups, good communication, and overall I learned a lot.
She encouraged me to write the kind of work that I want to read and gave me useful feedback on drafts. She provided space and time for me to learn to enjoy writing again.

She is willing to take the time to meet with you and help you get the assignment right. Get ready to watch films and analyze them. There is a quiz assessment every week which asks you to grade your participation in class. Come ready to participate and be critical. Overall, she is a nice professor who wants you to succeed in her class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: Tough grader who gives generic feedback and ridiculously annoying assignments. Takes a solid 2 months to grade papers, so you don't know what to do on the next one. Class revolves around boring 'direct cinema' films with a million different interpretations, but you have to write about the one she likes. Huge pain for an intro level core requirement

Be ready for lots of readings and going from paper to paper. Her instructions for papers are unclear and she does not give helpful feedback on assignments. If you're looking for an easy class do not take this class. What is nice is she has spent a lot of time organizing Canvas so it's easy to navigate assignments.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: I loved Professor Shumake. The class is definitely not an easy A since there is a lot of reading and work, but she is willing to do whatever it takes to help you if you make an effort. I thought that sometimes the grading was overly harsh and somewhat unclear, but I really enjoyed the course, and she was super invested in all of her students.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: I wouldn't say this class is an easy A because you'll need to actually put in effort to get a good result, but if you're willing to work she'll do whatever it takes to help you out. She answers emails promptly and is willing to answer just about any question about assignments. Also willing to let you zoom in if you "feel sick" which is really nice.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Not bad. Not bad at all. Tons of work and the grading can be a little tough, but I'd definitely take the class again. Don't sign up if you're looking for an easy A.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: pretty nice guy, he can be a bit sharp sometimes though. point-based grade system. Has pre-lecture readings that are not assigned but are important for lectures. PLEASE go to lecture it really helps. two exams (his study guide reviews are basically the exams). one final project (choose your group carefully). he has office hours often for homework.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Morrison's teaching style is very unique. He throws out lots of terms in lecture and talks about them but does not provide motivation for why he's teaching the concepts lectured about. He is often unclear in his in-class examples. However, he is extremely caring and is very willing to help students find jobs and contacts at companies.

Prof Morrison is the most caring professor I've met in the department. He wants all his students to excel in the class and tech interviews. I would say the pre-lecture readings are the most important part for this course, and as long as you understand the concepts covered in the readings, you are in good shape for the exams.
Morrison really cares about his students and constantly asks for their feedback. not the greatest lecturer, but slides are uploaded and homework is similar to exams and review guide.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Morrison is without a doubt one of the most caring and responsive instructors in the department. He prioritizes the success and well-being of his students and is constantly improving his course and adapting to student feedback. The preternship project is an awesome industry experience as well. Not the clearest lecturer, but I'm sure he'll improve.
Morrison is a really good guy, his lectures are just way too fast and typically unclear. He is super accessible outside of class and wishes the best for his students

Prof Morrison is a really good guy overall. He just throws an excessive volume of information at you on new concepts, it can be overwhelming. Professor Bui, I think, does a much better job of teaching challenging concepts in a clear and concise format. The Preternship is great, though.

A lot of work for this class felt like busy work. I felt like I learned very little for a class that's supposed to be super important for CS. However, Morrison has only been teaching for a couple years at ND and he improves the class each year. I took it in Spring 2020 and he had like 15 office hours a week. & he truly cares about his students

Professor Morrison really cares about having his students understand the material so he's almost always available whenever you have a question which is nice. All of the class material is uploaded online before and after class so it really helps you prepare for the course if you really like the stuff he's teaching

Professor Morrison sometimes isn't the clearest in lecture but he truly does care about all of his students understanding the material and is very helpful in OH. His animations in class help everyone visualize what he is teaching and he does a good job of helping students network and prepare for industry. Easy grader so you get out what you put in.

Great professor who really cares about his students. Listens to students and adjusts assignments/expectations based on feedback. Would recommend starting assignments as early as possible. Also definitely recommend going to his/TA office hours. Super helpful!

Dr. Morrison is a solid professor. He started out the semester assigning a bit too much work, but he listened to student feedback and quickly scaled things back, even canceling a few longer assignments and class days. He and his TAs didn't grade particularly harshly either.
Professor Morrison wants all of his students to succeed and will go to extreme lengths to ensure it. Awesome teacher/mentor
Lectures are not clear and barely help, workload is twice that of all other classes combined with insane lab deadlines. Avoid at all costs.

He's relatively new to the school and still is getting accustomed to the culture and figuring out the best way to teach his courses. A lot of people didn't like him, but I think he has some potential.

Assigns way too much busy work; oblivious to the fact his students struggle with hours of useless zyBooks homework each weekend while also studying for exam. Claims class designed for new coders, yet expects us to be experts in Git commands to submit assignments. Seems to think he's still teaching data structures Unstable personality. Don't take!!

He assigns too much work for a 3 credit class and tries to fit too much material into this class, including stuff that is unimportant for his target audience. He assigns hours of busywork each week. He acted like asking about test structure was unreasonable. He expects us to be professional coders after taking his intro to computing course.

Fantastic professor, highly recommend! He is passionate and clearly cares about his students - often spends class time checking in / giving advice and even invited us to his home for dinner! Weekly work is manageable: two handwritten pages per week based on a few pages of poetry. Grade based on 3 papers, but extra credit is available (A- to A, etc)

What he lacks in organization and clarity, he makes up for in character. From giving scholarship opportunities to inviting us over for pizza, he clearly cares about his students and always wants the best for us. Just know the final grade will be based on two final papers in the last two weeks, and the rest of the assignments will be handwritten.

Great professor (what a king!). He pushes you to expand your vocabulary and improve the quality of your class comments, which can be intimidating at first. Much of your grade (if not all, I believe) depends on 2 larger writing assignments/essays. Truly cares about his students. He is one of my favorite professors and never fails to make my day.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Accessible outside class

comment: I loved his class on Irish short stories. He is an engaging lecturer and was fair with all assignments and grading. He was always available over email or for his office hours and provided very helpful feedback. He clearly cares about the material he is teaching and his students and had us over to his house for pizza. Overall, I highly recommend.

What Mr. O'Conchubhair lacks in clarity, he makes up for in accountability and compassion towards his students. Clearly, he cares about his students beyond the simple relationship of professor to pupil; he invites every student into his life through his pizza nights, his one-on-one office hours, and his authenticity in class. Would highly recommend

He is very passionate and excited about is works which makes his students excited as well. Class included lots of reading and writing but ultimately our grade was determined by our final paper. Very interesting topics and he is very helpful if you take the time to ask for suggestions.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Great professor who absolutely cares about his students. 2 handwritten pages per week but they are on completion. Tough grader based on specific criteria unique to him so you'll have to adjust accordingly.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Amazing lecturer made me intrigued about a topics I had never thought about before. Only two papers but if you are willing to work with him and understand what he wants, which is clearly described on syllabus, you should do well. I looked forward to coming to class each week. He also provides extra credit opportunities and is readily available.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Overall, he was well meaning and a great person. The only issue is he was not always clear on what the expectations were and he did not respond to my emails.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Graded by few things

comment: Passionate and caring professor who wants his students to succeed. Is fair with readings and only assigns two papers a semester. Very approachable and willing to work with you on essays. Offers numerous extra credit opportunities. One of my favorite professors at the university.
Amazing teacher, especially if you are interested in the subject, but the whole grade more or less comes down to your final paper.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: I had him for my USEM and I am so glad I did. He is an amazing writing teacher and person in general. He is always available to help you with writing after class. He makes the subject very captivating and knows a lot about what he is talking about. Highly recommend taking as USEM!
He is a super nice and engaging professor, there is a decent amount of reading but is very fair when it comes to assessments

Professor O'Conchubhair definitely cares about his students. His classes could be a bit boring at times, but they weren't terribly difficult as long as you did the assigned work. He is very personable and will help you understand the content. The grade is comes only from two papers so definitely take his advice and listen to what he says
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Such a great guy and an excellent teacher!  He really knows his stuff and actually got me interested in Irish poetry.  He's really funny and nice, and he even invited our class to his house for pizza!  He also cares a lot about his students and always made sure we were getting through our first semester okay.

I had him for USEM not the one I picked it was the only option lol. He makes you read your papers out loud sometimes, but he is sooo nice. Would 100% recommend. Made so many friends in this class. We watched world cup in class one time. Love this guy.

Take him if you get the option! He's the best! He genuinely cares for the wellbeing of his students and the improvement of their writing. I feel like my writing has improved vastly through the feedback he offers.

Prof. O'Conchubhair is by far the best professor I've had at ND. He genuinely cares about his students and wants to see them succeed, and he tries to help you out in any way possible. His CSEM was very simple, just read speeches from the Irish president and Obama and write questions on them! Then you get to discuss in class. Would 100% recommend!

Professor O'Conchubhair is one of a kind. He is my favorite professor outside of my major at ND. He guides classes and discussions flawlessly, and is very relatable to many students. He even went out of his way to connect with me, and invited me to get coffee and talk about soccer with him! Although somewhat intimidating at first, he is great!

He definitely plays favorites, the class was poorly organized and somewhat all over the place. We lost the syllabus timeline on week 2 and never got back to it so it was hard to know what was due when. The quizzes are impossible to get 100% on. You have to memorize his lecture slides for quizzes. Papers are brutal.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Overall, a pretty quirky guy. His humor is very dry but you will find it funny. He assigns a lot of reading so be prepared. The classes revolve around a lot of discussions where he assigns two people to do a presentation about the assigned reading every class. During the presentations, he gives interesting insights. HARSH essay grader.

Professor Lindley was great. The course included two papers, one final simulation, event attendance, and quizzes. The expectations for all were very clear, his TA was very accessible. Lindley has some neat takes on issues, this was genuinely my favorite class I've taken at ND. Read the readings. Raise your hand in class. He's a fantastic guy.

Lindley is a talented lecturer but needs improvement in all other aspects of teaching. His class is disorganized and scattered. Linley does not predetermine dates on the syllabus, which leads to the content covered and the pace of the class being almost completely random. The reading is excessive and hard to retain when not covered in class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Class is basically guarantied A if you try. Incredibly funny guy with amazing lectures. However, he rarely lectures as the class is just usually a discussion over the readings. Readings vary from 30-60 pages. Discussions are fun if you get a good group and everyone's engaged. Readings are also pretty interesting.

He is a bit odd, can be funny, but it's not worth taking his class. He assigns an unreal amount of reading and you have to do multiple hour and 15 minute presentations on 50+ page readings. He doesn't teach the class, you and your peers do. His essay grading is brutal and it doesn't seem super fair. Don't take unless you love IR.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: The lack of respect for students' time outside of class is ridiculous. Expect to read a 300-page weekly. All slides are minimum 5 years old and I'm willing to bet there are some from before '90 because I've found some. He expects copious hours of work dedicated to his class but dedicates no time whatsoever to preparing new material. DON'T RECOMMEND
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Very good professor who teaches you to think analytically/expand your mind. Essay grading can be a bit harsh but necessary. Readings are usually extremely complicated, but the discussions make up for it. Likes to talk a lot. But unless you're really interested in Poli Sci/IR, I wouldn't take him, because the readings can take up most of your time.

Based on the amount of reading/work he assigns Lindley either assumes 1) students are not taking 4 other classes in addition to his or 2) students have no lives outside of the classroom. Unless you wish to devote your entire semester to USFP, I would not recommend Lindley. Oh, he also brags about being the hardest grader in the PS department.

Unless you are very interested in US foreign policy or security theories, I would not recommend taking Professor Lindley. He assigns an absurd amount of reading. The exams were very challenging, tons of material in addition to required knowledge of current events. Not a bad guy, but his expectations for an undergrad course are far too high.

Lindley spent the first day of my freshman USEM asking us where we were from, and then telling us where the closest nuclear target would be. It was one of the strangest experiences of my life. Beyond that, though, he will teach you how to write like a political scientist and is incredibly knowledgeable. He can be very intense but the class was good
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Lindley is a G. He is A) funny; B) hot; and C) an actual good professor. He's tough, you have to be ready to defend your thoughts and ideas. Lots of readings, but they're always enjoyable and relevant. He'll assign a reading then you walk into class and he's like yeah no that article sucks. He highlights how not everyone in academia is intelligent
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: Fantastic to talk to in office hours. A super friendly, helpful guy. Nevertheless readings are quite dense and while roughly half are interesting (and mind-blowing) enough to make up for it, all of it is heavily oriented toward (just) security theory, even if it's a foreign policy class.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Hilarious--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: VERY difficult class. Hard test, but I received an A- and did not do most of the readings. Attending lectures, paying attention, and engaging with him outside of class are the most important; the TA grades, so engage him as well as the TA.

This class with him was just the worst. His organization is pretty much zero. Throughout the class, we jumped around all over the place.  It's really the total lack of clarity which makes the class impossibly difficult.  It was so tough studying for the final, since my notes were totally jumbled and his syllabus had been corrected dozens of times.

I was in his Causes of War class and Great Books/Articles class.  He has high expectations of his students, but if you're really into Political Science I thoroughly recommend Professor Lindley.  He is well-known as a tough grader, but he was very flexible when I needed an extension.

I've had two classes with him.  His courses are very enjoyable but the work is hard and frequent (compared to other POLS).  His classes are definitely not easy As, but if you're serious about studying political science then I strongly recommend him.  His classes are often geared towards in-class discussion/debate.  His papers are tough.

He is great. I had him for my first module for Bio Big Questions and he is very passionate about the topics. All of the quizzes, assignments, and exams are fair and everything on them is directly covered in class.

The TA's were the only reason I passed! The quizzes covered material that were grazed over lightly in class, so if you weren't paying close attention, you could miss it. Taking notes is crucial, but rewatching the lectures would probably be better. Be sure to go to the TA office hours and ask tons of questions, they are more than willing to help!
Very accessible module. Lecture recordings and slides were available online. Not very difficult conceptually but there were a lot of topics so it was fast paced

Dr. Medvigy is clearly passionate and very caring. I ended up liking the class way more than I thought I would. The class is deceivingly difficult, though, with the grading being somewhat tough. Still, most people did well in the class. The content was way cooler than expected, and his lectures were really interesting.

Majority of the quizzes are based off of topics briefly mentioned in class, so be sure to pay attention there. The material isn't necessarily difficult, but you will need to rewatch lectures occasionally to catch what he says.

If you want to do well, shortly go to lecture is the simple statement. 
Make sure you pay attention especially to the TA's who are so helpful. 
He records lectures so you can go back to them because his slides are not helpful.
The class was also hard with no textbook.
He is very passionate about trees but is not easy A people make this module seem.
Nice guy, really interested about what he teaches. Quizzes and exams follow the lectures very well.

Great guy who's passionate about the material, but grades in this class are brutal. I feel as if he can't figure out how hard he wants the class to be because quizzes were particularly hard but the final and project were relatively rather easy. Don't hang onto reviews too much because Medvigy's class changes every semester as far as I can tell.

I thought he was a good lecturer and clearly passionate about the subject, if a bit awkward. The quizzes are not always easy, so make sure to study and take notes/find people to study with. Overall, definitely would recommend.

He is very knowledgeable and interested in what he studies. However, he can sometimes use jargon or not explain topics that beginner level students may not know. He provides clear PowerPoint notes and the homework assignments are straightforward. His quizzes are tough because you only get 16 minutes, but the questions were fair if you study.

Medvigy is definitely not a very exciting professor. He is often monotonous and reads off his slides. The quizzes and concept checks are short and easy, but you only 16mins for a quiz. His final is pretty tough, so be sure to study more than you think you need to.

Module isn't hard, just uninteresting. If you love trees, graphs, and carbon, this is the module for you. This is a lecture-heavy class. Write down every single word that comes out of his mouth because it could come up on a quiz/test. Every lecture is recorded and uploaded online. Encourages lots of questions and is passionate about this subject.

Dr. Medvigy's module is great!! Little homework and readings, only quick concept checks after class. Go to lectures and take notes and you'll be fine. Dr. Medvigy is so caring and really emphasizes in-class discussion. Quizzes are open-note and not too hard.

The course is by modules but the tests seem easier than others I've taken. He is a fantastic lecturer who is extremely knowledgeable in the subject and is very clearly excited about teaching well and effectively with real world examples. If given the opportunity, definitely take him!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: The nicest professor ever. Very little homework and reading. The most important information, usually on tests, was from the lectures and the questions he would propose to the class. The material wasn't hard and I felt well prepared for the exam.

Professor Medvigy is a real gem and truly cares about student success. This biology course is split into two separate modules in which you will be taught two separate topics in biology  Medvigy was my second part of the course. He is very lecture heavy, but makes an attempt to make the class interactive. I would recommend medvigy to any freshman.

The concepts given in class were so easy and straightforward. However, if you slightly worded things wrong on your quizzes, the TA's were very unforgiving with partial credit. His lectures were very good but the TA's were the worst. I wouldn't recommend this course if you dont want to be disappointed

Interesting and chill class that it would be a great idea to rank high on your module preference. Lectures are straightforward and as long as you pay attention in class and participate in the group discussions, then you'll be fine on the quizzes and the final. This man loves talking about trees, so don't be afraid to ask any questions. Great class!

Prof Medvigy is quite knowledgeable about what he teaches, yet is accessible and treats students as if their thoughts and ideas matter too rather than teaching down to students like many other professors do. This guy is actively involved in high profile research about what he teaches about, and his passion is quite evident. Def would recommend!

While I didn't particularly enjoy the topic of his class, I do have appreciation for how he taught it. Even though it was online, he tried to keep it interactive and engaging for the students. You can also tell that he is very passionate about his work and his field, which can rub off on students.

I wanted to write this because many of the reviews say that she's "utterly insane." Which, is not all wrong, but she is a very caring human being. She only wants the best and wants students to leave the class with an open-mind. She's not trying to change your perspective, rather, she wants us to feel comfortable expressing our view on the subject.
she is incredible. She is so wholesome.

Contrary to a lot of people on this page, there never existed a more caring Professor at Notre Dame. She truly cares about each person in her class. Sure, she can be disorganized but there is passion in the way she speaks about the topic, to which she is an expert. Would without a doubt recommend EVERYONE take a class with her at some point 100/10

Bederman undoubtedly and truly cared about her students and acted as a great out of classroom resource. I felt comfortable in her classroom and the environment was unbeatable. She created such a nurturing and cozy class that stimulated great peer interaction and led to friendships and connections both with her and with those around me. Recommend.

Disorganized, disorganized, disorganized, and really just seemed to wield the stereotypically pseudoscientific views Gender Studies has sadly become known for. A lot of throwaway racial/gender generalizations against the groups that are legal/fashionable to criticize. I felt like the only person taking the class seriously was the instructor.

I took CSEM on Sexualities and Moralities. She is a nice and caring person but teaching isn't her forte. Classes were disorganized, she often rambled on, and left the room as she interrupted our discussions often. That being said, it's an easy A with few assignments, but I didn't learn much from her.

She is the best professor I've ever had. She really wants to help you learn the material, and is incredibly accommodating and caring. If you put even a little effort into her classes you'll get an A, but it certainly won't be a throwaway class.

Absolutely terrible professor, opinionated nothing she says is rooted in fact. Lets her personal emotions get in the way in how she grades. Do yourself a favor and avoid this dumpster fire at all cost.

Bederman is horrible. She doesn't make clear her expectations and then faults you for not meeting them. She'll shred your paper if she doesn't like your writing style and doesn't offer helpful tips to improve. Avoid at all costs.

Prof. Bederman was one of my all time favorites. She is very knowledgable and interesting to listen to. She can be a little disorganized sometimes, but that usually resulted in classes that were more enjoyable.There is a lot of reading, but it was ok to fall a little behind and easy to catch up. She is also very approachable and understanding.

Yes, Prof Biederman is kookie and just a little more than slightly crazy, but she is also an amazing profesor.  She cares about every one of her students and her knowledge of the subjects is unbeatable.  She does expect you to work though and that may turn some off.  If you want a great prof who is not afraid to speak her mind, she is the one.

Contrary to many remarks made on this page, I must say that I found Professor Bederman's class to be interesting and worthwhile.  Not only can Gail lecture to and hold the attention of any student who has the genuine desire to seek an education, but she ca
Make sure to bring a crossword puzzle to class. It will help pass the time during Bederman's lectures.
Bederman gave up any pretense of teaching years ago. When she isn't lecturing to hear herself speak, she'll use class time as an opportunity to indoctrinate her students to her radical ideology.
No Comments

Prof. Hungerman is a great guy. Lectures are hilarious and he seems to really care about his students. Absolutely necessary to write down everything during lectures, but exams are extremely hard and not similar to notes at all. His exams are the hardest I've taken in college. Trust in the curve though, you will be saved.

Hungerman is an incredible professor. Lecture heavy, but he makes it entertaining, interesting, and funny. Class is test heavy, and those tests can be difficult, but they usually have surprisingly generous curves. (80% of the class tends to get a B or higher). Office hours are helpful and he genuinely cares about his students.

Hard lecture if you don't have previous knowledge of Microeconomcis. Heavy lectures you mostly look at a new topic each lecture and sometimes you will learn about 2 or 3. In comparison to other professors, this one is very fast-paced and you'll find yourself being more advance than people in other classes.

Professor Hungerman is a really goofy guy, who always manages to tie jokes into Economics. However, he does give out few homework problems, expecting you to go the extra mile to twist the problems in preparation for the exams, which are much harder than the practice problems.

Little homework. The few out of class assignments are graded for completion. There are 3 tests, the 3rd being a final. The tests are difficult compared to other Econ classes, but he curves them a decent amount. His lectures are funny at times, but there wasn't much work to help learn the material, and test problems were harder than practice ones.
rating_tags: Hilarious--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Tests are tough

comment: Yeah he's a pretty funny guy. Kinda of a goof. As someone else mentioned, each class usually starts off easy and then gets hard towards the end. Not much homework at all, and the tests are easy as long as you study three nights in advance (as you should for every college exam)
I honestly hated Econ as a subject, but he made it so fun and enjoyable I almost forgot how much I hated it, until I started studying for the tests....

Dan the Man! Excellent professor, excellent guy. Keeps his lectures interesting and when possible funny. Very approachable and nice to chat with. He knows his stuff and keeps the workload very low. His class starts off very easy, but gets a little complicated towards the end. His final is  just a third midterm (which is by far the hardest.
Dan is the man. Good lectures and curves the test. What more can you ask for?
Overall not a bad teacher, but if you're new to economics it might be a bit difficult to understand. Pretty easy-going guy, but you won't get to know him in a large lecture.
Had to buy book but did not need it for assignments. Felt unprepared for tests.
This guy is a boss! Excellent teacher, minimal homework, makes understanding easy.
He is a great professor. He makes the fun  incredibly interesting and explains things in a very clear manner.
Recommended!
Dan Hungerman is the man!
