I registered for this required Theo because it fit my schedule. I was surprised to discover how much I enjoyed it. If you just want to skim readings, you'll probably still get a good grade. But by trial and error I discovered I only got a lot from the lectures when I did the readings slower and took notes. So don't take if you don't want to read.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Glibetic is a super engaging and helpful professor. This was a super interesting second theology and she cares a lot about her students. Definitely is a tougher grader, but manageable if you listen and understand expectations. Readings were long and mandatory because she would randomly give reading quizzes at the start of class.

Slightly more reading that I was expecting for a required intro to Theology, but I understand she was really trying to push us to higher standards, which I appreciated. I really liked the lectures and the material. Overall, a great class.

I really enjoyed this class. If you are taking this for your second Theology requirement, just know that it is very focused on topic of women/gender in Church, so if you are interested in that like I was, you'll get a lot out of it.

Prof Glibetic challenges you to think critically. More than just learning the subject material, which I found very interesting, I felt like she was also teaching us a different, deeper and more thoughtful way to approach history and faith. I never thought I would consider a theology major, but now I am.

Arguably the most frustrating class I have ever sat through. I rate it a difficulty of 5 because of how impossible it was to stay interested in the course and how much I dreaded having to slowly rot away in my seat every class. Shockingly boring and the grading was unnecessarily rough for how little effort was put into the class by the professor.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: There is a bit more reading compared to some of the other classes, but it was interesting and Professor Glibetic challenges you to think differently about a lot of different topics. I like how she tried to be balanced and encouraged people with different views to express themselves.

Apart from the reviews here, I haven't met anyone who didn't rank this as one of their least favorite classes. Format for the midterm and final is wildly subjective, readings for the class are incredibly dry, and her lectures make 75 minutes feel like 6 hours. I struggle to find any reason you'd take this class if you had literally any other option

Extremely knowledgeable and open to any kind of discussion. Great professor for those new to religion. Attendance and participation are mandatory, and receiving an A is no easy feat. Not many assignments, but expectations are high and grading is relatively fair. Weekly reading with occasional reading quizzes which are pretty easy. Good first theo.

One of the best professors for first Theo. Reading before each class, but it is much less than others. No homework outside of one group project. Very knowledgable and a great communicator regardless of prior experience with religion. Attendance and participation are MANDATORY. One excused absence and then you go down letter grades.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Readings every day and occasional (random) reading quizzes. Class is great and really interesting. Participation matters! Manageable workload; midterm exam was 2 (long) essay questions. Kinda tough grader, but not too bad. Gives really good lectures and encourages students. Also encourages attending outside lectures for extra credit.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Amazing lectures

comment: I would definitely recommend Prof. Glibetic for the first Theo requirement. Compared to the other Theo 1 classes this one had the least amount of work. There are a decent amount of readings each week and occasional quizzes on them. There is an easy final and a longer final paper but that's about it.

She was very respectful of everyone's views, and although I had her for an online course, I did not feel like I knew her less than one normally would know their professor. Very personable, caring, and passionate about subject matter.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: She was a fantastic Professor, made me want to pursue a Theo minor. You have Bible readings for each class but that's really the extent of the work. Two easy quizzes, one exam, and one take home final.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: I had Foundations: Bibl & Hist. of Theology with Prof. Glibetic for her 1st semester teaching at ND. She is incredible. Very knowledgeable, respectful of differing views and encouraged a lot of classroom participation. This was my favorite class all semester and it's only a university requirement for me. Highly highly recommend!!

Great guy, very passionate and excited about the subject. Lectures are interesting and slides are posted. Reviews are posted before exams. Grading is mostly the three exams with some points from homework assignments and participation-graded quizzes. An hour of homework every other week.

I loved this class. I hadn't taken a stats class in high school, so I was really concerned, but this class was great. The weekly tutorials are also really helpful for clearing up any doubts. The problem sets were long, and a lecture definitely put me to sleep at some point, but overall, the class and the professor weren't as scary as they seemed.

Professor Dunne is really smart and a super nice guy. The course material is difficult to make interesting so I don't blame him for often dry lectures, though he definitely strives to be engaging. He explains the material very well and makes it very understandable. Homeworks are manageable and beneficial for grasping the material.
Really interesting guy who is clearly passionate about the subject. The class isn't too hard and grading is extremely generous.

I really liked Professor Dunne because he was always very clear about the material. However, I often felt that going to lectures and tutorials was not super useful because all of the slides are posted, which helps make revising for exams easy. Exams can be somewhat tricky with the MC and T/F, but the other portions are pretty straightforward.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy

comment: While the lectures for Macro are a bit dry, the content is all in the lectures and textbook. He is easy to understand and makes his points clear. Definitely read the book because he pulls questions from there that don't come up in lectures. Homeworks aren't bad and he answers questions on them.

One of the best professors I've had here. Very accessible lectures that are very specific and clean. He gives great examples, the homeworks are very fair and based on the lectures, and he is a really nice guy.

He is very comprehensive in his lectures, makes sure that his students understand what the material is. Tests can be a little tricky with some true and false questions, but they aren't too hard. Weekly homework is straightforward and tutorial exercises are easy as long as you show up to the Friday session. Super nice guy and seems to enjoy class.

He's a nice enough guy, but I didn't learn that much from the lectures - I mostly relied on the textbook. The homework is short and good practice. The tutorials are the worst, very hard to understand, and TAs are useless - not his fault but doesn't help.

His lectures and slides are very boring. Black text on a white background. Bullet points with sentences. He talks, you listen. Problem sets are not bad but they take some time and effort. You learn a lot if you can force yourself to stay engaged in lectures, which is not always easy.

Professor Dunne is an excellent professor. Very clear lectures and assignments, and he leaves nothing to the imagination regarding what he expects from you in the course. He really cares a lot for his students and is willing to go the extra mile to ensure their success.

Dunne is great if you already know the course material. However, I did not have any experience with the material before the class, and he looked down on me the entire semester. I went into his office hours asking for help on specific questions and he just said "do the readings." Incredibly disrespectful to me; treated me as if I was an infant.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Professor Dunne is a great guy who really cares about helping everyone out. I've now had him for two classes and he's known my name since the first week or so of the first class. His classes are definitely lecture heavy but he talks with enthusiasm and clear knowledge of the subject so it is rarely boring. I'd definitely recommend him!

Dunne was a good professor. I think he relied too heavily on the supplemental book required. But he explained the concepts very well. Sometimes he can be funny here and there in class, but generally he's mainly interested in the stock market & the likes. He's incredibly smart and can't wait to retire :) I recommend taking him if you have the choice
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: I like Prof. Dunne so far. He has a lot of office hours so if you need help, hes accessible. He is also a very personable teacher and tries to learn the srudents names which I always appreciate. The homework and tests are very manageable. Prof. Dunne does a good job of communicating the material and is very good at answering questions.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: This class was the reason I got an A overall in Bio. Hope Hollocher gives a bunch of assignments, like the concept check may take an hour, but if you are serious about learning and take it serious, there's no reason why an A isn't possible. Also extra credit is always possible, she can be a little snippy though, but still overall great!
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: She is very passionate about what she teachings and the content is lowkey easy but interesting! She just can be super passive aggressive at times but her intentions are very sweet. Quizzes are SO specific and based on concept checks/math, study those. You won't get a bug curve so be sure to study for the quizzes. Final was okay.

She goes through a lot of content very quickly and it can be very confusing and dense material. It is clear she knows what she is teaching really well which can make it difficult for others to follow what she is saying because she goes so quickly. Overall she is a nice lady.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Based on reviews I was expecting the worst, however, she was very kind. Her lectures were recorded and if you rewatch them you will do well on the tests. She provides good materials to study for tests (vocab and sample questions) if you study you should succeed. Overall, I enjoyed this module and would recommend it to anyone!
Not hard if you rewatch lectures and go to study sessions.
I thought she did a good job teaching the material. Clearly cares about material and students. Would recommend. You will need to study a lot for her quizzes, though

This woman is one of the rudest and most condescending professors I have ever had. She teaches as if she is reading off of a script, which is the case for the majority of the time. She doesn't take questions during lectures, and she just seems like she would rather do anything else but teach.

This woman is one of the rudest and most condescending professors I have ever had. She teaches as if she is reading off of a script, which is the case for the majority of the time. She doesn't take questions during lectures, and she just seems like she would rather do anything else but teach. I pray for whoever will be taking her module next year.

I was very disappointed in this module.  The content is very evolution heavy and more philosophical than biological, the homework is a big time sink (1-2 hours per concept check), and the TA review sessions are the only source of my success.  I was not the biggest fan of Professor Hollocher; she can be moody, rude, and condescending to her TAs.

I took this module for intro bio and didn't enjoy it. Very uninteresting lectures that don't really get to the point. Very vague and unclear about content that you're supposed to know for the quizzes. Also sometimes rude when asked question

Unfortunately, I was disappointed in the genetics module with her. Her lectures can be mundane, but they are also fast-moving. Something she says in 5 seconds might be on the next quiz. Because the course is out of 100 points, every test question or point you miss is a percentage off your overall grade. Dr. Hollocher is caring but sometimes rude.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She's is incredibly smart and passionate about what she teaches, but her lectures can be dense, verbose, and fast-moving; tests aren't usually a great assessment of what is taught during the lectures, but the concept checks and TA review sessions are helpful. She's generally pretty approachable but changes moods suddenly. Fine module overall.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: I really liked professor Hollocher as a person, but her lectures were just reading off of a powerpoint. She wouldn't finish the content and then assign two 30 minute videos to finish independently. She does underestimate the amount of time her assignments take, and some took me 3 hours. The TA does all of the grading, so go to his review sessions.

Professor Hollocher is kind of hit or miss. Some days she can be nice and easygoing, but more often than not she is slightly condescending. The concept checks take 1hr+ and the quizzes are not accurate assessments of material. Get ready to spend way too much time doing assignments and stressing over even little stuff.

Homework is absurdly long and worth little credit. Lectures were either reading off PowerPoint slides or discussing the homework questions. Quizzes were not reflective of the content learned. Too much class material and oftentimes had to finish lectures outside of class. However, some material was fairly interesting. Hope for a good TA.

Population genetics was a great course and Hope made it so. She strongly encourages participation and will call you out if you are not. She gives good feedback and cares about each of her students and wants to see you succeed. She demands a fair amount of work, but if you do it the 'A' is easily achievable.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Great professor. Not much homework. Exams are not easy but they are easy to study for.

Great professor, and such a nice guy! My favorite professor I've ever had. It was difficult to see where you stood at times in the class because he often doesn't enter grades but it's not difficult to get an A. I would recommend.

Keith is a great professor and a great introduction to upper level spanish courses.  Because the class if normally smaller, he loves to meet with each student outside of class and get to know the student as they continue their journey in the spanish curriculum. He was especially helpful with abroad applications and class selection.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Schaefer is INCREDIBLE if you want to become much better at speaking Spanish. He can grade hard and pushes his students to truly apply themselves and learn to speak well, but his class is an incredible stepping stone to becoming fluent or even more confident in speaking and evolving your Spanish vocab. A genuinely nice guy who cares about us.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: He is passionate about what he teaches and makes learning fun. He is not fast at returning graded work and we didn't get our second midterm back before our final which was stressful. It's more of memorization for exams and confusing when you do not know what your up-to-date grade is except for one or two times in the semester.
had no idea what i had in this class ever
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: nice guy but always falling behind
rating_tags: Hilarious--Beware of pop quizzes--So many papers

comment: Never followed rubric. Always lost on what he expected from students
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: You're going to like him as a person but detest him as a professor. I never knew where I stood in that class and despite assuring us that we would have feedback prior to the next big assignment, it was either never given or just given a few hours before. Basically set up to do worst than your actual best ability. Definitely not worth the stress.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Schaefer really cares about his students. The readings aren't always easy, but the discussions in class helped me to understand the material. Study groups are helpful for tests. Would recommend going to his office hours. He is slow to return grades, but I enjoyed his class otherwise.

An awesome professor. He made the classes really interesting and cared about his students. While slow to return grades, he gave lots of opportunities to get points back and do well in the course. He was very passionate about Spanish and wants everyone to enjoy it too.

Professor Schaefer is genuinely a really good guy- he cares a lot. Participation is super important to him but class is pretty laid back and he does a great job at engaging the class. I found the exams manageable bc he gives you a study guide that is basically identical to the actual test. It is annoying how long he takes to return grades though.

Lots of reading/homework.  Difficult exams. He's funny and passionate about teaching. Class is casual and fun. You will learn a lot.

He takes weeks/months to give back grades, which was very frustrating. I never knew what my grade was until end of semester.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes--Accessible outside class

comment: In class Professor Schaefer is a great person, honestly, he cares deeply about his students and is always available outside of class. However, he is slow to give back grades and his tests are often quite difficult to do even after days of studying. He is also a very tough grader and is very strict on how he takes participation.
Very interesting class, learned a lot!

This class was the best class I took at Notre Dame in relation to how much I use the information taught in my job after school. Viva is an amazing professor especially if you take the time to get to know her. Don't take this class if you are looking for an easy credit - you will work hard but it pays off.
Far and away the most valuable of all my classes.  I regularly use the framework for problem solving and it has made me a better employee and manager.

Viva is absolutely a star. Took the course as an elective in the EMBA program; wish I'd had a chance to take it in its more-intensive iteration through the regular MBA program. Absolutely, unquestionably, and unequivocally brilliant, and equally genuine. If you're not up to the challenge of staying with her, you should either shut up or stay home.

The worst teacher I had in all of business school, by far.  I felt like she was trying to prove that she was smarter than the class, which she obviously was because she was the professor.  And I felt like she was in competition with us; trying to show she was better than us.  Bottom line is she's weird and she wears beige clothes every day.
One of the best professors I ever had!!! Not only a professor butshe could also be a great friend and mentor in life!
My favorite instructor in all of business school.
Brilliant professor who challenges you to learn more but is there every step of the way to offer guidance and advice!
Prof was super demanding but was the best prof I have ever had.  Also, the most approachable  prof I have ever had.  Real world expertise finally used in class.
Interesting class.  Teacher is demanding, but the covered material is self-serving.
Problem solving is a true beast of a class. But mandatory. 90% of it is just surviving until mod 2.
No Comments
No Comments

Her lectures are almost impossible to follow and she does not explain things well. If I hadn't taken calc in high school I would have failed. Seems kind but doesn't bother to learn student's names in a small classroom setting. Find another calc prof, trust me...or be lost and bored in Hayes Healy for your afternoons.

I did not like her lectures; I just stopped going. She's always in her world and often starts talking about things that I genuinely have no clue what she means. She cares for her students, is accessible outside class, and is happy to help. However, the lectures weren't good if you're like me and would like to reach out.

Pilkington is a cool teacher, and she obviously wants her students to succeed, but she is so hard to understand compared to her TA's. I had her in a flipped classroom, and it was such an insane amount of work. She is a nice person to have as a teacher, though, and the TA's are nice.
Had her for calc 1 and genuinely she was just always in her own little world.

Professor Pilkington was pretty good at teaching. Sometimes she did not get to as many examples in class and instead lectured about the concepts which is not as helpful. Half of the tests are multiple-choice, each question worth 7 pts each with no partial credit, which is difficult. If you need help, Greg Macklem's tutoring hours are super helpful.

Dr. Pilkington's lectures are boring, but her occasional dry humor makes them better. She is okay at explaining concepts, but if you took AP calc in high school you'll be fine. The exams are harder than AP calc tests, but exam questions are predictable, so take the time to study and you'll be fine in this class with whatever professor.

I loved her as a person, but really did not like her as a professor. She was really funny. Did a bad job of explaining things and didn't really check to see if students were understanding. Took her flipped classroom in the spring for MATH 10560, and it was great - I would highly recommend the flipped classroom (more work, but much better).
She has very bad comedic timing but knows what she is talking about
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: I had Pilkington for Calc I. Lectures are not the best and she often runs out of time to go through examples, however, I recommend attending her office hours and the math help hours with a Grad student. Content is similar to AP AB Calc. Homework is manageable and there are practice tests for each exam. Definitely use online videos for extra help.
She is honestly amazing. Her lectures are extremely helpful and she does an amazing job at breaking down points as well as making it interesting. It is clear that she loves her job! :)

Never met the professor once. The class was taught by a TA that didn't really know what he was doing. The lessons were all over the place and poorly explained. Learned most of the class on Khan Academy rather than from the class itself. They make assumptions that everyone took Calc 1 in High School so they skip/brush over a lot of topics.

I absolutely love her! One of the best math teachers I've ever had. She explains the concepts very well and provides so many resources for extra help outside of class. On top of that she is hilarious and somehow makes calc class not the most boring thing ever. I would definitely recommend!

Does not explain lessons well, homework due at 2 am, does not answer questions efficiently, 0/10 would not recommend, told a student when they dropped the class "I wouldn't even take this class if I were a student. Don't even bother retaking the class. You're better off taking stats". Overall, I very much dislike this class.

Professor Pilkington is an Amazing person, but a bad professor. Descriptions of topics are not clear at all and will leave you confused. Review for exams in this class is old and irrelevant and won't help you on exam. Moves very fast and gets distracted. Most TA's for this class are even confused when trying to receive help. Would never recommend.

Do not listen to the sweats reviewing Stevens. Easiest class offered at Notre Dame, great guy, low stress. Put in almost zero effort and ended with a 99%. Is the content useless? Yes. But it's a free A and he's a terrific resource to have outside of the classroom and in life.

If a dean were to audit this class, they'd be appalled. Lectures are laughably low effort/nebulous and 75% of them are Ted Talks or "inspirational" videos. It's all empty lists and quotes from grifters to memorize. Stevens blatantly lied to us about the format of the final exam. Hard to have a less educational experience in a class. What a joke.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Test heavy

comment: He is great if you want a class that is basically all video lectures and barely any talking with mandatory attendance. The material is extremely unhelpful and the homework are virtually useless. He has some extremly interesting takes but  could with clarity in structure and material. Talks a little too much about sports

He knows everyone's name on the first day of class. He is trying to squeeze his previous semester into a half-semester class, so everyone is on their grind from day one. He assigns a ton of homework. The grade is purely based on how you do on pop quizzes and tests, which are only memorization. You memorize Ted Talks, the textbook, and slides.
rating_tags: Inspirational--Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: The entirety of this class is about how well you retain information from Ted talks. Professor Stevens is an accomplished business professor who is not afraid to tell you all about it but only spends about a quarter or less of the class speaking. Ted talks are legitimately everything. Memorize all of the slides for a good grade on the final.

Professor Stevens is a really inspirational guy. Take notes on the Ted Talks for homework as there was only one pop quiz in my class, so doing poorly on that would hurt your grade. The exam is all memorization on minute details from Ted Talks, the book, and guest speakers, so study hard (acronyms, quizlet, etc.). He is generous with partial credit.

This is not a good class. Graded by so few things everyone goes into final with a high grade. Final is on ridiculous Ted talks and asks for specific quotes from these assigned videos and from the text book. Final is heinous. Simon Sinek is the main man in this class and he is a tool.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things

comment: He is way overhyped and the grading stinks. If you're not in the tip top of the class, you won't do well. I missed one pop quiz question and dropped my grade from an A to a B+. I wrote a very good and creative final exam, and yet still couldn't bring my grade up. It seemed fun at first. Looking back, I would've taken someone else 100%.

The class is ridiculously difficult for no reason. He forces students to watch hours of speeches on youtube then creates exam questions about tiny details from them. He has unreasonable expectations and the content from his class serves no purpose outside of his exams. He should be teachings actual management concepts, rather than cliche lessons.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Stevens is an outstanding professor. Class is TedTalk heavy, and although attendance isn't mandatory you'll see pop quizzes fairly often. Presents management in an engaging way that doesn't necessarily rely on the textbook, but tests are mainly memorization and are pretty brutal. However, he makes a genuine effort to get to know the whole class.
rating_tags: Inspirational--Graded by few things--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Prof Stevens is one of my favorite professors. He posses confidence and gives insightful, inspirational lectures. In class, students listen to TED talks teaching life lessons. For homework, students provide book and chapter summaries. Additionally, on the last day of class, students participate in a talent show for extra participation points.

Calling Mr. Stevens a professor would be an inaccurate start to this review because calling someone a professor implies that you learned something from them in the first place. While he tries to be friendly, he is beyond condescending and self-congratulatory. His exams are useless memorization tests and he doesn't teach anything, just shows videos.

Stevens was not my favorite professor. While he tries to show that he cares for his students, he also is very narcissistic. His personality rubbed me the wrong way, but I appreciated his effort. The tests are based off of TED Talks and arbitrary aphorisms, and they are all short answer questions (even though he claims they're multiple choice).
rating_tags: Participation matters--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: Chris Stevens' class is honestly a once in a lifetime opportunity. You don't just learn about management, wow that's only the beginning. You learn so much more. He sets an example that I think we all can aspire to achieve.

Without a doubt the best professor I have ever had at Notre Dame. Every day I was looking forward to coming to his class. On the first day of class he memorized our entire class' names. Our class was over a hundred people.

Olsen is a great guy and good professor. Bio lab is super easy class, but Olsen's pre-lab lectures, though, are super unclear and long compared to the other options. Anyway, graduate student TAs basically direct the lab, so if you have a good TA the lab experience will be great. Assignments aren't hard and lab activities are interesting and fun.
Drones on and on in pre lab lectures. Wayyy more lecture heavy than any lab should be, and does not relate to what is learned in lecture at all.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Very dry lectures (with occasional cold calling) before labs begin.  Does not do any of the grading, that's all TAs.  Offers a helpful hands-on review session before the practical assessment at the end of the semester.

Professor Olsen, although tends to have dry conversation, is a good professor who is truly interested in the material being taught in class. Outside of the daily 20-30 minute "chalk talk" that he provides, you really only work with your TAs. This lab is pretty easy and the material is very straight forward. Would recommend if interested in ecology
He is not even as bad as the other reviews make him out to be. He just talks a lot but overall he's a pretty decent guy and the labs weren't even hard
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: He is so boring and in lab his talks always take so long. My friends with other lab professors say their talks only take 15 min, while his take 30 min to an hour. Lab is easy but he doesn't grade the work, the TA does.

He is a good professor. His lectures are dry, but contain important information. He is a harsh grader when it comes to research papers. However, he does not like to answer emails about questions and only want the TAs to answer questions. He assumes everyone has the ability to use EXCEL.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: a bit dry

This class may be only one credit, but its so much work. The prelab quizzes and lab tests are the most specific test you will ever take, so studying is almost pointless. What is on the test is the most useless information and he teaches data tech. that is so out of date. His lectures are very boring so that the whole class is asleep by the end.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--SO MANY PAPERS

comment: This class requires you to do the most work for a one credit class. The pre-lab quizzes are terribly specific, so much so that reading the pre lab manual three times won't get you a passing grade on the quizzes. But the worst is the lab tests. They cover topics you barely went over or topics that he addressed in such a boring and mundane manner.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--LOTS OF HOMEWORK--Tests are tough

comment: Very difficult class, no question. Must work very very hard. Dr. Olsen is a great professor though, so smart and really cares about his students if you take the time to get to know him. That said, if you ignore him and just show up, expect this class to be very slow and tedious. It's a very tough class, but so is almost every science class here...
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: pre lab quizzes easy if u read. huge lab papers v hard. His lecture parts during lab are so so so slow but the practical is impossibly hard and you are never prepared for it enough. labs not hard, but the assignments are graded very very specifically. seriuoosly, 1st sem was easy but 2nd sem hits you hard. papers due @ bad times ie orgo test days

Get ready for the most miserable 1-credit class you'll have to take! Olsen assigns WAY more stuff to do than most of my 3-credit classes, and his grading is relentless. If you're going the bio route, you really have no choice but to get through Olsen. His lectures could put a meth-head to sleep, and it's always hard to figure out what we have to do

One of the most mundane, unhelpful, and large-egoed professors you'll ever have.  Sadly for all freshman Bio majors, there is no way to avoid this prof.  He tests you on material you barely, if at all, covered in class, and the only thing that makes his class bearable is that he doesn't teach most of it.  But when he does, you'll probably be asleep

Dr. Dye is extremely self absorbed and completely absent from the band program at Notre Dame. He preaches diversity/equity in public yet fails to ever put them into action. While a good arranger, he is not strong in any other musical category. He literally could not care less about his students or his staff. The Notre Dame band DESERVES better!!!

He sucks the life out of marching band. Not supportive of students in their struggles at all. Seems to find joy in delivering bad news and never explains the news. Believes negative rhetoric against students to form his opinion of them and doesn't ever give students the benefit of the doubt. Will almost never have your back. Barely ever present.

He is an entirely unreasonable human being. Do not expect sympathy, support, or accomodations for any of your own struggles and you can almost surely count on a two-faced rhetoric when it comes to how he treats others.
Awesome director- just like the others
Ken Dye does not understand that he is only the custodian of the ND band. He does not get that it is something larger than himself. Changes he has made are questionable at best

Dr. Dye has proven that his interests are broad in scope.  He is a musical genius, but also has an interest in young people.  He is involved in helping to change the lives of young people through music and community.  He is active in the mission of The Kroc Center and used this passion to help me complete my Masters Project for ONU.
He once showed the class a video on cancer survivors.  He then promptly compared their heroism to that of the hockey team.  He's a waste.

Yes, Dr. Dye has taken the Band of the Fighting Irish and turned it into one of the best in the country. But he has also destroyed all of the fun and interest in the band and the moral and interest in the band has dropped all b/c of him.  Technicality and perfect music are not the most important things - interest, fun and desire are as important.
Dr. Dye has made the Band of the Fighting Irish one of the best bands in the country.
So?  He's awesome.
The proof is in the product.  His bands are phenomenal.
thinks being a musical genius excuses him from having the worst social skills on the planet.  Some band students disagree.
No Comments
He is arrogant, self absorbed, and basically has no life other than the ND Band
Philosophy of religion with Dr Rettler is the best philosophy class I've taken at Baylor. He was very fair to both sides of all the issues, and he seemed like he had a lot of fun arguing with us.
He's super fun and very flexible. Class is discussion-based, and you get to pick a lot of the topics.

Make sure that you do everything according to the syllabus. Do not sit in the back of class. If he says something in the syllabus, he means it. Do not use a computer in this class. He will assume you are surfing the web. Go with his opinion on everything. The teacher is always right in this class. Show strong effort on papers and you will do well.

Discussions were really thought provoking and he did a good job of leading them, teaching the class how to argue and keeping it interesting. Also very helpful with everything. Not a big workload. Definitely take this class
He set up a great class and ran it well. Promoted good discussion and encouraged students to express their opinions in well formulated papers. Great 2nd philo. Highly suggested.
Definitely the best second philo you can take. The topic changes every week, and he does a great job of leading an interesting discussion.

It is a little difficult to understand what he wants at first as far as papers go, but if you go into his office hours and talk about it he makes it pretty straightforward.  Also what we do in class is pretty consistent with how our papers should be structured.

The most effective aspect of Dr. Rettler's teaching is his ability to stimulate, moderate, and guide discussion.  As a result, while I don't always leave a class with a new opinion on the topic being discussed, I always have a new way of looking at the issue. He's also really interested in his students opinions and considers them thoroughly.
I really enjoy this class.  There is not too much work, and the class discussions have really helped my form solid opinions on some issues that are relevant.  Professor is very helpful and fair.

He is an extremely good guy. Very accessible to students via email or office hours. He grades fairly and is careful to represent all sides of an argument. The class served its purpose as a philo course, which is to consistently challenge a student's beliefs about current moral issues and teach the proper way to construct and defend an argument.

This was a wonderful class. It definitely made me think about my opinions on hot-topic issues and be able to justify them. There's no textbook for this class, only online readings or videos. Workload is fairly light. Class discussions are in depth, and he does a great job of addressing all sides of an issue. 10/10 would take again.
Very insightful. Develops sound arguments and allows for class participation. Great professor for second philo. Good reviews on papers. Gives perfect amount of homework. Keeps class interested.

This class was great as a 2nd Philo. Only 5 or 6 short 1 page critical reports. Pretty simple, he makes it clear what he wants. One essay and hes very helpful if you go in office hours. Rettler is a great guy, super nice. He is open about his opinions but definitely NOT judgmental at all. Grading is very fair. He lets conversation flow organically.
He is very opinionated and very intolerant of others' opinions. Not helpful comments on papers and not clear. Marked down for having opinions other than his.

I was unsure about this class initially but ended up loving it. Professor Boyd is very knowledgeable about neuroscience. Her class was easy to digest and she gave good examples. Exams are application-based, so go to class and spend time reading the textbook. TA review sessions were also helpful.

At the beginning of the course, I really disliked the class. However as the semester continued, I ended up loving the class and enjoyed Dr. Boyd. While sometimes she is confusing, she gives very interesting examples, case studies, and videos to help keep the lectures engaging. The exams were difficult but very laid out what would be on them.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria

comment: Dr Boyd is one of the best professors I have had. She's the perfect person to teach intro neuro. The content is challenging, but she is a great lecturer and explains concepts clearly. As long as you read and come to lecture, you'll be fine on exams. Practice exams are similar to the real exams. Homework is easy and weighted highly, which is nice.

I had Dr. Boyd for intro neuro, and she was awesome! It was a flipped classroom environment, but that allowed us to ask ample questions during class and watch the lectures on our own time. Some people might not like that, but I did. The tests are not tough- just do the homework and go through the quiz bank questions. Really great introductory class
Boyd was very knowledgable and took time to explain difficult concepts. Her tests were pretty tough though and she threw a lot of information at you at once

Dr. Boyd was one of the most amazing professors that I have ever had, the class was extremely challenging but it is well worth it.  She was very, very helpful and this class seriously prepares you for med school.

Dr. Boyd's the best instructor in ND's biology department, bar none.  Physiology isn't supposed to be easy -- most of you are applying to med school for chrissake.  She does a great job breaking down difficult topics and keeps the lecture interesting.
I really liked Dr. Boyd. She covers a vast amount of material but she does it in a clear and efficient manner.
The woman is a tank.  Holy cow.  She tries to do too much so you don't end up really understanding anything, just cramming for tests... that are hard.
Dr. Boyd makes her exams unnecessarily difficult and tricky. Not very compassionate either.
I don't know what these other people are talking about but professor Boyd is not worth the hassle.  Her tests are designed so you don't do well.  I got an A in the class though.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
The easiest A ever. He is also such a nice guy.

Prof Mathews was very knowledgeable of cosmology. My trips to the observatory for extra credit were out of this world (lol). Prof Mathews has been all around the world studying cosmology meeting all kinds of people. I hope I can open a wormhole to go back in time and take his class again.
Knowledgeable professor but lectures can be boring. Plenty of extra credit opportunities in the class so as long as you take advantage of that it would be hard to do badly in the class.

He has a chiller class that fulfills the WKST requirement. This class is the easiest A I have ever gotten. You do not need to go to class all semester. The textbook is great if you want to learn about cosmology.

Can't say enough about Prof. Mathews. Get ready to become a space traveler! There are fun class trips to the DVT, loads of extra credit (trips to the observatory), easy crosswords and quizzes you can take as many times as you want for homework, and a few essays and a midterm. Go to the observatory enough and you don't have to take the final.
If you hate science take this class. No labs and extra credit projects at the observatory are enjoyable. If you do well on the first exam and paper there is no need to take the final.

I absolutely love Professor Mathews. Attendance was not mandatory, and gave lots of extra credits. Homeworks are crossword puzzles and quizzes that you can take multiple times. He responded to my emails within an hour even on weekends. Lectures are kind of boring but there no excuse to not get an A. Did not even have to do the final.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: He is clearly knowledgeable about the content, but staying engaged is hard. LOTS of extra credit- there's no excuse for not making an A. Attendance not required. Homework is crossword puzzles, quizzes you can retake as many times as needed, and 2 papers. I did not learn much from this course but it was an easy way to fulfill a science credit.

This is the easiest science credit to take at Notre Dame. The extra credit gives you an insane grade boost, and the online quizzes are super easy and you are able to retake them an unlimited amount of times. I don't have to sit the final to get an A in the class. The papers are graded very easy. The tests are all MCQ and not difficult.

I'd absolute recommend Professor Mathews. His Cosmology class was very easy. That said, I don't think his teaching style was great; it focused too much on pure lectures to be very engaging after the second or so week. Still, the absolute abundance of extra credit means that you'd have to actually try to get less than an A in his class.

I genuinely enjoyed my elementary cosmology class this semester because Professor Mathews did his best to make the content interesting, but the class still was not difficult even if you didn't pay attention. It was the easiest A I've ever gotten and there is a lot of extra credit. Take this class if you want your science requirement taken care of.
Took Professor Mathews for Elementary Cosmology. Literally the easiest A I have gotten here. Tons of extra credit. Also hilarious, plays music during lectures.
Prof Mathews is too smart to be teaching this class.

Dr. Young is an amazing professor! She explains everything in a way that was super understandable for me, and she's always accessible outside of class to help students better understand the material. She is super kind and makes you feel very comfortable in asking questions about the content.
Great Professor! She explains the concepts super clearly and makes sure that everyone understands. Makes classes easy to follow and engage with the materials.

One of the best Chem 10171 professors out there. Her lectures are easy to understand. Provides an enviroment where students can ask questions without judgment. She is also accessible outside the classroom. Overall, her lecture alongside the other supplementary course 13171 provides valuable insight for further chemistry knowledge and swift learning
Professor Young was very nice, but I often felt that the lectures were somewhat unclear and had less explanation than what was needed to perform well on the exams.

Dr. Young is the best professor you can take for chemistry. She's super helpful when it comes to asking questions and makes sure to go slow if the class isn't understanding things. She really tries to help the class learn and her lectures aren't boring. Make sure to show up to lectures as they are extremely helpful.

Professor Young is an amazing professor who is engaging, really cares about her students, and is always willing to answer any questions. She writes the tests / quizzes so it is extremely helpful to be in her class. Definitely recommend.

Professor Young was the best professor for Intro to Chemical Principles! Her lectures were very engaging, clear, and helpful. She was also open to answering any questions that came up, and she made herself available after class and for office hours in case you needed help. HW and quizzes werent bad, as long as you pay attention in lecture.

BEST PROFESSOR EVER. Trust me on this, if you're taking CHEM 10171, you want Professor Young, hands down. She's super sweet and encourages questions; her notes and lectures are amazing. The tests were average-- but all of the chem professors share the same tests. GET KELLEY YOUNG!!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Despite my subpar grade in the class, I can't put any of that blame on having a bad professor because Prof Young is outstanding! She works through plenty of examples and tries to keep class very engaging, which can be difficult in a class with hundreds of students. She was accessible to students, was fun, and had very clear, concise lectures.
really good teacher

Dr. Young really wants to see her students succeed, and her caring demeanor makes her extremely personable. CHEM 10171 was manageable and Young's lecture style made the material really interesting and fun. If given the option, take her! Test difficulty was average but doable if you study and ask questions.

There is a limit to how good 8:20 gen chem can be, but Dr. Young made it manageable most days. It was not as hard as made out to be, although there was a decent amount of work. Great notes copy them down, work problems and tutorial and you will be fine

Professor Young is the best Professor I had Freshmen year. She really cared about her students and wanted to see them succeed. I never took AP Chem so the class was hard, but it is manageable if you work hard.
She was the best professor I have ever had even though she is brand new
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: I had 8:20 gen chem and that was a struggle, but Young made going to class worth it. She explained new concepts that I had not seen before very well, and she writes everything you need to know on the chalkboard. You can tell she loves chemistry and is very caring towards her students. I highly recommend taking her class over another professor.
Lectures were accessible in video form and slides were provided. Feedback on assignments took a long time. Very passionate.

His bio module was interesting and he was a fair grader! He made lectures fun and you could easily tell he is passionate about his work. His module seemed easier compared to others that I have heard about! Would recommend him.

Bio module two sections, first focuses on vocabulary w/ evolution/natural selection, second applies it to COVID/HIV. Interesting, but big difference between the basic concepts we learn and extremely complex real-world systems- was unclear/difficult. We went through a lot of figures in class and details from those were on tests. As a person, chill.

Alex was alright, but I feel like he didn't have his heart in teaching and it showed. Also the grading criteria was ridiculous. You'd think he'd be more clear on what he's looking for if he has his TAs take off for every little detail missing.

The first half (all about evolution) was boring but necessary to understand the more interesting second half (disease). Go to the help sessions for the problem sets, they basically give you the answers. There was only one quiz and the final, so super chill, but don't underestimate the final (avg was 80), it's way harder than the rest of the module.

I don't like Dr Perkins 👎. Also the final test was the hardest for most people [avg score = 80) (not exactly applicable for my own experience). Try to get friendly with the T.A.s; you're at their mercy. I had better attendance than the professor did for this module (I missed 5 classes). Still one of the easier modules though. Shout out T.A. Stacy

I was a little bit disappointed by the content of Dr. Perkins' pandemic module. We spent around half the module learning about phylogenies and life tables, leaving less time than I would've liked for learning about actual disease. Difficulty wise, though, a good grade in this class is very doable and the outside workload wasn't bad.
rating_tags: Group projects--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Easiest class I've taken content-wise, but him and his TA's made it difficult to get a good grade. I could get every question correct and still get a 75%. I even asked him for help once and missed points for what he told me to correct. Funny guy, but didn't like his personality outside lectures and he provided tons of untested information in class.

Freshman pandemic module- extra credit for doing an author poll before every class and the one quiz we took was simple. The lectures are interesting  and engaging. The midterm was fine although not very representative of the study guide and some included some diagrams were very hard to read.

Professor Perkins is an amazing lecturer and truly cares about his students. I took his pandemic biology class and it was very interesting and engaging. However, as with every Big Questions section there aren't many points to miss, so make sure to not miss any silly points. Overall, I would definitely recommend taking his Big Questions course!
He is very creative and the class is generally laid back and we didn't do too much. Would definitely recommend!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: This class is fun because Perkins is so laid back. Just beware that there is only a few assignments that you need to do well on the easy stuff and decent on the tests. DO THE SCIENTIST PROFILES.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Wasn't a terribly difficult professor, but his exams cover very very niche things. Some things would entail certain comments from a random paper you'll read sometime throughout the year. not the greatest.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: What a great professor! He truly cares about what he teaches and wants his students to learn. He always made the class engaging and tried to keep them fun. I learned so much in his class that laid a great foundation for future biology classes. I would definitely take his courses again.
Great professor! Really cares about his students and wants you to succeed in college.

Had him for American politics freshman year. Wasn't really a fan tbh. Wanted to make his exams "cheat-proof" cause of Covid (he made them harder), when he could've just had us take them in person (the class was in person except for exams).  Exams were tough, and only had open-ended questions.  Nice guy though and I hope he has a nice retirement.

Best professor at Notre Dame. Truly passionate about teaching, and any class you take with him will give you a truly unique insight into the subject that other professor's would not produce. Each class I have taken with him, although somewhat more challenging than the typical polisci class, leaves me feeling I learned what truly mattered.

This class was great! We had to read a lot of different books, but Kaplan made sure to choose interesting ones. You must attend lectures, and if you pay attention exams should be easy. He sends out a very thorough study guide before each test. He is super kind and cares about his students success. He shares his lecture slides with students.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: I absolutely loved Prof. Kaplan's class. Though it was slow at times, he was always so excited to share his thoughts on the readings (especially Thucydides). DO THE READINGS and listen closely to his tips and notes during class and you will do just fine.

Super kind, clearly is passionate about the material, and makes the lectures both funny and engaging. Took his Political Theory course for my second philosophy credit and absolutely loved it. Be prepared to do a lot of the readings to stay on top of things!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: I have taken Prof Kaplan for American Politics and Political Theory. He is a great thinker and always provokes interesting thoughts on the subject matter. I would recommend him to anyone, and he is a very nice, approachable man. He is a tough grader. Learn the content the way he wants it learned.

Truly an awesome professor. He fostered my interest in the subject matter and is actually the reason I am now doing a Political Science double major. Material itself really isn't that hard and neither are the tests or papers he just grades very harshly. Expect a B or less if you put in normal effort.
extremely nice guy. grading is a bit difficult and there is quite a bit of reading.
Long lectures and subjective grading. Nice enough guy.
Definitely one of the best professors I've had. Makes you work for the grade, but he's always accessible and has a ridiculous amount of office hours.

Best professor of my college career.  Helpful, kind, easy to get to know and very good at making difficult material easier to understand.  Don't let your four years go by without taking a class with him.

Prof. Kaplan is the nicest professor I've ever had. He really cares about his students. He had our seminar over for BBQ during the semester and even the next year. He's very helpful and will grant extensions if you need them. If never seemed bothered by anyone being late, but I'd go just out of respect for him. Exam was a research paper, wasn't bad

10/10 stats professor. Makes a hard course feel easy. Go to lectures and there's nothing you won't understand. Not only is she clear but also very engaging. Having a buddy in the class is especially useful for in-class assignments.

She is an excellent professor! She has so much energy for a "boring" class, and this makes it worth-while. She clearly cares about her students and will tell you EXACTLY how to do well in the class. She sets everybody up to do well and clearly just wants her students to learn the material. Absolutely take her class, even though it meets Fridays.
the best professor nd has. the content can be difficult for some but she really wants you to do well in the class.
i

Professor Waddell has been one of my best professors I've ever taken at Notre Dame. Absolutely fantastic, knew my name and things about me even though I never participated, always checked to see if I was doing well on ICAs, and grades incredibly fairly. She wants everyone to succeed and is a great human being. If I could take her again I would.

She is super passionate about the material and a good lecturer. She is really great about answering questions and she knew my name even though I never participated. The workload is not too hard and the tests are overall pretty fair assessments. She also lets you have a cheat sheet that you can fill front and back - which is super useful!

Professor Waddell is passionate about statistics and gives great lectures. There are three exams that make up the vast majority of your grade. They are super fast-paced with lots of questions. Many people severely struggled in this class so the curve was insane and benefitted everyone. Be prepared to study weeks in advance for tests to succeed.

Prof. Waddell is the best!!! She knows what she's talking about, and if you don't get it she will take the time to help you if you make the effort. She has fun examples during lectures, and everything that's on the exams is taught in class. Just show up to class and listen for 50 min = enough. If you aren't taking stats 2 with Waddell wyd??

The homework and assignments are not very difficult. The only part of this course where I struggled was the exams. The questions were not particularly hard but there were a lot of questions for the 50-minute time period. You are allowed 8.5 by 11 sheet of notes for all exams which is very nice but it is hard to use in such a limited amount of time.

Professor Waddell has probably been one of my favorite college professors to date. She genuinely cares about her students and is incredibly passionate about statistics; she really loves her job. She wants to see you succeed and will ensure you're prepared for exams/assignments. Put in some effort and you'll enjoy her class.

Most passionate prof you will ever have. Made my 9:30am worth showing up to every MWF despite not being a morning person. I did not participate often, yet she knew my name. Willing to explain/check to make sure everyone understands before moving on. I don't think she will be teaching ITAO 20200 moving forward, but if she has another class, TAKE HER

Prof. Waddell is great! Her lectures can go a little fast, but decks are posted for viewing after class. There are three exams, and you get to make a double-sided help sheet for each one. She is very smart and a helpful resource for stuff related to and outside of the class!
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Waddell is a great professor. She teaches the material in depth and cares about her students. The exams aren't bad and you can use a cheat-sheet. Reading the book isn't necessary, as most of the content is taught through lectures. Show up to class and you'll do fine.

Shes so great! The class is challenging but doable and the exams are all open note. She also doesnt take attendance and posts the powerpoints so you can do whatever you want! Great lecturer though - if you go and pay attention you wont really have to teach yourself anything else. Tests closely resemble in class assignments
Ugh I love this professor! She's such a good professor and clearly cares about the class and students. 10/10 would recommend!

Dr. Waddell is an awesome teacher! Nightly textbook reading but not many people actually read it. The homework is easy and due before each test; she also gives you 50 tries to get a question so it's easy to do well. She posts her lecture powerpoints online so attendance is not really mandatory (but recommended). Tests aren't too hard if you study.
This class made me want to change my major. He is extremely knowledgeable and passionate about the subject, but the lectures were often unclear. The papers are VERY hard and difficult to do well on.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I simultaneously feel like I learned nothing new and like the content was too far out there to grasp. The readings were easy, but the lectures can only be described as wild. The instructions for the papers are super unclear (the prompts are OUT THERE) and the TAs are not helpful at all (even after going to office hours every week).
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Very very nice guy. Can get tangent heavy during lecture. Lecture as near nothing to do with assignments. I personally realized political science was not my passion, so I found it incredibly difficult to be motivated to do work, but the essays are quite hard.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: i did not like mcadams at all. his lectures were not well organized and i literally had no idea what they were about. so much reading that we never talked about too. would not recommend, not a really hard class but a really unnecessary one - dont think i learned anything.

Professor McAdams is the bomb. No tests, just a few papers that are not too difficult to write if you've read the assigned readings. Sometimes the lectures were a little hard to follow, but McAdams was always more than willing to meet with students outside of class.

some ppl really like him but I did not. I thought his lectures were all over the place and they were hard to follow and I found his class boring. No tests only essays, which makes it a relatively easy class if you do the readings. Lectures are mostly useless, you're better off just doing the readings on your own.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Very passionate about world politics, as well as interested in his students. Assigns a lot of readings but gives very in-depth lectures and is very accessible outside of class. I recommend his Intro to World Politics class to anyone interested in politics.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Took POLS- Intro to Comparative Politics. Get prepared to do a lot of reading. There are discussions every week. He lectures for twice a week so make sure to take good notes. Will most likely discuss topics such as political ideologies.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Didn't really teach us anything. I took his University Seminar, and the entire class consisted of him assigning us readings, and then he would make us discuss it by ourselves. He didn't ever just teach us about social science.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Fantastic professor. Really knows what genuine learning is, and has a wide breadth of experiences travelling the world that he incorporates into his lectures. Very eccentric and very personable.
difficult to follow lectures
No Comments
No Comments

He has a good personality but he doesn't teach well. It's noticeable that he knows chemistry very well but when it comes to teaching the concepts to first learners he is not good. His slides and notes were not helpful at all. Many students skipped his lecture to attend another professor's lecture.

I had Prof Helquist for Orgo 2. Prof Helquist was very accessible outside of class with many office hours. He also helps you with the material until you understand it. He is also very funny and has great jokes. His problem sets and practice exams prepare you very well and also match the real exams pretty well.

Taking orgo 1 with Prof. Helquist was not the most fun. His problem sets did not line up with lecture and you somewhat taught yourself the material with the textbook. I think this was a case of knowing a subject way too well that you forget your students are just learning it for the first time. He's not a bad guy but he could be a better prof.

Prof. Helquist was honestly one of the most accessible professors on this campus. He had office hours Monday through Saturday and was always willing to explain key concepts for problem sets and practice problems for exam review. His exams were always fair, and I always felt that he wanted the students to succeed.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: horrible. he has toxic office hours and he has no regard for how students learn

Everyone that is hating on this professor is butthurt that they didn't study for the exams or read the book. He was a great teacher and is extremely helpful during office hours. If you go to him for help, he will give you the answers. If you read the book and actually do the practice problems like you're supposed to (It's ORGO), you'll get that A.
Just the worst. Would recommend avoiding him but you might not have another/a better option.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: No thanks

Organic Chemistry as it is is a very hard subject. It doesn't help when the professor is boring. There is no doubt that Prof. Helquist is extremely qualified and knows organic chemistry extremely well, but he can't teach. I literally had to do most of my learning outside the classroom through the textbook and other videos.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: Helquist's favorite phrases are "this is all simply review" and "these are simple concepts" when teaching his class. Does not believe in curves when tests around about 80% of your grade. He will also make you feel dumb for asking a question in class and is very condescending. Do not recommend.

Helquist is one of the worst professors I have ever ehad. He constantly tells the class to "figure concepts out" ourselves rather than teach it himself. The lectures are pointless but you have to go to turn the homework in. Due to all this, there's tons of work outside of class because you have to teach yourself organic chemistry.

Professor Helquist always made his best attempt to make the lectures interesting albeit the subject was Organic Chemistry. He is very caring and sweet and going to his office hours is probably the best choice you will make all semester. He will offer help if you need it and does all he can for the success of his students. All around clear and great

Sullivan is great, unlike the other GGL profs, she doesnt care if every student in the class gets an A. Lots of your grade depends on your TA so make sure to go to office hours and get close with them. Most classes you don't really have to pay attention especially after the first "exam". Never really did the homework and was fine
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Absolutely hate her and her TA Rebecca Kates. My paper was graded very poorly, even though my essay followed what was stated in the rubric. When I asked for feedback and why points were deducted on where it shouldn't be, she just ignored my email and a follow-up email that was sent several times. She isn't an educative and reachable professor.

Attendance isn't mandatory, but there's surprise pop quizzes. Grades are going to be based on dialogue attendance (which is really fun), pop quizzes, an exam, and a draft/final 'apology'. The grading is pretty tricky on the exam and draft, but everyone should walk away from the class with an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: GGL was a fairly useless class in my opinion, but Sullivan was a good teacher. Pretty easy to get an A if you put in effort on your final paper. Attendance isn't mandatory and occasional in-class assignments for points, however, only your top five count towards your grade and there ends up being around eight.

I would definitely recommend take her for first Philo. Biggest assignment is the apology, which is definitely doable. Sometimes the TA's can be a little wack, but that's not necessarily her fault. All quizzes are open note and class goes super fast every meeting.
Love Prof. Sullivan!! She was so engaging and made philosophy entertaining. Do the work and you will get an A. The TAs are not as tough as everyone says. Great Philo 1.

Sullivan is a solid teacher for GGL. She was well versed in the topics and related the course material to recent events as well. There are pop quizzes every couple of classes, but you get to drop some of your lowest ones. I enjoyed the class but was not my favorite. The grading in the class can be dependent on your TA as well.

Professor Sullivan makes an attempt at getting to know her students  both in and out of class. Makes lectures very engaging and is very high energy (great pick-me-up for early lectures). After talking to friends with different philo professors, it is easy to see Sullivan's curriculum is both the easiest and most fun.

Great, interesting professor who seems to really care about her students. Diff TAs grade differently so that sucks a bit. Attending class isn't mandatory but there are 7 surprise quizzes (you can drop your lowest 2). While there is a lot of hw/readings, you can do well without actually doing it all. Pretty easy class, minimal assignments, fun prof!

I took Professor Sullivan for GGL and it's such a chill class. The class is interesting, so even though it's 9 am you're paying attention not falling asleep. Not too much work, there's a few major assignments and then thats really it. You have a tutorial once a week, which is at 8 pm either on Monday or Tuesday, I really liked mine so no complaints

Had her for GGL and loved her! The class taught me so much about myself and really helped me think deeply about my life. Professor Sullivan is clearly passionate about teaching and cares about us. She delivers the material very well and the course website makes organization easy. Not a lot of work and easy to get an A. Would take again if I could!

I question the wisdom of teaching Intro to Philo to 100 freshmen, but that can hardly be blamed on Professor Sullivan. My real objection was her unconcern for students' grades. Her grading system is very convoluted and often misleading. If you have a question about the details she is simply not interested; all you get is "read the syllabus."

Professor Olsen is a wonderful person, and you can tell he is very passionate about what he teaches. Class is graded mostly off of three exams and one group project. The exams can be a bit tough, but there is a heavy curve. I never spoke but always came to class and got an above-average participation grade. Very minimal outside work except exams.
Easily one of the best professors I have ever had. While his exams are tough, he is such an engaging lecturer, and is super helpful throughout all stages of the group project.

Olsen loves marketing and tries to make boring content interesting. 10% of your grade comes from participating in class, but attendance is loosely enforced and its hard to get a great grade for participation in such a big class. You can pick groups for the final project, but between the project and the final exam the end of the semester gets busy.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: Mitch is a great teacher and lecturer. The content can be a little dull sometimes but he's the best for Foundations of Marketing. 3 exams and a group project.

Mitch is a great, caring guy who genuinely loves marketing, and it shows. His class was pretty boring, though, and, as much as I studied for the exams, memorization only got me half-way as they are all application-based (much to my demise). The participation grade seems a bit arbitrary to me. Not much homework, thankfully.

Lectures are awesome- he mixes in a lot of examples and is really entertaining himself. He's engaging, even with the 100+ people in my section. It can be hard to participate in the big class, though. Exams are challenging and have some math. You can pick your group project members, and it's a good way to apply the content you're learning.

One of the best professors I've ever had! His lectures are really engaging and makes learning the content enjoyable. He really cares about his students and learned everyone's names within 2 weeks in a 70+ person class. His exams are a little challenging, but definitely tolerable if you take good notes during class and study for them.

I really liked Professor Olsen as a guy--he's witty, wholesome, and kind. While a lot of my friends enjoyed the class, I personally did not like this class at all. It is SUPER subjective and you only get graded on a few things. The exams are super tough. It isn't memorization based, so if you want an easier marketing class, don't take Olsen.

A big chunk of his grading is extremely biased, participation accounts for 10% and he's not going to give you full credit in a 100+ student lecture hall. Getting good exam scores are easy in his class if you study, but if he doesn't like you he's gonna screw you over other grading portions that have nothing to do with the course content.

Marketing's boring but Olsen's the best you're gonna get. He's enthusiastic and goes over the slides well in class. The tests are mostly conceptual and tough, but the curve helps at the end. The group project is time-consuming so don't procrastinate until the last week if possible. Also, take the class with friends because you can pick your team.
Olsen super passionate about marketing, and it clearly shows in his teaching. I really enjoyed his class, and I didn't find it too difficult, though I did take it online over the summer.

Even though his grading was easier than most, he rather focus on the quality of the students' work. From the very beginning, you can tell that he's passionate about his craft. You can also tell that he wants to share his love for that with the students he interacts with. I would definitely recommend this class to other people.

Although Olsen is awkward, it's obvious he makes a genuine effort to connect to students & share his passion for marketing. Somewhat different than other intro classes, his class consists of a large ongoing group project, multiple difficult case studies, & some math-based assignments. There is no memorization on his tests, which makes them easier.

Prof. Moasser is a great lecturer and takes interest in every student. The lab reports are very long and tedious but are graded fairly. This lab functions as a good buffer for the overall chemistry grade.
Best chem lab professor ever. Long lab reports, but it's very worth it.

If I could give this guy a 6 I would. Very interesting pre-lab lectures. He is a very kind person who will work with you to help you improve. With that being said the lab reports were sometimes grueling.

Moasser is an incredibly nice and helpful professor who truly cares about his students. The main work in this class is the incredibly long lab reports that get longer with every lab (up to 4000 words). DO NOT WAIT TO THE LAST NIGHT TO DO THEM. The grade for the lab is part of lecture grade, which is a great curve for Seth Brown's difficult exams.

Prof. Moasser made this chem sequence doable. He is so clear in his lab instructions and truly cares about all of his students. Definitely my favorite all semester despite the advanced difficulty of his labs and lab reports. You will learn a lot from him, especially the crucial skills like writing a report, that isn't taught in lecture.

After I got a 66 on the first exam, I started going to his office hours every single week and ended up finishing the class with a flat A. He truly wants you to succeed. It is a hard class but if you use your resources and go to office hours you can succeed. He is the best ever i love him so much. Got to know us well and cared about us. Slay

Moasser did a great job explaining the material and preparing for tests. It's a hard course, so you'll need to study out of class. MAKE SURE TO GO TO LECTURES. If you showed up to class every time, you thought he was a good teacher, and if you didn't, he wasn't. His lectures can be boring at times, but he is a very sweet and amazing teacher/person.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Moasser is easily one of my favorite professors in the College of Science. Makes every effort to assist students in and out of class. Very common for him to make lectures in stories so that they are easier to grasp. Tests are very similar to practice exam, utilize problem sets as extra practice. Would highly recommend.

Prof. Moasser is an absolutely amazing person and prof. He's always willing to help and wants everyone to do well and understand the material. There were 6 major lab reports due over the semester and were REALLY time consuming (DON'T WAIT TIL THE NIGHT BEFORE!) but overall manageable. TAs gave good feedback and were quite generous with grades.

I love Moasser. He is such a kind and caring professor. His beginning of lab lectures can get a little boring and his answers to your questions are always really long, but he always wants to make sure you understand the material. On the last day of lab we did watercolors and he complemented everyone's art.

I love this man!! He is absolutely one of the greatest professors at ND. He is very inspirational and his lectures are good. He is very passionate and a person that is easy to talk to during office hrs.
He is one of the kindest and smartest professor I have had on this campus! Highly recommended!

I've had Moasser twice now for two chemistry courses. He has been a great and thorough explainer of concepts that are difficult to learn. Extremely kind and considerate, he genuinely wants every student to succeed in his class. His tests are very straightforward and fair, not designed to trick or "catch" students off guard. I highly recommend him.

She is a very sweet and interesting person and is genuinely interested in your life outside of class.
