That said, her class could be a little disorganized at times or hard to follow, but eventually, you will get the hang of it, and she is very forgiving when you accidentally forget to do something. She does note when you participate in class.
Very nice person, but this class was not enjoyable at all. Unnecessarily difficult and not well organized.

Took the class for fun as a business major. Never again. 

She assigns insane amounts of homework and is so vague with the guidelines surrounding it. Then she'll get mad that you did it wrong.
Just don't. Please, don't.

Just don't. Bad idea. She is incredibly unprofessional. If you aren't one of her favorites, good luck getting a good grade. I am quite literally fluent in the language and only took this because I am required to per university requirements and I did not get an A. She assigns a lot of homework, which would be fine if she graded fairly but she doesnt
As a very unprofessional and unorganized professor, her class made me want to join Baraka Bouts so I could have an outlet for all of the anger I gathered over being in her class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Pretty challenging class with lots of homework. Enjoyed the class a lot and I'm definitely way better at Spanish but it was not easy. Participate in class because she notes when you do or don't speak. Probably won't take another Spanish class but Professor Botero is genuinely very nice and cares for all of her students.

The most unprofessional professor I have ever had at Notre Dame. Her course is incredibly disorganized, yet she has insane expectations for her students. She picks favorites, is incredibly rude, and is not well-versed on the subject of immigration. She will also continuously remind you that her time is more precious than yours.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: If you want to enjoy your semester, don't take Immigration and the Construction of Memory and, above all, stay away from Tatiana Botero! Insufferably arrogant. Course is very disorganized, assignments lack specific objectives and she provides no instruction. Above all, she allows little to no room for objections. AVOID HER AT ALL COSTS!

She is a very kind and caring person, but she has very high expectations. There is a substantial amount of homework every class and participation is closely monitored. The class is taught entirely in Spanish, with little English. That being said, the subject matter is interesting and well-selected.
She gives out more work and projects in comparison to other Intermediate Spanish 1 classes. She is very caring and nice, but a harsh grader. You have to participate to get a good grade.

I had her for Cultural Conversations and Writings (covid times so online). She is an amazing professor- clearly cares about her students, the information is so interesting and opens your eyes to issues you didn't know about, some hw doesn't feel like homework. Def my fav prof and class! Say something every class and she grades tough so proofread!

I took 20202 and this is my major so I got a good grade, but the course is fairly difficult. She will grade oddly at times, but she makes up for it with many extra credit opportunities. She is arrogant, and she flexes on her teaching achievements, and she makes her left wig political views very clear, but she is passionate about her craft.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Profe Botero was an excellent Spanish professor.  She speaks clearly and slowly to where even basic speakers can understand.  I'd recommend her class to anyone at any level of Spanish.

Amazing person. He truly cares about his students and has tons of experience in the field. His exams are all multiple choice and taken from the book. His lectures are great and he tends to go on tangents that are usually about his experience working in accounting but the things he talks about aren't always on the exam.

Prof Hums is an excellent person who clearly cares about all of his students. He will do his best to demonstrate obvious care for everyone. However, the class is difficult to stay engaged in because lectures can get boring. You will also have to teach yourself a lot of the material. He is a great person who teaches valuable life lessons, though.

Attendance is mandatory but he tries his best to make the material interesting and engage students. Can tell he loves Notre Dame and teaching. Exams are all multiple choice- there are a lot of questions and not a lot of time to answer them but the content isn't that hard. Besides exams, there are homeworks, excel assignments, and chapter quizzes.

Attendance is mandatory which is unfortunate considering you do not learn anything during class. You must teach yourself everything using the textbook outside of class, but the class is not particularly hard so this is manageable. There is not much required homework outside of class but do the extra problems so you can learn stuff.

Really passionate and caring guy, but lectures can sometimes feel like a waste of time. Class on Friday begins with a prayer which is a really nice touch. Lifelong ND man who truly cares about his students.

I really liked Professor Hums, but I found myself teaching myself all of the content. While topics and problems seem easy, the exams consist of way more difficult questions, and they were often a major time-crunch. Overall, I thought he was a super nice and great guy, but he was not the most clear when it came to teaching.
His lectures are not very very engaging but his tests are not too hard.

So Hums is a great guy and the class itself is entertaining But he is a horrible instructor/lecturer. You will teach yourself everything and the tests are 1000x more difficult than anything in class. I would not recommend simply because you have to go to class (mandated attendance) and then additionally teach yourself everything

Professor Humss lectures often made no sense and it felt like he wasnt really teaching accounting. Exams were difficult, and you have to teach yourself the course. Isnt the most approachable guy when it comes to asking for help, but can be funny at times.

I would highly recommend Prof. Hums for Accounting 1. He makes his lectures fun and really cares about his students. Compared to the other accounting classes his is the easiest. The textbook is key and you need to teach yourself but other than that the class isn't too bad.

ND legend for sure. The guy made me cackle like every class. Everything you need for the test is in those yellow sheets, HW, or quizzes. I've since taken upper-level accounting classes and did not feel "behind" at all compared to other people.

Prof. Hums is a really nice guy and a funny professor. His classes are heavy on lectures and reading the textbook is important for harder chapters. There isn't too much homework besides a weekly online assignment that takes about an hour. The tests account for the majority of your grade.

Professor Francalanci is great! He is always willing to help outside of class and wants you to succeed. Make sure you participate in class and do the daily readings. There are two exams and a couple essays which are relevant to the readings. I loved this class and really enjoyed the course material.

Francalanci is super nice, understanding, and always willing to explain something you don't understand and answer questions. Pretty easy grader, just make sure you participate. Enjoyed this class a lot more than I anticipated--highly recommend taking it with Francalanci.

I took him for Intermediate Spanish 1. He does things exactly by the book, so just check the calendar on Canvas to make sure you're keeping up. Lots of VHL homework, but that is the course, not him. Tests are simple and he is an easy grader. Very kind man as well, always willing to answer questions. He is a great choice for a Spanish professor!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Francalanci is an extremely nice guy, and it's clear that he cares about his students, but honestly his class was SO boring. We had a ton of reading and then just talked about a poem ad nauseum all class. I don't feel like my Spanish improved and I lost a lot of my interest in learning Spanish.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Profe was an amazing Spanish professor. Although I am pretty horrible at Spanish, he was a very lenient grader and I ended up doing pretty well. Overall, we did not have much homework day to day, and besides a few papers and tests, the course was fairly easy. Definitely would recommend taking.

Most of the learning is done online and outside of class, which was very difficult for me personally. The tests weren't too bad; writing assignments were graded leniently. My main complaint was that we mainly did online activities in class rather than explaining the concept to us. He is very good at explaining but should do it more!

He truly cares about our learning. He speaks in English when he needs to explain important things but overall speaks Spanish. You read a couple chapters (of an English book) every week and get credit for discussing it in Spanish. The only flaw is that he is an extremely slow grader. We have 1 week left of school and he's only graded one assignment.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Caring

comment: Solid professor. He's a cool guy who really cares about his students and the content. His participation expectations are a little excessive, but he's pretty lenient when it comes to grading papers and extensions for assignments.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: This man is such a sweetheart who CARES about his students. Very understanding and will talk in English to clarify important points. I am praying that I can take this man again. This class I took actually had no tests (only papers, participation, and presentation).

Love Professor Francalanci. Super understanding of all students' spanish level and creates a welcoming and comfortable class environment. Slow to return papers (2-6 weeks) so not really sure where you are grade wise until the end of the semester. Regardless, minimal homework and great overall class to take - Leo is the best!

Professor Francalanci was awesome! I've had four different professors in the Spanish department so far and they've all been amazing and caring! Show up, do your work, and participate and you'll be totally fine in his class.

Maybe my favorite prof at Notre Dame! I've now had him twice and really enjoyed both classes. He's super understanding of your level of Spanish and makes sure everyone feels comfortable. He's also very intelligent and generally a thoughtful guy. As long as you bounce back his care for the material you will succeed in the class. Take him!

Leonardo truly cares about each one of his students. He wants everyone to enjoy Hispanic Literature and tries to make in-class activities as intriguing as possible. Tests pretty easy and straightforward. Overall a quality professor.

Dr. Creary is one of the best professors I've had. He distills complex concepts into understandable building blocks, despite teaching some of the most difficult material in teh engineering curriculum. He understands his class' understanding and has postponed exams until he feels the class is ready.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Very mixed reviews. No one can say he doesn't work hard to make himself accessible, but if you don't do exactly what he wants he will make it difficult to recover.
He is the chemist of the day, everyday.

I cant believe there is a single negative comment about this man. If you do the work he tells you to and attend his office hours, you will do well. He goes through each mechanism in exceptional detail explaining exactly why everything happens the way it does. And there are two review sessions after each class. I couldnt imagine a teacher doing more

His tests were absurdly hard.I got a 35/100 on one.The curve made that a C+.But the worst thing was that I went to see him for help after studying the stuff for five hours. He totallyconfused me.He said I needed to study more.I left in tears.I'm taking the class over with Carl Wamser at Ptld St.His class sets up students for success.A REAL teacher.
Dr. Creary told me I'd never pass his class nor would I ever be accepted into medical school. What an encouraging chap!
Great prof, tough subject. TAKE HIM IF YOU CAN.

I was always told organic chemistry was impossible, but Dr. Creary made the class very enjoyable.  He truly cares about his students and wants them to succeed.  Attend his review sessions in the afternoons; they reinforce his lectures and definitely help in preparation of the exams.
You'll learn a lot from this guy, but it's going to be a crucible.  His tests are ridiculously hard.  Might be worth the trouble for the future.
No Comments

Its a difficult class, but he does a good job of relating the material.  He is smart and helpful, but look for him to challenge you to help you arrive at answers yourself (a method that will give you confidence on exams).  He grades hard, but fair... organic is tedious, so he grades carefully.

If there is another section, take it!  Creary tests over the tiniest details that he "mentioned" in class but did NOT emphasize.  You get absolutely no partial credit (no matter what they say).  Averages on our tests were in the 60s.

Professor Hunt is incredibly lovable and leads engaging class discussions. The course is relatively unstructured, and the final grade essentially boils down to a few papers and attendance, but the papers have plenty of chances for revision. If you're willing to put in the time and participate in class you'll earn the scores you want.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: She's very kind and passionate. However, it is important to note that the class periods are completely unstructured discussions of the readings, wherein she responds to students' comments but does not prioritize organized discussion of the main ideas. If you value structure and clear guidelines, do not take this class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Botting is so passionate about both the subject material and her students. She is very accessible outside of class for both paper help or general help. Also grades pretty easily and leads a fun class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Caring

comment: She was amazing and made sure the students understand what was going on. She was not too tough and made herself readily available outside of class.

My course with Professor Botting was the highlight of my freshman year. She allowed me to be creative and was very helpful to me and my classmates inside and outside of class. She is great at leading discussion and encouraging students to do more. The quality of reading and discussion in this class influenced my eventual choice of major.

Professor Botting is my favorite professor I've ever taken. This class was mainly discussion-based, and she is an expert at facilitating the perfect balance between free-flowing discussion and contribution of her expertise. Also, she is a great mentor and will help you achieve your long term research or career goals. This course changed my life.

I enjoyed Botting's Mary Wollstonecraft & Mary Shelley course tremendously. She sparked my interest in the political thought of these women through interesting readings, discussions, and assignments. More importantly, Botting is a compassionate professor who keeps up with her students and helps them find ways to pursue their interests.
Treats students like children. Very patronizing outside of class. Tries to be the cool teacher but is very insular.

Super enthusiastic about the subject (Mary Wollstonecraft), understanding about extended deadlines, missed classes, etc.  Went out of her way to help with research, contacting colleagues at other schools and authors of texts used.  Took us out for drinks and pizza.  I wasn't a poli sci major, and this was one of the best classes I ever took.
Sometimes the explanations become frustratingly unclear, but she does demonstrate much concern for students' learning.

I had her for an upper level class on the Englightenment.  She was very nice, and was obviously really into the material.  We had a small class so we could ask questions which made it easier to follow.  She seems genuinely concerned with her students and was understanding if you had a good reason for being late or needing more help with an assignment.
She's supposed to be brilliant and all, but half the time, the class can't follow her. But, she's really good looking and she acts like she used to be a party grrl.

Prof Schafer is a great teacher and very knowledgable in his field. The quizzes for his class can be kinda tricky (he loves which of the following is NOT.... style questions, which can be hard to interpret). If you spend time on them, though, they are doable and you can get good grades. For sure one of the best bio modules you can take.

Cancer module is super interesting material and he is a really great communicator. However the quizzes for his classes are super oddly worded and can be hard to get good scores on. Other assignments are really interesting, including the paper on naked mole rats.  Lectures are a lot of listening to him talk, but he keeps it engaging.

Professor Schafer is very knowledgeable on the subject and super kind. However, his quizzes are very difficult. Despite taking them online during your own time, the outcomes of these can be fatal....BUT I will say, this is by far one of the most interesting modules. I would not recommend taking this if you do not have a strong biology background.

The quizzes in the cancer module are difficult but there are lots of opportunities to get to know the materials better through TA office hours as well as office hours with Schaffer. The class is very reliant on discussion, the more you talk the more you will get out of the course.

Professor Schafer was very nice and seemed very passionate about the topic. However, the quizzes were very hard, as the phrasing was misleading, and oftentimes, topics on the quizzes weren't outright discussed in the lecture. This bio module was difficult, especially without a strong bio background.

Very interesting and engaging lecturer, is very passionate about the content.  Devotes a decent chunk of class time to answering questions, peer discussion, and concept check completion.  Homework is light, but quizzes (which are all open-note) and final exam (not open-note) are tough.  Certainly one of the harder bio modules, but not impossible.

The cancer module is one of the harder Bio 1 modules, but the content is very interesting. Zach is a great professor, very caring and respectful, but his quizzes are impossible. This module is more difficult than an intro bio course should be, but if you have higher level bio knowledge (like AP Biology) then it isn't too bad.

Great professor who teaches an incredibly interesting module for Bio 1. Some people will tell you it's one of the harder modules but I found it to be by far the fairer of the two I took. Quiz questions can be worded very confusingly, but trust yourself and you'll be fine. Take good notes on class discussions, and use the resources he gives.

Zach is an incredible person and the material is so engaging in the cancer module. However, the quizzes are very difficult and the wording is often confusing. He doesn't post the notes before class, but he records every class which is very helpful for reviewing. While it was difficult, I still loved this module and definitely recommend it.

Prof. Zach is great and cares about his students. Paying attention in class is important and if you miss anything, watch the lecture recording. Final test was easy (study ppts, lectures and attend TA review) and similar to practice exam. No need to take notes & lectures are posted on Canvas. However, quizzes were difficult & hard to understand!

Super nice professor and the lectures are really interesting. The quizzes are insanely difficult for no reason though. I wouldn't recommend this module for bio. Definitely harder than an intro bio class should be.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Zac was fantastic for his cancer module in Bio 1. The course is incredibly difficult, but he makes it seem interesting, even if you aren't into cancer research. He really gives great lectures, but sometimes his quizzes get a little confusing with double negatives and awkward phrasing that makes you really think about what he means to say.

10/10 Professor. Cares about his students, engaging, funny. His lectures and the tests are difficult but as long as you study the main arguments you should be fine. He is one of the reasons I decided to major in philosophy. Genuinely amazing person, will give you an A if you bring in baked goods.

In Prof. Snapper's office hour, he teaches each student in a tailored way. If you struggle with your overall schedule and think it is fairly hard for you to keep your workload, you can come to his office and talk to him, for he is willing to help you improve time management and give some extensions if you really need.

Professor Snapper is the best professor I've had at Calvin. He cares about what he teaches and for his students. The class itself can be a little difficult (but that's just philosophy in itself) but he makes it easy to understand and interesting to learn. I'm considering minoring in philosophy because of this prof!!!

One of, if not the best Prof I have had. He spends hours outside of his lectures, even on weekends doing review sessions with his students. He responds to questions with informative emails. Prof. Snapper made intro to philosophy so interesting and engaging that I decided to add a minor in philosophy because of him. Took him in logic

Loved this class, professor Snapper is a hard grader and expects a lot, but is willing to work with his students. He is caring and in general a great person to get to know. Don't be afraid to ask questions or go see him for help!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Snapper is a good guy, but his class seems to go off the rails a bit. I personally did not struggle but heard stories of tutors having no idea what he was teaching. I enjoyed the class and the discussion. Snapper is a good guy but picks favorites a bit. His exams are difficult but study the main arguments and you will be fine.

Best professor I have ever had. His lectures are so interesting and immersive. Lots of homework but its enjoyable. Never taken any philosophy classes before him but he made it awesome.. Really down to earth and overall a great guy.

Jeff Snapper is one of the best professors I've ever had. He makes intro philosophy fun and is always energetic about the material. He gives great examples of concepts and is willing to do whatever he can to help students understand the material. He is so caring and genuine. He really likes participation, so speak up in class!

I generally liked the professor. Surprisingly,  the lectures were somewhat fun. I would often stay after class to understand the ideas and philosophy in greater detail, sometimes pointing out alternatives or possible issues. He grades quizzes (over the readings) fairly, but be careful writing your papers. I'd recommend asking plenty of questions.

Jeff is easily one of the most down-to-earth professors out there. He's committed to helping everyone understand the material, and he does it in fun, hands-on ways. There's definitely a lot of reading for the class, but it's worth it because you learn a lot! Overall amazing professor.
He's a really nice guy; he'll go out of his way to ensure that you understand the material. He's also extremely helpful when it comes to writing papers.

This is by far the worst class I have ever taken at Notre Dame. The lectures are extremely boring and confusing. So, in the end, everyone has to read the long textbook to understand what is happening in this class. Especially if you compare this class to intermediate micro, you will see why the prof is bad at teaching.
The entire course depend on one textbook. Lectures are extremely vague and unnecessary. Taking this class = reading the textbook
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: There are so many questions on the problem set that he did not teach. You have to read the super long and boring textbook my yourself to understand the material. Like if you can study the entire course by reading the textbook, what is the point of the lecture and making the attendance mandatory? Avoid this professor at all cost.

There are 10 long problem sets and three exams. Lectures are also really long and kinda boring, but he really does care about his students. He is always available outside of class, but you'll mostly be learning on your own. He is smart and compassionate but not very engaging.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Not great. Lectures are hard to follow, and the slides and textbook do not help much. Long, hard weekly problem sets that do not reflect what you learn in class, but they are similar to the problems in the exam. Exams are hard too. He posts practice problems, but does not give answers to most problems. Cares about you learning, though.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: Pugsley is a great guy! He takes the time to learn all his students names and is incredibly smart and patient. The class has lots of homework and the exams are tough, but it is doable with many collab sessions and office hours available throughout the week.

He clearly cares about his students and puts in a good effort, but has his faults. Lectures are calculus heavy, so developing the intuition is mostly on you. He is also a deliberate, careful speaker, but definitely not the most engaging, so sleep well or have coffee ready. Beware of hours-long weekly problem sets, but you can do them in groups.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Doesn't explain the material well. Exams and problem sets are not reflective of the material learned in the lecture.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Obviously smart and well-meaning in teaching. But a lot of his explanations go right over your head because they're honestly not dumbed down enough. Very calculus-heavy. Problem sets are difficult--had to go to office hours every week. I did well on the tests only with help from people who've taken him before.
Obnoxiously hard class, not made any easier by his 8-hour homework assignments (he takes a sense pride in how difficult they are) and exams so long it's almost comical. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: This class was really hard. Pugsley isn't the best lecturer, & it was difficult for me to comprehend the lessons, even when I read the textbook. He allows students to work on the problem sets in groups, but they're really hard still. Pugsley seems like a good guy, and he made the effort to learn everyone's name, but I was confused the whole time.
He is a great professor: he cares about all his students and answers emails super quick, but he is a little hard grader and unclear with rubrics, so getting the high grades is not very easy.

Dr. Bartolini is a great professor and even better person. He took the time to help our group outside of his regular office hours. He definitely cares about his students. Take his section if you are able to!
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Amazing professor. Very kind and relatable. Gets to know students well and definitely cares about them.

EG 10117 is an awesome class and taking it with Dr. Bartolini makes it even better. He's caring, funny, accessible, and always respects the many problems first-year students might encounter. Grading feels a little bit tough sometimes compared to other EG Design professors, but it's honestly ok for the amazing time I had during class.

I had Professor Bartolini for Engineering Design 10117 and I could not recommend him enough. He's the director of first-year engineering so having him as my professor was so nice, as I formed a personal relationship with him. If you can, try to get in his section because it was a great class.
Best prof ever
The best professor for first year engineering. He wants you to succeed.
Great professor who clearly cares for the success of the students both inside and outside of the classroom.

An amazing Intro Engineering professor because he helps you navigate Freshman year, and gives you life advice about things like how to fit academics and the football schedule together, and the best study spots. Beloved by students.
best professor ever!!

Super nice guy and cares so much about his students. The enthusiasm that he brings to class every day is really contagious. He is always available to help outside of class and it's clear that he wants us to find the same love for engineering that he has. If you have the chance to take him for freshman engineering classes you definitely should!

Andrew is an amazing professor, I had him both semesters for Intro to Engineering. Everyone who took his class before wanted to again. He is very clear and puts in more time than he is required to because he really wants you to learn. He gives a lot of detailed feedback and responds to feedback about his teaching. He is a real gem.

While she is a really nice person and very knowledgeable about genetics, her lectures were so dry and monotonous that it was difficult to stay focused and pay attention. That is tough when you need to go to class to fill out the notes from the PowerPoints. Had Prof. Filchak for the first half of the course and he is way better.

She truly cares about the material and knows a lot. She connects it to real life which is good. However, her lectures are disorganized and don't usually make a lot of sense. There are few outside resources and she forgets sometimes that we are learning the material for the first time. Overall, not a great lecturer but a nice person.

Absolute shit show of a class. I think I actually got stupider from her power for life module. Not one coherent sentence came out of her mouth the entire class. Her slides were more disorganized than anything I've ever seen and I had to rely fully on AP Bio knowledge to survive this class. Please don't take this class.

She's not so terrible as people make her out to be. I took her module, did average work, and got an A. The final was exactly what she put in the study guide (although it was quite long). Her lectures can be confusing sometimes because they don't follow a clear outline. Some of the topics were pretty interesting and she's a really sweet lady.

She's a super cute old professor but is absolutely terrible. Her lectures are incoherent and disorienting. Nothing made sense in that class, not the lectures, quizzes, exams, or any of her grading. I'm extremely thankful I only had her class for half of a semester. The only plus was that there was barely any homework.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: I had her for the power of life, and it was one of the worst classes I have taken here. I never knew what we were learning about or how it all connected. It made no sense as a course. The grading was off because we would have group problem sets and we all got different scores with the same answer. DO not take! I put her down as my last option too.

Romero-Severson taught an interesting Module for Biology... for about half of its duration. After the first 6-7 lectures it kind of fell apart and I didn't really know what she was trying to teach me. The class is interesting, though, and not too difficult.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects--Lecture heavy

comment: I took her for my Biology I module and it was the worst class I had all semester. I don't even know what the course topic was on. She has very unclear lectures and even harder tests. I stopped studying for tests because I didn't even understand my own notes. She's a very sweet person, just a terrible professor. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects

comment: Prof. Romero-Severson is perhaps somewhat charismatic. However, as I took her Bio I module on the power of life I truly suffered through this class as it was never truly clear what she was teaching about. Although she is extremely passionate about it she often goes on into different tangents. Perhaps this class somewhat negatively affected my GPA.

Prof. Romero-Severson's lectures were not very clear and the course content was not at all cohesive. I could not tell you what I was supposed to learn in her class. She was not responsive outside of class and would only email me back after I sent her several emails. The tests and quizzes were difficult despite her lectures not teaching anything.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Graded by few things

comment: I took system genetics and genomics from her. The class was difficult, but it was fun to listen to her teach and to engage in conversations with her. She is incredibly smart and opinionated, so be prepared for a lively discussion if you disagree with her, which is encouraged.

Fred's exams were a lot easier than other coding professors. They were on paper and we got 4 sheets of notes. He was a nice and helpful guy, but with flipped classroom you're mostly on your own. TA's took off a lot of nit picky points on assignments/notes, and sometimes I failed the outside of class quizzes but still ended with an A.

Getting used to the flipped classroom took some time. Lessons are done outside of class and challenge problems in class. Sometimes I felt that going into class I knew a lot about the lesson and others I didn't. But he, or the TAs will help you figure it out. He is a very nice person. He'll only guide you to the right answer, which I think is better

Profesor Nwanganga is a great professor. The flipped classroom did pose a challenge at first, but you get used to it really quickly. TAs are always available with a session almost every day of the week. Furthermore the lectures are incredibly engaging and entertaining. A true pleasure to be in this class.

Flipped classroom, you teach yourself and have class as lab. Can be difficult when you need help, he wants you to find the mistake first, but good way to learn. TA's sometimes nitpicky, take off points if you spell one letter wrong in a variable. 2 exams on paper with cheat sheets. Gave extra points on the exam for a course evaluation question.

I would recommend taking Prof. Nwanganga because although the class is extremely difficult, it's not his fault. The flipped classroom is really hard to learn from if you have zero experience in coding. Prof. Nwanganga gave us two opportunities for bonus which definitely helped my grade.

Professor Nwanganga is a really nice guy who knows his stuff. However, the flip classroom is difficult to manage, especially if you've never coded before. I think the problems with Fundamentals of Coding are more so the structure of the class than him, but still, he could be more helpful at times.

Professor Nwanganga is a very kind man. The structure of the class was flipped, so I did not interact with him a whole lot during the semester. I actually enjoyed the course with him and learned a good bit about coding. He wants to make sure you actually understand the content.

Flipped classroom: learn online, practice in class. Sometimes doesn't answer questions to "let you find the mistake." The professor doesnt make or break this class, the amount of effort you put into it does. Fred is very kind and organized. I used TA's as resources outside of class and they were great. Im sure Fred was too, i just never went to him
-good class but taught primarily online where you essentially teach yourself

I went in thinking coding would be hard, but this class is not bad at all. Labs were helpful and we always checked over at the end to make sure we got a 100, and homework was not bad at all (only 1-2 hrs per week max). Only meet once a week and had one exam in total which were bonuses. Really improved my coding skills as well.

I loved Professor Nwanganga. His class made me switch my major from Accounting to Business Analytics. He is super kind and the class was not very difficult. One thing I will say is he isn't always straight forward when answering questions in class. I did meet him after I took the class to talk to him more just about BAN and he was super helpful.

Professor Nwanganga is a super nice guy and encourages group work and participation, and I found the class interesting. However, I feel that the administration could do a better job with the layout of the class overall. The flipped classroom setup implied that students really have to teach themselves, which was difficult as the class progressed.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects

comment: The class only met once a week because of the flipped learning format (you do all of the pre-reading and tutorials before class and then do practice problems in class with your group members). Weekly quizzes are open-note and you go over the in-class problems together. Professor Nwanganga is very willing to help you, you just have to ask.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Loves to help students if you need it. Class is solidy difficult.

Hes alright. Has a very vibrant personality but hes a ex- marine and will make fun of you if you say a wrong answer in class. The class itself wasnt too bad. Only met once a week, but good amount of weekly homework. Only one test (online, open book/note/Google) at the end worth 30%.

Professor Seachris is passionate about teaching, so it motivates you to learn. His classes are interesting, and he is very caring and patient, and really wants you to learn and question like a philosopher. I learned a lot in this class, I would definetly take it again. He's great!

Professor Seachris is a fantastic instructor who genuinely cares about the well-being of his students and their personal and academic development. He Tries his best to keep class interesting with group projects and interesting discussions. There is a lot of reading, which you should do for your own personal development. Overall, great professor.

Prof. Seachris genuinely cared to form a relationship with each and every student in our seminar. Though he is a tough grader at times, he enjoys the course content and conveys that to his students. His class is enjoyable and thought-provoking.

Professor Seachris is an amazing teacher and facilitates discussions so well. He takes the time to get to know each student and is very straightforward when it comes to feedback. If you can take his First Year Seminar, would highly, highly recommend.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Seachris was AWESOME. Best teacher I've ever had and made the class genuinely interested in the material. His positive energy is infectious.
it was a pleasure to be a part of his class. He is a very understaffing and caring professor.

If you have the option to, definitely take Prof. Seachris for the gateway seminar. Aside from "The Meaning of Life" focus allowing us to have incredibly interesting class discussions and readings, Prof. Seachris is a great guy in general. You can tell he has a true passion for the subject, and he makes a real effort to get to know his students.

Prof. Seachris will give you the best philosophy intro you can get anywhere. If you can take this class, do it. Readings are very accessible and very interesting, quizzes and papers are all fair, and you get as much out of the class as you put into it. Always looked forward to going to class on Tuesday and Thursday mornings.

Professor Seachris is one of the kindest profs I've had. His USEM gave us a good overview of core philosophical issues but didn't require rigorous homework/discussion. If you want a good but easy class that double counts for philo and a USEM, take him! However, if you're looking for more of an intellectual challenge, I would choose another course.
Great professor, really makes you think hard. Very interesting class, amazing guy, take him.
Amazing professor that really cares about his students. Class was full of interesting discussions. Readings were mostly modern philosophers, and pretty short / clear.

Prof. Seachris is a great choice. I had him my freshman year for my Philo USEM and it was relatively little work and also very interesting. There are weekly readings that are used in class and weekly take-home quizzes over the readings and class discussions but they are super easy if you do the readings. Two longer essays at the midterm and final.
Dr. Seachris is a captivating lecturer, empathetic teacher, and a good man. If you can, take his class.
Such a great professor who cares about philosophy and how his students are doing. A very kind person in general. Good material delivery.

Tests are pretty difficult. The problem sets are impossible. He wasn't willing to give me points back on multiple questions when I was off by less than 0.01 because he thought it wouldn't make a difference.

Professor Leady seems like a great guy, but I HATE his class so much. I'm a finance major and I study for at least 20 hours for his tests just to get an awful grade. The tests are impossible and the graded problem sets are super tough. I would recommend anyone taking finance to avoid this class at all costs. Take Ackermann or someone else.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Not as bad as older reviews say. Exams were not as difficult as before. Lectures are not exciting but he communicates material well. Does not give a lot of homework. Solid option for intro to finance. Do not feel like you have to take Ackermann.

Leady's class wasn't as bad as other reviews said. Material can be dry, but he tries to make class engaging and cares about his students. Problem sets are difficult, but help you prepare for exams, which are short but reasonable. Make friends in the class as you can work together on problem sets, take advantage of office hours, and you'll do fine.
He changed the class. Tests are now fair. He is nice guy, available in office hours, and he records classes so you can always go back and review.

Jim is a great teacher for Finance. I love being in his class and his teaching style to be very clear. The exams are also not too difficult or complicated. If you understand the problem set, then the exam should be fairly straightforward. There are also some online hw assignments which you get multiple tries on, so those are good grade boosters.

Professor Leady was very difficult. I do not recommend his foundations of finance class to anyone. This was my first class in the business school and it was not great. The tests were incredibly difficult and the problem sets were extremely hard. Did not learn much.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The class can be hard but he really cares about his students and wants to help. The problem sets are pretty difficult and it really helps to work with other people in the class. But the tests aren't too bad once you understand the problem sets. It definitely requires a good amount of individual effort to understand the material though.
Tests are very difficult
Don't take his fundamentals of finance course unless you are really genius. His problem sets and exams are harder than other professors'.

Jim's class is very hard. He has 3 hard problem sets and 3 hard exams. On the first exam, before the curve, the average was a 65% - unacceptable for a business school exam. He is also kind of a jerk and is not very helpful in answering questions and problems. He is also very inflexible with due dates. You have to read the textbook to do well.

I am not exaggerating when I say that only 7 people of a 50 person lecture attended class. Lectures are frankly pointless to attend. He starts problems that he is unable to finish or just shows the other professor's solution on the board without explanation. You will have to teach yourself the material, but he is very nice and understanding.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: The material itself for this class is not particularly hard, however, Sapirstein's lectures are unbearably boring and not helpful to learning material. He is a poor explainer, puts people to sleep, and feels disconnected to the students. Most of your learning happens in tutorial.  Just do your best.
Nice guy, not so great lecturer. Occasionally had him as a sub--wasn't worth showing up to lectures on those days.

His lectures were hard to follow and very boring. I stopped going to lectures halfway through the semester and just focused on doing the readings and going to my TA's office hours when I had questions and that worked better for me. He is very understanding and helped me a lot when I got sick during the year.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Great guy, smart guy, awful professor

Prof Sapirstein is genuinely a nice guy and extremely smart, but he is a poor teacher. He uses pre-prepared slides that provide the basic concepts but no relevant examples. Most of what I learned came from the textbook and working homework problems. Class is graded on a bell curve and exam scores are very high. 96 was an A-

Cannot teach. At all. He is clearly passionate about physics, however the slides, practice problems, and all other material for the course is written by someone else. It often has mistakes, and he assumes you know more than you do. He is a good physicist, but a very bad teacher.

Great guy but not a great professor. He uses lecture slides from another person, notation for equations is brutal and hard to follow. He seems genuinely excited about physics but cannot articulate it in any shape or form that is understandable or exciting. Would not rec. for students with little to no physics experience in h.s. I got a B with a 90%

the class was an absolute joke because he pretty much gave us the exams beforehand in the form of practice exams. the averages on the exams were all super high, which would normally be fine, but the class is graded on a bell-curve. The final ended up being the only thing that could actually be used to differentiate grade cutoffs
His lectures don't make sense and he assumes you know more than you do. I did not learn anything from him and relied solely on the textbook and what I already knew.

Sapirstein has an extremely monotone voice so it is almost impossible to not fall asleep in his class. He is also primarily a researcher because he isn't good at conveying information properly. He gives a massive weekly assignment that is due on Friday nights, which doesn't make any sense, there's no reason to not give us the weekend to finish it.

I wouldn't recommend this class to anyone. The curve is so bad in this class that a B or B+ is in the 90s. The class is 50% group based so if you are put with a bad group at the beginning of the semester you will not do well. She talks about herself half the class and is not a good teacher.

Daily homework was manageable readings. Lots of group work but she gives very clear grading criteria so follow the rubric and you'll get an A on those. The final exam was absolutely atrociously hard...she does it on purpose so she doesn't have to curve down at the end of the semester. Study very hard for the final and you'll get an A

Professor Hollis is truly one of my favorite professors on campus. The exams for this course are pretty difficult, but honestly, I would take BLAW II (I think its an elective for accounting majors) as an elective if I could because it was that interesting.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Prof. Hollis is a good professor, but the class is heavily group-project based and can often feel unfair. There is definitely an expectation that you do the readings for the class, which are often boring and long. There's nothing bad about her, but ultimately did not find the class interesting or fun.
Great lecturer but lacks a clear grading rubric in some regards. Class is almost entirely group projects with a lengthy final exam.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: Prof. Hollis was a fantastic teacher for both business law and management competencies. Attendance is very important as well as participation, but if you show up, pay attention, and raise your hand once a week, you should be good to go. She shares a lot of entertaining stories and class is always fun, so I highly recommend her for any class.

Professor Hollis is the best professor I've ever had. She is so charismatic and kind. Her passion for entrepreneurship is evident and she makes everything seem so interesting. She is always available outside of class and super opened to talk about anything. I wish I could take a class with her next semester. She is truly iconic!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: I absolutely love profesor Hollis; however, her tests are merciless . To get an 'A' simply read the assigned text. Of course, you'll get tempted not to read them , but seriously, eat up the texts for breakfast, lunch, and dinner because the test questions are straight from the readings.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Made me drop the entrepreneurship minor, a really stupid class all group projects and I did all the work only to get shafted in the grading. Tests super annoying

Hollis is a nice conservative teacher who has so much experience and expertise in this area. She knows the cases and concepts like the back of her hand. However, she has obligations to many ND classes and therefore does little of the grading herself. Your grade comes down to your TA. She is great, but I wish she would be involved more directly

Prof. Hollis was an awesome Professor. She uses lots of examples and stories to easily convey the material, and the class always seemed to fly by because it was so entertaining. The grading criteria is clear, and she gives you all the tools necessary to succeed. She keeps students engaged while teaching and truly wants them to succeed.

There are only a couple grades given out throughout the coursea midterm, a paper and the final but her lectures are interesting and helpful. Need to be at class though, only allowed two i excused absences. Overall a really great lecturer. Would definitely recommend.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Inspirational--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: She's a tough grader, and there's mandatory attendance with two unexcused absences allowed. The grade comes from a midterm, a contracts paper, and a final, and attendance. You can go to a different section of her class for attendance too.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Campbell is such an interesting, funny, and engaging professor that I'm being honest when I say I looked forward to his lectures. On top of that, he gives amazing study guides for the exams. Out of any intro level course I've taken, I think I learned the most and gained the most interest in a discipline from this one.

Prof Campbell has really interesting and engaging lectures. Does random attendance checks but not a big worry since going to class is interesting and only 50 minutes. Class is not too difficult, he gives you the questions for the midterm and final.
10/10 take Keeping the Republic

This was my first POLS class and I loved it! Good lectures and prepare for all the dad jokes! You have to read before every lecture but you can get away if you attend the lecture. He was very accommodating. For workload was not bad, only answer a question every week, write two papers, one midterm and one final exam.

Professor Campbell is one of the best at ND. His Religion in American Politics class is quite interesting, and the assigned reading is engaging. The class is not too difficult, and he has a few fun projects throughout the class. He also gives out prizes which is a fun part of the class. Definitely take it if you can!

i LOVE professor campbell. You can get away with not reading, as he explains everything pretty well during lectures. He gives the short answer exam questions beforehand, so there is really nothing to worry about when it comes to getting a good grade in the class.

The professor is great. He's a great, passionate lecturer who keeps the class engaged. My problem is the content of the class. Keeping the Republic is the most useless, dumb introductory course I have ever taken. They teach to "keep the republic" while advocating for eliminating the electoral college and assigning the 1619 project as a reading.

great lecturer but really overrated class. Isn't easy by any stretch and his TA's are genuinely grumpy people. Campbell is overrated too because he doesn't care about meeting students or giving reasonable grades.

Really cool/great guy. did random attendance checks, but attending class should not be an issue because he keeps it very fun and interesting. There's quite an amount of reading that you have to do for every class, but it's very interesting. tests are very straightforward,just going to class and taking good notes can go a long way. 10/10 recommend!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Going to class was like being on a late night TV show.  Campbell is awesome.
amazing prof
No Comments
really cool prof, always has engaging lectures and awesomely bad jokes
Tougher class content-wise but Prof. Urtel did a great job teaching the content, answering questions, and running through examples in class.

Professor Urtel is great for accounting 1. The material itself is somewhat challenging, but he does a phenomenal job teaching it. He is a very caring teacher, and he tells a lot of jokes in class. I would definitely take him for accounting if you have the chance.

I don't think it matters what Prof. you take for ACCT 1. All put homework/reading before class and read presentation slides verbatim of what the textbook taught. Homework is fairly time consuming if you really want to understand it. 

Urtel is hilarious and there were points in class where it was absolutely comical. Perfect for having fun in class.
I had never taken accounting before and had to teach myself every concept in this class by the book. By far the most difficult class I have taken. He is funny and a nice guy but not a good teacher.

The class was all asynchronous. You must teach yourself every concept and do the lessons ahead of time. Class time is to briefly take up the homework for the class that you complete before class, and you will be randomly called on. He is nice and caring, but the structure is difficult.

Urtel is a relatively good lecturer who tries to keep the class entertained. He is very chill and understanding if there are any conflicts or problems. I just wish the homework was worth a portion of our grade because there was a lot assigned.

Great professor that is knowledgeable on the material and makes the class very interesting. Exams can be difficult but if you put the time in to do the hwk, readings, supplemental videos, kahoots, and take notes/attend class you can do good.

-1 group project with 3 parts spread across the semester
-midterm and final exam
-hwk is not graded
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: Prof. Urtel is an absolute gem! Accounting I is definitely very difficult, but if you put the effort in, you can get a good grade. Prof. Urtel is definitely there to help you along the way, and he's there for his students outside of the classroom too. He also gives an inspirational quote before every lecture!

This class is hard, but Professor Urtel explains everything well and gives a lot of great resources. It's a lot of reading, but he works to make things interesting and answers all questions. He connects with his students and was really understanding when I came down with the flu on exam day. A really great professor for a really difficult class!

Accountancy I is hard, but Professor Urtel makes the classes enjoyable. Make sure you listen in class and do both the graded and recommended homework. Some days he just lectures and on other days it's lecturing + going through example problems. He cares about students and sometimes hosts panels where he invites alumni to talk about their careers.

Do all the hw before class or lectures and examples won't make sense. He really values and notices participation and effort. (Participation is graded) Tests are open note and online but decently hard. Gives a really time consuming group project that other acct profs don't give. Gives great career advice and will help you out if you ask.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Group projects

comment: Professor Archie was my favorite professor this semester! She is super sweet and does a very good job explain the concepts. It is clear she is very passionate about her module and overall she is great! While the quizzes were graded toughly, overall she sets you up for success in the class.
She is very passionate about her research and what she teaches and works hard to make it very clear what the expectations are for each assignment.

Prof. Archie's lectures are very straightforward and interesting, but her quizzes...not so much. She's a tough grader on the quizzes and you really need to study to get exactly what she's looking for. Can be a bit passive aggressive and picky with where students sit sometimes (do NOT sit in the back row on the first day).
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Archie's bio module is fairly interesting. It is also easy compared to most of the other modules you can take. She's a very nice person.

Experienced prof. with extensive research experience. She is very kind and has passion for the subject. The course module is out of 100 points, so each quiz question you miss is essentially a percentage point off of your module grade. I wish there were more opportunities for points, but this must be addressed by the department. But she is great!

Professor Archie is kind and approachable. She introduces content in an interesting way. She is not overly hard, but definitely grades appropriately. I had her for the biology of morality module for intro bio, it was definitely my preferred module compared to the other one that I took. Workload totally manageable.

I liked Prof. Archie. Super nice and material was definitely very interesting. Did a really good job keeping in mind some people had not taken a bio class in 3+ years. Her module is definitely easier, and with the way BIOS 10171 works, it could screw you over if you get an A- and then struggle in your next module. Archie is super nice tho. 10/10.
Professor Archie is super sweet and makes an effort to help all students succeed. Her notes are clear, she requires minimal work outside of class, and her quizzes are relatively easy.

Dr. Archie is an amazing professor. She is very willing to listen to everyone's ideas and is understanding when something is difficult. Even curved an exam when it was too difficult. Lectures were interesting and homework was manageable and helpful to the class.
Loved her. She always made lectures very interesting and I never got bored in that class. She is very kind and understanding and answers emails very promptly. Amazing as a prof and person

Was a very interesting class and is made better as she is a good lecturer. Gives HW but was very manageable. The quizzes are easy especially if you pay attention in class. The class is only worth 100 points though so it is important to do good on every assignment. Overall it was a great class though love her and her work

I cannot recommend Prof. Blanchette enough. She is very caring. She wants you to do well, but you must take the initiative to go to her office hours and put in lots of effort. She is incredibly knowledgeable, and you can tell she enjoys teaching. You must be precise with your language as she is a harsh grader. The quizzes are easy if you read.

Professor Blanchette is a great teacher and truly cares about the philosophy she teaches, and she wants her students to truly grasp it. She is a tough grader but gives great feedback on rough drafts and makes sure students emphasize precise wording. The seminar is very engaging and not overbearing with work. Great professor and great class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: She grades very rough on papers. Philosophy requires very precise language because of its broadness. If you do not say things the right way or miss a part of something, you will lose points for it. She started the year with small readings but progressed to longer readings. The two papers are heavily weighted. Proofread everything very carefully.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--So many papers

comment: I absolutely love Dr. Blanchette. I struggled in her Formal Logic class, but she was always happy to help. She understands that logic can be hard to grasp, so she is super supportive and really wants students to be able to learn the material.

She's an all-around excellent professor. She is highly accessible outside of class and gives great explanations for difficult topics. She is impartial in grading, selects fascinating readings, and keeps class moving at a great pace. She also lacks the arrogance that many professors have. I recommend taking her class if given the opportunity.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: As a philosophy major, Blanchette has been my favorite philosophy prof so far! She has high expectations and takes her students seriously. Her lectures are clear and she does a good job of answering questions. She also encouraged everyone in the class to dig deeper into topics they found interesting. She's a fair grader and gives great feedback.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: You'll get out of this class what you put into it. If you are willing to do some work, Prof. Blanchette will move mountains to make you into a better thinker and a better writer. She's caring and wants to see you succeed--and will spend a great deal of her time giving very detailed feedback on your work to help you. Also, the discussions are great!

Professor Blanchette was one of the sweetest professors I've ever had! She gives lots of feedback if you ask and is so generous with her time. Definitely don't be shy about asking to meet with her or about sending her emails. She's really nice.

She has high standards for essays. You must have very clear, concise writing on difficult topics. Her feedback is very detailed and specific. There is a lot of reading, and most of the lecture was spent walking through the papers for better understanding (which was very useful!).
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: For someone who didn't expect to enjoy a philosophy class, Professor Blanchette really kept me interested.  She is a tough grader and has very high expectations, but she is always willing to help and give feedback.  The readings can be tricky, but the discussions in class are interesting, clear, and thought provoking.  She explains concepts well.
Professor Blanchette is a great professor. She is very fair, very clear, and very supportive. She gives good feedback on papers, and leads an interesting discussion in class as well.

Prof. Blanchette is one of my favorite professors. She is the clearest teacher I've ever had. The work load is totally manageable, and she provides helpful comments and feedback on quizzes and papers. I learned a lot about speaking and writing concisely and precisely. She also really excited my interest about philo and math. Awesome professor!

Seelinger is a great person overall, one of the best professors I've had at Notre Dame. He makes a clear effort to know each of his students on a person level. I had him for Intro to Design Thinking and the material was kinda boring but he was clearly passionate about it which made lecture somewhat interesting. Pretty easy to get an A in the class.
Good guy, tough class. Not much else to say bout this one.

I was struggling with my mental health my first semester, but Seelinger was truly understanding and caring. Do not be afraid to reach out. He seems to enjoy teaching first and second years as he loves to seem them grow.  He also loves making connections with his students. #ourengineeringfather
He's a genuine guy and really loves his students. Would recommend to any engineers getting there feet wet at ND!

Seelinger is an awesome man. I've met with him outside of class for lunch to pick his brain and for advice, and he was so helpful. He always has great advice and takes care of his students. However, for Mechanics II, his tests were extremely difficult. Do the S problems and pay attention, it's important. Great teacher, but very tough class

Seelinger is one of the chillest professors I've had. Homework is easy, lectures are usually engaging and are only dull when the content is, and the group project wasn't easy, but it was pretty close. He tells great stories, is very learned in engineering, and a good guy overall. 10/10 would take again.
great guy, very easy going and wants you to learn. the class is pretty easy so if you can take seelinger, go for it

Prof. Seelinger is carrying the AME department. He is purely a teaching professor and it shows; his presentations and lectures are finely tuned learning bombs and he might be the most accessible professor on campus. No free As in his class, but there is never a bad learning curve nor do you ever feel alone in tackling the material.
Prof Seelinger makes a genuine effort to get to know and support students. Best Intro EG prof out there.
He is just the greatest. Takes really hard material and makes it much easier to understand. Really cares that you understand what is going on. Best professor I have ever had.
If you want to know the material and understand it, he gives you every opportunity. Available outside class a lot, nice and interesting lectures. Great guy overall.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Amazing lectures

comment: Doesn't care if you learn. Funny guy but disinterested in teaching.
he made chem intresting.
Awesome professor!
Funny guy.  Made CHEM bearable.  Sweet Scottish accent... sweet curve on tests.
He's a lot of fun, and really nice.  Also gives really nice curves on tests.
Great and funny guy.  Very entertaining if you can stay awake.
No Comments
He's a funny guy and has a wierd Scottish accent.
No Comments
He is a cool, funny guy that keeps it interesting.

An extremely hard teacher. I took both Systems and OS with him and both impossible. The workload was crazy and his classes definitely become your main source of focus/stress. He assumes everybody is a computer science wizard already and is not good at building the foundations.

GREAT Professor. My GOAT. Can't have enough words to describe how grateful I am to take his classes. Definitely a hard class but excellent Professor. Please go to lectures and do the HW on your own as much as you can. You will learn A LOT from Bui's class and they are really helpful for learning the fundamentals of CS:)
Prof is a great teacher and very knowledgable about the material. If you go to lectures, pay attention, and do the homework yourself, you'll get a good grade.

Professor Bui is an AMAZING teacher. His exams are really tough, but at least in his earlier courses (Systems Programming, Programming Challenges, etc) he offers extra credit, and if you do the extra credit, you have a really good shot at an A. Take him, and then DO THE EXTRA CREDIT! You won't regret it.

Very good at making topics interesting and explaining them in an understandable manner. The class was challenging, but he puts you in positions to succeed while also always being available to answer questions and help.

Idk why I'm doing this cuz everyone know's he's goated. Accessible outside class -- will slack you at 1:00a if you need & has prolly 10 office hours/week which isn't counting tas. Great lectures, people say his teaching is like "osmosis" cuz what he says goes right to ur brain. Not sure how true that is cuz the material is hard, but he's awesome.

Bui makes being a tech nerd cool. Genius, funny, and helpful at all hours. His grading system is fair but be careful about exams! they are out of 60pts and impossibly hard even with them being open notes. Every 10ish points lost will drop you ~ 1 letter grade but you can miss 3 of 13 hws which are easy and the 4 group projects are very doable.

Has to be one of the best CS professors in the country - explains things so clearly, is unbelievably smart, and is almost always online and available to help with HW questions. Really funny too. I actually get excited to go to his lectures. Systems is a lot of work and the exams were very hard, but he provides opportunities to get As in his class.

Bui is one of the best profs in the CS department. While his classes are extremely difficult, the way he teaches makes you want to try your best. He's hilarious and cares so much about helping you learn. His exams are impossible but all other work is easy to get good grades. Would recommend!!

Systems is the hardest class Bui teaches and the exams are pretty difficult. OS & PC are both easier (PC easiest). That being said, Bui is the best prof I've had and he is so willing to support his students. His instructions are super clear and it's easy to get 100% on all HWs. He cares about you as a person outside of class and respects your time!
Actually one of the best professors in the department.

Definitely prof you want for coding. She is super nice and enthusiastic. Homework is light but do it well as it comprises a good chunk of your grade. Midterm exam is pretty easy. Final was much harder (but not unfair). Don't worry about the curve.

Not much work considering class only meets once a week. No surprises on exams. Very nice and approachable. However, grading guidelines for tutorials and labs are not clear and can vary based on the grader.

Duan is pretty good as a coding professor but the content can get tricky if you don't stay on top of it. Lots of free points but also higher grade ranges so not as easy to get an A. You don't do much in class and the content is largely self-taught.

Very fair and fun course. The bulk of your grade comes from homeworks, online quizzes, and two Exams. Collaboration is necessary for the quizzes (I did them all solo, and got an A- because of that). Exams are fair but a time crunch. Duan is such an amazing woman who really cares about her students. Definitely take her, she's absolutely awesome!

Foundations of Coding is not a challenging class to teach. She has an accent, which makes her difficult to understand. She also does not have clear grading criteria and will deduct points from your coding assignments if you do not answer the questions exactly as she wants. The teacher DOES NOT MATTER as much in this class.

Duan is a great teacher for coding. She is very caring and wants everyone to do well. If you go to office hours, she will help with the weekly assignments and explain the concepts. There is also not too much work in the class. Duan also gives great lectures and goes over the main concepts for the week. Open notes for exams and quizzes as well!

Duan is THE one to take for coding! She is very caring and helpful. Highly recommend going to office hours frequently because she will answer all your questions if you show effort towards starting the problems. Coding has a lot of work but it balances out with the fact that you only have class once a week. Exams and weekly quizzes are open note.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Duan truly cares about her students, she makes an effort to get to know everyone, and encourages you to ask questions. Although the content of the course can be difficult, if you go to her/the TA's office hours and put in effort, you will be fine. I had no prior coding experience, but did well. Duan is one of my favorite professors.

Duan is a kind and caring professor. She knows our names and wants everyone to succeed. She is attentive to everyone's questions. She patiently answers questions until you fully understand. She knows how to teach Python well. She is always there to help. I enjoy participating in her lectures which helps me to fully understand the material.
Hardest class I have taken at ND so far.

Professor Duan is very caring and accessible outside of class. Her office hours are a great resource. Graded for completion of tutorials, labs, and quizzes. With her help in office hours and class, the tutorials and labs are easy grades. Quizzes were take home, 5 questions in 5 minutes.

This class is in a flipped format, so you meet once a week to review the assignments that were due in the prior week (Meet on Thursday to review the work from last Friday-this Thursday). Overall a good teacher. Very accessible and helpful outside of class. The tutoring sessions are really helpful if you get stuck on the assignments.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Cross is a fantastic professor and a great choice for your Philo1. His lectures are engaging, clear, and oftentimes funny. Don't bother buying the textbook or doing readings as they are explained in class. The discussion group was helpful too. The 3 exams were manageable with quizlets provided and minimal studying. Highly recommend!

This is the intro philo to take if you are just trying to get the ND requirement filled. Sticks to basics and grade is off of 3 exams. I didn't read a single page of the textbook and missed lecture quite a few times. Just rote memorized everything night before exams. Required attendance discussion sections on Fridays were helpful with the TA.

Cross is a really great guy who loves philosophy but gets sidetracked in lectures really easily. However the class is nice because it is not hard and the study guides/quizlets provided ensure a good score on the exams, which are not difficult. Discussion sections on Fridays help you to learn the materials as well. If you can't take GGL, take Cross.

Professor Cross is a great professor who makes philosophy extremely interesting. He is a unique character and gets side tracked quite often (but in the best way possible). The philosophy 101 class is really easy, with a bit of memorization, as it is fully based on three exams throughout the semester.

I went into this class assuming it would be an easy A given the other reviews, however, I along with the majority of the other students were left confused with the grading criteria of the exams. It is assumed the exams are easy but the entire class is surprised after the rubric is super strict and specific.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: The whole grade is based on 3 exams, he said 4 but he canceled the final which was nice. Great guy, if you are not good at memorization this class might be a little tough, but manageable.

To me, philosophy is pretty boring but Prof. Cross makes it much better. He makes lectures entertaining and teaches you all that you need to know. Tests are easy, and our class did not have any papers. Highly recommend!

Prof Cross is hilarious and will get side-tracked more than any other. He loves to talk to the class and trade stories. But he also loves the class and teaches it very well. Grades are based on three essays but if you takes notes on what he does say on philosophy you'll be fine.
Awesome professor! Super nice and understanding. Teaches Philosophy very well and keeps the class engaged. 10/10

Professor Cross is one of the funniest people I have ever met. He lectures every class but will get sidetracked and tell the most random stories. The course is super easy to understand if you attend class, and the course load is very light. He's not a harsh grader and will keep you heavily entertained; I wish I could take him again.

Philosophy readings can be technical and hard to understand, but Prof. Cross does a great job explaining what's going on in the readings with good explanations and sharp British wit. Grading is pretty much entirely based on a few papers, so the key to doing well is coming up with a good argument and being able to defend it. Watch your grammar, too.

Professor Cross is an excellent professor. He is a stickler on grammar in grading, but he is willing to work with you on this. He gives engaging lectures and knows his subject well. I would definitely recommend him.
Prof Martin is great! If you go to class and pay attention, you will easily end with an A. This class really opened my eyes to theology and made me excited to study more!
Can i give this guy more than a 5? He is definitely one of the coolest professors I've ever had. Super nice, super helpful, super chill
v
rating_tags: Group projects--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Jay Martin is a chill cool dude. Lectures could be a bit boring sometimes but he had great insights. Graded on 3 papers (he isn't a harsh grader) and 2 exams. You'll be fine on exams if you review his lecture slides and go to class. He also gives study guides and clearly cares for his students

If you want an amazing Theo 1 prof, take Jay Martin, no competition or argument. Put in effort for work, do ok in exams, come to class, and you will most definitely pass or probably get an A. Two exams that he makes a study guide for, mostly based on lecture slides, that he posts on canvas. He also practically leads you to the answer on tests.

-great lectures but slides are text heavy
-graded by 3 papers, in-class group labs, a midterm, and final
-caring and personable professor
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Martin is an angel. He gives great lectures and his study guides are very helpful and actually has what's on his exams. The exams are straightforward if you read the notes. He's very understanding if you are sick and doesn't mind if you skip class. Would 100% take him again!

Prof. Martin was great! His lectures can be a little dull at times, but he genuinely cares about his students and is so passionate about theology. The assignments were super fun, and were closer to creative writing projects rather than a normal essay. This is a great first theology! He is a super lenient grader and is very understanding.

Professor Martin is amazing. He understands that life as a college student can be overwhelming at times, so he is very compassionate when setting deadlines for papers.
