His lectures were very easy to understand and he went over all homework material in class. He is a little bit of a hard grader and his jokes are a little corny but he is a great professor and a good reason why I like engineering.
Super funny and available outside of class. 10/10 would recommend

Prof. Smith is a great professor. Excellent clarity of communication in lecture. Accessible outside of class. Gives really positive and helpful feedback. Facilitates group work. Funny guy, would take again.

Lapsley is great! Class is relatively easy and straightforward. Tests are very much aligned with the lecture and reading material. No homework, just reading, but the textbook is actually pretty interesting and enjoyable. Must do very well on each of the exams to get an A (as opposed to an A-) though.

The content was extremely easy BUT the tests are impossible to pass unless you memorize his slides word for word. He even admits this. Good luck memorizing every word from 200+ slides... For ex: the tests are all MC but all the answers are like the same with a few word variations and you have to pick the one from the slides.

Dr. Lapsley is a great professor. While lectures aren't mandatory, they make up nearly all of the test material. Make sure you study the PowerPoints and the vocab words from the text he assigns, and you're golden. He is a super relatable and understanding guy, and I would recommend him for any psychology class.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Amazing lectures--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Lapsley is one of the best professors I have ever had at Notre Dame. I'm currently taking this class, and he is genuinely such a wonderful person and a great teacher. The material is pretty self-explanatory in many ways, but reading the textbook helps a lot for lectures, quizzes, and exams.

Took his Child Developlment course in the fall of 1989. Great experience. Dr. Lapsley gives a great lecture. Informative class. He was always available to answer questions after class or in office hours. I still remember enjoying his class thirty years after taking it. The fact he is still teaching shows how much he enjoys it.
Incredible professor, definitely take his developmental psychology class! There's no homework and he's a funny guy

Professor Lapsley is one of the best professors I've ever had. I took his Developmental Psych class and it was one of the most interesting classes but not overwhelming at all. His lectures are engaging and he's pretty funny too. He assigns no busy work, all you have to do is study for the exams. It's easy to get an A because he's a great teacher.

Professor Lapsley is one of the best professors I've. He is a really nice, fun guy and lectures are enjoyable to listen to. Not too difficult and you can tell he cares about what he teaches. Loved his developmental psych class.
She assigns so much work due at end of semester do not take
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Super interesting course and not very difficult, especially for a science course. 100% worth your time.

she offers a ton of extra credit - if u want an A u can get it. u can literally look up a summary for the book report over fall break and get a 100 on it; her reflections were due Monday and posted Friday and was A TON of reading and videos to analyze; midterm is fine and can correct for 1/2 back; she communicates pretty fast too and is super nice.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy

comment: Prof Goodson was not necessarily bad for Big History it's just a ton of homework for people who aren't used to the content. If you r looking for ur Glynn science credit j take it.its not that bad. Goodson is low-key funny but lectures get tiring and nothing in them matters..midterm is entirely problem sets; the reading for reflections is INSANE btw
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy

comment: Lectures can sometimes be a bit bland, but Dr. Goodson has a real passion for her class. While Big History can sometimes seem a bit foreign, she always does a great job to foster understanding. She is oftentimes unknowingly funny, so lectures keep students on their toes. I would totally recommend to Glynn students seeking their science credit.

Professor Goodson is not a great professor. Trying to get a hold of her on email is difficult, and she is very inconsiderate with student's time as she sometimes wouldn't post the homework until a night before it was due. She also assigned a book to read over break which is not cool. The class isn't difficult, but it is needlessly annoying.

My BIGGEST issue with Dr. Goodson, and I emailed her a few times about this during our class, was that she posts homework at the very last minute. The weekend assignment of three HOURS of lectures and 50pgs of reading was always posted Saturday or Sunday, so getting ahead was never an option. She is highly inconsiderate of students' time.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: She was my only option for a required course, Fundamental Principles and Biological Processes (aka Biochem). She treats lecture as a "review of what you read in the textbook," aka "I will fly through this stuff and assume that you're already familiar with it." You also must be present so you can answer her polls, and it counts as participation.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Todd Adkins was a very good teacher. Always prepared and on time. Lectures were interesting and loaded with information.  Todd also has some great skills for test taking as well.

Adkins was extremely knowledgable about the topic of the class (American Politics).  He made our discussion classes really interesting and was always open to answering any of our questions inside and outside of class.  He went out of his way to help us understand the material.  One of best TAs I've ever had!

He was great at leading discussion and was always willing to answer any of our questions.  He was available outside of class for any help we needed in understanding the material.  Over all, one of the best TAs I have had so far in my college career.

Adkins did a great job relaying what he has learned in the actual governmental fields we covered. Driven by text book analysis and personal experience, Adkins added a new level to teaching. He didn't act like a cocky professor. He understands how to have day to day relationships with students and people. He is understanding and easy to talk to.

Todd Adkins is legendary. Not only does he have real experience in the field, but he's brilliant as well. I was in his discussion section for American Government, and there was never a dull moment. His questions are surprising, thought-provoking, and constructive and he has never once lacked an answer for our own questions.
The discussions were very interesting and engaging, and his experience in politics made his insight valuable.
Great instructor all the way around.  One of the best I've had here at Notre Dame.

Professor Adkins was great!  He made discussion sections a blast and was very thorough and helpful.  He was always available to help when needed. His experience in real politics made the class much more interesting.

Puts blanks on slides so you have to show up to class to fill them in so you have the notes. Goes through material fast, but if you study, the exams shouldnt be that hard. Case studies are easy 100s but dont make up a lot of grade. Exams arent cumulative, theyre weighted equally

An awesome professor! Very willing to help and willing to meet outside of class. She made the class engaging and overall was very nice. The information of the exams was very laid out and there were never surprises. Overall, a very enjoyable class.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: This course was very easy and is a good choice for students who are not science majors. Professor Datta teaches the concepts in a clear and easy to understand manner. She is caring and always willing to help. This course is easier than AP biology. Do the study guides and you will do just fine.

I recommend taking Datta for Biology II. She uses PowerPoints to guide class discussions with frequent and clear examples of concepts. This course is very similar in content to AP Bio and reading the textbook may be helpful at times. Datta offers office hours several times a week and a VERY HELPFUL TA led review session once a week.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Datta, throughout Biology II, provided great instruction through each of the individual units and utilized clear examples throughout her lectures. She provides all of the lecture slides before starting each unit which makes learning and reviewing much easier! She is very personable and, overall, I would highly recommend taking her.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Very easy class, especially if you took higher level Bio in high school. Provides great study material and is very clear with what will be on the exam.

Great professor!! I had her for the second semester of biology and she is AMAZING. Very clear during lecture and goes in depth. I know a lot of friends who had other professors but would skip their bio class to listen to her lecture instead. Definitely recommend!

Molecular Basis of Disease was ten times easier than my high school AP Bio class. Anjuli uses powerpoint lectures and almost all test material is within these. She makes you a study guide sheet to base studying on, and her lectures are easy to understand. It has a high school level feel, and is prefect for athletes and students not majoring in BIO.
rating_tags: Respected--Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Such a tough grader with few opportunities to bring your grade up.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment:
I am in the progress of taking with class with Professor Sterba. Based on the first few weeks, you learn not to disagree with him. 
Lots of reading on books that agree with his political affiliation and additionally, just a few major assignments (3, 5-7 page papers for Sterba's sections)
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Boring class that is dominated by professor's own ideas. Disagreeing with him isn't really an option and there is only a very specific way to see the world if you want to do well in discussions. A ton of readings and discussion posts for every reading. Papers are graded harder than any other class I've taken at ND. B average for papers in the class

Very nice professor, means well. First part of the course is super dry but towards the end it ends up becoming lively discussion. Sometimes difficult to disagree with him, but mostly a productive intro class that was fun and an easy A.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Participation matters--So many papers

comment: Lousy professor, dominates class discussion. Expects everyone to agree with him. Even the Marxists in the class didn't like it.

Upper-level ethics course, basically told the class that if you disagreed with him you were illogical and immoral. Thinks very highly of himself. If you're a belligerent socialist atheist sign up, otherwise your GPA and self-esteem will suffer.

The class was all over the place, he never led discussion. Too much reading for a 200 level course and not enough direction, especially since the class had a lot of underclassmen who haven't properly learned how to debate topics. Frusterating.
No Comments
Ms. Porter is a very nice and kind person. I enjoyed some of the readings and some I found pretty boring. The class is graded on 6 essays you write throughout the year: she's a pretty fair grader.

Professor Porter is an amazing lecturer and teaches a seminar called Love and Sex in the Christian Tradition that is absolutely fascinating.  She looks at the nuance of issues and teaches the course in a way so that all perspectives are given fair treatment, rather than just blindly defending Church teaching as many theo professors at ND do.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: Doesn't know how to grade - similar quality papers graded by other professors I've had were no lower than ~93 instead of the low 80s she gave me. Would have had a C+ or worse if I hadn't dropped it. Avoid
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Dr. Porter is a fantastic professor. I have her for my theology seminar, and I do not regret taking the course whatsoever. I was surprised and sad to see the rating she had on this site as I've always enjoyed her and her class. She's very open to any opinion or perspective. The course is not too difficult- 6 papers and participation.

Professor Porter is a wonderful human being and she sure knows how to foster a worthwhile discussion. The class can be very boring at times, and the readings can be tedious, but the class overall isn't too bad. Basically your whole grade is determined by six papers, and she isn't an easy grader, but she is fair. I appreciate that she is openminded.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Easily the best Theo 1 I could have taken at Notre Dame. Very open-minded, and we had many discussions on interesting topics that I had not considered before. 4 years of Catholic high school, but topics were still fresh. Nevertheless, the lectures could be slow and there was a meaningless assignment each class period to "prove" we did the readings.

Would definitely recommend taking her! She is very sweet and tries to keep things interesting. You only write 6 papers a semester and have minimal other work. Her grading is pretty fair and she is a great professor!

Brilliant woman and delightful professor. I'm a grad student from another school and it was an honor and delight to be in her class. Even though she is a scholar, she seems to enjoy teaching and had great respect for her students.  One of the best I've ever had.  Take Her, ND students.  She is a gem!

Only complaint is that participation is weighed heavily and it seems that most people, no matter how much they participated, received a 70/100. However I emailed him and he changed my grade. Quiz content is not too difficult and somewhat lenient grader on other two assignments.

I don't think the ratings for him are justified. Super kind guy that really cares about his students. He makes lectures engaging and calls upon students in class to help them understand the material. But overall you can tell he's very empathetic, loves all his students, and enjoys teaching. I wouldn't listen to these other reviews.

Dorian was very willing to meet outside of class, but his quizzes were nearly impossible to do well on. They were extremely subjective with multiple answers that made logical sense. The material was not complicated, so it should not have been so hard to do well in a fairly basic class. I also participated constantly and he still took off points.

Speaking of leaders, he embodied the exact opposite of the trait. He truly was one of the worst teachers that I have ever had, not even just at Notre Dame. The first quiz was nearly impossible. I have never had a teacher who was so unhelpful. He spent more time every morning figuring out his outfit than spending time preparing for his lectures.

This class consists of 1 essay, 2 quizzes, and participation. The quizzes were difficult, often with subjective answers. He solicited student feedback, but then ignored it. Participation was random, based on cold calling, and rarely a clear question, and was graded randomly.He tried to connect with students, but failed due to his overall attitude.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: NEVER take this class unless you want to get absolutely violated. The two quizzes are absolutely heinous and most students received sub 50% on participation despite regularly contributing in class. Even the smartest people got violated

There are two quizzes in this class, both brutally difficult with 5 answer multiple choice in which 3 of the 5 basically mean the same thing. The final paper is not discussed at all in class, worth 40%. People who participated every class got 50% in participation. It's extremely frustrating and very unclear.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: There are two quizzes in this class, but they are more like tests because they account for over 40% of total grade. Teacher didn't prepare us well for the quizzes -- when students asked for quiz review materials, he said he was too busy. He is a harsh, unfair grader and will cold call in class with hard questions. Doubt anyone got an A.

exams are sneaky hard even though you will feel prepared, he doesnt really care about you and relies only on cold calling for participation. his questions are super vague and hard to answer because they are basically statements. dont take unless you hate yourself
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Management seems kind of pointless, but he was a fine teacher. I would say that reading the textbook is more beneficial than paying attention in class, as the materials on the midterm and quizzes can easily be found there. Three group projects/presentations, but they're manageable. No final. The class is easy so watch out for the curve.

I was so glad I had Corcelli freshman year. He was very clear and did enough examples to make sure I understood things without belaboring the point. He clearly cares about his students and wants them to succeed even in what is slightly considered to be a weed-out course freshman year. But seriously, Corcelli is great and the best gen chem prof IMO

One of my favorite professors ever. Hilarious, energetic, and really really cared about making sure that we learned things. Made a tough subject like chemistry more understandable. Would 100% take again (wish I could've taken his class 3x instead of doing physics for two semesters).

This man is the BEST professor for Chem. He is clear during lectures and gives lots of examples. He is also extremely charming. I highly suggest going to lecture, because then you don't even have to read the textbook to understand.

Great professor, definitely would miss him when I finish the semester. Very accessible after class too, I was having troubles with Chem the first few weeks of college. He helped me improve my grade, and send me an email to congratulate me on getting an A on my next exam. Hilarious professor, did a self-carving pumpkin experiment in class.
This man is a saint... if you have the chance to take any of his courses, you are blessed! Not only is he an amazing teacher but hes hilarious and just an all-around great guy.
He's an absolute monster. Always brings the energy and made gen chem bearable. Complete goat
His lecture are fun and he has a great southern accent.

Love this man. Gen chem is ND's biggest lecture hall but Corcelli really cares about his students. Right before class he always just looks so happy to be there. After his lectures my section usually had applause. He tells jokes, keeps you interested, does fun demonstrations, and explains things clearly and understandably. He's accessible too.

I took his young adult novel course and loved it! In addition to being a fun class with fun readings, we also had very good discussions of important topical issues. Felt like the work load was reasonable and he had fair expectations for papers

Took his Young Adult fiction class and LOVED IT! The class had a really fun and up-to-date reading list of YA novels. We had such good discussions and I was truly excited to write my final paper for the class, which has never happened to me before.
Take his class! Was amazing!
I took this class spring of 2013 and it is easily one of the best classes I have taken at Notre Dame in my two years here.
Such a good course. I would highly encourage anyone to take WR with him if you can. Great class discussions, and we watched fun movies too.
Truly an excellent teacher. Take his class if you can!
His assignments are sometimes challenging and very time consuming but overall I really learned a lot in this class. He is fun and very helpful. Visit him during office hours, it helps!
This class helped me so much as a writer and thinker. I am so grateful for having taken this course - it was also really fun and had great discussions!

By far the worst prof I've taken. He incredibly mean and narcissistic and lacks basic communication skills. Emails either go unanswered or receive condescending replies. He believes students should magically know everything without proper teaching....Avoid him if you value your mental well-being and want to actually learn. Not sure how he got hired

Professor Rose was very interactive with students, and he made the lectures very engaging. His assignments were very thought-provoking but not time-consuming, and each exam had practice exams which contained many of the questions on the actual exams. Overall, a great, personable professor that did not complicate the course.

I think Prof Rose gets a bad rap based on other reviews. I took him for Cognitive Psychology last year, and I really thought he was engaging, funny, and fair as a professor. He lets you drop your lowest exam score and he also offers 10 points of extra credit and EC questions in exams too. Give him a chance, and don't immediately trust other reviews

This class seem really easy but then you get into the exams and absolutely bomb your grade.  Then when you go to office hours he condescends your study habits and makes it seem like you had horrible habits that barely got you into Notre Dame.  The class is hard, powerpoints are confusing and the only good part is the TA who leaves nice comments.

I don't have a problem with him as a person, but he's not a good professor. He expects you to know things not taught in class and does not explain things well. I was excited about the class (Intro to Cognitive Neuroscience) but it ended up being the worst one I've taken at Notre Dame. DO NOT take a class from Professor Rose.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: Condescending to students when they ask questions that they "should already know". Seems too busy outside of class for meeting, even when you do manage to schedule one. Tries to relate to students occasionally, but just leaves everyone confused and on guard. Dry lectures, would not recommend.

Socially awkward. Wants good reviews rather than genuinely being a good teacher. hilarious that he has one positive review thats clearly him writing one for himself. Who does that? condescending at office hours too

Keeps the information up-to-date. Makes his lectures interesting & usually has things in there that help keep your attention - adds jokes & funny videos into class. Very knowledgable about psychology - is active in his field. Has a great policy for tests (4, drop lowest) & holds many review sessions (will go over test Q's also).

Dr. Jensen is hilarious, and a very kind person. He's super smart and really funny, and while I really enjoyed his class I can say it is not for everyone. The grading criteria isn't super clear and the lectures can be a bit hard to follow at times. However, he is an interesting professor and a genuinely nice person.

Dr. Jensen is a genuine professor who cares about his students far beyond the scope of the classroom. He is incredibly intelligent in his studies of Chinese philosophy and culture. I would highly recommend taking his class to any student regardless of their interest or knowledge in Asia.

Limited Canvas usage/grades, group essays, 100+ pages/wk
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Group projects

comment: Unknown grading criteria. All feedback the whole semester was positive, 100%. Somehow ended with a B+. Syllabus was not complete by the start of the semester. Cold calls on people in class. Expected us to meet requirements not specified in his assignment. Readings can reach up to 100 pages per week. Are all the readings helpful/necessary? No.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: Disrespectful and unorganized. Touches students without consent and makes crass comments about appearance or ethnicity. Very little social awareness. Lack of organization makes assignments/readings hard to navigate and grades are pulled from thin air.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: This class is entertaining, but there will be no grading criteria whatsoever. It wouldn't be a big deal if everyone made an A, but I made a B+ both semesters, and I'm not sure where my grade came from. The class is also very unorganized, so if you like order, don't take it. However, you will trauma bond with your peers, so that's a semi-plus.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Really funny but not for everyone. If you're someone that likes structure, this class will stress you out a lot because it is extremely unorganized, and you'll never be 100% sure about what the homework and expectations are. No assignments were graded the entire semester, yet I didn't get an A so not entirely sure what it was based on.
funny

USEM with Dr. J was a great class. He is so smart, knows interesting facts about everything, loves to teach, and above all loves his students. SO FUNNY- you won't regret taking his class. He puts less emphasis on grades and more on learning something new and engaging in something interesting.

Okay the ratings for Professor Gresik are just not fair. He is a difficult grader and teaches difficult course material, but that's just because he's very informed and knowledgeable in his field of study. He also takes his class very seriously (which is good!), so for him participation in his class is very important, and that's understandable.

Smart guy, probably knows his stuff. Seems like a good person. Exams are difficult - seems way more concerned with having a low class average than whether students are actually understanding content. Lectures are extremely boring. Don't take.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Extremely unwilling to help. Attending to his office hours is useless. Totally agree with the person below that says that you leave his office feeling demeaned and lost. He makes everything personal and it is extremely vindictive. His lectures are outdated. Textbook will teach you different but he only accepts his method.

Extremely unwilling to help. Despite attending his office hours multiple times, I received little useful information and left feeling demeaned every time. His exams/homeworks are designed to trick students and despite putting in hours of studying, I was told that I needed to put in more effort. I have never felt so discouraged before.
i took this class like 4 years ago but i had to get on here to warn everyone about this nutjob.  he puts a copyright on each of his powerpoint slides, that's really all you need to know.
What an absolute waste of time!  And what a shame!  The classes don't need to be as painful as they are.  I want my money (and my semester) back!

Horrible, horrible class.  I completely agree with the other person that he pushes his views on everyone. He is a vindictive little man who cares little about whether students learn and more about making himself look smart.  Oh, and the class average on the last exam was about 40%

Instead of teaching economics, Professor Gresik frequently teaches 'How the world should operate according to me'.  He's not a terrible teacher, but his attempts to push his views on the students is very annoying.

DISCLAIMER: This is not hyperbole, this is me being nice and PG for y'all.
This man is tenured. He is tenured because of his extensive academic research, not his teaching. He lectures by reading off a 400 page note document that's over a decade old. His exams demand a complete understanding of material. 48% average on the final, 10% failed class.
His passion is very clear. He is strict on grading, particularly harsh on exams. This class should be taught with delicacy.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Just one more account to make sure you really get the message. If this man was not on tenure surely he would be let go.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: All lectures solely consist of him monotonously reading off notes. His passion for thermodynamics is very clear but it can get in the way of effectively teaching students who are new to the topic. The grading is consistent insofar as practically zero partial credit is given on exams, which make up a drastic portion of one's grade.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Weird guy, like a clinically odd obsession with the topic of Thermodynamics. You would think from this passion he would inspire students to learn, but the lectures are like watching paint dry. Read the notes.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Very passionate about Thermodynamics, making the class more bearable. Reads off of a rewritten version of the textbook for the entirety of the class. Grades are a set curve based off class rank, and the tests can be tricky without tedious preparation. Lectures interesting and helpful if you listen rather than read the board.

His Thermo class is very difficult. This class was high effort, and his tests were very difficult. HOWEVER, there are many things you can do to make it easier, and his advice for this class carries over to others. Reading the text he gives you, doing practice problems, and just being invested in the material all make this class doable and rewarding

All he did during class was scroll through graduate level notes and the textbook, briefly explaining each thing as we went along. We never did any examples, and the homeworks were horrible because of that. I've heard he's not horrible for Thermo, but I am avoiding him at all costs from now on.
Pretty good teacher. I didn't pay attention in class and barely did the readings and still managed a B. Papers are graded kind of toughly by TAs.

The class depends entirely on your TA who does all the grading...the papers can be hard but no one does the assigned readings, and reviewing the lecture slides (posted online) is enough to do well on the final
makes class intersting and explains tough material pretty well.  only a couple of assignments per semester.  just pay attention and class is not hard.
Hard class and really boring, but the prof is extremely funny
He does a good job of making the material understandable with interesting (and often hilarious) examples.  It wasn't an easy class, but you do get a good feel for the basics of philosophy.
Hilarious teacher.  Tough subject.
cool guy, fairly hard class
She is a wonderful teacher, however, philosophy was really boring to me. If you are not into it, it can be hard to wake up for it as an 8:20. Do not recommend the 8:20.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Prof. Rodriguez is a very nice lady however she tends to just ramble in lectures and is the type to put paragraphs on ppt slides. When it comes to tests and papers, not a lot of total work but her grading scale is not very clear and it's one of those classes where you could sink hours into a paper for a B. I would recommend GGL over this class.
The papers are harder to write as freshman first semester but the exams are easy.

Assigned readings but she goes over everything. Go to class, take notes, and everything will click. Three essays, one is optional, and she drops the lowest grade if you do the third. Mid-term and final are easy but memorization-based. No excuse why you shouldn't ace. Don't do it if you want an interesting class; do it for an easy class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: ABSOLUTELY take her class. She goes over every reading so you can clearly understand it, so don't worry about the reading complexities. 3 papers, one is optional, only highest two grades count. Midterm and final were easy. No hw. The easiness is due to how simple and understandable the class is despite lack of work, and her charisma!

Professor Rodriguez is a great philosophy teacher. The examples that she gives during lectures help you understand the material, but also put me to sleep more than once. The essays aren't bad as long as you give her a good amount of original thought.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Professor Rodriguez isn't an amazing teacher, but she gets the job done. She tries her best to be accessible outside of classtime and she really takes the time to help you understand the concepts. She's acutely aware that you're probably only taking the class for credit, yet she's very understanding and helpful.
rating_tags: Participation matters--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Montalbano forces you to go beyond understanding the "what" to understanding the "why." He is tough on his students and when he thinks you are giving him a nonsense answer he is unafraid to call you out on it. He treats you like you work for him and pushes students hard to become the best versions of themselves they can be.

Montalbano is a character. Participation matters a lot, but don't get down if you receive a bad initial grade on participation because there is still a chance of doing well in the class. Prepare a lot for the final and you will do well. Meet with Montalbano early on in the semester. Case studies and a group project make up a lot of the class.

I took Professor Montalbano for Foundations of Strategy and I learned a lot from the class, participation matters a lot, be prepared to contribute in class unless you want your grade to suffer. He's a very unique professor, be ready to adjust to his methods and try to have fun in the class. Be prepared for somewhat vague assignment descriptions.

(Found. of Strategy) Montalbano's class will shock you at first. Make sure to carefully read the syllabus. He is a personality, but the case-based learning and group projects will teach you very valuable information about business. Make sure to ask questions and be very respectful with all emails and interactions with him. He is your "boss".

This class WILL put you outside of your comfort zone but it is worth it. Professor Montalbano will question every statement you make and push you to genuinely think. His teaching style may shock you but it has helped me learn so much about business. I highly recommend taking his class if you want to see what the business world is really like.

My favorite professor so far at ND. His real world experience and emphasis on discussion help you take away A LOT from the class. Challenges you to think differently than typical mendoza student Pretty funny, very real dude. That combined with his ability to relate to students makes discussion interesting. You will actually enjoy going to his class

Professor Montalbano is a great professor. His professional experience really shines through in the classroom. He provides clear examples during his lectures that make them engaging. The class is not that difficult if you put the work into it. Participation is necessary to succeed. There is also a group project worked on throughout the semester.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment:
Professor Aprahamian is a good person. 
The course is challenging for non-STEM majors especially if you didn't succeed in HS Chem/Physics due to the complex calculations you'll make. 
Lectures are long slides and aren't clear. 
Practice tests and exams don't coincide. Topics on the exam are practically a surprise. Lacks communication w TA. 
AVOID

Prof. Aprahamian is a very sweet person, but do not take Radioactivity & Society unless you are confident in your background in science (specifically physics/chem). There is a lot of math involved that a lot of students weren't expecting, and the practice tests are not the same as the tests. The TA and professor also don't seem to communicate much.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Concepts of Energy and Environment: straightforward class that was informative about energy and climate issues. Three midterms which were not too challenging, one final 10+ page paper and presentation. Pretty lax grading criteria and semi-weekly HW assignments. Prof. Aprahamian is well-respected in her field and knowledgeable on climate issues

Gave us too much excess material in slides that we were never tested on. Practice exams looked nothing like exams given. Questions on exam were extremely ambigious and could have had multiple correct answers but she would only take one.

The class itself was easy but there were constant things that were unclear. She never seemed to know what would be on the exams and didn't organize the class in a way that made it easy to be successful. The homework assignments sometimes had difficult calculations that we didn't go over in class which was pretty frustrating.

Earth Focus: She is a super nice lady and definitely overqualified to be teaching earth focus. The class was relatively easy and focused more on concepts around climate change than actual science or math relating to it, she had a really hard time communicating with students about assignments, we never really knew what was going to be on exams.

Earth Focus was a very easy course, but the assignments and lectures get very boring and repetitive. She teaches some very insightful things on the science of climate change. She is extremely overqualified to teach the class as a nuclear physicist. There is a disconnect between her and students as science majors cannot take the class.

Vollon is a super nice and caring guy. He was fair with homework and often took out problems that students were struggling with. There are only a few homework problems per unit and not much work outside of class (besides studying). He details what will be on exams very clearly and that saved my grade tbh. A bit boring in lectures. Would reccomend!
Consistently had higher class medians for all exams compared to other professors classes. Clear instruction and guided problems. Definitely take him.

A great option for Foundations of Accounting. Does a great job of not only teaching the material but also working through examples in class. Really cares for his students and has one of the most organized and complete canvases I've seen. Makes sure you are adequately prepared for exams.

Vollon is a caring professor, but his class can be a bit boring. He could be a bit unorganized at times, but I think that was mostly because it was his first semester teaching. He is available at office hours if you ever need help. Class is mostly graded off three big tests and a couple group projects.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Accounting as a class is boring as a whole, but Vollon is very caring and helpful outside of class in office hours on demand. Be aware of Mendoza curve. Very generous with grades, curves, and projects when it comes to issues that arise. Incredibly understanding.

Review the provided videos before class and you'll be fine. The main value of going to class is working through in-class exercises with him. This was his first semester so he'll probably be better for future classes. Also you'll be lost the whole course if you don't get the first two chapters so lock in early.

Homework is optional and not graded. Lectures are very boring as well. Not a lot of energy or participation in class. Two exams and one final. They are somewhat easy and the Mendoza curve usually helps in this class. There are better accounting professors at ND in my opinion, but not a terrible one to have either.
Very nice guy who cares about his students. Lectures are straight to the point which can be dry, but he is effective at teaching. Grade is mostly based on the exams but there are group projects, too.

Could not imagine a better professor for this class. Super relaxed and understanding, but also makes sure you are actually learning. He also makes sure his classes are fun (and literally apologizes if topics are boring). Sad I will not have him again. Cinque stelle!

Vivirito is a fantastic Italian professor. He is hilarious and genuinely cares about his students' success in his class. Homework is for completion, not accuracy, and he gives you the opportunity to correct your mistakes on writing assignments as well. Great guy and professor overall.
Best teacher at ND - take his class.
I took the 6 credit Italian course and he was the best!
Awesome guy who really loves the language and to teach. Very approachable and will always be willing to help.

Patricio is the man. Seriously. Take his class. He is awesome. He's entertaining and really nice. More than willing to help anybody do well in the class if they are willing to put in the work. He makes class fun. Take him if you can.

This teacher is very helpful when it comes to studying.  He is more than happy to answer any questions you have about his class.  A little slow on getting papers back but overall a really dedicated teacher.  He loves his students and is takes great pride in his work.  TAKE THIS CLASS!!!

Love this guy. He can be a bit monotone but he's awesome. Relatively light grader, goofy, and genuinely cares about the class and students. Most of your time will be spent doing readings, most of which are very interesting but can be long. Would definitely recommend the class though.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Prof Battin was great! Lectures were sometimes a little boring and he talked a lot but he really cares about his students and wants everyone to succeed. Would recommend this class.

Super easy A. We had no exams, just a midterm paper, final paper, and small group project. There are two or three articles/Bible passage readings and quick response on them for every class, and these readings can get super long but you're fine if you just skim them. Easy class, but just really boring and not engaging so lectures went by slow.

Professor Battin was really kind throughout the semester, I took it during COVID times so it was an online class for me. There were only a few short essays, reflections, and a final paper. LOTS OF READING! The class was super easy but very boring. I don't know if I would necessarily recommend this professor but it is a very easy A.

I don't know that I would necessarily recommend Professor Battin's class but he's really sweet who knows a lot about Theology, there's short daily homework with 2 papers and 1 project. He's a really easy grader so it's an easy A and he actually cares about his students, he just doesn't engage the students so it's really boring. Not terrible overall

lots of readings and a daily 'paragraph/question' homework assignment, but super easy grading. No exams, only a midterm and final paper, creative writing assignment (which is fun), and an easy presentation with a partner
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: life-changing course

Go to class and you will learn SO much. He makes learning fun. He's super available for meeting/emails. Sometimes when you ask for help, he will make you feel like an idiot but thats because he is so smart AND his sense of humor is just like that. I seriously learned so much and I loved it. From my experience in ML if you miss a class youre behind!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Don't be fooled by his 5-star rating. Thurk's class is VERY challenging. If you are not an economics major or really into math, I do NOT suggest taking this course. Very math-based with multi-variable calculus. Very, very approachable and is willing to move due dates if his students need more time. I really enjoyed the content and learned a lot

Jeff was funny in ways I doubt he meant to be, and that helped alleviate some of the content that we focused on. Honestly, if you are able to take derivatives you should be okay in the class, and I found the homework solutions to be vital to my success. Make sure you do the work and go to class but if you do that I'm sure Jeff will work with you.

The class itself is really challenging but Professor Thurk was great. 3 midterms + the final (lowest midterm dropped and all of them are heavily curved and you get a cheat sheet for each one). He's a really nice and funny guy and made the material as enjoyable as possible. He's accessible and helpful during office hours as well. I'd take him again.

His entire course was designed on his experiences as an adult in the workforce. This sounds great in theory but in reality this was too challenging for econ students that have barely, if any, introduction to statistics, coding, and econometrics. There's no use a textbook, not enough online resources, ask him for help and he is vague.
Had him for a data science/python class. Imagine having a professor with the mediocre teaching skills of an econ professor combined with the superiority complex of a CS professor.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: Thurk made the class really interesting. He made sure to connect the theoretical concepts to empirical examples. Some of the problem sets were tricky, but he was accessible outside of class. The tests are pretty close to the practice ones, but there were a few twists that I was never prepared for.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Gao's notes are hard to understand and he rarely writes words. I found myself having to watch youtube lectures after each class because I basically understood nothing from him.

Professor Gao is a very direct and concise teacher which makes learning complex material, such as organic chemistry, much easier. I would STRONGLY recommend that, after each lecture, you should go over the lecture material and ensure that you understand the topics at hand thoroughly. In this class (regardless of professor) it is easy to fall behind
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: I took him for Orgo 1, and I thought he did a good job at teaching. Orgo is hard, so no matter who teaches it, so be warned, but Gao was clear and comprehensive. He also did practice problems that helped see what the reactions did in real time, instead of just doing a powerpoint. Whatever you do, MAKE SURE TO DO THE EXTRA READINGS
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: Better than Helquist
Nothing can be learned from his class.

Professor Gao often says in class he fears that his students take away nothing from attending his lectures. His fear undoubtedly became true for myself and the rest of the class, maybe except for a graduate student in his own research group.

He is the worst professor ever. He has strong accent. Its very hard to understand his words. He treat student never equal. He never give student time to ask. His smile makes people uncomfortable. He is stubborn.

Great professor! He genuinely wants you to do the best in his class and his feedbacks are specific, easy to follow, and super motivating! He does not only give feedback on how to improve your work, but he puts in the effort to commend you as well. He is also very understanding with absences and late submissions. My favorite professor!!!
great professor, really makes you want to produce your best work
Very cool professor and is a very reasonable grader. Tries to add humor to the class which is much appreciated early in the morning. Easy A.

Prof. Schepers is THE BEST! He really wants you to succeed, and he'll respond to emails within 1-12 hours (even if you email him at 2 am...). His feedback is very thorough and motivating, and he encourages you to discuss the readings in class, so do the homework and come prepared! He gives you every opportunity to earn a good grade.

professor schepers is a gem. great teacher. i've missed class a few times & he's been super kind about it. as much as i don't really like english/writing, i'm glad that i'm in his class bc i've learned a lot about becoming a better writer. homework consists of reading a couple of chapters/an article & then sometimes writing a short response.

My favorite professor yet!! Literally the nicest person ever and is always available on email. He cares about his students so much. Multimedia writing and rhetoric was super easy and he is always super understanding. If you need an extension for a paper he would probs give it to you. Literally best writing and rhetoric, take this class if you can!

Great person overall. Such a nice soul and is very willing to accommodate. There are 5 or so essays for the class but they are very manageable. Homework is relatively low demand. Would highly recommend taking this class for the Writing and Rhetoric requirement. Our class was small however so it'd be difficult to skip class without him noticing.

I LOVE THIS WOMAN. Not only is she a great person, she is a great professor. She was extremely insightful in both sociology and the actual writing part of the class. If you are looking for a USEM, take Mim. The topics of the class were pretty interesting on their own, but she made the whole class laugh at least once per class.

THE BEST! Literally the kindest, nicest and most amazing professor I have ever had. She is so smart and her classes are super engaging. Also, she really cares about her students. I wish I could take a class with her every year!

I had her for Criminology. She is deeply passionate about the subject and about conveying it to students. Tests and reading reflections are easy. Final papers was slightly harder but not by much. Fun class, athlete-heavy.
I love Mim for a discussion heavy course, but sometimes the lectures can be slightly hard to follow. She cares so much about her students and will do anything you ask for. She is truly the best.

Mim is one of (if not THE) the best professors at Notre Dame. She is laid back, understanding, and clear about her content. I've had two classes with her actually, and the class structures were pretty much the same: homework question once a week, 3 exams, and a paper due at the end of the semester. She has made me excited to learn, which says a lot

Mim is literally the best. She is completely understanding, if you ever are going through something and need an extension she'll give it with no complaints. There's a good amount of reading, but if you listen during the lectures she covers most of the material so if you pay attention to the lectures and don't read as attentively you'll be fine.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Mim is a very nice professor and does care a lot about her students. However, the lectures are incredibly dry for criminology. Lots of black text on plain white slides for 1 hour and 15 minutes twice per week. It's hard to sit through at points. Tests are fair but the paper due in the middle of the year really kills when there's little direction

Had her for macro. Sweet lady, but badly organized class. Consistently wasted time in lectures, causing her to skip through tons of slides and material on the exam. The tests weren't too difficult, as long as you learn the material she glossed over in lecture. Relatively easy A, but not a quality class. Homework assigned is also irrelevant.

Professor Flannery is kind and available outside of class to help. However, her class (Macro) was incredibly uninteresting, unorganized, and she often struggled to get through the lectures. Because of this, you are forced to self-teach before every exam, often on content you weren't able to go over during class. Avoid her if you hope to learn.

Super sweet lady. Lectures aren't super interesting but are very informative. Intro to Macro with Flannery is an easy course as long as you pay attention in the lectures. She definitely wants everyone in the class to succeed and tests are straightforward.

Dr. Flannery is an above average teacher. She is such a sweet lady and really cares about the students, and loves the material. Her class is pretty easy, with little work and simple tests. Her lectures can get a little stale at times, but she still makes you learn the material. Would greatly recommend her if you need a macroeconomics teacher.
Great Lecturer. Extremely Helpful. Difficult Tests.
Simply put, she's an amazing individual.
Extremely boring, tests are hard. Avoid at all costs and take a different professor

Election 2024 was a super cool class until the election, then it felt kind of repetitive for the last month. Layman is a laid back guy who cracks some late-night comedy at the beginning of every class, and isn't the hardest grader. Tests were very manageable for the most part, and the papers were tons of fun to write. Readings are kind of optional.
one word: King. I love this man I learned so much in this class and genuinely enjoyed it. 3 exams + 1 essay. the powerpoints are the exam so if you're good at memorizing you'll get an A

Prof. Layman is a really great professor overall, and he's super funny. Would definitely recommend him. That being said, Intro to American Politics is basically just a repeat of AP US Government, so it's a super easy class for anyone who took that in high school. Unfortunately, that means that lectures are pretty boring for you as well.

Professor Layman is a nice guy (and also quite funny), but I found his class extremely boring. If you know anything about American politics, this class will be super easy for you. I constantly was bored from this class and had little motivation to go to class (although I did go). Go to the discussion sections, as they take attendance.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: Prof. Layman's class is slightly difficult but he is actually really funny. He will give you good feedback and equip you to use the things you learn very well.
honestly the tests were the worst because they were always the most obscure and specific questions that aren't talked about in class. It's not a hard class but it seems pointless
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: You don't really need to go to lecture, but you should definitely go to discussion sections because those count for credit. Although if you go to his lecture, you'll definitely enjoy it. He's a hilarious guy and starts every class off with late-night political comedy or memes.

Professor Layman is awesome. He starts each class with political humor and lectures are informative but easy to understand. Though his TA runs the Friday discussions, Layman is always available to meet and discuss your work.
Just an odd man.
he does teach fast, but compared to other profs it seems like he teaches the "why" a lot more while still providing examples too. i can visualize in 3D better after having him as my prof too

Professor Edelen is the best Calc professor I've had at Notre Dame (from Calc I, II, and III), but the bar is admittedly incredibly low. He is very fast responding to emails, and is great about answering any questions you have in class. He does tend to overexplain concepts that aren't integral to the exams, but he usually prefaces it.

Nicholas Edelen is a good guy. One thing he lacks is control over a class. People will talk and he'll try to interject but he just can't. His lectures are fine, nothing too crazy. A bit boring but it's calc 1, you know?

As someone who had already taken calc, I can say that he tends to overcomplicate the material and is quite difficult to understand. In my opinion, he is super rushed and overwhelmed when teaching (and runs over class time frequently). Overall, he cares about his students but most people in the class constantly looked confused.
Many didn't like him but if you're interested in the material he is a very interesting professor. It is true that he goes above the level of learning of most of the students.

Prof Edelen cares a lot about his students' success, but he just goes way over students' heads. Calc 3 does not cover that hard of material but the way he explains it and the abstract, obscure examples he gives confuses most students in the class. I had to look up videos for every unit to understand what we actually were learning.

Overall, way too qualified for his job. His lectures expect that you know everything already and are heavily conceptual with poor explanations (instead of examples). An A is definitely possible, but out of class studying is necessary. Take at your own risk. He's a really nice guy, though, and wants you to succeed.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Don't take this class if you care at all about maintaining a decent GPA. Class material is interesting, but he's gonna tear up your papers with no mercy. His directions also do a dismal job of actually describing what he expects you to do. For the sake of your future, take a different class.

His lectures are long and can be very dull. Readings are also so long. His grading is just extremely harsh and his advice in office hours is always very general so doesn't help that much. He's a nice guy but definitely just wish I had taken nuptial or something else.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment:
DO NOT take science theo and creation: 

-too many readings, colossal waste of time
-zero supplemental material provided to understand readings
-no structure to class whatsoever, never feels like you're accomplishing anything
-not a theo major but so so SO repetitive and monotonous

Would not recommend, please try to avoid if possible
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Worked super hard and still got an A-. He gives a ton of readings and does not grade easily. Assigns BOTH exams and papers. Exams are hard to study for because he is unclear about what will be tested. This class is very hard for students who do not have a solid Catholic background. I DO NOT RECOMMEND for a theo 1 course.

Overall he's a good guy and very passionate about what he teaches. However, this class is heavily based on daily, difficult readings that averaged anywhere between 30 and 60 pages. The tests were hard to study for since the questions could be about any reading or topic we covered in class. However, he was a relatively easy grader and seems to care.

The class was very informative. I went to Catholic school K-12 and learned new things in this class. The tests are heavily based on the readings, so make sure you study them carefully. The projects are fun. We had to observe the moon and a specific tree. Prof. Ehrman is very nice and passionate about theology and nature.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Ehrman is a great guy overall. It's one of those classes where it's tough, but you respect it. The class was interesting for me even as a STEM major. There is a good bit of reading and homework, a couple papers and exams, but manageable. Would recommend Ehrman.
I have learned a lot in this class.
Very helpful
inspiring teacher
Very bad teacher at every thing.
No Comments
No Comments
Bad Teacher

Professor Polini is an incredibly intelligent and kind person. Just a fair warning: this class is WILDLY difficult. If you aren't good at math, this will be one of the hardest courses you take at ND. However, Prof. Polini is such a character and makes it all worth it.

Professor Polini gives great lectures, makes the class fun and engaging and is always willing to slow down if it means her students will understand more. She is by far the most accessible professor I have ever had, and will help you in any way you need it. Enjoyed her class so much I'm taking her again next semester!

Professor Polini is very kind and entertaining. She is intelligent and evidently excels in her area. However, I would not recommend taking this class unless you truly enjoy math, and are good at it already. I struggled a lot with the homework assignments, and 70% of the grade is determined by two exams. 
There is a textbook, but it is not required.

Her class was incredibly interesting, but difficult. It completely changes the way I viewed the world and greatly improved my critical thinking. The most rewarding class I have ever taken at this school. I would highly recommend.

I think Polini's favorite thing ever is proofs. That's fine if you like that, but I struggled a lot because I've never been good at proofs. Between her handwriting and accent, I struggled with taking good notes in class. However, she was super passionate &overall I would recommend her - you just need to be attentive and seek help asap if u need it
This professor is absolutely amazing and inspirational. She is super caring and understanding. Be ready to work hard though!

Prof. Polini and her class inspired me to study math. She makes her class very difficult, but if you put in the time and effort, you will learn a ton. Compared to other teachers who taught Introduction to Math Reasoning, I would choose Prof. Polini again without hesitation.

I took Intro to Biocomputing with Dr. Jones and really enjoyed it. He had us read through the lessons before class and had supplemental lectures and practice problems during class. Dr. Jones is approachable, explains the concepts well, and his office hours were helpful the few times I went. If you do all the assigned work it's not hard to get an A.

Class was fairly easy, and mostly covered by AP Bio. The class was online, so it was easy to get distracted and zone out. But the notes were posted afterward for easy review. The tests accurately reflected the difficulty of material taught in class. Group project was frustrating (as are all) due to uneven quality of work but still good for review.

Dr. Jones is great. I've taken 3 different classes from him and gotten an A in each. If you put in the work, you will get an A. He is also really approachable and willing to sit down with you to help you understand any of the material. I highly recommend his courses.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--GROUP PROJECTS

comment: While Dr. Jones still needs to improve his test writing skills, it's obvious that he cares about his students and about what he's teaching
There is a lot of work, but it's all very worthwhile. He is very available to help students. Class participation is encouraged, and the lectures are very engaging.

Professor Jones is a good instructor, especially for those interested in Aquatic Ecology or the Environmental Sciences. Labs are easy: no write ups and you pretty much just play in the lakes on campus most of the time. Tests are easy and straightforward, everything that's on the tests is in the powerpoints. Friendly guy.

Professor Jones is terrible at teaching.  No amount of studying will allow you to get an A in this class not only because he's so incompetent but because his tests are so poorly and ambiguously written and graded.  Jones himself is an inconsiderate and awkward person, and does not care about students. The lab is also a joke, and a lot of work.
I never understood this man.  Unless you regurgitate his misguided thoughts, you will fail on your papers. I dropped and went on to get "A's" from my other professors.
Very challenging classes.  A keen philosopher who was rarely stumped by a pretty smart class.  Knows his stuff and forces one to think hard.
Hard class.
No Comments

Anti-religion, Anti-Catholic,Anti-deist shouldnt be teaching at Notre Dame.  Should read up on philosophical figures instead foisting his agenda upon his students and putting words in the mouths of long dead philosophers.
No Comments
Very good

This class is structured so that the material is learned PRIOR to class, and thus the class acts as a review session. I really liked that, but it does require participation and a principled student. Even so, Prof. Hanabusa is a joy to work with and is accepting of mistakes, and sympathizes with her students. Take a class from her if you can!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Lovely, lovely professor. It's only my first semester with her and her is already one of the best teachers I've ever had.
Hanabusa-sensei was incredible at helping students learn. Completely dedicated to the class in every way imaginable. She has high expectations and will help you reach them.

She is such a good teacher because she cares so much. She will bend over backwards for you- all you have to do is want to learn and she will meet you farther than halfway. She was one of the best teachers I have ever had.
She is the cutest thing that  has ever lived, and even though Japanese is (obviously) a very difficult language, her teaching style is very easy. I love her.
One of the best profs at ND. She's really nice and has really adorable personality quirks.
Although I have yet to take every class the school offers, I can safely say that Professor Hanabusa is the best professor at Notre Dame.  Possibly the world. At least the continental US.

Professor DeLorenzo is a great teacher for foundations of theology. His lectures are amazing, and I learned a lot through his class. There is not much work besides a test and a decent amount of projects/long writing assignments. His course is not an easy A, but I would still recommend taking it as he offers a thorough understanding of theology.

I took his class for ND Vision (a theological based summer camp at ND where ND students mentor high schoolers) and he was one of the best teachers I've ever had. He grades exactly how you deserve, his lectures are inspirational, and as long as you pay attention and take notes, the midterm and final will be (deservingly) easier than most!

Charismatic and engaging lecturer, and wants to make the class enjoyable for his students. Series of readings and short responses, plus midterm and a final. Tough grader so not a guaranteed A, but definitely a possible one. The theme of the class seemed a little all over the place at times, but you leave the course well-read and knowledgeable.

An engaging and highly skilled lecturer. He really makes the most of your time by packing a lot of information into lectures and keeping the reading to the essentials, and so the class is easier than those of some of the other great Theo faculty while still helping you learn a lot. Definitely don't take Foundations with a random grad student.

I took this class to fulfill a theo requirement, so I wasn't particularly interested in the material. That being said, the class was definitely manageable. There is a lot of reading to prepare for class discussion, but it is fairly easy to do well in class and on papers if you take good notes. Overall a great intro theology class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: The professor has an incredibly difficult course that is neither helpful nor supportive. It is not for the faint of heart and I would highly recommend against it.

Incredibly intelligent and thought-provoking, and wants to help students learn how to think. Very accessible outside of class, and excellent at encouraging students to share their thoughts and at listening to their views. If you're looking to do no work, he's not the right professor; if you're looking to learn, you couldn't ask for better.
Great guy, great Pinterest, I just wish I never had to be taught by this man ever again.

Don't be afraid that the cuttoff for an A is a 97.5. In Principals of Physics he gives extra credit problems on every test and multiple other opportunities for extra credit. The homework is challenging but the tests feel pretty easy. I'm 3/4 through the semester and have a 104% in the class.
Has a very cute dog. Sit next to the aisle and eat beef jerky before class and the dog will come to you.
He's an amazing, caring professor. Although the cutoff is strict, he gives you a chance to raise your grade by 10% at the end of the semester.

Collon goes a lot into the derivations and "why?" of physics concepts. Sometimes lecture feels slow, at other times he goes very fast through difficult examples. Homework is very hard. Tests - pretty easy. No matter how you feel about the class itself, he is a very understanding person. Lots of out of class opportunities. CUTOFF FOR AN A IS 97.5%
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: Really amazing professor that cares a lot about his students - puts in the time and effort to make sure we understand the content, even if it means explaining a problem multiple times in different ways. Very fair and well-respected; tests and homework can be hard but he more than prepares you for them(lots of help available). Great sense of humour!

Was an awesome professor the whole year, really nice guy who cared about us, then turned around and said the cutoff for an A was a strict 97.5%. Recommend communicating more specifically with him about what grade you need at the beginning of the semester so you aren't blindsided.
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Caring

comment: Dr. Mulholland is a wonderful lecturer and really helped me understand the material. She's very accessible outside of class for additional help.

Dr. Mulholland is one of the best math professors that I've had! She is so kind, thorough, and knowledgeable, and she explains everything extremely well. She's also always available to help students if they have problems and she's amazing at answering questions!

If you can, take a class with her! She is awesome, both as a professor and as a person: you'll learn a lot, she is always there to help, and she cares about her students. Would definitely take her again!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Mulholland is so caring and she shows that she truly wants her students to get a good grade in the class. She explains everything in great detail. I could not recommend her enough. I looked forward to going to her class.

Professor Mulholland is the best professor in the math department! If you are taking any math courses at Notre Dame, always register for her courses. She explains concepts so well and is super caring and amazing. She is available outside of class and truly cares for her students. If you need any help, she is always there for you and is so kind!!

Professor Mulholland is by far one of the best teachers I have ever had. Regardless of my grade I feel that I learned a lot and better understand Calc 1 and 2. The structure of the Calculus Exams makes it hard to earn an A but that is for all sections. Professor Mulholland is very caring and gets to know all of her students. Always has office hours

I'm not good at math, but Professor Mulholland's lectures and office hours were IMMENSELY helpful. She is so respectful and kind and helps you work through the problems rather than telling you the answers. I couldn't have passed Calc I (and hopefully Calc II) without her guidance!

Prof. Mulholland is the best Calc teacher I've ever had. Her tests are super fair, and everything you need to know will be presented in the lectures, but exams make up 75% of the grade so don't take them lightly. Overall, an extremely nice prof who wants you to do well in the class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Overall a very good Professor for Calc II. Calc II is a very fast class but Prof. Mullholland teaches concepts quite well in class. Keep up with the homework, study well for tutorials quizzes and especially exams.
rating_tags: Respected--Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: great teacher, not a super difficult class. grade doesn't reflect her teaching - i am not good at math and didn't put in enough work. GO TO OFFICE HOURS!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Clear grading criteria

comment: I am almost hesitant to give him such a glowing review on here as I hope to take his classes again. Guided by the spirit of Holy Cross in a political science/history crossover, Father Bill looks to give his students a baseline foundation not only in history but in analyzing texts and coming up with arguments. Father Bill is THE MAN
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: TAKE FR. BILL! He is a very interesting guy which makes for great lectures. I had him for a seminar and he led very interesting conversations. He also genuinely cares about his students and requires 1 on 1 meetings with him to get to know you. This is something none of my other professors have done. Live, laugh, love Fr. Bill.

Father Bill is AMAZING. And I am not exaggerating. I don't think there was a single class period where he didn't have the entire class' attention. You can tell by his lectures he's an elite professor who has done in-depth research in what he is teaching. An amazing personality and a great, kind-hearted man. He's a MUST HAVE professor at Notre Dame.

Father Bill has the biggest personality out of anyone I've met. His lectures are entertaining and informative, but there is definitely a strong conservative bias in everything he says. Although his lectures have a conservative bias, the readings he assigns are fairly balanced. Show up to class and participate in discussion and you will be fine!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Hilarious

comment: Moderately funny, very convinced of his views and the great dead white men he likes.

There is something to be said for learning Australian history from an Australian. Brilliant, personable man who brought such enthusiasm and joy to every class lecture. He seems to be the type of instructor who genuinely cares about each student he meets. Plus, the video on cane toads is a must-watch.
Great guy, great prof.  Nice to see that there are still some brilliant AND Catholic Holy Cross priests around.  Take his classes.
The class is easy and very introductory, but good for first Theo. I absolutely loved her as a person and teacher. Very respectful and willing to help. Not a lot of work but very lecture heavy
She says little with a lot of words and is not very direct. She lectures every class for the whole period. She is an easy A but not great for learning.

Class is very introductory, so if you aren't very interesting in theology in general the lecture may be boring and repetitive (which was often the case). However, she is very respectful, professional, cares about her students, knowledgeable about the topic, and definitely a great easy first theo.

You need to do the readings at some point even if it isn't right when they are assigned to do well on the tests. However, she gives students study guides and holds review sessions before tests so tests are pretty manageable/easy. The class isn't the most enjoyable, but it's great for the 1st theology requirement because she is insanely positive.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Caring

comment: Professor Cavadini is genuinely the sweetest lady. The class wasn't too difficult but the lectures were pretty boring. It's fine if you're fulfilling a requirement, but probably wouldn't recommend.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Cavadini has been my favorite professor at ND. She's incredibly passionate and eloquent and truly cares about her students, even in a larger class. While the workload was pretty standard for a 4000 level class, she had creative assignments that I really enjoyed. Can't recommend her enough.

While I don't find theology particularly interesting, Prof. Cavadini maintained a positive attitude and was able to keep the students engaged in her lectures. Short reflections before each class (simple) and short essays (average to difficult).

Professor Gilligan was very hard............. but an enjoyable experience overall. His area of specialities is the gender studies with a focus on archetypes of traditional asian females and how they compare to modern Asia and a nuclear western dynamic.

Very great professor; not the best looking guy, but you can't win them all I guess

Professor Gilligan has high standards when it comes to the female body. Whenever we would do poorly and not participate he would punish us severely with tests. He is very passionate about his students learning, he even told us he loved us after only knowing us for a short period of time.

Professor Gilligan was passionate about the topic which made the class spectacular. He really filled me up (with information, of course!) His dress code was somewhat odd, as I had to wear a sundress even when it was freezing cold outside! Overall, extremely satisfying

Professor Gilligan really challenged me this semester. He really wore me out, as the class requires a lot of hands on teaching. I was not expecting Professor Gilligan to be so passionate about this class, but every class session I could tell he loves what he does.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Gilligan really wore me out this semester. He clearly cared deeply about the subject, but I questioned his real-world experience in the field. I enjoyed class, except for the two brutal punishments Professor Gilligan dished out (on test days of course). Ample chance for extra credit.
Professor Gilligan was always accessible after class and the class was very hands-on. Class sessions were long and hard but well worth it. I feel more than satisfied with what I learned.
Prof. Gilligan is a very engaging teacher.
There are a ton of absolutely terrible professors in the Notre Dame math department but S-P is not one of them.

Prefacing by saying that I withdrew, but I urge all Glynn students to not take the second semester without taking the first math seminar. The material covered is very obscure with scarce resources out of the class. Additionally, the material is very proof-heavy, so if you don't have a thorough understanding, it will be near-impossible to catch on.

Professor Schommer-Pries was a really nice guy and always took the time to ensure everyone understood the material. The material was pretty weird, but very interesting and unlike any math class I'd ever taken before. Homework was manageable and tests were straightforward as long as you did the study guide.

Professor SP's lectures were always very entertaining, as he prioritized active learning in the classroom. He always gave study guides before the tests which were incredibly helpful. He was very open outside of class as well. He made an incredibly odd math class somewhat fun. Would definitely take his class again.

SP's lectures were incredibly boring and far too focused on small group work. It reminded me more of a high school class than a college lecture. Grading could be incredibly arbitrary, and the professor was very standoffish.
