Professor SP is a great professor and genuinely wants you to succeed in his course. The homework can get tedious and annoying at times, but just work hard and you will be fine. The class is not very difficult as long as you put in the time necessary to succeed. I would definitely take another class of his. He is a nice guy!
The class isn't very difficult. The lectures he gives are long but extremely in depth. Homework 2-3 times a week. If you pay attention in class and do the homeworks you should be fine.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Myers is wonderful! I took his class simply because I needed a writing intensive and I am so glad I did. He is incredibly caring and provides very detailed feedback that made me a better writer. The class was very close knit and one I really looked forward to. He is one of my favorite professors at ND. Highly, highly recommend!

I absolutely LOVE Professor Myers! Please take his W&R class if you can. He truly cares about his students and is super accesible outside of class for feedback. He responds to emails within an hour (even on weekends). He values hard work and seeing his students become better writers. If you put in the effort, it will be worth it.

He is a great guy with good lectures and relevant, interesting material. He cares about his class, so he's a tough-ish grader. Just make sure to try with your essays and assignments, and you will be fine; he truly cares for the success and well-being of his students. I love him; he's like a dad!!

Professor Myers really cares about his students. His classes are fun, and the small class size encourages a sense of community. He is not the easiest grader, but he likes to see improvement and strong effort. Hard work pays off. I felt like I definitely got better at writing as a result of his class. Would recommend.

Professor Myers is genuinely one of the best professors I have ever had at Notre Dame. If you can, take this class. He cares about his students and really wants to help them learn and become better writers. The skills I learned have been super helpful in higher level classes.

Prof. Myers is a genuinely great guy. His class completely changed my relationship with English- I had always hated it in high school. The course load is manageable, maybe an hour total outside of class every week on top of three papers for the entire semester. He is very understanding and makes an effort to have a relationship with his students.

He is simply amazing!! Please, please take his class. I am pretty sure you are going to love writing after taking his class even if you don't like it right now. He is super sweet, accessible and caring - if you work hard and progress well it will definitely pay off.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: I cannot recommend Professor Myers highly enough. He makes you earn your grade, but he is very accessible outside of class and willing to help out. I genuinely learned a lot from his Writing and Rhetoric multimedia class. He's an outstanding professor, but also just a good person who cares about his students.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Participation matters

comment: Kind yet demanding professor. Utilize office hours to better understand what she wants out of your writing.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: Professor Jarvis is tough but fair. She has a great passion for teaching and it shows.

Prof. Jarvis is helpful and a blast. The French Revolution is her bread & butter, and the roleplay "reacting to the past" unit was fun and a great way to learn "from within" the history. She does a remarkable job correcting writing/mechanics and happily assists students in learning.
PS: Obv. the 10,000 (USEM) course has more writing than 30,000s.

Professor Jarvis is demanding but wants her students to succeed. The amount of material between readings, lectures, and discussions can feel like drinking water out of a firehose, but I felt better for it and that I learned more. She provides the best feedback on papers I have ever received. I was able to grasp historical concepts and trends.

Very hard grader. She usually likes assess you through two essays and three essay tests. The essay tests are on the readings and themes covered in class. Nice person, but you really have to know how to write at a quasi graduate level and meet the writing expectations if you want to do well.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: She was a good professor who clearly cared about the subject and her students a lot. That being said, since I didn't really like the subject, it was a difficult class with few redeeming factors. But if you like the subject of the class, she would be a really good professor.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Even though I didnt want to really take this class, it wasnt as bad as I expected. While she gives lectures every class you arent really expected to know the material extremely well. She does assign a lot of reading and is a harsh grader, however she makes the class interesting and you can tell she is very knowledgeable on the subject.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read

comment: Needs to make a rubric since would suggest certain changes to a paper during office hours, yet after making these changes would receive points off on the actual paper that was submitted for them.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Took Cities and Suburbs as a USEM where the only grades were participation and essays. Very lenient essay grader for very easy essays. He's a great and engaging lecturer who's always prepared for class and knows a lot of the material/information on suburban history really well. I haven't heard as glowing reviews for his test-based curriculums.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: Fr. Stephen the goat. Great lectures, minimal work, clear expectations, this is the History you wanna take.

Fr. Stephen is an amazing professor. You can tell that he really cares about his students and is passionate about what he teaches. The class is formatted more like a discussion than a lecture and participation matters.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Accessible outside class

comment: Fr. Stephen is absolutely amazing! He is a caring and responsive professor. He reduced the page count of one of my papers because I was struggling with my workload. He gives engaging and interesting lectures and is invested in each of his students, and he proves that! I wish that every professor at ND was as wonderful as Fr. Stephen is. 11/10!

I had him for USEM. I loved it. More just discussions than lectures, which made class interesting. Lot of reading, but you don't have to read it thoroughly, I just skimmed it. Only have 3 papers and participation. There were no quizzes or exams, so you don't have to take notes. The papers were pretty easy. Loved the class. Definitely recommend.
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: Absolute legend professor Such a great class. Great lecturer, easy grader, interesting content. Brought in treats for our class several times and took us to dinner. Cancelled homework a couple of times. Has extremely flexible office hours (esp if you live in Stanford) Also dont be afraid that hes a priest. Hes a normal cool guy

Despite the miserable 3 hr lab, Prof Horgen brings good energy into the room and is always readily available to help a student. SHe is definitely the best you can get for lab. You spend a lot of time with TAs too and they're all very sweet. Grade cutoff is very strict so actually focus on the in class quizzes.
She is a great professor, would take class with her again. Definitely recommend.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Hilarious

comment: If you have to take Weitstock over Horgen I feel bad for you
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Beware of pop quizzes--Online Savvy

comment: Horgen is a good professor. Her pre-lab lectures are pretty good (even if you already know all the content from looking over the material for the pre-lab quiz). She is very accommodating, too, and was willing to give me points back after TAs had made stupid grading mistakes.

Chem lab is a super annoying course, regardless of the professor. Dr. Horgen was a super fun and a really great teacher. She was very receptive when it came to asking questions and was always willing to help. I would really try to get her over the other chem lab teachers.

My favorite professor so far! She is super helpful and active in the lab and answers questions very well. Her pre-lab lectures are very informative and helpful and she will give hints about the writeup. She's the best professor for gen chem lab!
She is very helpful in answering questions about the lab as well as the writeups. She explains things very clearly and truly helps you understand how to answer the questions.

This girl is my queen fr. If you have a question she will help you fully and in a wonderful kind manner. she literally is so nice and so good at teaching. also her prelab lectures are not super long. i literally cannot express my love for this womans teaching TAKE HER LAB OK!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I had Professor Horgen for Gen Chem lab freshman year and she is absolutely amazing. If you have the option to take her lab instead of the other professor, do it. She explains things so well and is absolutely willing and able to answer any question you have. She also is willing to work with you and your TA if there is an issue.

I love Professor Horgen. Her Foundations of Chem class is a film based class and really a blast. She puts in so much work and really cares for all of us. She makes the class absolutely amazing. I cannot recommend her enough. The class definitely had me working, but she adjusted the workload cause it was only her first time teaching the class.

The clips and related activities/assignments were such an excellent, exciting vehicle for learning chemistry. Being able to see the application of ethereal concepts to real-world things like perming hair (or making meth) was cool! If it was this organized and well-taught the first time around, I can only imagine it would be perfect in the future.
dedicated to making sure that you succeed
No Comments
Fire! He brings fire to the classroom!
No Comments
Great teacher, he is really funny
A great prof for physics.  He loves flame and does many wacky demos in class.

Professor Valenzuela is extremely knowledgeable about the subject. The lectures can be boring, but the class is very easy overall. If you show up and submit everything you are going to get an A in the class. There is also no reading and you only present once every 3 weeks.

Your entire grade is determined by only your midterm and final. If you do poor on one there goes your grade. He also can move you up or down two full letter grades based on "participation" but in reality it is a way of control over your grade. Watch out for this course! You have no idea your grade until it comes out on your transcript.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: My favorite class that I've taken at Notre Dame. Professor Valenzuela is incredibly knowledgeable about so many world events. Great opportunity to gain a better perspective of the world.
his class is not entertaining and its just him talking

This is the least organized professor I have ever had. No rubrics. He still has yet to give us any feedback on anything and it's November. Our class started with 15 kids and has been cut in half because of how unorganized he is. No conversation. He assigns an absurd amount of reading every week, but never gives any guide to understanding it.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Took him on word that his class was an easy University Seminar. Minimal writing for a seminar (not sure how it counted as one) which was fine by me (science major)! He is EXTREMELY knowledgeable in history of all types. Very relaxed atmosphere, and get to read the Times as "homework". Good discussion of many issues. Easy, fun seminar of learning.

This course is based mainly on the 7 quizzes, so knowing the material is really important. Camden is super reachable outside of class and always willing to help on problems you are confused about on the homeworks.  Lectures are fairly engaging and I was usually more prepared for exams than my classmates who had other profs.
Really funny professor, lectures were always interesting and pretty engaging. Only complaint is that he doesn't post his solutions afterwards so you would have to look at other professors'.

Camden is a great guy. Always puts an interesting/funny quote at the beginning of lecture, and goes on interesting tangents (with practical applications). I stayed after lecture several times to ask questions, and he always gave great explanations. Even if you're not a chem nut, the class is enjoyable.

Professor Camden explains chem concepts very clearly, and his slides are super concise, helpful, and probably all you need to study for quizzes and the final. Very minimal homework. He will stay after lectures to help you if you need it. He's super nice and tries to make his lectures interesting and engaging. All around great professor!

Nice guy who does a good job explaining gen chem. Pretty engaging in lecture and does plenty of examples so if you take good notes and follow along you will be prepared for quizzes and tests. Overall solid and seemed better than the other sections from what I could tell.

Prof Camden is a really good chem lecturer--as someone who barely understands chemistry, I actually could follow the chem lectures. He's pretty engaging throughout the lecture, so it wasn't hard to pay attention. He's helpful outside of class as well.
My experience with this Professor was great! He tries to make the class interactive and is enthusiastic about the topic. Very accessible outside of class too.

Professor Mulhollland is unquestionably an amazing professor. His mastery grading system relieved so much stress. Basically, you get multiple attempts at each homework assignment and midterm question. He's also extremely kind and caring.
Great human being and great teacher

The best professor in the math department, hands down. Cares deeply about students on top of being an extremely skilled lecturer. Teaches review sessions for classes that he doesn't even teach that are wildly popular. Standards based grading pares down the amount you actually learn, however.
Brian is the best Math professor at this University. His class is a must take for whatever subject he is teaching.

AWESOME teacher. Your best choice for math at ND. 10/10 would take again.  I had him for calc III and while the material can be boring, he makes it interesting.  Because this class uses mastery grading, you will need to motivate yourself to pay attention because you can get by until the final exam without learning much. Easy A if you pay attention.

She is a very good lecturer but I found myself bored just because of the amount of theory we talk about, so it's not a testament to her ability. Papers aren't graded too hard and TA's give good feedback on how to improve your work. You can get a good grade in the class if you either do the readings or go to class, not really necessary to do both.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: really nice and helpful in office hours. lecture is huge so you could fly by without going at all, but the content is hard to grasp if you don't work at it. 3 take-home exams each consisting of a few short essays on technical matters and one longer opinionated response, and one final essay are the only assignments.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Prof Sierra is the best. Just an amazing teacher and woman! Her IR class is super interesting and engaging, but also reasonably challenging. The TAs grade, but at least mine was super helpful and available outside of class. Take Prof. Sierra!!! She is literally NDs best political science professor!

Professor Sierra's lectures are truly amazing. She has a knack for explaining difficult concepts in ways that make the information very accessible and understandable. She is truly a gem of a professor. The class isn't difficult, but I feel like I've learned a lot from it. Would take another class with her!

tbh I never went to class and did fine. your grade is 3 essay-based take home tests + a final paper graded by the TAs. so your grade depends on your TA. she would release the exam Sun then it'd be due Tues. if you're a good writer you can bs your way through this class very easily.

Simply the best. I had such a great experience in Professor Sierra's class in the spring, I decided to take her again this fall. She is super knowledgeable, and she makes the discussions and lectures so applicable and digestible. Easily one of the best political science professors at ND. Take her without hesitation!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: DEFINITELY TAKE HIM. He is by far one the easiest theology professors for an intro course and not much work at all.

Dr. Wise is overall a decent professor. Class consists of 2 exams, 2 papers, and 2 simple assignments per week. He is a quick grader and gives opportunities to receive help outside of class. It is fairly hard to get an A (A- is a 91 which is annoying). Exams are fair and mostly straightforward if you pay attention in class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Borello Wise is probably the easiest and nicest professor for Intro to Theo. The homework load is light compared to other classes. The class has easy weekly homework, two papers that are not difficult to write, a midterm, and a final. Overall, the tests are easy, and the paper grading is very fair I Highly recommend him.

Professor Wise is great! The class is straightforward with 2 exams, 2 papers, and weekly homework questions that only take a few minutes. He sets clear expectations so you do well on assignments, and if you study the study guides for exams, you should do well. He's also very kind and understanding, and does his best to make lectures interesting.

This professor was amazing! His lectures can be boring sometimes but are very intriguing. His personality is great and his teaching style is too. He gives out homework assignments that are not graded but done for completion, two papers, two exams (literally tells you what to study) and loves participation during class. Great professor overall!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy

comment: He is a very caring professor and has very easy homework due at the start of every class. It is typically 2-3 reading questions, graded mainly for completion, that are answered in just a couple sentences. There are only two exams, both of which are very easy if you study for them. There are also two papers which aren't difficult either.
Highly recommend, super sweet professor. There are two papers, a midterm, and final, all are relatively easy and straight-forward. Homework consists of a lot of readings.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Quizzes will determine overall grade. Most classes were lectures. Almost no discussion. He is really intelligent, but if you do not like the topic, you will be bored within seconds. Not an easy A.

I really liked the class, but I got the sense that others who were less enthusiastic about the material were often bored. Very bright man and a good lecturer, but not as much discussion as I would have thought for an English class

The professor is clearly an intelligent man, but he doesn't convey (or inspire) much enthusiasm for the subject matter. He tends to override discussion with lectures. I learned a lot from the course, but I might look for elsewhere if you want to study the pertinent literary period
Great professor. Very intelligent and really knows the stuff he teaches.
All I can say is I'm glad I liked Shakespeare before I took this class, or I'd be turned off the Bard forever, or at least a long time. A resounding "meh".
No Comments

Lectures are vague and unorganized.Exams are based on weekly study guides but the slideshows dont have all the info. If she grades your paper or visual analysis, your grade will be lower than other students. Final exam was online and three essays in two hours. Class is doable but strangely more difficult than I expected. I didnt go to many lectures
She was a great professor! No complaints

Even though Basics of Film and Television has lots of readings, quizzes, and papers, one will come out a better writer and film viewer. She provides insightful feedback on assignments and papers. After taking this class, I feel prepared for upper-level film classes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures--Tough grader

comment: Do not take this class thinking it will be a GPA booster or an easy A, it is neither. While the course material is not challenging, the grading in the course is unfair. I have yet to meet anybody that received an A in the course.

Took her Media Industries class and found it incredibly informative. She does an excellent job of balancing lecture with discussion - students have a voice, but she also provided a lot of content and info that was just good to know for the major. Highly recommend it

Took her for an elective course for my English major in Fall 2009. It was entitled "TV as a Storytelling Medium." Fascinating class that changed the way I watch TV and films. Extremely intelligent, eloquent and genuinely helpful professor who challenges you. Highly recommend.

He was a nice guy and put together a great syllabus. There was a lot of freedom within assignments, which was nice, but expectations for grading and due dates were somewhat unclear. Lectures could get dry if no one participated, but class discussions were great. You get out what you put in.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: don't take him because he never gives grades for papers and tends to assign a grade lower than you expect at the end of the semester lol

This dude may just be the most boring professor to have ever taken the podium in front of pupils. Grades heavy, drones on for lectures, and gives poor feedback for material that is turned in. Do yourself a favor, if you are reading this after signing up for one of his classes, turn back now. Drop it. Seriously. He is a garbage teacher.

I had Prof. Rea in a small seminar-style class. I can see why he might be a boring professor to have in a large lecture, but in a smaller discussion-based class, he is fantastic. He is a tough grader, but if you provide any sort of interesting insights in your essays and proofread well, you will do great. His class is very thought-provoking.

Professor Rea is clearly a gifted philosopher. He is not a gifted teacher. Lectures were dry and class participation was dismal. Papers and tests were graded rather harshly for an intro class and very little feedback was given on work.

I wouldn't take this guy again, he focuses way too much of lectures and the class involvement is lackluster. Not because he doesn't offer the chance for students to speak, but they are so bored with what he says and his way of delivering lessons that they don't care.

He made so many off-putting comments borderline sexist and racist, like when he pointed to two Black kids in the class while mentioning racial discrimination and laughed. Lectures are mandatory because his exams are just memorization, and the most random details of a Biblical story would be on there. If you're not good at memorizing, stay away.

Prof made many sexual comments in class throughout the semester. Shared a fantasy about his wife wearing a sheer negligee. He said that he is allowed to "look but not touch" in regards to younger women on campus. He told the only black girl to imagine she was "back in Africa." Content was only lecture, tests were very hard. Don't take this class.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: If you're not good with tests, especially memorization tests, don't take this class. 80% of your grade is determined by this. Also, if you're looking to be stimulated by a class, don't take this class. Doing well in it is all about regurgitation. You need to be there for every class and take notes word for word, otherwise you will fail.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Notes are sparse and not very organized. It's necessary to pay attention in class because often times exam material covers things that aren't written on the board.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Tests are really hard. Even with a lot of help from the pr I did not do well
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Long and boring lectures that fill 5 or more pages of notes per lecture. It's very easy to fall asleep or make sloppy notes and the Grad TA makes all tests/essay topics. Due to this tests were exceptionally hard for foundations and required heavy memorization.

If you've come to check up on JFitzgerald, research no further. This guy is the friendliest, most down to earth professor in Notre Dame. He's clear in his lectures. He animates stories in the Old and New Testament; ever heard of a professor doing that before? The quizzes and tests are entirely based on lecture notes. Study those, and you get an A.

Out of all the Elements of Calculus teachers, I've heard he's the best of the worst. Personally, I thought that he was a good teacher and actually had a good sense of humor, although it was a bit quirky. He does a good job of teaching the material, and he is always willing to answer questions.
Best math professor I've had here at Notre Dame. Super nice guy and all of his lectures are super clear and directly correlates to the homework you do.
Great teacher, explains things well.  Definitely take.

Gabe Conant is the coolest man alive! He's very good at making boring class material interesting and he keeps the class engaged and interested. He actually inspired me to pick up a supplementary major in math! Aside from his actual teaching ability, he's also just a very funny, cool guy. If I got the chance I would take him again in a heartbeat.

His lectures were hilarious and every student in the class loved him. He was a very clear teacher and was always willing to help his students in office hours and in class. Possibly one of my favorite math classes to date.
He is the greatest math teacher ever. Take him if you have a chance. Super smart, yet humble and wiling to help!

Class is pretty easy because all of the quizzes are take home. It was his first time teaching the class so he was a bit disorganized, but I learned a lot. Sometimes it is hard to know exactly you are supposed to learn but he still does a good job of repeating important topics. The final is not too bad if you have been paying attention. Good module.

The quizzes were extremely easy, but the final was pretty hard. The lectures were really disorganized. All of the quizzes are closed note and take home. If you have taken Biology before, this class will be mostly review with some applications of it that were cool. If you want a module that isn't much work, take this. Study for the final, though.

Enthusiastic about teaching, but an unclear communicator. Lectures had convoluted slides that his explanations failed to clarify. Also, writes rather confusing quizzes, which are take home but supposed to be closed-note, essentially penalizing students who don't want to cheat. If you want a genomics module, Hollocher's is probably more organized.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Ferdig was very  passionate about his module topic, yet his lack of organization made this class harder than intended. The class assignments were very easy and straightforward, while the final was much much harder. Great, caring professor, just is extremely disorganized and HEAVILY relies on TAs.

Although Dr. Ferdig is very motivated to teach, I personally think that it wasn't the greatest module to take. Nothing is very clear and he goes on ramblings that don't really make sense, he sent an email after saying "sorry if I didn't make any sense". I would recommend taking a module that might be a little harder but more organized.

While Prof Ferdig's class could be disorganized at some times, his lectures definitely made up for it! He is super passionate and funny! He has a great team of TA's that are available to help and the content is super interesting. Sometimes the expectations for projects were a little unclear but overall I enjoyed his module and would take again.
A bit scatterbrained, but clearly knows what he talking about! He is easy to get in touch with and will take the time to sit down and explain material to you. 10/10 would take a class with him again.

Dr. Ferdig is VERY passionate about the material he teaches and that makes class a lot more fun. He is a bit disorganized, but asking for clarification and scheduling office hours does wonders. 10/10 guy
Great teacher.  A little scattered, but communicates very well.
Awful. Do not take!!!!! All he ever does is yap. He doesn't give out homework; grades only depend on the exams. He's only ever given 4 A+'s in his whole career—very tough grader.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Absolutely do not take him. The only grade you got was from exams, nothing else. His feedback was unhelpful, and he did not try to help you improve but rather made you feel worse about your grade. It was an intro-level course, but he did not act like it. It was so confusing, and everyone fell asleep. Do not take him at all costs!

I took Intro to Philosophy (arts and aesthetics) with him and it was a lot more complicated than it had to be. I feel like his lectures were hard to follow, especially since a lot of his notes did not make sense.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Everyone was wide awake at all times. His classes were engaging and the readings were super interesting. Everyone was super attentive and loved to participate. The hands were up at all times. I can only recommend Prof. Fred Rush. He never forgets you in emails.
Great professor. Great lectures and very effective readings. He knows how to chose his material to condense philosophical knowledge in an easy to digest way.

Professor Rush just stands at the front of the class and talks the entire time. Some of the lectures are funny and he tries to engage students, but I ended up falling asleep most of the time. To do well, go to class and take good notes. You don't really need to do the readings so the only homework is studying for the exams.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Avoid at all costs.

Bad. Avoid at all costs. Does not give you an explanation or feedback but just assigns any grade he pleases. No rubric for assignments and not helpful when you ask questions. He doesn't teach, he just talks at you and makes the subject painful.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Rush is a notoriously tough grader. Luckily I took this course (Socialist philosophy) during the pandemic, so I took the passing grade. Rush is also very condescending and not very interested in student input. He loves to hear himself talk. Sometimes hundreds of pages of reading each night. Made socialism boring, somehow.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Favorite's a pretty funny, kind, and encouraging, and he's great at breaking topics down into more intuitive terms. Lectures and homework problems are helpful, so exams should not be too bad if you review and understand those. The class has so many TA and prof office hours to go over anything. (He's also a former ND football player which is cool.)

Prof Favorite is easily one of the coolest profs I've had at Notre Dame, and probably the coolest business school professor I've had. He gets that CFR is a requirement and no one really cares about it. His tests are fair and the hw load is minimal. If you can take him for acct, definitely do it. Only issue is he usually teaches one section per sem.

Mike Favorite is a great guy. Really knows his accounting stuff. In accounting 1 the homework is not required/graded, but they help you learn the material. Grade depends pretty heavily on tests and a couple group projects. Favorite goes through material REALLY fast in class, so I would recommend going to office hours to ask questions.

Professor Favorite was great. He was very fun despite a generally boring accounting curriculum which is set by the department. My class had lower average scores on the exams but the class was curved appropriately at the end. Does "casual" Thursdays or Fridays to brighten up the beginning of class a bit. Tons of professional experience in accounting

Professor Favorite is an AMAZING accounting teacher, super funny and gets to know each student in the class. Though the material may be difficult, he does his best to make it fun. The exams are difficult but manageable. No outside homework outside of class, just suggested assignments to become familiar with concepts.

Favorite's a funny guy and actually made me somewhat enjoy Accounting II. Tests are kinda hard and time-consuming, but the curve should help you at the end. Show up to class or else you'll miss problems that will be on the test. Reading the textbook isn't mandatory. Homework is light and easy.

Prof Favorite mainly teaches through the PPTs. Pretty light workload of average 20-30 minutes each week; exams are based on his lectures, but can be a little long. Pay attention in class and study powerpoint slides to do well (no need to read textbook). He knows every student's name and takes attendance. Very fun prof who does casual Fridays.

Professor Miller is a great prof. All Foundations of Accountancy classes have the same exams, but I think that the notes handout and the way Miller lectures allows his students to do better than the other professor's classes. Don't stress about doing homework on time, just do it all a few days before and you will be fine. Office hours dont help
He's a nice guy. Not too tough of a class but PLEASE do the work when he assigns it and go to office hours. It really helps.

I originally thought ACCT 20100 was going to be a boring class requirement for my major, however, Prof. Miller helped keep the class lively through his lectures and genuine care for his students. He's a great professor and I'd recommend anyone to take his class.

Great professor and a really sweet guy. He made most topics easy to follow through his lectures. Homework is optional but great to use as a study guide. Occasional pop quizzes from pre-class videos (easy to go through on 2x speed). Exams are surprise-free and look like the homework (no time crunch). Overall made me love accounting, great class
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Out of all the Accounting 1 professors, he is probably the worst. The lectures bored me to sleep and I just couldn't seem to do well no matter what. I attended his office hours and met with him to see what I could do to improve. After telling him what I did to prepare, he said "I don't know why you're not doing well." Avoid.

Prof. Miller does a good job of explaining accounting topics for a newcomer to understand. He emphasizes building a foundation for the subject as a whole and then fitting new pieces of information into that foundation. If you want to do well, keep up with the reading and recommended homework.

Teaching style wasn't great, very unorganized. Assignments are worth a good portion of your grade but gives little to no guidance to the assignment and subtracts points for the most menial things. (This is for unstructured data)

Intro coding is taught in a flipped classroom style and she didn't do much teaching. Each class you get a worksheet type assignment and questions are usually answered with more questions or being told to reference the videos you watched before class

This class is TOUGH! Professor Lanski cares, but she turns it back on you when you ask her a question. I've never coded, and I don't do well with the class structure. When taking this class, make sure to have a good group of friends with you because teamwork in this class is so important! She's still probably one of the easier coding profs.

The beginning of class is sorta like being pushed out of a nest. With no previous coding exposure, I started the semester on a rough note because the introduction is not entirely fit for beginners. She is a good teacher, but she under-prepared us for the final. No one felt confident afterwards, and it tanked a lot of grades.

I don't think your prof for this class matters as much as people say. Most of your learning is done on your own so if you spend the necessary time on homework you'll be good. TA office hours are very accessible and you should go several times in the semester.
Profesor Lanski is very caring and wants her students to succeed. Even for someone who has never coded before, this class was pretty light. If you have the chance, definitely take Lanski!
Took him for Honors Calc I, very good at making the lectures accessible yet also challenging.

I took Honors Calc 2 with Prof Hind. He is a fantastic professor, who is very available after class and during office hours. I enjoyed discussing class material and unrelated math topics with him. 11/10
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Best Professor I have ever had. Very Passionate about mathematics and strives to teach it to everyone
He's a great teacher and really wants you to do well, so ask him questions because he's more than happy to explain.
No Comments
Hind is the best math prof you will ever have.
The guy is great!
Smart guy.
worst professor ever.
My favourite Prof!
No Comments
No Comments
Bellis is now teaching at IUSB i found his class very interesting and very entertaining to attend.  very good prof
This man is a genius, and saved my life.. in fact I think he, if listened to, could save the world!
I thought he was overly harsh on our class because we were not anthro majors, which really bothered me a lot.
Take a class from Bellis - I don't care if it fits in your schedule - do it.  He's amazing.
No Comments
No Comments

Dee is an amazing professor. Many students fear Calc 2 but if you take it with Dee you will be well off. There is a lot of homework, but it is not graded. But you need to do the homework to do well! If you pay attention to her awesome lectures and do the homework, calc 2 will be a breeze. Thank you Dee!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Dee is the best Math professor I have ever had. She explains concepts very clearly and does many example problems in lecture. She makes the exams challenging, but if you attend lecture and do the homework you will know the techniques to solve all the problems. I highly recommend taking Dee as your Calculus professor.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Caring

comment: Dee is a very kind person however she is one of the worst professors I have ever had. She over complicates things and elaborates on something simple until you don't know if you understand it. Then when time comes for something complex, she uses bizarre analogies and speeds through the concept. Avoid this professor...
She is the best professor I've ever had. She is clear in her teachings, she is engaging and she has a sense of humor. She offers a ton of resources to help supplement class time.

By far one of the best Professors I've had. She puts in a lot of time outside of class to make sure the students have more than enough resources to prepare for exams. If given the option, definitely take her courses.

Dee is a good teacher if you actually pay attention in class and take notes. Everyone in the class does well on the exams, especially compared to the other classes. Her English is not the best but you can understand her. One of the better Calc II teachers.

This class was extremely easy. The only assignments were two papers and an optional third essay for extra credit. He also has canceled the final for the past few years and there is no midterm. Attendance is mandatory but laptops are allowed and you don't have to pay attention to receive a good grade.

Was worried about taking my first Theo class prior to meeting Bradley Malkovsky, but after the first lecture, I knew that I had found the right teacher who has both passion for the subject and the ability to look critically at the material and invites students to do the same!

I took Professor Malkovsky's class during winter session: after the first day of class, he proactively reached out to me and one other student saying that we weren't required to come, since it would be at 5am for us. Just one example of how kind he is, which manifests clearly in his teaching as well.

Prof Malkovsky can ramble on sometimes, but he explains stuff well and is literally the nicest man on earth. He isnt there to see you fail, he wants yall to do well. I took his winter 2021 Intro to Theo course it was way better than I thought. Was boring at times but I rather it be boring than hard!

An excellent professor, gives fascinating lectures, treats students as adults, helps with student understanding as much as possible, has very interesting stories, never assigns an unreasonable amount of reading/homework, is open to students' input on when assignments should be due, and overall is very friendly and helpful. Would take again.

Professor Malkovsky is an extremely engaging professor. His lectures are always interesting, entertaining, and informative. He has also studied other religions which make class lectures exciting, as he mixes in information and facts from other religions to compare them to Christianity. The professor is extremely welcoming and tolerant of other POVs

Some of these are misleading. He is a very nice, funny guy but as a freshman with limited experience I had to go to office hours each week just to complete the homework. He assumes you understand and moves on quickly, so you must be focused all the time. I've heard others had an easier time in Ackermann. I wouldn't take it with him as a freshman

this class was definitely helpful in building my finance knowledge!  short answer exams at first seemed impossible but honestly it ended up being great because of partial credit so i much prefer this exam structure. got a decent grade with some hard work  and enough studying. would recommend

Some tricky exams in my opinion but I appreciate the challenge a lot since I plan to pursue a finance job. i had to try pretty hard to get a B+ (i think) but honestly i could've tried harder . prof chen was always available, i just didn't make the effort to go to his office hours. but overall great prof and would take again

BEST PROFESSOR! I loved his class, he always made learning fun and even brought prizes to class for answering questions and winning kahoots. His exams are not difficult if you put the time into understanding the material. He's a very funny professor and he even got a mullet because he made a deal with our class!

I had a great experience in Prof Chen's class! His lectures were fun and he would bring prizes! He was always available after class and would respond to emails within 5 minutes. He gave me a mock interview for my GS superday (I got the internship). In his class, if you put in the effort, you will do very well. He will help you all along the way!

Really nice guy that's looking out for students' interests. Decent teacher of topics but I can't say explanations are his strong-suit. HW load is pretty low. Exams are not easy and can expand beyond what was discussed in class in unexpected ways

This guy is so much fun. Energetic lectures that make class interesting. You can tell he really cares about his students. Honestly, this class was more work than I expected, but not too bad. A good amount of reading at the beginning of the semester, but SparkNotes helps. Tests were okay as long as you prepare based on his study guide.

Professor Tagliabue is a fantastic lecturer, and above all else wants you to learn and enjoy! This class is not particularly challenging, so pay attention in class and read enough to write good blogs and papers. He has the best energy and enthusiasm of any professor I've had. I highly recommend!

Professor Tagliabue is an amazing and engaging professor. He always makes an effort to connect with every one of his students and it shows how much he really cares about the class and his students. He is also very accessible outside of class, so please use him as a resource when studying or writing a paper.

Professor Tagliabue is awesome! Makes an effort to learn your name, where you're from, and things you're interested in even if you're in a large class. Super funny and loves getting dinners with his students to get to know them better. He's super passionate about the class and greets every student individually before the lecture starts. Great dude!

I read my butt off in this class but Prof. Tagliabue's energy for the subject made it all worth it. He was hilarious, and the class really stimulated learning about ancient heroism in a way that makes it accessible and interesting for the modern day. He was always available and eager to meet outside of class, and even discussion groups were helpful
Best classics professor at ND by far.

Like 60% of your grade will be determined by the tests and there's like 4 (including final). Super important to participate in class and form a relationship w her. Def take the class,  pretty easy teacher for cult conv because it's movie based and not reading. Most essays are at home so you have plenty of time. Overall, awesome teacher def take her

Professor Coloma is extremely kind and caring. She laughs a lot and really wants to get to know her students. She cares a lot about participation, so make sure to raise your hand at least once a class. The only downsides are that she struggles a lot with technology and takes forever to grade papers and tests and return them.

Prof. Coloma is extremely kind and clearly cares about her students. Just a few things to be aware of - she was somewhat disorganized throughout the semester - sending assignments via email days after we were supposed to begin them per the syllabus. The exams were pretty difficult so taking the other section without exams is probably preferable.

Professor Coloma truly cares about the class, material, and her students. You can tell she cares about Hispanic history and culture. However, she is very bad with technology and changes the syllabus pretty often. Overall a great teacher and a great course, especially because the movies we watched were entertaining.

One of the best Spanish professors at ND. Super caring. Gives a good amount of hw but has long due dates. Study guides are exactly like test. Super accessible, holds office hours everyday. Will get a good grade if you show that you try.

Profe Coloma was a pretty good professor. For my class, she only talked in Spanish and talked quickly at times. She gives decent lectures and seems to really care about teaching. She is pretty bad with technology tho, and does not grade the quickest.

Very chill leadership class. Got out early most classes. Individual assignment and group assignment were both easy and straightforward. Final exam was challenging but if you do well on the exam it's an easy A

Super nice dude, although the class itself was terribly structured. This is more of a Mendoza thing, and the content itself was super subjective and hard to study. All exams were either subjective-ahh multiple choice or subjective-ahh writing questions. The case study projects such, bc you're in a group of Mendoza students (enough said).
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Amazing prof! The lectures were always super interesting and engaging. There was one individual project and one group project that I think were graded fairly and not too difficult.  The final exam was a little challenging

Prof Muir is a really nice guy who definitely cares about his students. You are only graded on 4 things (individual paper, group paper, mendoza research and the final). The individual paper and research are graded on completion but doing bad on the group paper or the final could really affect your grade. The final was hard and the hw takes forever.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment:
very hard quizzes, few questions, hard to study for, no cheat sheet for final so a lot of memorization needed, 

though he definitely cares about his students and wants them to do well, if he revised the syllabus and allowed students a cheat sheet for the final I think it would be a lot better
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He was terrible. Only had a few assignments and no exams but quizzes were worth 100 points with only 15 questions. Questions were very difficult to understand and time consuming. WOULD NOT RECCOMEND
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: Such a great professor. Pleasant to be around, interesting, upbeat, able to make otherwise very dry course material engaging. Fair, not too much work, only two short quizzes, one paper, a group project, and a final that end up factoring into your grade.

Bio 1 Lab is naturally not a very difficult class, so I wouldn't worry too much on who you take. Additionally, lab activities are run by and assignments are graded by a graduate TA and assistant TAs, so your professor has little impact on the overall experience.
Prof Rudenga is a nice guy and all. But not very helpful in the teaching department… he goes too fast in both lab and lecture
Very helpful and kind professor. He is always happy to offer assistance or clarify things.

Professor Rudenga is great—he's a solid lecturer for M2E, and while the course is tough, that's not on him. He's incredibly helpful in office hours and went out of his way to meet with me 1-on-1 after I missed a couple of lectures, ensuring I caught up. I heard other profs were a bit better, but I never personally had any complaints about him.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: This is for BIOS 10172 M2E. For some people he was fine, but majority was not great. Take a different prof if you can pls.
Get ready to learn absolutely nothing, but don't worry he'll wear a cute sweater vest and smile at you after teaching you nothing and flunking you.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Awesome pick for bio lab. Laid back but you learn a lot. TAs aren't tough graders, but you still need to put in the work to get an A. Rubrics for assignments are very clear. Sometimes makes lab procedure unclear but is very understanding if he messes up.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: She was lovely, and open to help outside of class.
Took her for Orgo 1 for CBE majors and it was not easy. Definitely make use of office hours and study groups!
easy exams
she is way too smart to teach
No Comments
No Comments

Having never taken a class with Prof K I was a bit uneasy. However once classes started I felt so welcome and never wanted to miss a single minute of his class. Prof K is one of the most interesting intellectuals I have ever met at ND or any other school.His breadth of knowledge is only surpassed by his caring attitude towards his students success.

Undoubtedly one of the finest, kindness, most compassionate human beings God ever placed on the face of the earth. Dr. K not only taught me CIS/PHOTOSHOP he taught me patience, understanding, and self confidence. Dr. K is one of the best Prof's that UND students will ever have had the opportunity with which to study. Dr. K is the best ever.

Prof K is not only 1 of the best prof's at ND but also one of the kindest, considerate and caring human beings ever. He provides his home phone # and tells students they may call him 24/7 should they ever require his assistance even once the course is complete. Prof K  should be the standard by which all Prof's are judged.

Prof K is the best prof I have had at ND. He is patient, understanding, with knowledge beyond belief. One of the few Prof's that genuinely cares about his students. He assisted me on many occasions and even drove from Chicago on his days off to assist his students. He was the most exceptional Prof at Notre Dame. Sadly he retired; a big loss for ND.

I did'nt fully realize either the depth or breadth of Prof. Kadlubowski's knowledge on this very difficult subject matter until my graduation from UND. Aside of his knowledge, PROF K. would meet any studnet at any time of day or night to assist in their understading of a particular lesson. The subject matter wasdifficult, but hemade class time fun

When God brought Michael to Notre Dame we were sent an angel. EXCEPTIONAL PROF with knowledge beyond compare. Assistance provided to students is unmatched even at the Golden Dome. Helpful regardless of the simplicity of complexity of the question asked. I was saddend to learn that Michael retired from UND. He was/is the best there ever was!
Absolutely fantastic. Took every course he offered open to non-theology majors  and I was a business major.
One of the best profs I ever had. Still use was he taught me 40 yrs later
Prof Ulrich is the man

Prof Ulrich IS a legend.  I had him as a freshman my first semester, first class at ND all the way back in 1992.  He started out explaining how involved he was with the Dead Sea Scrolls and I thought "fantastic - I'm gonna fail".  He was amazing and very patient and never looked at me like I was as lost as I felt.  His class was one of the best @ N
Great prof!  Yeah, he expects a lot, but you learn a lot.  That's what we pay tuition for, right?  The guy is a legend, one of the experts in his field.  You are obliged to take this guy.
His tests are hard, no doubt.  But he's this amazing mind and I learned a LOT in his class.
She is a great professor. She always looks out for her students and gives good feedback, making it easy to understand the material.
I just don't like the set up of the class

EG 10116 was formerly Intro to Programming for EG, learning MatLab and Python. Dr. Meyers does a great job coming to morning classes with enthusiasm and finding good ways to keep the class engaged through useful examples. She provides notes to watch before lectures. Do the assignments and attend class, and you learn the material. Very kind person.
Professor Meyers is caring and wants everyone to do well. Engineering Design has something for everyone, so it will be interesting for any true engineer at some point.

Really nice and really cares about her students. She understands material can be tough for inexperienced students and tries to help. She can get you an internship or a job if you just ask her. Great person. Course itself is tough if you have no prior coding experience.

Dr. Meyers is a solid choice for the first year engineering course. She cares about her students and does a good job relating engineering concepts to how they're applied. She also welcomes student feedback after projects, emphasizing how useful it is for her.

Professor Sikorski has daily reading with quizzes on those readings every class, with a 5-6 page final paper. He has supposed 'open' discussion, but he only wants you to say what he already thinks. Overall, his ethical behavior class is not difficult if you do the readings and meet with him over your final essay.

Professor Sikorski was overall a good professor. He is extremely intelligent and well-versed in seemingly every ethics/business topic. He gave informative lectures, and class discussions were always very interesting. I would highly recommend taking this class, as it changes your perspective on the world and a career in business.

Absolutely ridiculous amounts of reading. We were also somehow always behind on the syllabus, so that sucked too. Sikorski doesn't have the best control over a classroom: once people start discussing, it's almost impossible to move on, so we were always behind. I enjoyed the discussions that we did have, but they got really circular really quick.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy

comment: Loved this class. The class style is great, part lecture and part discussion, which makes it super interesting and honestly flies by! There was a LOT of reading, so get ready for that, possibly 2-4 hours a week (although I will admit that I am a slow reader). Highly highly recommend this perspective-changing class.

You have reading for each class, which is usually pretty manageable (probably like 1hr), and quizzes each day. If you read and take notes, you should get 100% on all the quizzes. Graded assignments are quizzes, a lecture summary, an exemplar essay, and a final. His class is definitely more theological than other business ethics professors.

10/10 Best bible study course ever; don't know why they kept calling it an ethics course though, we never even touched that topic. We were cheated out of a proper ethics education because John wanted to play teacher. He copied a dozen syllabi he found online and mashed them together without thinking about how they contrasted. Course was a mess.
rating_tags: Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: Smartest prof I've ever had but was not an interesting person. Readings are long. ~35 pages average. Every week there is a reading report - write one page summarizing the readings and one page of opinion/reactions. 2 big papers - midterm of 10 pages and another that is min of 6. Content was really not that interesting or contemporary. Would avoid.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Philpott is not as bad as he's made out to be on here. His lectures are so-so and the exams have a lot of writing, but for Poli Sci majors Catholicism and Politics knocks out several requirements. This won't be your favorite class here, but it's interesting and it's not that difficult to do well.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: I've had him for Cath and Pol and Why the Church.  I liked him a lot.  You don't find too many conservative profs anymore so this was a nice change of pace.  Grades somewhat tough and the material can be challenging, but he is a really nice guy who gets way too much flak from people imo.  Amazing lectures and would recommend.

Prof. Philpott is a classic right-leaning political science professor at ND, so he's very vocal about his beliefs about abortion, gay marriage, etc. He is a pretty tough grader and doesn't do a very good job of explaining complex theoretical topics.

Professor is a gem. He invests in students. He holds us to an academic standard when it comes to writing, but makes sure to give plenty of feedback/advice before the grade. He is VERY good about representing/hearing all students' viewpoints. He encourages students to argue (respectfully) to learn. Take him for organization and personability.

Professor Philpott is so kind! Unfortunately, his content is very dated. He also can't answer many of your questions. Not much homework but your entire grade is 2 exams and a debate. Def don't take him if you don't want a difficult philosophy class. Definitely don't recommend for anything poli sci!!!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Group projects

comment: Excellent professor. Knows all his students' names and gives great lectures. He really inspires people to pursue engineering (if it's right for them!) and to really discern what discipline within engineering to do. The excel and solidwork homeworks could get a little long sometimes but that's not dependent on your professor.
He is the guy.

Professor Neal is one of the most energetic and full-of-life people I have ever met. He greeted me by name whenever we passed each other, which is a small thing, but does not go unnoticed. He does his absolute best to fill his students with a true love and passion for engineering.

Can't go wrong with any of the FYE teachers, but highly recommend Neal. His enthusiastic teaching style makes the class less boring. Neal wants to see you succeed and is super helpful in office hours even if what you ask is unrelated to class.
rating_tags: Group projects--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Never had more of an enthusiastic professor. He cares about his students and most definitely wants you to be successful. He is also super funny ( I laughed too much at his jokes that were both cringe and funny at the same time). It is wonderful that he brings light into the classroom during the most tiring time of the day.
Great professor! The class was kind of boring but he definitely tried to make it interesting and is a super funny guy
Great guy, makes you laugh, if you do the work you will get a good grade
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: We did 8 books + 2 movies this semester, with a total of 10 papers (1 for each). Overall, the books are interesting. Workload is heavy but he grades extremely easy and an A is pretty much ensured for everyone who puts in effort. This class is a lot of fun and I bonded with my classmates. I would highly recommend despite it being on a Sunday night.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: Father Malloy is one of the best professors on campus. His university seminar was very insightful and thought provoking. I would recommend taking the class again.

An overall great class. Every week you need to read a different book and write an essay, but he's a very easy grader and everyone I knew got As. Also, the material you read about is very eye-opening and he even brings in the authors to speak to the class sometimes. He really cares about his students too.

Father Malloy is one of the most amazing Professors I have ever came into contact with. He is someone who not only cares about you as a professor, but can be a true friend to you inside class and outside. He has helped me through tough times, and he is a very understanding. Taking his class, you should give 100% of your attention and participation
Do whatever you can to get into this class. This professor is awesome, and the class is fun

If you have any experience with calculus this class will be a breeze. If you don't you will struggle. All of the calc is done on a software program so at times you'll learn more about how to use the software than calculus. The assignments are the same across the course so your prof does not matter much.

Gursky was ok. Sometimes the lectures are too fast/hard to follow so it's good to have friends or people you know in the class for help. Lots of tedious homework assignments and weekly in-class quizzes that are weirdly extremely difficult. There are lots of grades that go into the grade book though.

Gursky was passionate about math but had no idea how to use the tech required for the class like Mathematica, relying heavily on his TAs to answer student questions. Class was boring but the concepts were pretty easy if you have already taken calc, so you could skip all semester and still secure an A. Final and midterm were open note.
Professor Gursky is hilarious

This guy might be one of the WORST teachers I've met at ND. He is the most condescending teacher I've met. I would stay away from this guy, seriously. His lectures are ehhh, but his mannerism is just unbearable.

This teacher is such a jerk. Any question you ask him he gives you a condescending response and acts like you dont get it. He makes no effort to explain anything. This guy is the definition of how a math teacher should not act. Stay away from this guy, unles you want a bad grade and a far below average prof.
Hard to understand in lectures, had to use my notes from high school.

He's super sweet and clearly cares. Overall a solid choice but the lectures aren't super engaging and I think it would be really hard if you haven't taken calc .You'd definetly need to do khan academy or something before but if you've had calc then its pretty easy. There aren't a lot of points on tests and quizzes so you can't miss many questions.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: Han was the man.

Smart guy and seems like a good person. Doesn't make an extra effort to make class more exciting, but professors can't be judged for their entertainment value. He's professional and his teaching is average. If you've never had a Chinese-American teacher or friend, keep in mind that he has an accent.
No Comments
No Comments

Econometrics is a very difficult class, but Professor Lieber makes it much easier. He is very available for office hours and takes time for questions during class. The quizzes (especially the first few) are pretty tough but if you use his resources, go to office hours, and study a lot, it is doable. Highly recommend Lieber over other metrics profs.

Econometrics gets a bad rap, but I think I was lucky to have Professor Lieber. His quizzes and final are very fair, and he doesn't make students do midterms. He's very open to questions, has a good sense of humor, and gives good lectures given the subject. I'd recommend going to class for the notes.

Professor Lieber is a great lecturer and a kind man. I always walked out of class understanding the content for that day because he explained it so well. I loved his dry sense of humor, and was slightly disappointed that the class didn't laugh at more of his jokes. Definitely take his class if you can! He truly wants all his students to succeed.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Test heavy--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Lieber is a great professor but can be monotone and awkward at times. He teaches well and prepares you for the exams well. He is also very understanding to students concerns.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Test heavy

comment: His examples are very illustrative, and Prof. Lieber's dry sense of humor is engaging. As long as you understand high school algebra and remember how supply and demand work, you should be set in his course. He also illustrates things so well that I hardly used my textbook.

I love this professor. He is so passionate about his research and principles of micro. And he explains everything with a hypothetical situation, which is super helpful and also helps on his exams. He writes down all his notes on the board, so the book is not necessary at all. Would definitely recommend to take his class.
rating_tags: ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: I really enjoyed this course. Valenzuela is ridiculously knowledgeable about international issues and much of the class is him talking about his views on them. Your final grade depends very heavily on the short midterm and final papers. Writing and presentation skills are definitely helpful to have.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Valenzuela is without a doubt the most intelligent professor I've had at ND; He's able to talk about any issue in any region of the world. He lets the students dictate the direction of discussion for the class, something which was great, especially with the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Highly recommend.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Very knowledgeable professor but dry lectures. Easy USEM with group projects based on The New York Times as the reading material. Interesting topics in class. 1 midterm and 1 final which are 2 pages each.
rating_tags: Group projects--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: you will get an A in this class but at the cost of listening to a boring old man talks about history and proceed to argue with you in class and then rant about history.

Very strange man... but he's nice and the class is easy. Almost no reading in comparison to other seminars. I am convinced that this is the easiest Usem possible. 2-3 2-page "papers" (basically just a summary) which you work on in groups; 2-3 oral presentations in groups. There is a midterm and a final, but they're easy essays Everybody gets an A

The work required is basically groups taking turns presenting world topics followed by the prof lecturing and some discussion. If you take minimal notes during presentations then zone out for the rest you can get an A. Presentations are 2 double spaced pages and take less then an hour. Grading system is Good, Fine, Needs Improvement.
rating_tags: GRADED BY FEW THINGS--GROUP PROJECTS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: This class was a lot of work but I enjoyed it. She really cares about the progress of her students and the activities are interesting. The downside is that is it a lot of homework each night, she doesn't grade till the end of the semester, and doesn't really respond to emails. Overall good professor that I recommend.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: She doesn't respond to emails, including time sensitive questions, nor grade timely (~80% of grades released 3 weeks til semester end). The class is a ton of work, yet my Spanish skills are worse. The final is an essay/portfolio of your progress, reinforcing her deluded belief of the efficacy of her class. This course killed my passion for Spanish.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: literally LOVE HER!! nicest teacher ever. theres a lot of assignments but they aren't anything unmanageable, just a lot of article readings and movies to watch. you also do a lot of group assignments so sit with people you like. she calls on everyone but shes very understanding and kind about it so dw if you aren't super fluent in spanish

I took Cultural Conversations with Professor Mangione-Lora and absolutely loved her! She is quite possibly the nicest human being I've ever met. I will say there is a ton of homework for this class, and you will have a full essay, an entire movie, or a long reading passage/questions every class period, but only some of it gets graded.

Profe was unlike any professor I have had before. She was understanding and made classes engaging, oftentimes accommodating lectures to encompass real-world occurrences. We spent a lot of time working in groups with students in class and from Mexico. It was difficult to know where you stood grade-wise though because she did not post them at all.

She is a great professor and really cares about your improvement. The only issue I had with her class was she waited until finals week to start grading any of our assignments so it was hard to know where you stood in her class. Other than that she was understanding that we are not fluent yet and really only wanted us to improve!

This class is amazing! She is the best Spanish teacher I've ever had, and I'm taking her again in the spring. My Spanish has improved so much with her help. She cares about the success of each student. Make sure you come to every class. She is a slow grader. She gives you a very clear study guide for each test and allows corrections.

Professor Mangione-Lora is one of the best professors I've ever had. She is so caring and always available for students. She truly wants to see her students grow and succeed. There are tests every couple weeks but they are not that difficult as long as you understand the topics. What truly matters is your ability to use the Spanish language.

The way she explains things in class is so unclear; you're better off reading about a concept from a textbook than listen to her craft a murky explanation. Also, if you wanted to go back and look at the slides to teach yourself the material, you won't be able to because her slides mostly contain diagrams with little to no words.

This course is a total weed-out for neuro majors and Boyd is the only professor. She is very crass and has little respect for students and their success in her course. That said, she seems a lot worse than she is. She adjusted the grading scale to account for low averages and counts homework as a large portion of the grade. Neuro is hard but doable

Dr. Boyd is awful, but she's the only option for Intro Neuro. You have to deal with her. Her lectures are interesting, and the content itself isn't complicated, but her exams are impossible. Be prepared for averages in the 70s. However, she cushions the grades with homework worth 40% of your grade (answers on quizlet) which makes an A attainable.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Boyd is an amazing teacher for Neuroscience and Behavior, who tries hard to make her lectures engaging and the requirements well-known. The tests are very detail-oriented, so make sure to read the textbook, and engage heavily with the lectures because exams are a large portion of your grade.

I like Prof. Boyd's lectures and the class is very interesting, but she is pretty brutal to students and not terribly invested in people's success. That said, the class is generally fair, and the grading criteria offset the serious difficulty of the exams somewhat.

Intro neuro requires a lot of work, particularly textbook readings. The tests are hard but homework is weighted fairly to help offset that. Dr. Boyd can be funny at times during lecture but condescending towards students as well. Don't take unless you are ready to devote a significant amount of time to preparing for every midterm.

Overall good professor but often, some things that end up on the exam are sentences she only says once very quickly and they're easy to miss. You need to be writing down nearly everything she says. If you have an average writing speed like me, recording the lectures is essential in doing well in her exams.

Took her NSBH40300 course and this was the most entertaining class i have ever taken. She does give GREAT feedback on all of the assignments. Read her comments and improve over course. It is simple to pass if you adapt in her class.
rating_tags: Group projects--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Ok hear me out on the rating. She is a good Prof. and lecturer - lectures are straightforward and exams match that and the reading. Now, she could be a questionable person in kindness. She deliberately scheduled all the neuro exams during orgo. If anyone asked if she moved them, she would get upset. You have to take her, not that bad but painful.

Sunny Boyd is my favorite professor ever. Just watching her teach makes my day. She loves frogs and she gave us bagels. You have to take her class as a neuroscience major, so you don't have a choice but that's good because she is the best.

Professor Robichaud is an excellent teacher and very accessible outside of class with her office hours. She cares a lot about the material and wants students to succeed. Her exams are pretty tough but I learned a lot both in class and from reading the (optional) textbook. Probably my favorite class this year.

Great professor, I took her for Physiology and she knows her stuff. She also likes to tie in anecdotes and some parasitology facts into this class which honestly helps a ton and maintains the class' interest. The textbook listed with the course is not required and the tests are solely based on the in-class lectures. Would recommend!

Took her physio class and it was relatively easy as long as you paid attention in class. She takes random attendance but gives you a few free passes. She made the lecture interesting and cared about making the class an easier workload for us! She even moved an exam because it overlapped with another course many students were also taking.
Very knowledgeable-- took her for parasitology and I never felt confused. Not too much homework and the workload is definitely manageable.
Prof Robichaud is a good professor. You don't really need to pay a lot of attention to get a decent grade, but in-class attendance is always taken. Pretty easy A if you do the quizzes and homework

Easy physio class but the professor is just very dry and strict. Typical librarian stereotype that you see in cartoons applies to her. Also takes in-person class attendance seriously even though we are in the middle of a pandemic.

Group project heavy with very tough grading. Was told to take this class because he was a great guy. I looked at previous reviews on rate my professor, and in the past it seems people liked him. Now I look at the new reviews and seems like many other people experienced the same issues as I did with this guy this semester. Would not recommend.

Honestly a formatting class. You learn useful excel stuff at the start but then down hill from there. The grading is insane. Format one thing wrong and you're getting points off even though he always misspells instructions. Have fun doing 10+ of work a week! Says that he hates the Mendoza curve but creates his own to destroy your final grade.

Would honestly would never take him again.Very inconsistent grading and super nitpicky.Takes points off because one visualization in power BI has size 9 font vs size 10 font.Even when you technically follow the “rubric” he finds ways to take points off.He screwed everyone over on the participation grade.Also get ready for 10-12 hours of hw per week

Grading is tough, inconsistent, subjective, and unclear which causes a ton of frustrations. Workload is pretty high for a foundations class - would typically spend 5-6 hours every Sunday on his assignments. Overall experience wasn't bad but I wouldn't take his class or a BA class again.

Prof. Lewandowski is funny and kind, but the class is challenging. Grading is harsh and inconsistent, creating a curve like outcome despite his dislike for it. Expect 5–10 hours of work weekly. Group projects depend heavily on your team. Exams and quizzes are fair. Participation in leadership topic discussions can significantly impact your grade.

I was told to take Professor Lewandowski, I wouldn't recommend him. All about group projects, which take forever to complete,one indiv assnmt. No final exam, brutal grading. He's extremely strict about deadlines—no flexibility at all—and it takes him at least a week to grade anything, which can be really frustrating. Outside of class, he's caring.

Great guy but the TAs grade almost everything and nothing is consistent. He makes formatting mistakes in his PowerPoints yet deducts heavy points for tiny formatting errors. The amount of work and assignments that you have to do every week is insane as well. Probably close to 10+ hours when you have projects due.
