Prof. Lewandowski is a very personal professor. Committed to getting to know his students if they want to get to know him, he makes students feel very comfortable. You learn everything on your own and then when you have trouble with something he helps you. A stickler for professionalism docks significant points for names, proper formatting, etc.

I loved the concepts we learned and the way things were taught. One thing I did not like was the way that things were graded. He would take off points for spelling errors when his own exams and emails would have errors. He was not a harsh grader but none of the projects had clear rubrics so he could basically take points off for whatever he wanted.

Starts every class with dad jokes and leadership topics. Class is fun and collaborative. Only critique is exams were hyper specific to exact wording of something mentioned once on a single slide, but this is the new BTech replacement class so he returned a lot of points on unfair questions. One of my favorite professors here by far

Great Professor, keeps the class fun and engaging on a daily basis... will be sure to make you laugh. Take him for Btech, would highly recommend this class if you have any intention of going into Banking, PE, Data Analytics, or other investing fields. Fair class, tests are challenging but you are prepared well.
Good at teaching Excel and giving practical applications.

Prof. Goehler is a model professor, and Notre Dame is incredibly lucky to have him. I had him for both Design Thinking and Design Tools, and I've yet to have a singular poor experience with him. Goehler makes the content interesting and easy to learn, and he does not waste any time, so if he finishes lecture early, everyone is free to go. King.

Prof. Goehler's Intro to Design Thinking isn't the most interesting class of all time, but he certainly did his best to make it as entertaining as possible. The workload was manageable, he did a great job talking about real-life applications of what we're learning, and the group project is actually pretty fun.

A very kind, funny, and welcoming guy. I took his Intro to Design Thinking course and absolutely loved it. Due to the project-based nature of the class, he made sure to structure and grade exams fairly (even lightly at times). An overall awesome guy, if you take his class, be sure to chat with him about football and just get to know him.

Prof. Goehler is a great, down-to-earth guy who ran an engaging class. Make sure to get a group you like/can work with for your semester project. Although the class is labeled 2 credits, it's more like 3. However, the work is not hard. If you go to lecture and do the homework, you will do fine on the exams.

My second class with Prof Goehler was DoME. Hearing about the class from upperclassman and his past in teaching more difficult classes, I was worried about how hard it would be. However in his first time teaching it he did a really good job of making sometimes boring material easy to grasp, and made the series of projects to help us learn well.

Professor Goehler is great and you can tell he really loves what he does! Wants to get to know his students by name, and is an ND grad so really likes to talk about football and engage with students. If you do the work you'll do well. The semester project is career/design oriented and great to bring up in interviews. Made friends in the class too!
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Group projects--Hilarious

comment: Professor Goehler was awesome. He had previously taught at Valparaiso after being a student at ND, so his love for here is unparalleled. His Design Tools class was mostly based on SolidProfessor Lectures to learn, Solidworks homework, and a semester long project. He was hilarious, fair, and really made me like what we were learning.

I liked Rumbach and I had him for Lab 1. As long as you watch the lecture videos and read his textbook you'll be fine. The course starts off pretty tough and then gets a lot easier as the semester goes on. I think most people end with an A in the class. Office hours are super helpful as well, he's pretty nice once you get to know him.

He makes an effort to know all of his students which I appreciated a lot. He was accessible and fast answered his emails. His grading can be tough but it gets easier when you get the hang of it. The final exam isn't bad but using the textbook makes it easier to prepare for it. Overall, not a bad class and a great professor that I'd take again.

He definitely grades harshly, so be careful of formatting on your documents. Some say his textbook is unnecessary, I definitely thought it was helpful (it even includes code you need to use for some assignments and practice problems very similar to final exam questions). It's not hard to get a decent grade, but you have to work for it.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Harsh grading on memos: once you get the format down it becomes a lot easier. Interesting labs and after the first couple weeks once you get the rhythm, becomes a lot easier. The final is arbitrarily hard, probably to bring down the grade distribution, but only worth %11 of the final grade. If you're friendly he becomes a lot more pleasant

He grades extremely harshly, most of the TAs have no idea what they are doing in lab and are very little help, the opposite goes fro Dr. Rumbach who is very knowledgeable but has excessive expectations for Tech Memos which one will loose multiple points for petty reasons.

The material we tested in lab correlated to the other classes I am taking concurrently. It was very helpful to see the material from lectures used in a tangible way. Tech memos need to be done meticulously. But they are very useful to help teach good engineering practice. He is a very smart man, and he'll continue to make lab better every year

I learned so much in this class, and it was all important in the following coursework. Professor Rumbach has high expectations, but it is only to make us better engineers. Quit whining, or change your major.

Very bright man. Lectures for this class were practically useless. His lab videos were quite well done, and the actual labs were reasonable. Don't buy his book, waste of money. The lab Tech Memos were graded harshly, but it teaches you a lot about proper formatting. Not too hard of a class, but can be tedious at times.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: he is just an idiot. the other reviews below except the obviously fake one with 5 stars are right, he isn't a bad person but horrendous teacher. not helpful, pretty random grades and assignments, would not recommend.

So shocked by the bad reviews on here! I took Prof. Perez-Linan's Quantitative Political Analysis Using R class this semester, and he explained extremely difficult topics with ease. He is a fairly easy grader as well. He really wants his students to succeed and is a really caring person.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy

comment: Kind of shocked by the negative reviews; if you work hard and pay attention, it should be a piece of cake because he's an easy grader and class expectations are clear. He's not the most clear lecturer I've ever had, but I think he genuinely wants to see his students succeed and if you're confused, he's willing to meet with you to clarify things.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: he has no clue what he wants to "teach" each day. This class on R is the most confusing, complex and boring class Ive ever taken. probably will drop it but not surprised by these ratings. he is a fine person but just a really clueless "teacher."

yeah no. just don't take him, his syllabus and assignments are so unclear it gives you a headache. His final grades were kind of randomized, and he called students the wrong names in December. Nice guy, really really bad at teaching
nice but so confusing and bad. Seems to enjoy inconveniencing students lives. Random grader. Would get a beer with him but not recommend his class

I had Professor Weiss for Descriptive Astronomy.  I am not a science class person, but Professor Weiss made this class very memorable and educational.  Although it is a big-lecture class, Professor Weiss makes an effort to get to know her students, and she is very accessible, holding dining hall office hours and constantly asking for our feedback.

I had her for descriptive astronomy. She really cared about feedback from the class on things that we liked and didn't like about her teachings. Homework was super easy, and the quizzes were only three questions and also easy if you paid attention in class. Overall, very engaging and very easy course and her lectures were cool.
Very easy class with relatively easy grading if you put a little bit of effort in. Projects and lectures were good, but in-class activities were chaotic and confusing.

Easy class. She is very patronizing. If I wasn't in her lecture I'd think she was teaching a bunch of 1st graders. 

The way she grades is a little weird. Seems inconsistent but nothing major. Personally, I don't like getting demeaned so the whole talking to us like we're kids thing is really insulting.

As a senior who has had about 35 professors, I can hands down say Professor Weiss is the worst professor I have ever had. She is so unaware of the needs of her class despite constantly asking for our feedback (which she ignores). She quizzes us on content we never learned and in all honesty is not cut out for the teaching profession
The lectures were helpful in a way that I knew how to attack a problem when doing the homeworks. This class was really challenging for me but I always put in effort.

Professor Weiss is such a strange teacher. She CONSTANTLY calls on the class to participate and walks around the class to check on students participation. She doesn't realize the ineffectiveness of her teaching. She needs to be more lecture heavy and less interactive. Not engaging and should not be teaching college.

Flipped classroom. He is knowledgeable but does not really teach.  Two 5 minute videos per week were supposed to suffice for the entire course. They did not. It's easy to get by until exams come around. I've heard the other professors for this class are much better and easier classes. Do not take his class unless you have prior coding experience.

It's a flipped class, so the professor doesn't really matter. However, Professor Easley is a great man; he cares and is passionate about the subject. If you put in the effort, and go to the TA office hours, you'll be fine.
Flipped classroom, so professor doesn't matter that much but overall a good teacher. Nice guy. Better TAs-they taught me everything I know. Go to office hours otherwise ur screwed

Passionate about coding but does a poor job teaching in the flipped classroom. TA office hours and finding a good study group saved me. Only meets once a week but the asynchronous model is actually more difficult in this case. Only 2 exams (midterm/final) but very difficult. Don't take this class without 1-2 years of prior Python experience.

Though the classwork was not super hard, the assignments themselves were near impossible without help from the TAs or ChatGPT. Easley did not teach during the class. He was also extremely inappropriate with female students, touching my back during class and coming up to only me in class to ask about my weekend, getting close to me. DO NOT RECOMMEND

The flipped classroom made this class feel useless to me. He did not teach much at all, and I had trouble with even the most basic concepts. Over half of the class did poorly on the midterm, seeing as the test was among the most difficult I have ever taken. If you need a gentle push into coding like I did, this is NOT the class for you.

Flipped classroom so he doesn't actually do any of the teaching, so this isn't that important. He isn't great at explaining concepts, but he's an extremely nice guy who loves his subject. Two assignments at home per week which should take about an hour each. Questions on assignments are very unclear, and exam was poorly written.

Foundations of Coding is flipped classroom, so the professor is not too important, but Easley was not great at explaining himself when asked a question. I wouldn't say this recommendation should dissuade you from taking his section if it's at a good time for you, but he's likely not the best teacher for beginner python learners in any given year

The homework and textbook are useless, along with the TAs and Branco, for that matter. No one is accessible outside of their office hours and will most likely not respond to your emails. Practice exams were nothing like actual exams, and exams were application-heavy.

Dr. Branco was not a good lecturer and there would often be a couple random information-based questions on the exams that we did NOT learn. That said, her exams are easier than those of the other professors. TAs were useless and do not know what is going on. Branco is not accessible outside of her office hours. Homeworks have multiple tries.

The other person who wrote a review failed to mention that the 3 extra credit assignments are one point each. For a 350 point class. This class was hard and you need to spend a LOT of your time on it. Her tests have a lot of applicational questions so you have to really understand how processes work. The book and homework are not helpful.
Biochemistry is an intimidating class but Dr. Branco is an amazing lecturer! Class has lenient grading - 3 extra credit assignments and an optional final (that replaces lowest midterm).

Loved Dr. Branco for Molecular Neuroscience. There was never a class where I felt bored. She keeps everyone very engaged and always makes sure to ask for questions after doing in-class practice problems. She values active participation and wants you to build long-term memory on the material. Highly recommend taking this class with Dr. Branco!

Professor Branco is very invested in the classes she teaches. Very knowledge and utilizes unique teaching strategies to get information across to students. However, questions on tests can be difficult as she will only teach the basics of a topic, but ask very applied questions on the test. If you dedicate enough time to the class you'll be fine.

Dr. Branco is an engaging lecturer, and she is really intentional about reviewing previous material at the start of each class. Test grades are a combination of your individual score and your group score (re-taking the same exam with a group), which was odd at first but actually pretty helpful. Weekly homework is graded on effort, not accuracy.

Dr. Branco is one of the most amazing professors I have ever had. She makes sure all of the lectures have purpose, does many practice problems in class, and makes lectures interesting. She is super reasonable with amount of work and grading. She also does fun review activities and is amazing at explaining hard topics.

Absolutely loved having her for USem Family and Narrative Form. Really knowledgable professor who is funny and easy to talk to. The reading can be a lot at times, but she spaces it out. Always got great feedback on my papers - take advantage of her office hours, they're very helpful. Left the class feeling like I improved as a writer.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Wharton is an amazing individual. I was switched into her class, and felt a little uneasy about the topic "Family Narrative." Yet, Wharton made the class fun, engaging, and undeniably improved my writing skills. She is funny, caring, and extremely kind. I recommend taking her for USEM or writing and rhetoric.

I'm more a sciences person (econ major here) but Prof. Wharton made me want to do a double-major with the humanities. She can seem intimidating but she is very nice and easy to talk to. I was worried about my final paper, but with her help I wrote a research paper I really cared about. W&R was so much better than I thought it was going to be.

Prof. Wharton is so nice. I was intimidated by her at first but she is kind and helpful. English is not my first language and she was very patient working with me. Very clear lecturer and good at jumpstarting class discussions

She is super hot, no joke. The class was difficult and the essay assignments were often hard to follow. The class a whole didnt seem very organized. Professor Wharton is funny and nice, though, and she is good at leading discussion. She cold calls (and calls out) people - so be sure to do the reading!
Professor Wharton is kind and very articulate. She can be difficult to understand sometimes but she is really helpful if you come see her after class or in office hours.
easy and interesting!

Everyone loves Prof Zhao. Really charismatic and passionate person who made the class very enjoyable. Course itself was so easy and enjoyable. If you get comments from your TAs (which is recommended to the class), you shouldn't really get anything other than an A. I legitimately haven't met a single person who didn't love his class. Def take it.

Good lecturer, can convey new material well. Not for hardcore philosophy students, at least not in the intro class. Was popular with students.

Would be at least a 4 but there was a controversy in which several students' paper grades were lowered weeks after the fact and I didn't like how he handled it, but I imagine the average student is fine.
Really good guy, very well organized, not too much work.

Pretty easy class, 2 reader responses a week, 3 short argument analyses, 2 2k word papers, and a final exam. Mandatory attendance for lectures. Just don't bomb the argument analyses and papers and it should be an easy A. TA's grade fairly strict on papers though so you should go to office hours before submitting or email for feedback.
Great dude but like yea
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof Zhao is a great guy and makes boring topics entertaining. Attendance is "mandatory" but you can skip up to 5 classes making it very doable.
Professor Zhao was a vibe; his polls were the best thing of the lectures.
Prof Zhao is great. He makes challenging concepts easy to understand and is a very talented lecturer. Not too much work outside of class. Would 100% recommend taking him for intro philosophy.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Great dude, two papers one final exam, after class reading response
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Such a great professor—knowledgeable, helpful, and entertaining! Explains concepts well with examples and answers anonymous questions during lectures. Fair grading, helpful TAs, and a manageable workload. Everyone loves him. Highly recommend!

Prof. Zhao is the best professor I've had at Notre Dame. He makes his lectures incredibly engaging, and he grades very fairly. It's not a free A, but if you put in the work and go to his and the TA's office hours you should be able to get an A. Chill homework assignments. Overall goated professor

Professor Zhao is AMAZING!!! Very funny and makes his lectures engaging. I took his Intro to Philosophy and he is very accommodating with his grading— allows five unexcused absences, drops five homework grades, etc. He is also very helpful at office hours. 10/10 recommend!

Perhaps the best professor I've had at Notre Dame. If you're a philosophy major and have the opportunity to take his class, definitely seize it. Very smart, gives great feedback, very fair exams that are graded charitably, not too much work, lenient with paper extensions, and he gives engaging lectures. He's also a really nice guy.

I took him for Calc B and honestly I learned the whole course by myself. He is very nice and really tries that his students understand however he has a very thick accent which made it really hard. The calc B department is overall not very good so if you have to take him, it would not be the worst but also not the best.

Calc III uses mastery grading, so it honestly isn't too tough as long as you do well on the exams. Combined with Professor Starchenko's excellent lectures, the course honestly isn't super difficult. Study for the MCQ exams, pay attention during lectures, and you'll do great.

Professor Starchenko is very intelligent and direct, but he avoids overcomplicating difficult topics. However, there were times when it was hard to follow lecture examples because he moved through solutions so quickly. The class moved fast and took a lot of work to keep up with, but it was manageable.
Decent teacher, can lecture a bit fast sometimes, but that is to be expected of someone who is an expert in their field

He is very nice and helpful when approached outside of the classroom. However, his lectures are sometimes a little confusing because of his accent. He also speaks very professionally about calculus instead of dumbing it down which makes it harder to learn.

Eric is incredible; his class is extremely informative and enjoyable. He frequently gives extra credit and is a fair and generous grader. Readings include law cases that are long but he summarizes them in class; a couple quizzes and tests but they're online and super simple. He's very respectful and funny; lectures enjoyable.

His lectures are super engaging, something unique for a class of its size. He will talk back and forth with students in the lecture and poses questions to the class pretty regularly to drive participation. You don't need to read to do well in the class, but it helps a lot and the content is really interesting. Great class and great prof.

Super engaging lectures. You can get away with not reading for every single class. However, the readings are actually interesting and you'll know a lot more.  Quizzes and Tests in a way force you to read.

Eric is an amazing professor and a really great guy overall. He's super funny and extremely passionate about what he teaches, which makes the class a lot more enjoyable. He is definitely an easy grader and will regularly give extra credit or drop a question from a test or quiz if a lot of people got it wrong. 100% would recommend!

Eric is amazing! His class is just exams and quizzes, but they're open note and super easy (literally, I got a 100% on everything and I never did any readings). The average on one test was lower than he wanted (like 80%) so he gave everyone extra credit so we could all still get As. He is super passionate and engaging and it's a genuinely fun class
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Lewis is my favorite professor on this campus. She is an excellent educator and truly cares abt her students. Plus she's actually an ND alum

Prof. Lewis has helped me a lot this semester. She is very sweet and passionate about the course material. Her and Whaley are your best options for Bio 2. I'd recommend staying caught-up on pre- and post-class work as it can help you on the exams. Professor Lewis is very well-organized and cares about you as a person, not just an academic.

Professor Lewis is the best and genuinely wants everyone to do well. She teaches the content as clearly as possible in lecture in a way that makes the tests as clear and manageable as possible (she writes them), offers plenty of review sessions if you need them and is available to help literally any time. Absolutely take her for Bio 2 if you can.

Professor Lewis is such a caring and dedicated professor. Her weekend review sessions saved my grade! Her class was a bit fast paced and touched on a lot of information, but as long as you take notes and use the study guide for exams, you will do just fine. There is pre and post class work for each class, but the work usually does not take long.
Pre class and post class assignments every day that are a complete waste of time. Way too much busy work for a very simple high school level class.

He has to be one of the most understanding professors out there, very interested in what he teaches and it shows. He also makes the class very engaging, highly recommend to do the reading. He truely is one of the reasons that I stayed afloat this semester. He is truely one of the greatest blessings on campus.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Inspirational

comment: Fr Aaron is really qualified and gives very interesting readings. you can get away without doing the readings before class, but it does make papers and group discussions more difficult and he can tell. he cares about the improvement of every student and encourages exploration of unique ideas
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--So many papers

comment: Father Michka is still learning how to teach. Throughout the course he told us not to get lost in the details and just know the main parts from the readings. On exams and quizzes, however, he would test us on the details. The material and the lectures are interesting and discussion heavy. He will notice if you are absent from class.

He does not know how to teach. Does not show passion or interest for subject he is teaching. Lectures are boring and not engaging. He also does not care about his students. I would not recommend taking him.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Awesome professor who really enjoys his work. Graded by quizzes, 2 papers ~1200 word papers, and final exam. Lenient on grading quizzes and papers. 2-3 hours of work/week not counting studying for quizzes/writing papers. Assigns readings from textbook but they arent mandatory. Still would read it because it helps with doing just about everything.

Had us do five papers for the whole semester ranging from 3 to 10 pages, so not a terrible workload. He's not too tough on the grades but not lax on them either. Make sure you at least skim the material before class or you'll be lost. Hachen himself is a total goofball but it keeps class interesting.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: He is very nice guy - you can ask for an extension for the paper. He even allows you to rewrite the paper if you are unsatisfied with your grade.  Very good professor for sociology - highly recommended!
He is pretty insane, but intelligent at the same time. loves to play blues music for us before class. TA's do most of the grading, but as of this year they are reasonable
He's kinda insane. And the TA's do the grading and evaluations.
No Comments

This professor was great when lecturing in the classroom, and he always made classes engaging which was unexpected for a leadership class. You will read some articles but they are interesting and so is the Individual Case Analysis & Group Project you will do. The exam... uhn uhn.

You can tell it's his first semester teaching here. Grading criteria is unclear and not particularly fair. Final exam was unreasonably long and the class overall was more work than a 1.5 credit course should be. Lectures were cool but there's no excuse for having the overwhelming majority of the final grade determined in the final week of class.

I would recommend Rosenblum for Foundations of Leadership! He is one my favorite professors I've had thus far at ND because his lectures were extremely interesting.The only long assignments were a case analysis paper and the group project that you work on throughout the half semester. There is one written exam that is quite long, but doable.
Exam was extremely long, almost nobody finished. Large amount of work for 1.5 credit class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Expect A LOT of work for a 1.5-credit class. His exam is CRAZY LONG and impossible to complete in the time assigned. The class itself is okay but you have to take notes since he doesn't make the slides available.

Professor Hogue is the most caring ITAO teacher at ND. Professors like Lewandowski are Bad! They speed through the material; this is sharply contrasted with Hogue. She makes sure no one is missing anything and that everyone is prepared for the exams. Take her instead of the other ITAO professors.
Professor Hogue is pretty funny and great at answering questions when you have them. This class is pretty easy although the final is fairly difficult.

Prof. Hogue is AMAZING! Not sure if the students below had the same professor as me because she's hilarious and cares for each of her students. Don't be afraid to ask Prof. Hogue anything, as she is always willing to help! If I had the chance to retake her as a professor, I would NOT hesitate one bit. TAKE HER!!

Hogue is one of the better IT teachers from what I've heard. She communicates the topics well, and she seems to care a lot about her students. She tries to make jokes, but they don't usually do so well. She usually tells students what will be on the quizzes and tests ahead of time, which helps for studying but hurts the curve.

From what I've heard, Hogue is one of the better IT teachers. She goes through the class material and explains it pretty well. She also gives hints as to what is going to be on tests and quizzes (which could be good because it's helpful or bad because of the curve). She tries to be funny, but a lot of her jokes land flat. Overall, very nice person.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Extremely dense readings all semester long, and slides have minimal words. Laptops banned in class (even for note-taking). As a second semester senior, just avoid this dude entirely. Very tough grader as well
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: The grading in this class was crazy. It was really difficult to get an A on the work handed in. I have taken a lot of history courses and received better grades than this course which I thought would be fun. The topic is really interesting, but the grading and lectures were not worth it.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: The material in this class was very interesting, but the workload and grading did not make this class worth it for an elective. Prof's grading was insanely hard and the lectures were very long and dry. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this class to a non-history major.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Prof Soares is a really kind guy. That being said, his class is all him talking TO the students who rush vigorously to write everything he said down.. He is also an insanely hard grader and has very specific expectations. The highest score he gave on a paper was a 92. There is also a TON of work & the readings are rly boring.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Class was interesting and I enjoyed the material covered, but there was a ton of reading (probably 50 dense pages per class) that you were expected to fully digest for class. Papers are graded fairly harshly, but it did make me better at writing them. If you're looking for a challenge with a good prof, I would recommend.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Easy, really super easy.

Super easy writing and rhetoric. Professor Swanke is a lenient grader and as long as you do all the assignments and revise your papers you should get an A. She is also very flexible with attendance and deadlines.

Professor Swanke is an absolute gem. She makes the class inclusive and relaxing. Classes pretty much ran like a discussion, and she values student input. There were 3 papers (which you could revise for a higher grade), and they had pretty fun topics. She would also have a 1 on 1 meeting after a paper was due for feedback. 100% recommend!!!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Swanke makes writing and rhetoric all but boring. Most of the time, class was a group discussion/ conversation about a reading or topic rather than a lecture. She LOVES student participation and enjoys to hear comments and criticism regarding course materials. Work load is pretty light outside of a few essays (3). HIGHLY recommend taking!

Professor Swanke is one of the best W&R instructors. Her class has 3 papers (that you can revise) and a final portfolio. You have little assignments, typically before each class but not after the weekend. Her class is always so entertaining and a great place to make friends. Definitely recommend!
I cannot recommend Gurel's teaching. Sorry for that. I found her class dull and I did not learn anything that I already did not know. 3/10

Prof Gurel is such a kind and caring professor. She is very helpful in office hours and knowledgable about her topic. Also is very positive about students' opinions! Lecture could be a bit dull at times but was overall interesting. She truly wants her students to succeed and helps them do so. I recommend her class!
Not a good class.

Professor Gurel is super young and funny, so she makes class relatable. Unfortunately, it's kinda all over the place. I liked the class but didn't like my TA - who made the discussion class portion painful.

Get ready for the most liberal class of all time. This is not exaggeration. Gurel is super nice but she cannot hide her political views in the slightest. The intro class was pretty simple, and there weren't many graded things. If you're a decent writer, you'll get a B+ or better

Easy class for first theo, but don't take if you're passionate about theology (especially Catholic theology). Workload isn't bad, easy grader, but he is extremely slow giving back grades and feedback. If you have a different opinion, especially one that reflects Catholicism, beware because he can be condescending and pretentious at times.

This class was fine. Most of the grade was based on daily reading reflections, which he didn't give good feedback on. He also waited until the end of the year to grade almost everything, so you had no idea what grade you had, or if your response grades were improving. Overall easy, and better than some other intro theos I have heard, but not great.

He waited til the end of the semester to grade 80% of the homework assignments, so I didn't have a good idea of my grade in the class. He always read his lectures from a script and if you didn't interpret the bible his way, you were wrong. It's an easy class, but there are easier theology professors at Notre Dame.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Hes a really good guy and he doesn't grade hard at all

Super interesting guy and definitely learned a lot from this class. The readings prior to some classes could be lengthy, but overall the workload wasn't too bad. Highly recommend for a first theo--enjoyed it much more than I anticipated.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Arner has a passion for his subject, which is always evident. However, his class is rather boring for someone who has already learned all the subject material in the past.

Professor Arner was the perfect professor for my first ever theology class. He did an excellent job of teaching the Bible in a way that makes much more sense than I thought was possible. There is a good amount of reading required, and a short writing response before each class, but there shouldn't be a problem with those.
Highly recommend! Great lectures and intriguing conversations.

Far too partisan in the classroom for my taste. If you yourself subscribing to the left most corners of the political compass you will enjoy his courses. A dramatic lack of academic neutrality.

I also experienced wildly inexperienced/problematic guest speakers. Seemingly chosen by Fitzgerald.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: I adored Fitz during my capstone, he cares so much about his students and the goal for him was for us to see our projects succeed. He's a wonderful collaborator and helps you brainstorm but not in an overbearing way. He breaks concepts down where you can understand easily. Easy grading with genuine feedback, and very responsive to emails!

Professor FitzGerald is an incredible professor. He is deeply caring about all of his students and super respectful as well. He also is very understanding when it comes to mental health absences. His class is engaging and dynamic and you will learn something. I want to take one of his classes all 4 years here.

Dr. FitzGerlad is amazing! I'm ending my first semester here at Pace, and he is my intro to Peace and Justice Studies professor. This class is quite lecture-heavy but manageable. The only homework is a discussion question each week, and there aren't many papers. Dr. FitzGerlad is a very well-educated professor, and I can guarantee you'll like him!

Garrett is one of those profs that truly wants to see you succeed (inside and outside of the classroom). I had a lot of personal issues come up during the semester, and had some bad performance, and he was more than understanding in making sure that I could still get a great grade in the class.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: I enjoyed the History of American Capitalism course with this professor. Their feedback on written assignments is insightful. While the workload is manageable, actively participating in class discussions and submitting coherent essays are the keys to success. Basic effort through attendance and doing the readings will lead to a good grade.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: I took History of the Book. Really interesting lectures if you like history and do the reading. Most of the reading is doable and interesting, but it can be long, so brace yourself for that. Essays are difficult and take a while to write. Make sure to go to office hours because he will give you lots of extra help, which I appreciated.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: He is great!! Loved him!

Absolutely amazing professor! We were given a variety of readings to discuss and synthesize in class. His classes are manageable if you keep up with the reading and the largest challenge comes in learning to think for yourself. In my class there were no prompts for papers just requirements on how many pages were needed.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: The professor was truly amazing. Lectures were great and extremely informative, learned so much from the class, and he gave much space for creative writing when assigning papers. There were no exams in the class just readings, very few responses, and papers. 10/10 would take one of his classes again.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Accessible outside class

comment: Turned me off from anything in the art world. Thank you!
She is an okay-ish professor, but anything else immediately, no.
Go to path and take any other class. Save. your. gpa. and. mental. health.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Needs to work on people's skills

Extreme art snob that has out of touch grading rules. Claims her rules are fair but in reality the rules are out of touch and not accommodating to the student. This class made me realize the professor does not care about you and "the student is always wrong". If you want to take a class with Mr. Burns from The Simpsons take this class xx

Not being accessible outside of classes makes it clear you are just a student and below here. She is not willing to go over content with you, which is not fair to other students.  

Get ready to put on your professor's hat because you will be teaching yourself and doing her job that she fails to do. May tenure never come her way.....

She does nothing to help students!

 Good luck trying to figure out what is on the Mid-term it is a puzzle figuring out what is on there. The professor is a bit out of touch ngl.

Prof Minor is one of the best. I recommend her to anyone. She cares about her students so much and teaches with an enthusiasm you won't find elsewhere. Building Europe is excellent for anyone remotely interested in architecture/history. Her dog Dosso is a frequent visit to class too!

Love Prof. Minor. Her lectures are interesting and made me want to get an art history minor. There is a lot of reading for pre-class but its completion-based and participation matters in class. Her exams are not that bad and you write three essays. She clearly is passionate in the subject and in her field, I would highly recommend taking her class.

Professor Minor was great in gaining my attention in class. She lectured by telling stories and helped you envision the history. She assigns readings for every class and response papers for each one, so be prepared. However, she grades them on completion and is fair otherwise. You can choose which essays/papers and test prompt you want to do too!
He is such an amazing guy who cares about his students. Good lectures and great accessibility outside of class.
He really cares about his students. He gives good feedback to make sure that you succeed. Highly recommend taking his class
Professor Jo is the best
If you can take it with Prof. Jo! He is the best!
Great guy that explained well and really cared for his students. Was detailed with his feedback.

Incredibly unhelpful professor that does not care about advancing his students finance knowledge. He makes everything more confusing and just puts typed answers up on the board for the problems. You can go to his office hours but he would not know how to answer your question. The TA who is a senior) could honestly teach the class better than him

I would only take him again for his appearance. He makes me regret picking Finance as a major. He takes everything from the textbook and adds nothing to his class. You'd get more entertainment trying to scrub a bathroom floor with a toothbrush. Would not recommend. He still doesn't know my name, even though I sit in the front row and talk to him.
Eye candy

Everyone in the class finds him attractive, but unfortunately that doesn't make him a good lecturer. I extract the same amount of value from sleeping an extra hour and a half as coming to class. He's nice, but he's pretty confusing and his lectures are not incredibly helpful. His tests aren't crazy hard as long as you study.

Rizzo is probably the hottest, best-looking professor at Notre Dame. But beyond that, he is probably the worst professor I have had at Notre Dame. Does not explain things well. Goes through the notes as if we already learned the material. Does not thoroughly go through practice problems. Overall, would not recommend him for Corporate Finance.

Professor Jancha is amazing! She is kind, friendly, and personally makes sure everyone can participate in class. She speaks in Spanish in a way that is very easy to understand and is always happy to answer questions.

Prof Jancha spoke exclusively in Spanish, but she would explain questions asked in English as well as important directions. I felt the course covered a lot, but I also think she did a good job explaining all the concepts. If you have no prior Spanish, I would not recommend taking ROSP10110 with her, but take her as a prof.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Great professor. She is very clear on grading criteria and doesn't screw you over on tests or compositions. If you take some time every few weeks to study the vocab you will do well in the class. Class time is very engaging and never feels too boring.

I cannot say enough good things about Professor Jancha!! She is so sweet, always available, and wants her student to do well. I had her for two semesters, and I'm so sad I can't have her again. Definitely recommend to all looking to improve their Spanish!!!
Really nice professor, easy grader, fairly easy class as long as you do the assignments. Participation matters, but the class was fine, I definitely recommend her as a professor.
Shes very nice easy grader. HW and tests are very fair. Pay attention and try and participate and youll be fine.

Class was overall easy, but didn't grade our final exam ever, like hello??? You don't have to pay attention in lecture in order to write the papers. As long as you go to tutorial and do some of the readings, you'll be fine. I would have a much better review if he graded our final.

Professor Ocobock's classes are overall just really fun. I took him for Global Africa and he cares more about you learning something new than trying to achieve a certain grade. The workload can be very inconsistent though and you jump from doing nothing to reading full books out of nowhere, but it's manageable. No homework due for lecture days.

Mr. Ocobock was one of the best teachers I have ever had. He's a super funny and all-around good guy. He jokes around and makes the class a lot of fun. You have to really do well on the papers, but it is overall easy to get an A- or a B+. It's trickier to break through to that perfect A but not impossible if you're confident in your writing. 10/10.

Professor Ocobock is hands down my favorite professor I have had at Notre Dame so far. He is super funny and brings a sense of humor to class discussions that can be based on rather dark readings. He is also not a super tough grader, but you really do have to put effort into your writing regardless because it is 75% of your grade.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Knowledgeable teacher who is flexible with attendance if you are overloaded with work. A lot of reading and a few papers but you'll learn a lot.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Respected

comment: He seemed like a nice guy, although the subject matter wasn't particularly interesting (not his fault).  Wasn't a fan of the cold calling, but got used to it.  I think the bigger issue with the course was that the TAs graded everything, and they weren't the best imo.  Would take again, but he's provost now.
A great professor!

Professor McGreevy is the nicest professor I have had at Notre Dame. He truly cares for each of his students, and his lectures are elite. The paper topics for this class are interesting, but the grading can be tough. Be sure to go to your TA or McGreevy for help if you need it!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: He's an amazing professor and wants students to grow and succeed. Classes feature lectures and discussions. He teaches students to understand and apply big picture ideas instead of memorizing tiny details. For the final, we got to choose between doing a paper, a podcast, or a test, which allowed us to show our strongest work.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: He is a genuinely nice person who cares about his students. He gives excellent lectures that are easy to understand. He may occasionally call on students during the lectures, but it's manageable. He understands the subject well and has a great passion for it.

She cares SO MUCH about her students. During COVID year I was stressed about life in general and got behind on homeworks. She reached out to me and offered to meet on  weekends so answer any questions I had and make sure I really understood the material so I would be successful going forward. Believed in me a lot.

Dr. Woodard is one of the best ACMS faculty at Notre Dame. She is truly caring about both her students and the material she is teaching. She is accessible in and outside of class, answering many questions very well. She is by far the most organized professor I have had! Her tests are very similar to practice problems and things in class. Must take!

Woodard is an awesome professor in the ACMS department. She is very personable and a great lecturer. Her Intro to Probability class was not bad at all. Very reasonable HW's due once a week that definitely prepare you for the tests. There's 3 midterms (that you can use a notecard on) and her notes prepare you very well for these exams.

Prof Woodard has organized note outlines that she goes over in class. She is a clear teacher and her homework is similar to class examples. About a 1.5 hour workload each week. Exams are easy as long as you study and understand concepts (she allows notecards).
Fun and energetic. Teaches everything you need to know for exams. No complaints--HW levels are reasonable.

Luis is very clear. Very. His two TAs were world class, both PhD students, not some lazy upperclassmen. The exams and papers were explained extremely well, and his lectures + slides are all you need to study, they cite the readings as you need them. He's got a neat sense of humor and his class was well organized. Would love to take again later.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Super nice and funny guy, sometimes hard to understand but exams are exactly like the study guides

Professor Schiumerini is a fantastic and engaging professor. Lectures are well-balanced in content with some jokes sprinkled in. The actual class is not the most fascinating one I have taken, but it is fairly easy as long as you know the major points of the lectures.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: This class was great! Prof. Schiumerini is a great lecturer. He is very clear and helpful. Tests made up 90% of the grade, but he gave us a study guide with the questions in advance. If you study, you should get an A. There are no surprises. I attended every class, but attendance is not mandatory, except for discussion section on Fridays.

This class was good, but you need to put in effort. Everything is graded by TAs and you need to attend the discussion and participate. You can get away with not going to class but you 100% should attend. You can hypothetically not do the readings but for the exams and final essay they make life easier, so just do them. Not an easy A

Professor Robles is awesome! He cares about his students and wants to see everyone succeed and enjoy the class. He's also pretty funny, too. The course is straightforward, with 4 papers that range from 2-5 pages each. You are assigned readings every class, but you can get away with not reading everything, which makes the class very manageable.

Robles is a great professor that makes usem very interesting, especially for a literature course. Technically reading is optional since it's just discussion and you don't have to speak if you don't want to. Additionally, all papers are graded with completion (If you put effort into it, you will get an A)
He is the best professor extremely caring and give the best feedback on papers. All the readings were very interesting and he really cares about the feedback of his students. 10/10 professor!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Hilarious

comment: Professor Robles is great! There is a decent amount of reading but the in class discussions are interesting so you want to participate.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: I love Prof Robles! He is a super caring, kind, helpful guy who is genuinely interested in helping his students. My class became super close by the end of the semester--with him and with each other. Readings are not really mandatory, but you should read to contribute to the conversation. But if you can't or if you need to skip class, he understands
Prof. Weithman was pretty good, but, just as a warning, know that the TAs do ALL the grading without any guidelines from him, so this class probably varies depending on the year and who the TAs are.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Inspirational--So many papers

comment: Super nice guy, really wants you to learn. Assigns more papers than the usual, but the papers are like 2 pages so it's not horrible.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --So many papers

comment: Prof. Weithman was a JOY to have. Prof. Weithman is one of the most intelligent people I have ever met, yet he let students shine in his class. As someone not too interested in philosophy, I found myself surprised as how much I gained from the class at the end. Take Prof. Weithman if at all possible.

Professor Weithman is one of the best! Great professor and even better person! The Justice Seminar is a difficult course, but he is there for you along the way. He is the most accessible professor I've had, asI've never had to wait longer than ten minutes for him to respond to email. He also is great at explaining complex concepts in simple terms.
He did a great job explaining tough concepts and bringing together philosophy and history. He obviously had a passion for the subject and his lectures were great.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Amazing lectures

comment: She was really nice and inspired me to add an English major! Her instructions were always clear and she was available for questions outside of class.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Even for an English class I thought there was a lot of reading, but it was worth it. Prof. Maurer brings a fun energy to class and is funny as well as knowledgeable. It was a lot of work but a class I would recommend
rating_tags: Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: Was a good class. I was pressed for options during registration and even though I'm a major I wasn't too keen on the specific subject area going in, but I ended up liking the course a lot primarily because of the professor.

This is my second time in a course with Prof. Maurer and I really enjoyed it. It is true that she assigns quite a lot of reading, but the sub-field is my passion so I was generally fine with that. As well, she does give great constructive criticism on papers.
Great teacher. Very smart and funny, has an infectious enthusiasm.
Fun class on graphic novels. Learned a lot about different kinds of graphic novels and it was discussion based so that was good.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Dry professor, would not recommend.
what. just. happened. Confusing doesn't even say it.

The prof. is an okay teacher and isn't too tough a grader, and he has a cute accent, but the class is just straight up boring. Some of the class discussions just didn't even make sense. We read a lot of interesting things but I'm not sure I'm a better writer

He's a nice guy and he does a good job of incorporating new and topical material into class discussions. A few assignments were not very clear at all, which only makes his grades and comments frustrating to read. Would highly encourage seeing him in office hours. The class is sometimes really boring, but hey, that's a writing class
Don't take this class.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: BJ is by far the worst professor I have ever had. He chastises you if you get a question wrong in class, he has an accent that is very difficult to understand, and he only gives one midterm and one final, each worth 40%. The tests are impossible to finish in time, and the average score is an F. The only upside is that even a 45% curves to a B-.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: BJ Lee does not exactly do a good job of conveying any aspect of metrics to students. He will, however, let you know what will be on tests so if you can manage to extricate information from the notes, you'll be alright. While not a good teacher, he is hilarious (sometimes intentionally & sometimes not)--he literally patented a spreadsheet

BJ Lee is by far one of the top professors in the Economics department. He has an absolutely awful reputation among students on account of his old practices as he has taught at the university for 20+ years. He literally offers up the test questions in class, a true gem.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Hilarious

comment: Quite possibly the worst professor I have had in my time at Notre Dame. While he appears to have very in-depth knowledge of econometrics, he is utterly unable to impart any of it in his classes. His speech is dificult to decipher and his writing and phrasing in questions are far too vague.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--TEST HEAVY--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: Easily one of the funniest and greatest professors I have ever had--if you are interested in Chinese history or culture, you MUST take his class. His lectures are incredibly engaging, the homework is very manageable, and he is a very fair grader on papers and tests. Just a fantastic course and person.
The best usem Professor and I highly recommend. Very helpful feedback for papers and made class extremely entertaining.
My favorite professor at Notre Dame. Entertaining class and not too much outside work.
Very intelligent and humorous man. Suitable for students who do not have a background in Chinese but still want to learn about its culture and history or just simply need to take a usem course.

This class is awesome and Professor XY is a hilarious, highly intelligent man. If you fear taking Chinese Poetry (or any other of his classes), don't! I have no background in Mandarin or any Chinese language and I love this course. You simply read translated ancient Chinese poems and discuss them in class, then you write 4 papers over the year.

I had Prof. Parker for the OMNM Usem course. At first I was hesitant about him and I could tell the class was going to challenge me. While the class did end up being challenging, I wouldn't trade it for an easier Usem. Prof. Parker is fascinating and his advice shifted my perspective on how I live my life and view my future. Can't recommend enough

A good professor and an even better person. I find his class informative and entertaining. The OMNM USEM is a seminar style class and participation is important. This is not an easy class, but it is a rewarding one. In fact, this is probably one of the hardest USEM classes offered at Notre Dame. If you try your best you will do well.

An amazing professor and perhaps a class that could change your perspective on a myriad of topics. Gives personable advice and is a professor to look up to. Take him if you are lucky enough to get into his class!

He was my favorite professor of freshman year. I took him for USEM, and it is most likely the hardest USEM class at ND, but it was enjoyable as the class focused on discussion of heavy and controversial topics related to money. You become close with your classmates. Tough grader, but is exceptionally fair as the grade you get = grade you deserve.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: Dr. Parker was the best professor I've had at Notre Dame. It was obvious that he put adequate effort and care into his lectures. I took his OMNM course, and he was consistently personable, understanding, and encouraged fruitful discussion. He's a fair grader but gives good feedback and is available for OH often. Can't recommend Dr. Parker enough!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: ehs pretteh cool.
No Comments
No Comments
No Comments
Plants and Food made easy!

Professor Bergstrand is clearly an incredibly intelligent man, but is not able to articulate those thoughts to the students. Archaic teaching style--talking head in the front of the room with an overhead projector and 1000's of handouts. The midterm and final are merely a test of your ability to memorize and test taking skils. Did not learn much.
Good, helpful teacher. Positive and polite.
No Comments
No Comments
Excellent Professor!  Great Economist.

Professor Hartland is a genius, hands down one of the smartest people I've ever met. However, as nice and great as that is, he often speaks to us as if we know everything he does, which is not the case. On top of that, he is a powerpoint reader, so there's not much learning done really in class. Great guy, well-known and all, just can't teach.
Good teacher, not really available very often except right after class
He was a great prof.  Cute drawings fairly easy to understand even with the accent I loved his jokes.  It is still a chem class but if you need help there are people available.
Very nice guy with a sweet Australian accent. He's pretty easy to understand. Also, his drawings are awesome! I would definitely recommend him for Gen Chem.
awesome prof. very helpful. sweet aussie accent

He is an amazing professor, honetly one of the only reasons I am still afloat after my first semester. He barely give work, I only have 2 essays and two exams, but he ended up making the final exam optional. Highly recommend his class, I don't think I have heard of anyone complaining about him at all. Completely fair man, and pretty funny.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Prof Bays is clearly really passionate about philosophy and it shows in his lectures. He's fun and funny and its easy to get away with a good grade without doing the assigned readings, one of which he gives before each class. he assigns readings in person in class and does not use canvas.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Graded by few things

comment: Tim is a great professor. He assigns a lot of readings, but you can get by without reading them if you pay attention in lecture. GO TO OFFICE HOURS for his papers; it's a huge help!

The class only consists of him ranting about the most random philosophy topics. It was sort of interesting but in order to get a lot from the class you have to do a lot of the expected reading. His style of teaching is just being like a mentor to someone who already likes philosophy. Not great for someone that only takes it because it's required.

Tim is knowledgeable and genuine. In his introductory course, he gives two essays and two tests. If you do the essays in advance, he can give you feedback before your final submissions, which is very helpful. Truthfully, in this class you get out what you put in. You can coast or you can engage with the readings and speak in class.

Sr. Ann is one of the nicest people on this campus! She genuinely cares about you and wants you to succeed. Office hours are very helpful for help with papers. There is a 1 question short answer quiz every class based on the readings. There is a midterm and final exam in addition to 3 papers and daily quizzes.

Very sweet and kind teacher, and she gives students some extra credit opportunities at the end of the year. However, as someone who never went to a Catholic school, her class was extremely difficult for me. The tests at times felt near impossible, with questions that had choices from A-E. Do not recommend unless you have a good Biblical background.
rating_tags: EXTRA CREDIT--Beware of pop quizzes--Test heavy

comment: Sr. Ann is a very sweet person. She really cares about her students and really loves teaching the class. This is probably my favorite class I've taken so far, and I am not a theo major. Lots of readings and 1 question daily quizzes, but mostly manageable workload. 2 essays. Memorization required for exams.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: The hardest thing about the class is the writing-intensive part. The theology part is relatively easy if you read the material expected, however, the papers are harshly graded for grammatical errors.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: Sister Ann is a very kind woman and really wants students to do well in her class, but she is a harsh grader because the theology university seminar is a writing-intensive class. There was a lot of work given out, but she is always available if you need help and loves when students go to her office hours.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Tough grader

comment: Sr. Ann is a very sweet nun. She's knowledgeable on the topics she teaches and not a very tough grader. There is a lot of reading and daily 1 question quizzes, but overall the workload isn't bad. As a theo major I like the class, but I know that other students find it boring. Tests usually involve memorization and essay questions.

His Intermediate Macro course is a safe bet. His midterm and final are really easy, and the workload isn't bad. Classes are entirely lecture based, and they're helpful, but a bit boring. He seems like a nice guy.
He did his best to make the content easy to understand, but he was a bit dull and it was difficult keeping his students engaged. Most of your work is graded by TA's.
he's a good prof and lecturer. very sweet man. You need to put in effort for this class bc it's not easy. the exams and problemsets were kinda hard

Goedl isn't the best, but isn't the worst. Intermediate Macro has a lot of hard problem sets and readings. The tests can be difficult and graded unclearly. He is more disorganized than I would have liked, constantly forgetting to post assignments and changing due dates. Nice guy though, and is respectful to students. He has a dope Austrian accent!
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Graded by few things--Lecture heavy

comment: Not bad-- very nice, clear, and organized.

Great professor, wholeheartedly enjoyed her lectures. Makes the material interesting and teaches it incredibly consistently such that grading is never subjective. Reading is relatively light compared to other theology classes and to the point, and creative writing assignments are a lot of fun to do. Definitely recommend if you can take her.

Her class was very engaging and assignments were creative but she was VERY unclear about expectations for assignments. If you prefer to take notes electronically on iPad or laptop, she doesn't allow electronics during class. My biggest issue was that sometimes she said things that weren't biblical at all and misinformation. Take a priest's class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Very engaging lecturer that really gets to know students. Class is not too much work, with ~4 papers that are short, creative assignments. There are readings, but she will never put information on the test that isn't covered explicitly in class, and gives resources to prepare for exams. Overall, great professor.

Thought her grading was unnecessarily harsh and assignment instructions weren't clear about expectations. Its frustrating that this theo was harder than my major-related courses and tanked my grades despite working hard at it. This being said, I loved her interactive lectures and she is a very kind understanding person.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Professor Leyerle is one of my favorite professors. She is so caring and respectful of students and their stress, but does not baby sit them. She is one of the best lecturers and engages EVERYONE in discussion which is funny sometimes but also let's the students learn in a more engaging manner. 5 papers and two exams in total. Great Class.
Navia was a great beginning Spanish teacher. She explains concepts clearly and is very easy to follow. Definitely recommend if you need a beginning Spanish class.

Very sweet and caring teacher. She really cares and tries to make the content engaging. As long as you put effort into the textbook homework and participate in class, you'll do well. She's on the student's side and tries to help us out (like giving us hints for what to study for tests). I highly recommend Profe Navia.
Not the most helpful lectures, but she is very kind and interesting.

Overall a good professor. The only noteworthy negatives are that she does not necessarily answer questions well and can get frustrated if students are not understanding the things she is teaching. It is pretty easy to get an A-/B+ but I would say hard to get an A.

Professor Navia really cares about her students and takes the time to make sure everyone is on the same page. I definitely recommend her class. She also spoke mostly in English, which was appreciated.

I love Professor Navia! 100% recommend. She's very sweet and caring toward her students and a great teacher. She taught the class in English too, with some things spoken in Spanish. Very detailed in her explanations and lectures, and tests were fair.

Eubank is one of the nicest, most genuine professors you'll ever meet. Hilarious and INCREDIBLY knowledgeable. Attendance is mandatory at every lecture, but it's fair in my books since his lectures are so engaging. Final exam was a little stressful to study for (had a Scripture Identification portion), but it was very fair and quizzes are all easy.

I really enjoyed this class and recommend it to anyone wanting to take Foundations of Theology. There are no essays in this class which most Theo 1001 classes have. Our grade was based mostly on easy reading checks and unit tests. He makes the lectures super interesting and I always felt engaged. There are readings assigned for each class.

Professor Eubank is such a g. Taught at Oxford so he's insanely knowledgeable, but dumbs stuff down so that anyone can understand. Sure there are readings "every day" but just pay attention and take some notes in class and you should get an A. 3 tests including the final and you'll get an A if you go to study sessions and somewhat put effort in. EZ
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures--Lecture heavy

comment: This guy was awesome! He was always so kind to those who raised their hand in class and he always has open discussion to really engage students within the content. The exams are always based on lecture so make sure to attend class
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: The guy is a gem. His knowledge on the Biblical History is something to be beheld and his snarky disposition always makes class a lot of fun. This guy knows his stuff and is not afraid to tell everyone.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: She is an amazing professor with a lot of knowledge. I came into this course with not the most confidence in my French speaking abilities, and she was very accessible and very helpful in helping me become more confident in my abilities. I would highly recommend her as a teacher, participation is huge for her though, so be prepared for that.

She is a pleasant professor and makes her lectures fun with activities. However, grades kind of harsh on assignments, of which there are a lot of, which means a lot of minuscule errors lead to multiple points removed. Wish there was less assignments. Participation also is huge for her.

Very fun class with an AMAZING professor. Most grades were done through projects, and I promise that your level of effort directly correlates to a good grade. The homework was dense at times, but overall I would highly recommend this class to anyone seeking to expand their French knowledge and/or their business knowledge!

I loved her Intermediate I class and would definitely take it again. She encourages participation and is extremely kind. It had been a while since I had taken French and she was extremely accessible. This is the professor you want in the French department. A LOT of assignments and the class isn't easy, but you really learn so much and enjoy it.

Prof. Schaefer is an incredible French professor that I would happily take again. She makes her classes engaging, she heavily encourages participation, and uses a wide variety of content from books to movies to broaden your understanding of French culture. I would highly recommend this class, you will learn so much French surprisingly fast.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: This class is centered on French cinema, so don't be surprised when you're given movies to watch for homework! Dr. Schaefer is a tough grader, but the homework and tests are manageable. You can tell that she cares about her students, not just the subject. She re-ignited a love of French that I lost years ago. Couldn't recommend her more highly!

Prof. Barone is genuinely the coolest person on campus. However, she is not a good lecturer, and every time I left her class I was always so confused. She gives tons of practice (5 practice exams per midterm and final, and a practice for every homework), yet her tests are way harder than the practice ones. I would take another Prof if I could.

Solid professor in that she teaches the exact material she tests us on and gives us PLENTY of study resources. Also very helpful in office hours. Intermediate micro is a hard class, so I don't think she made it overly difficult. Brush up on your calculus and be ready to work hard, but know that she's very caring and willing to help!

She is very nice, but just not good at teaching. Never understood the lecture; they always confused me more. The class itself is not bad, though. My grades on the exams and problem sets skyrocketed when I stopped going to class and taught everything to myself. This was hard, however, so I would recommend another prof who is better at teaching.

Don't get me wrong, Professor Barone as a human being is a 5/5; she is super nice and caring. HOWEVER, she is not great at making or presenting slides. She writes her own tests which are impossible; most people get Ds. Problem sets are fine I guess, but neither the problem sets nor the many practice exams prepare for the misery of the actual exams.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Barone is genuinely a kind person with a great personality, however she is not a good lecturer. Many of her slides are unclear and the lecture moves very fast. She writes her own tests and they are extremely too long for the time allowed. Not a single person ever got up and finished the exam early. Overall I would recommend another prof.

Prof. Barone was a good teacher. She was very clear in her instruction and really wanted us to succeed. She made sure we had ample resources outside of class (lots of practice problems, office hours, collab sessions, etc.) to be prepared for the exams. Overall, a solid professor.

Solid choice for honors intro to philo. He's a fairly tough grader and the entirety of our grade was 4 essays (lowest of the first two got dropped, so actually 3), but he'd identify any problems in your essay during office hours. Fairly large amount of reading, but most need-to-know information is on summaries that he hands out during class.
rating_tags: Caring--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: If you want a professor that is extremely qualified and experienced in the field, take Audi. If you just want an introduction to the topic and aren't a philosophy major, maybe seek someone else.

Audi is clearly passionate about philosophy. However, this course was far from an introductory course to philosophy. Amazingly taught if you have interest in philosophy, but for someone who is only taking it to fulfill a university requirement, it gets boring at times. Lectures and readings aren't so bad. Pay attention to wording. Sweet guy tho.

Professor Audi is a passionate philosopher. I was already interested in the subject, but I appreciate it more after taking his class. The amount of reading is reasonable. He does not grade based on participation, but he will call you out at times (lol). One issue is that he is *very* particular about wording, so beware if you struggle with that.

Professor Audi was great and I could tell how passionate he is about philosophy. I am not super interested in philosophy but if I were I bet I would have found this class a lot less boring. Unfortunately for me, every class was basically nap time. There was a lot of reading which was essential to doing well in the class. Easy grader and very kind.

A true philosopher in every sense of the word. Not like the others, who won't give respect to those who disagree with them. One of the few professors that I felt respected me. His intuition is golden. His publications numerous. I'm a psych major and he was right on the mark with many topics in the field. Truly, a reward to hear a man of his stature

I took 4 semesters of Marullo. Russian Language, Imperial Russian Literature, and Modern Russian Literature. They were some of the most rewarding and challenging classes I took at ND. If you have an opportunity to take any class with him, you owe it to yourself. He has deep knowledge and loves teaching. His dinner parties are awesome too.
I took this professor like 23 years ago and never forgot him and how much his class made me think and grow as a thinker.
Professor Marullo is great and his class was one of the highlights of my college experience
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: This man wrote all his emails in lowercase LOTS of reading in short time, 4-5 papers tops Wasn't afraid to fail students if they didn't write what he was looking for Will doc points for not reading all prep material or speaking in class Is not available Randomly call on you in class for questions Doesn't care abt life outside his class Not flexible
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Class discussions were interesting and he was a very engaging professor. I learned a lot and enjoyed the subject. However, he assigned a lot of reading (about 50-150 pages per class). While the papers weren't too difficult, he had a very specific idea of what he wanted and students often had to submit 4+ drafts to figure out what he wanted.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Very clear and organized classes, with simple and straightforward assignments. Likes to have discussions in class on the current topic.

His corporate governance class is a pretty easy A-. Easier than the other finance classes in Mendoza. Iffland and a TA do all the grading. Cremers is actually extremely boring, but he's very nice. The class was interesting. 7 problem sets, a take-home essay midterm, a 6-page paper, and a couple small assignments. They took us out for drinks twice.
His work on active share and shareholder rights is amazing.
Hard course.

Prof. Cremers did an excellent job of first building our knowledge in the three categories of corporate governance.  Once our foundation was built, we explored many cases to apply these concepts to real world examples making the learning more memorable and applicable.

He gives good feedback and is a perceptive and even generous reader of student work. Some class sessions were insufferable, though. It's sometimes funny, but mostly just annoying. He really does talk about himself ceaselessly.

I was excited to take this course but ended up pretty disappointed. O'Rourke does offer keen commentary about student writing - - his notes on my work were really insightful in a few cases - - but actual class time was a waste when we weren't workshopping. He does talk about himself. A lot.

This was the worst class I've ever had to sit through.  It was fun to write the stories and get feed back, but I actually dreaded him opening his mouth cause he was just that boring.  And most of the time all he talks about is himself, or the famous writers he's friends with.
