He polished paramount topics of academia that few even have the courage to discuss. A man amongst children. He settled the tides of dispute, disruption, and turmoil with ease and elegance.

This was the hardest class I had first semester, but it was worth it. The professor is knowledgeable and clear, though the pace is fast because of the curriculum. Since there were only two professors, they had control over the exams, and I KNOW he purposely made them harder than the past exams. Overall, great guy and hilarious!

Very clear spoken, but moves fast. Super reasonable guy - gives formulas for trig identities on Calc II exams and this year allowed two bottom tutorial quizzes to be dropped. Cares about student success.

Professor Salter was great for Calc II. I had to start going to his lectures because another professor I will not name was not cutting it for me. There are lots of online resources and information about what will be on each quiz and exam, et cetera. The information is there to get an A if you work for it. Overall a good class.
Amazing teacher. Makes calc 2 much more understandable.
He taught well and gave a packet with the notes which helped when reviewing for tests.

Had Prof. Salter for calc 2 and he was pretty good. His lectures are pretty easy to follow, he uses the same packet to teach from that he passes out so you just need to copy the notes down. Some of the concepts are difficult but he's really accessible during office hours and email. I'd take his class again
I wouldn't say he is the greatest professor of all time ,but he is very personable and willing to help if you ask.

You will not find a better professor of rhetoric at a university. I don't know where the above comment is coming from at all--must not have ever talked to him before. If you show any willingness to work, this man will teach you how to argue well, which, as he says, is to argue responsibly.
He never explains assignments and likes to go on rants. He's also really high on himself. But when you do actually turn things in for a grade, he grades fairly.

Lectures can be boring, yes. Yes, you must show up. But the readings are technically optional in the fact that you don't have to say much during class to still get a good grade. Just show up and only participate when you feel like it. Very caring guy, pretty easy class.
Lectures can get boring, but does not require very much outside work. Papers are clear, and he is a very easy going guy.
No Comments

Robert Rosenbaum is one of the easiest ACMS professors you will ever have. He is not the best professor in the world, but he gives you all the notes you need for class and all 40 people in my class section received either an A or A- grade.
Very easy, and flexible yet fair and consistent with the syllabus. A really easy ACMS intro overall.
Used lots of examples.

Professor Howard is a brilliant, caring man who is a wonderful professor. His lectures are very interesting, and he is very accessible outside of class. He grades fairly and gives wonderful feedback regarding the papers you turn in. Take his class if you can! They is a lot of reading involved with his class, but it is interesting and not boring.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Amazing lectures

comment: Howard is the ideal professor to have. He is the nicest person ever and will likely give you an A if you try. It can be easy to fall asleep sometimes in his class, but he does offer a lot of cool information if you tune into the lecture. He is very intelligent and excellent at answering questions. Highly recommend.

Prof. Howard is one of my favorite professors at Notre Dame. He is incredibly knowledgeable and the nicest professor I have ever had. The class requires quite a bit of reading but Don goes through and explains everything in depth so you come away with a great grasp of the concepts. Show up early to class, get to know him and it will go a long way.

Prof. Gasse is great! His lectures are confusing a lot of the times but he makes up for it during his office hours. You can bring him any question you're confused on and he'll explain it in different ways which speaks to how much he cares about your learning. Try rephrasing what he's teaching and ask him if it's right. Would definitely take again.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: He cares a lot about his students and it shows in his flexibility, availability outside of class, and encouragement of all perspectives. His lectures can be hard to follow (mostly tangents that lack an overarching theme). He is particular with grading essays (but not journal assignments). He says that participation does not matter but it does.

Prof Gasse's class was amazing! There are no tests which is great, just keep up with the daily reading journals (super easy to do well on). He's super accessible outside of class and is always willing to help/talk about any concerns. He addresses any questions that anyone has and is super accepting to people of all backgrounds. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

She is very nice and understanding. Her lectures are interesting and she makes class very engaging. If you ever have any issues at all, related to class or not, she will go above and beyond to help you.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Group projects

comment: Had her for intro to engineering. The class is about discerning your major, yet she made the class very interesting.
Professor Goodrich is down to earth and makes the often boring lectures of Intro to Engineering interesting.

Dr. Leighton is a fair prof, and while he can tend to insult a student sometimes, this is not intentional, and you just need to let it slide. I had him for Transport 1, and he knows it like the back of his hand. My 3/5 rating: he simply struggles to explain the material on a level that the students can understand. Office hours are key to succeeding

This is a very challenging course. Only one midterm exam and a final compose the grade. Suggestions: look at all assignments and past exams. Know each problem set-up. The professor cares about the students and will grade nicely if they show effort on the exam.

I took him for NumStats and am taking him again for Transport next semester. He grades fairly, and teaches very tough material decently well. He uploads great notes online. The class is hard, and the homework is brutal unless you are great at coding, but it is reasonable to get a decent grade. He is very available outside of class.

I highly recommend taking Professor Cutter if you are in the Glynn program. Readings are manageable (5-10 p) and homework consists of short summaries for each reading and two 3-5 p essays. Definitely have him read a draft of any writing assignments before submitting them. Participation is necessary and graded and exams are easy with no tricks.

Professor Cutter was great. The amount of homework is very manageable, and the flow of the class is great. The style of class is discussion-based, and he intervenes when he needs to. Hes very laid-back and accessible outside of class. Id recommend him.

Cutter is ok. I took God and the Good Life with him, and while he was fine, I would have rather taken it with Meghan Sullivan because she's just more animated and more entertaining than him. My sustained discussion group had problems with the grad TAs grading, but one of my SD leaders emailed him, and Cutter dealt with it the situation well.

She is a caring and highly intelligent woman. We had great convos during office hrs. She does expect a lot from her students, so do not think her class will be an easy USEM. A lot of (very interesting) readings, pop quizzes, and 3 10-12 page papers. She did lessen the workload after student feedback, so she clearly values our opinions. LOVE HER!!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Professor Ocobock is definitely a hard grader, but she is an awesome person. I have gone to her office hours and we have had some great conversations. You can tell she really cares about her students and wants to prepare us to do well. She expects a lot from students, but she is also willing to take feedback and work with you.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: I won't sugarcoat it, Ocobock is a tough Professor. However, I have never had such a caring and understanding professor in my time at Notre Dame. Not only is she fantastic and an expert in her field, she is funny, and great to be around. She WILL push you to go beyond what you believe you can do and is not afraid to push. 11/10 take her class!

She's not a bad teacher. Just a snoozer. She also asks for too much... the class is pretty simple and straightforward so you'd think the papers you have to write wouldn't require much explanation, but they definitely do. Lastly, go to class, even if there are over 50 people in the class, she will notice you gone and email you an hour later
rating_tags: Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.--Tough grader

comment: Test heavy, but plenty of easy extra credits to get at least a B. Professor Gibson does not care about lectures and reads off a script, but they are very important to the tests which are hard in a subject already not easy. Does not care about attendance.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Test heavy

comment: Lectures are EXTREMELY boring, but make sure to write down everything he says. He will put the most random things on the exams, so this course is memorization heavy. That said, I would take it again because it is not difficult. Make sure to read the textbook because at least 5 questions from there will be on the exam. Homeworks are free 100s.

He may be extremely boring, but if you get to know him he's so quirky and funny. His class was so easy, he literally gives a 100% on every homework assignment, and the tests are not bad if you take good notes.

Exams are the only grade, based on a combination of lectures and assigned reading. Readings and lectures sometimes diverge, usually based on the same things though, but you need to know both. Seems like he cares about his students but it doesn't translate into quality teaching. Really bad at answering questions and doesn't keep up with schedule.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Test heavy

comment: The man, the myth, the legend right here.
Great guy. Cultivated a welcoming environment.
Great teacher - highly recommend
Unrealistic teachings, can't be applied to real life
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Respected

comment: This professor has a very specific way he thinks about things, and he expects everyone to think along the same lines as he does. He often tries to explain concepts in roundabout and convoluted ways, leaving the entire class confused. Then when students ask him to explain it differently, he just refuses and criticizes us for not thinking like him.

Prof. Betson is fine in class, just gives long rambling lectures that don't seem to matter very much. The exams are always super confusingly worded, so the class avgs are low, but the curve is pretty good. However, an A in his class is 95-100, so I'd say expect an A- unless you put a lot of work in.

He is everything that you could want in a theology professor and more. He is super clear at explaining complex topics and organizes his class in a really relevant way (e.g., reaching the passion narrative in Holy Week). His papers are (productively) challenging, but he is super willing to help. Same for exams (his review sessions are super helpful)
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: One of my favorite professors that I have had so far at Notre Dame. Professor McKenny cares a lot about his students and does a great job of making them think and consider issues in a new light. There is a bit of reading and a few 4-5 page papers, but as a whole, his class was my favorite of the semester.

Hands down one of my favorite teachers at Notre Dame. You have reading assignments for each class which isn't bad. You are given 10 short answer questions on a study guide and there 3 of the questions are your quiz. (5 quizzes overall) There are also 4 (5-7 page) papers. Amazing teacher! He cares about the students, so participating helps.
Great prof.
Probably because the course is virtual, the quality of the lectures are mediocre at best...
Not sure what is going on, the course is just lecturing from books. He seems not familiar with the concepts from functional analysis, which is what ACMS40950 is all about.
She is a very good professor. Very nice

She is sooo sweet, and works super hard to make sure class is engaging and unintimidating. She'll bend over backwards just to make sure you get the support you need. One of my favorites in the Chinese department for sure!

I've taken language classes my whole life and she is the best I've ever had. She engages all students' multiple times a class and really makes sure you process, understand, and learn the material. You can tell she loves her job, and cares for her students. I am definitely taking more of her classes in the future.

Started taking attendance again after the first exam bc she realized no one came to class. Daily writing assignments due before every class, but they're an easy 100%. Nice professor overall but left a rude comment when I requested a regrade on the final exam because I already had an A in the class. Exams aren't bad, just study all the concepts.
Very engaging lecturer and makes this class an easy A while ensuring that you learn a lot!

Langenkamp is a super nice professor that makes the class really easy. You have a daily written assignment with readings before each class but these are quick and easy. Exams are not hard and are mainly based on vocabulary and applying to examples. Quizlet is great for her class. Go to the lectures before Fall/thanksgiving break for extra credit!

Dr. Langenkamp is very considerate and deeply cares for her students. Her lectures are engaging, she gives minimal homework, and the exams are very fair. I definitely recommend this class if you're looking for a relatively easy social science elective with minimal outside work.

She was phenomenal. I took Intro to Socio for a premed elective (MCAT material) and loved every minute of it. Easily my favorite class of the semester. Daily writing assignments, a few papers, and a couple of tests. The class wasn't difficult if you paid attention, and the material was so interesting, I found it easy to do so.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: never saw poorer teaching
He only talk about his own research
you will regret if choose his class.
People like this make me realize what it means to be a good teacher.
Amazing professor, amazing human being. Reason for me to continue being a student here at Notre Dame.
He's just great. The best part is his lecture style; he teaches you while telling a story.  You feel like you're a dinner guest instead of at a lecture.  Just wish I could take him again and again.
Such an encouraging Prof. Constantly giving me new challenges and provided more than enough help to help me achieve my goals.
I never thought I'd say this about an English class, but this was honestly my favorite class last semester. It really helped my confidence in reading and writing, and the Prof. was very encouraging

Leanne is a great professor! I really miss taking class with her this semester. She's nice helpful and she gives alot of good feedback for your papers. She's also the most Canadian person I've ever met :-)
Literally was going to fail me because of a blizzard. Do not take his class, omg.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: This was a very tough class. LOTS OF READING! But he gives great lectures and is available all the time to meet and talk. He even gives his cell number on the syllabus if you are struggling. You really have to fight for a good grade, but he will help you if you get there. Big on attendance and on-time papers. All lectures start with music.
Really smart guy.

I had Dr. Mahon for Moreau first semester freshman year and she was great. I got A's on every assignment. As long as you do the homework on time and go to the class once a week, she will give you a good grade. She also looks for participation.
She is an easy grader. For exams, she gives a study guide and gives the answers for the study guide the class before the exam. As an extra credit in the final exam she asked us to do Theology Memes.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: She is amazing. Although there is a bit of homework for every class, Dr. Mahon makes the lectures easy to understand and follow. She also gives study guides for all of her tests, and everything comes from those.

Had him for USEM; most students receive an A or A-
There are 10 two-page papers for completion and 2-3 larger papers graded for quality. Class is mostly mandatory. Provided good insights to modern applications of theater and the general issues society faces today.

I had Prof Stephens for the History of Chicago Theater USEM and he was great!! It's super easy to get an A as long as you submit everything. Everything in the class besides the 2 essays are graded for completion, and he grades the essays pretty leniently. So, just do all the homework, attend class, write your essays, and participate once per class.
intro to theatre is easy, fun, and light with homework if you have the *other* teacher
rating_tags: LOTS OF HOMEWORK--BEWARE OF POP QUIZZES--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: She'll be there if you need help, if you pay attention in class you will be fine

so far i really like professor mapes. she does speak fairly quickly in class, & it took awhile for me to get used to the speed of her lectures. i have her for calc 3, and she makes great analogies to help us understand how to visualize the math that we are doing in 3d. she responds to emails quickly & encourages questions. highly recommend! :)
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: Prof. Mapes made a difficult subject matter, group theory, interesting and built up intuition so that it was understandable. The course required no prior knowledge. It was very clear what was expected on the tests, and similar practice problems were given beforehand. However, it may be better to fulfill a requirement like history with your seminar.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Loved everything Trish had to share. I ended up writing way more than I wanted at first, but ended up loving it. Miss her.

I was also in her first class, and thought it was great. Professor Hartland tries to make you think outside the box, and wanted us to push our creativity. For me, it was a nice change of pace. I also read a lot of stuff I never heard of, which was interesting. She definitely had an unconventional approach to teaching, but I really appreciated that.

I enjoyed the class, but that's because I loved the opportunity to explore poetry, with no real assignments or lesson plans. Patricia is a sweetheart, but she let the class walk all over her (not showing up, not doing work). All of her plans fell apart and it was a mess in general. However, I liked the class material and it was the easiest A ever.
He is a literal king.

The class itself I did well in the course, however, this professor does NOT teach well at all. I ended up stopping going to class entirely because I learned more from teaching myself out of the textbook than in class. He teaches as if we are already on the same level of expertise as he is. I recommend another professor like Bentley.
Made Physics I better. Interesting lectures and examples. Definitely a good choice.

Dr.Oakes has amazing lectures and is such a nice person. The class is lecture heavy, but very interesting if you like theology. If you pay attention in class and write two decent papers you will earn an A.

I had him not for foundations but for god suffering and evil. Highly recommend that class because the course content is meaningful for your whole life (religious or not) and this is the ONLY class here where you can find this content. Two papers that are easy because the subjects are thoroughly talked about in class and no tests. but SUPER sad clas
Dr. Oakes' class is very straightforward and in order to get an A in the class, you just need to show up to his office hours three times during the semester so he can fix your papers for you.

I took him for British Indian Lit. There is a quiz every other lecture on the reading (you can just SparkNotes it). If you have the time, the books he picks are ACTUALLY good reads. Classes are discussion based and papers are graded easily. When he occasionally lectures, they are quick and to the point and mostly background on author. No tests!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: hes so sweet! lots of readings but nothing unmanageable. we got a couple of quizzes (but we knew based on syllabus when they were coming), small individual projects, and 2 papers. classes are normally lectures + discussions so just participate and you'll be good! he's very passionate about philosophy and thats clear in his lectures :)

While Professor Thomas was monotonous at times, he enjoys what he does and highly values students' input. The readings were theoretically dense, but you could skip them and not miss anything. His class has 3 papers (5+pgs), which he grades very easily. If you can get through the mundane lectures, you have an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Thomas is hilariously eccentric. The material (Lit USEM on Modernity) is somewhat dry, and honestly, Professor Thomas is a little mundane as well. But he is a very sweet and caring guy and when it is time to write papers, he grades fairly easily. Readings definitely enhanced my reading comprehension. Strange but memorable class overall.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Hilarious--So many papers

comment: Expanding on my previous rating. His class notes are on the chalk board, and Parker writes so fast and small that half the class is taken up by students having to ask what something is or correcting his mistakes. His test reviews were inefficient. Homework that was correct was marked wrong. He taught all of Eigen values/vectors/decomp in one day.

If I could rate Parker Edwards at a 0, I would. He is the worst professor that I have taken at Notre Dame. There is no doubt that he is a smart guy, but he is terrible at conveying this in any way. He's unavailable to meet if you have classes during office hours. He doesn't test on what he covers in class. He's bad at communicating with students.

This man is truly tragic! Do not take his class. It is a crime that he is teaching an applied math class. Be prepared to memorize definitions and theorems. He once told us if we don't properly punctuate our definitions, he will take off "a few points." Seems like a nice guy, but truly would rate a 0/5 if I could.

Professor Sirry was an amazing professor and I loved the course. He is an extremely lenient grader and is very understanding, which meant I could focus on actually learning what I thought was interesting instead of trying to memorize a bunch of facts. Definitely would recommend.

Professor Sirry is such a sweetheart and is really passionate about teaching this course. Prior to taking this course I had no background in Islam and I ended up learning so much about it. There is only one midterm, one paper, and the final. As long as you do the readings and pay attention in lecture you will do just fine.

His class and teaching style were very straight forward. Most of the class is organized as a lecture and discussion for those who want to participate. There are two written test that he provides clear instructions for and he clearly outlines what information you should know. Pay attention in class and review before tests and you will get and A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: Overall, very nice, understanding, and accessible. Lots of reading but can retake hw quizzes. Lots of different assignments to help with the weight of your grade. Very high standards for an A on papers, however. She was always kind which is why I was shocked I ended with an A- when I was only a couple hundredths of a percent away from an A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: She is honestly the nicest professor ever. Super understanding and will always give extensions. Online quizzes which you can take as many times as you need. Kinda heavy reading but you can definitely just skim it. I put in very little effort and it was fine. Hundred percent recommend her for your first theology.

Quizzes are online and open book with unlimited retakes. Tests are all multiple-choice/fill-in-the-blank. Two essays over interesting topics. Super easy class if you put in a sprinkle of effort. Very welcoming to students of all religious backgrounds and beliefs. Will grant extensions for ANY reason.

This lab is definitely pretty tough; the sheep brain practical is really challenging and the lab writeups are pretty hefty, but it's also a lot of fun and Dr. Lane makes it all doable and enjoyable. She's incredibly kind, thoughtful and knowledgeable about the subject, and her love for neuroscience will rub off on you.

Dr. Lane is one of the sweetest professors at ND. She genuinely cares about her students and wants you to succeed. The sheep brain dissection is very difficult, but even if you fail it, you can still get an A in the class if you do well on other assignments.

Dr. Lane is my favorite professor ever. I had her for lab and she was the most kind, helpful, and respectful professor I have ever met. She makes lab very interesting and wants her students to succeed. I am definitely taking one of her lectures in the future. I could not recommend a professor more.
The best mathematics professor in Notre Dame . Teaches in such a way that is easy to understand .
4.5/5 difficulty. Very nice professor who is very engaging. Does a great job explaining the topics but it is a very hard class.

Prof. Nicholson is perhaps the greatest math professor of all time. He has this way of explaining calculus that is simple and very easy to follow. He cares about all of his students and always makes time to explain concepts if you ever need it. 11/10 professor

NOT for BIOS10161 this was for BIOS40419. This course is and will be the most difficult course you will ever take. It is HIGHLY recommended to study at least for 2-3 hours each night. The detail required in her exams is extensive.

Wonderful! Dr. McDowell is incredibly smart and always willing to share her knowledge with others. The way she set up the class made me not only understand the material, but made me excited to learn more. Finally, her little jokes always make me laugh and make me look forward to going to her class. I think everyone should take her class!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: She speaks very quickly, so it's helpful to print off the PowerPoints for notes. She is very helpful in office hours and communicates well. She's extremely organized and expects the same from her students.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: He is an amazing professor. While there is a lot of readings, it is manageable and the course load is not bad. Getting a good grade is pretty  guaranteed. Love this guy.

One of my favorite professors. Extremely knowledgeable about history and enjoys teaching it. I am not a huge history guy, but I enjoyed learning it in his class. He also puts much more emphasis on learning over grading, so it is quite enjoyable since you can just go to class, learn it, and show what you know on assignments without worrying about it

Amazing professor. Super engaged and interested in what he teaches. Is very knowledgeable and provides very interesting content and readings. Loved taking his class. The course is graded on presentations and papers, there are no exams, and he gives the student feedback on the first draft before giving an actual grade. He is very caring and kind!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment: Beihammer is the real deal here. Is very informative about his subjects in history and will definitely talk about a topic if you ask a question about it. Gives good feedback on papers, as they are the main grades for the course, and is also lenient with extra time if asked. Overall, great guy and even better if you're interested in the topic.
He doesn't explain stuff clearly enough but goes through a lot of examples. You can tell he is very intelligent and does most of the work in his head, and doesn't explain it.
Lots of in-class examples
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Makes calculus much easier to learn. The class is hard, but he is very clear with his lectures and will not let a student have a question go unanswered.

Pretty easy to get an A in this class if you do everything on time and read the lectures. Hardest part of the class was the midterm and final because you had to show you'd done the readings and understood the concepts from the entire semester, but nothing too crazy. Prof is chill, but you'll interact mainly with the TA who's pretty forgiving.
Good USEM to take. He is truly an expert in terrorism and national security. The readings and discussion posts are long and can seem very overwhelming but he is a generous grader.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment:
POLS 30236- UN Politics
AMAZING class. Lectures and reading were really interesting and easy to follow along. Grading standards are clear, and as long as you do your work, a good grade in guaranteed. 
Mid-term was a take at home test, based on 10 FRQ's. Final is an essay. 
Weekly 200/300 discussion board posts and 3-question comprehension quizzes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Easier USEM. It's a lot of reading however usually 20 sometimes 80 pages. Don't have to do the readings but makes the papers easier. Weekly discussion boards ~300 words that are graded easily. Only 2 papers 1,500 words that are graded somewhat easily. Class can be a little boring sometimes. Content wasn't as interesting as I thought it would be.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Pretty easy as long as you try do do all the work and turn your assignments in on time. She doesn't grade based on writing ability or overall correctness... mostly just effort. That being said, the grading system is disorganized and I didn't have a single grade put into canvas the entire class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: Prof. Harris cares about her students. She was great at leading class discussions and gave good feedback on papers!

Professor Harris is a wonderfully kind woman who cares about the well-being of her students. She is very clearly knowledgeable about what she teaches and has a good selection of poems and plays that the class is centered around. It isn't the most entertaining class and the lectures aren't great, but it was a good experience overall.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: I took Aquatic Ecology from Dr. Hellenthal. I loved it. We spent a lot of time out on the lakes at Notre Dame getting samples, testing the water, etc. The final project was an absolute horror to complete--at least for me (I found out much, much later that I have ADHD). It was a lot of work, but it was worth it.
No Comments
his experience makes his expectations more reasonable than younger profs

Prof HG is a very nice professor, but the class was frustrating at times. It was hard to prepare for tests and the attendance quizzes were actually pretty difficult. Easy homework assignments and a group project. Pretty easy B difficult A
HG was a bad professor. She read directly off of the slides every time, and made the content extremely boring.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: HG fails to engage the class in her lectures and makes her exam questions ambiguous.  There could be multiple correct answers, but she stubbornly does not listen to the arguments for other choices. She hands back work significantly after it was due and does not offer feedback. She also gave us a final project, final exam, and final paper.

His lectures really emphasize the material in a simplistic manner. As long as you read the book and do as many practice problems as possible, you are set for the class. People make it out to be harder than it is. Just address any confusion you might have at office hours and you're set.

While I 100% agree with the other review, I took PHYS-20220 during the summer and had a MUCH better lecturer (Dr. Becker). Dr. Wayne has horrible lectures that are usually unrelated to homeworks and exams. People prefer him because his tests are easier than the professor who teaches this course on sequence. This is a self-taught course.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: If you're a pre-professional student at Notre Dame, you'll want to take Physics I & II off sequence with Professor Wayne. He's one of those professors who you just grow to really appreciate and enjoy. His class isn't impossible but it isn't easy either. It's a perfect challenge that if you work hard enough in, you can do well in. 5/5 would rec.
Professor Fallon is one of the most passionate humanities professors I have ever met. He has a great love for the materials he teaches, and he goes all the way to help each student.
Prof. Fallon Directed my senior thesis.  He is brilliant.
Proffesor Fallon is in the Program of Liberal Studies and led my Humanitarian Seminar.  Proffesor Fallon choose interesting but challenging text.  He askes good, probing questions.

She is a great and caring professor. You can tell she is passionate about teaching. Very easy grader: all my grades were between 90-100 even tough I sometimes did not read the assigned readings or prepare much for my presentations. There are reading quizzes every day from the readings, though.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: 10/10 would learn from her again.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Awesome language professor

I love astronomy. Beers almost ruined the entire subject for me. He has a very lazy teaching style and is quite prone to distractions, often going on tangents about his personal experiences with famous astronomers rather than actually teaching course material. The class is extremely writing-heavy, with multiple 15-page papers so get ready to write.

DO NOT TAKE ANY OF HIS CLASSES. I know Rate My Professor reviews should be taken with a grain of salt, but I am warning you to not take a class with him. He does not convey or teach the material well. Very boring voice and lectures. Relies on textbook to formulate our homework and exam questions (the textbook is elementary and long).

I almost fall asleep during every single lecture, and during the ones I don't, I don't understand a single thing. He does not do a good job of communicating the material during lectures. The observing projects are annoying, but good for gradeboosting. With the extra credit, a high grade is possible, but the tests are very hard, and the class is bad
Great guy. Terrific scholar. Compassionate mentor. Will be missed tremendously.

Professor Stamper is an incredibly respected faculty member at Notre Dame. While the lectures are not the most exciting, doing well is not hard at all. There is no required outside work, mostly just optional readings meant to increase student understanding and there are only 3 tests which make up the final grade. Overall a very manageable class.
rating_tags: Respected--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Be ready to memorize every building ever created
Condescending, egotistical, and thinks he is smarter than he is. Tries to be relatable in the worst way.

Professor Thain is one of the best lecturers I've ever had. He explains concepts so clearly and most importantly explains the motivation for a particular concept or idea. This helped me build a mental picture of what I'm learning about extremely well. He is a pretty tough grader and issues difficult projects, so don't be afraid to ask for help.

Professor Thain is one of the most gifted Professors in the CSE department at Notre Dame. He is an amazing teacher and someone who makes going to class at 9:25 a joy. Although the group project and exams in Dist Sys were quite difficult, I can't help but to be glad I took the course. He is amazing at explaining and detailing quite complex concepts.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: Doesn't really go back over examples if students are confused. We had to beg for a study guide Nice guy, but has a seriously outdated teaching style. He curved immensely at the end, but because we all struggled so much. Curves are weird, it's kind of an excuse for teachers who have absurdly difficult courses. You'll survive in the end.

He just reads off slides from Pearson. They're more than often arithmetically incorrect, but he doesn't bother correcting them. Glides through topics and doesn't explain them.
Gives a ton of homework throughout the semester, and each homework takes a few hours at least.
Not the best course to enroll in, wouldn't recommend anyone.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: Professor Bern is a real life audio book that reads off of 100+ unorganized slides. He did not do any arithmetic on the whiteboard throughout the entire course. You're better off taking an online class. His Pearson assignments take about 3 hours to complete. Everyone fell asleep during lectures because he made no sense.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Absolutely amazing. No readings, no tests, a few short reflections/papers. Classes are discussion-heavy and every class is extremely thought-provoking. I'd repeat this class in a heartbeat if I could. Definitely one of the best professors at Notre Dame.

To be honest, I like Professor Sedmak but not the course. It was quite boring and the work was tedious. I didn't do most of the readings because he would just explain them in class anyway. He's a brilliant man, but sometimes leans into the Catholicism a little hard. Having said that, I always appreciated his perspective.

Professor Sedmak is an incredible and brilliant individual. In class discussion, he provokes thoughtful discussion and doesn't let anyone get away with lackadaisical answers. His in-class activities are challenging and never have a clear black-and-white answer. He also lets you choose your own pathway to the grade which is awesome.

Professor Ghada is the best professor I've had at Notre Dame so far! I came into her class already interested in Arabic, and she's sparked my curiosity even more. She's incredibly caring, approachable, and always willing to help. Highly recommend her class!
Ghada is a very kind and understanding professor. As long as you participate and show effort, you can end with an A.

Professor Bualuan truly loves her students and is dedicated to helping them learn Arabic. If you struggle, she'll help. She makes learning this immensely difficult language so easy and honestly fun. Highly recommend.

This is a 3 week study abroad couse in Poland studying the Holocaust and is an amazing experience. Professor Powell is from Poland and I loved getting to learn about the culture from her. She made herself very accessible to the students and helped us navigate the complex emotions that arise from visiting historical Holocaust locations.

I love Professor Powell! She has such a fun personality and is clearly an expert on the topic of international law. She explains niche topics very well, and cares about each of her students. Do all the readings because she often gives short pop quizzes, but they are very easy if you've done the readings and can be an easy way to boost your grade.

Islamic Law and International Relations is a freshman USEM I highly recommend. Professor Powell does a great job teaching a very nuanced topic. If you read the book and come to class prepared to talk, you will get an A. Professor was very respectful.

Mooney is absolutely amazing. He's a young guy so he is definitely pretty chill. But he's so clear and concise, I'm always impressed with his lectures. There's a bit of reading but it's a theo class so what do you expect. Definitely possible to get an A, just stay on top of things. Go to his office hours! He's great to talk to.

Great prof if you are looking for an extremely in-depth intro Theo course. He makes you work for it--the tests are more difficult than most other intro Theo courses, and is not always an easy grader. Be prepared for a lot of memorization. He is very available outside of class and gives great feedback.

Chris was a nice guy. His lectures were clear. If anything was unclear, he provided a summary after every class via email. The class has a good amount of homework - an assignment before every class. Tests aren't terribly hard - not easy. Fairly easy essay grader. He takes himself a little too seriously. Attendance is always taken.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Lecture heavy

comment: In the realm of BPS, I would recommend Balko for sure. The course isn't fun if you end up in a bad group but given the stressful nature of the course, I would say Balko is your best bet. He's about as understanding as you can get when it comes to group issues / the many difficulties that arise when working with the same 4 people all semester.

As far as Business Problem-Solving professors go, Balko is a great choice. While most of your grade depends on group projects, you can do just fine in the class by making sure your individual project is well-created. Show up to class, participate, and be a good team member.

I really liked Balko as a professor. He's a little quirky, but it is clear he cares about his students. His Business Problem Solving class had 4 group projects, where the groups were assigned based on Myers Briggs types, a few short reflection essays, and a semester long project. The class gave me good experience, but I really hated the projects.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Group projects--So many papers

comment: Genuinely the worst professor I have had at Notre dame. Very unclear about grading criteria on presentation and writing assignment. Not nearly enough material provided to sufficiently be prepared for exams. Be prepared to teach yourself the material because she will not. Office hours are a waste of time because you will get vague responses.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Group projects--Graded by few things

comment: Watch out. Took Professor Shrout for Managerial Econ. She uploads blank notes so if you miss any classes you have no idea what happened. She tells you to come to office hours and then is horrible at explaining concepts in office hours. If one of my best friends here wasn't an econ major I would've had a hard time doing well at all in the class.

Prof Shrout was alright, but really couldnt care less about individuals. Because of COVID, our exams were online, but I had technology issues which caused the system to give me a failing grade, when my work and answers were actually enough to do really well. When I emailed her to ask for help fixing this issue, she ghosted me. Thanks for nothing.
waited for feedback for weeks. not a good professor at all. knocked down many people and played favorites
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: My class was entirely reading and writing based, which is fine. However, he chose not to grade almost all of the writing assignments we did. As a result, my grade did not even change from fall break to exam week. Bad grader. Too much homework. Over 35 pages of writing all semester only for him to grade about 5 of those pages. Impossible to get an A
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--So many papers

comment: He's a very caring and nice guy. I took his USEM about America and the World and we only had 4, 2-page papers, and 3, 5-page papers which for a USEM class that is supposed to be focused on writing, it really didn't feel like that much and he grades pretty easy with good feedback. The final was challenging but it was open note so that was nice.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Speaks is an amazing Art History teacher. I took her class as an elective (WKAL) as a STEM major, and I greatly enjoyed it! If you want to develop your writing skills while enjoying the nuances of different art styles, this is the course for you. Yes, there are a lot of papers and reading that you have, yet, it's enjoyable and exciting!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Caring

comment: Dr. Speaks is an excellent Art History professor, but her class is not for everyone. Her assignments are hard, require long readings, and grading is tough. She's caring and wants her students to succeed, but I would not take her to satisfy a core requirement, only if it counted towards my major and if I was really into the subject.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Really hard class. Every class is discussion-based. Readings are the most intellectually challenging texts I've ever read for a liberal arts class. It is very niche and she knows what she is talking about. Only take her class if you know you like the subject, not to satisfy a general credit.
Prof. McCullough is the goat. I couldn't have asked for a better writing and rhetoric teacher. He is so chill and is also very knowledgeable. Take him if you can.

I had a fantastic time in Prof. McCullough's Writing & Rhetoric class. We had three papers and a final portfolio. His teaching style is super chill and is never a stressful environment. He cares a lot about his students and is always prepared for class. I enjoyed the small class environment, and it was easily my favorite class of the week!

This is by far the best professor I have had in college. He is a grad student and cares so much about his students and is very understanding. He is incredibly informed on the topics we research and makes all classes super interesting. Overall great guy, super funny, and it's an easy class.

Professor Weaver was a great, chill professor. Calc A with him was great cause you could skip class but still learn from the notes he posts online. The homework is the same for all Calc A students so it's not him. Weaver really cares about his students. Highly recommend. Don't take Arthur Lim. Take Weaver.
I loved Matthew Weaver for calc A. Major dad joke energy, he was super chill, but also kept lectures interesting. Would totally take again

Matt Weaver was a good professor for calc A. He was constantly joking in class and had a quirky attitude but was pretty good at explaining concepts. Mobius homeworks are way harder than the content learned in class so most of the harder content was self tought. Tests are not done by him, however he will try his hardest to see students succeed.
Fr. Streit seemed to find the material very interesting but had trouble with engaging students in the class. Easy A, but hard to pay attention/stay awake

Father Streit's class is as confusing as it is boring. Although his grading criteria isn't difficult, it is extremely confusing and convoluted. If you're looking for a topical science credit, I would highly suggest taking another one.
Best teacher ever.

The material is difficult, but he makes it much easier to understand. There's homework due every lecture, but it's definitely manageable, and the exams are straightforward. He's a really great person, and he won't let you fail if you've put in the effort.
Good professor. Would take again.
Wonderful teacher - speaks a bit fast and rambles but besides that is very helpful and very easy to follow in terms of taking notes. Very nice guy in general. Would take his class again.

This class was the hardest class I had ever taken up until that point. It will drain you at times. But Ken Gomes is the dude. He cares about his students a lot and wants them to succeed. Told my class we sucked the other day. Savage.
So I dropped my class and changed my major from ACMS to Menbroza mostly because of him... he told me I had anxiety and depression but he also says he failed as a person because I dropped the class

His personality is great. He is willing to help his students a lot to get them to succeed in the class. But dont be fooled, his class is ridiculously hard. The way he curves allows more people to pass the class, but you still need to put in a lot of effort in the class. I highly recommend going to office hours to receive help on concepts and hw.
Too much personal radical views... Too much personal biased opinions are added
Awful professor, class was a mess.
Professor Hui is a great professor, but you have to do a lot of work for the class. If you do the work, she will make sure that you get an A in the course

Dr. Daniel (Blake) Roeber is one of the best profs. His lectures are already prepared from years prior and they are really interesting. Reading is light (7-10 pages per class) and power-packed. Grade consists entirely of 3 papers (20%, 30%, and 50% of final grade), so make sure you proofread and write them ahead of due date. Caring and funny prof.

Professor Roeber was a good lecturer, but I was constantly bored during class. Hes a very nice guy and is super willing to help out, but the classes can be somewhat brutal due to the difficult subject matter. Make sure to go to office hours and discuss your papers with him! Also, do the readings for each class. Do those things, and youll get an A
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Beware of pop quizzes--Lecture heavy

comment: He's a great professor, but don't expect to get an A in his class. Although he's really chill, providing pdfs of our textbooks and being relaxed about the readings, the three papers are 90% of the grade, and he is a tough grader. I'd recommend him, but be warned if you're doing grad school and worried about GPA. Otherwise it's pretty easy.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Participation matters--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: If you prefer more structure, maybe chose a different professor. The class was supposed to be discussion based, but he would go on tangents often. Easy class, just boring at times. Really nice guy, though. Ideal if you're majoring or minoring in both Theology and Philosophy.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Lectures are watched outside of class and in class discussions happen during actual class time. Because of this, there was a lot of work outside the class but it was very easy to pace yourself/ do it when you had time. During class the prof sometimes went on tangents, so focus on video notes for the exams. Exams not too bad, you can pick questions.

I dropped his class since he goes on complete tangents during lecture. He barely writes anything down, and anything he says could be on the exam. Powerpoints are vague, and you need to be a fast notetaker. If you decide to take his class, you should REALLY enjoy the subject and maybe have prior knowledge about it. If not, don't bother.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Stolz genuinely cares for his students. He posts his notes and lectures to a Google Drive, so they're easily acceptable. As someone who didn't take Calculus in high school, I had to put in extra effort to understand the material, and although Stolz may not be the *absolute* best professor, he provides you with the resources to succeed.
stolz is great, he almost entirely uses examples to teach which makes it a lot more applicable to the exams/quizzes. Calc B is hard no matter what, stolz is good

Honestly he is the sweetest guy ever but his style of teaching is just so all over the place. He never goes into concepts and will straight up just dive into examples without telling the class what exactly we are doing. Be prepared to be teaching yourself a lot of the content outside of class.
Shes a great professor who makes a usually pretty boring subject kinda fun. Shes very accessible and clearly wants her students to succeed.

Very hard class, but she's a nice professor. Makes you work for the grade. Lots of reading and optional (but if you don't do you won't get an A) homework problems. She wants you to succeed and gives you lots of resources though. And good lecturer. She just expects to do a LOT of work outside of class. If you want the easy way out, take Hums.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Prof. Larocque was a great accounting professor. She really tried to communicate the material and was very accessible outside class. She truly wants her students to do well, but in order to do well, you have to pay attention in class and read the textbook/do practice problems. Overall, she was fantastic.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: Readings for every class which could get a bit overwhelming once you get to the novels in the course, but for the most part you could get by skimming the pages. Some of the topics discussed didn't seem relevant to the course. 4 major papers but nothing too difficult. Discussion was kind of boring and sometimes hard to follow but not too bad.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: I had Professor Solomonescu for two semesters and loved both classes.  I thoroughly enjoyed the course content and learned how to improve my writing.  There is quite a bit of reading involved, but nothing unreasonable.  She is particular when grading, but fair, and provides helpful feedback if you go to office hours.  Would definitely recommend.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Solomonescu is super accomplished and knows what she's doing. But she is super picky on interpretation for an English teacher. Lots of reading and homework, but she will make you a better writer. Don't take if you want an easy A.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Cai has to be one of my favorite professors. You know whenever people discuss THAT professor who they'll remember forever, she's mine. Cai has such an amazing personality and makes the class super fun. This has to be the best USEM on campus. The class is super chill, but there are some papers and presentations, but she grades them easily.
She is a very understanding grader. As long as you do all of your assignments (6 essays) and show up to class every day (important) then you will be fine.
easy A, best professor ever, very understanding

Was a funny guy, however had very disorganized notes in lectures and would often make mistakes. He was very sarcastic and would make snarky remarks towards students when they asked questions. Be prepared to read the textbook in order to make sense of his lectures.

I had Vlad for Orgo 1 for chem majors, and while it is a very difficult class, he is pretty good at explaining topics and his lectures are very useful. Requires a lot of time dedication outside of class to read the textbook and do problem sets, but he gives a very generous curve in the class so you can focus more on learning the material.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Lecture heavy

comment: He is not the best lecturer, but highly intellectual. His handwriting is kinda bad but legible. Problem Sets are usually pretty difficult but doable and he is accessible for Office Hours. Funny guy might I add.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Professor Ho is very knowledgeable in mathematics, just not a very good teacher. The problems he does in lecture seem just random and it is often very confusing to try and learn from him. The poor structure of the Calc A course in general doesn't help with this.
Hard to understand, but if you work along w him in class, you can succeed. Lots of homework just because of the course structure, but hes great at answering questions.

If you put in effort, pay attention, and go to class, Ching Wei's class is a great option. The class is clearly structured, and he takes time to answer any questions even in a large lecture. He makes it clear where things come from in math and relating current material to past material to make it clearer.

Prof Kackman is awesome! I learned a lot in this course and also had a ton of fun. He is relaxed and cracks jokes all of the time. I hope to take another course with him before I graduate. Top 5 professors I have had while at ND!

I loved Kackman! He runs the class with more of a discussion style, which makes it easier to stay engaged. History of TV feels like it has a bit of pointless content in the beginning but gets more interesting. No exams or quizzes, just two long-ish papers/projects for midterm/final. It's not bad, though, because you can basically pick your topic.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Kackman is one of if not my favorite professor at Notre Dame. The entirety of FTT10101 was less of a class and more of an experience. He makes you think about films themselves with a completely different light, and goes about it in a unique way. His lectures are fun and intriguing, and cares about all of his students. 100% recommend!

He really cares about his students and wants them to succeed. Gave a lot of opportunities to improve our grades. I didn't love the lecture style and lack of any type of visual aids, and he does cold call a lot.
He is a wonderful person. He truly cares about the students and getting to know us. The class wasn't that hard, he provides a lot of guidance.

He has an awesome personality, and he really connects with students well. His lectures are very insightful, and he offers very funny mnemonics to remember specific details. He has 'blog posts' assigned for each class day, but they don't take very long and are very collaborative. He does ask for quite a few things to be printed out. 10/10
Dong Quan Nguyen is the best-dressed person I know. Would take his class again.
Fantastic, very easy

Dong Quan ís simply a brilliant and caring professor. His biggest effort is for you to understand the material through his teaching, and grades seem to be of little importance to him, as I believe everyone in the class received an A or an A-. Be ready for helpful practice exams, lots of extra credit, and a humorous professor.
Pretty tough grader and really makes you work to understand the topic. Grade is dependent on exam performance for the most part

Accountancy I is a tough class all across the board, but Prof Imdieke makes it interesting and fun. Though the material and exams are quite tough, there are tons of guided practice problems in the textbook and online workbook. The exams are the same no matter what professor you take, but are curved based on professor. Solid class overall.

Plays music he has never heard of before class starts. Super thoughtful, always available outside of class, and makes the boring lectures fun. The tests are hard but they're all made by Meyer and they don't give you practice tests. Overall, great teacher, tough course.

He's old and he's so kind but his lectures are unfortunately quite boring. Super disorganized slides and hard to hear in class. Lots of people never came to class regularly after the first exam. If you wanna skip just read the textbook before exams and you'll ace every exam. If you don't care to learn and just want an easy A, this is your class

Very very easy class. Based on four exams, homework with answers in textbook. Prof LoSecco is very kind and tries to engage the class, but it can get a bit boring just because of the topic. He does try and I appreciated that. Just read the textbook and you'll get an A+/

Prof. LoSecco was a decent professor in my cosmology course but his lectures can oftentimes be boring. Grading is broken into two exams, a book report, and weekly quizzes. He gives a good amount of extra credit as well. Overall an easy course and moderately interesting but the lectures were a bit lackluster.

Professor LoSecco was great! He is very passionate about physics and makes it accessible to non-STEM majors. He is very kind and funny. He can be hard to hear at times during lecture, but as long as you keep up with the readings this shouldn't be a problem. This is an amazing class to take if you need to fulfill your science requirement.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Caring

comment: Great professor, kind and passionate. His college seminar requires a lot of preparation, at least 5 hours per week. His class content is very interesting and varied.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: Bless this man. Genuine, passionate, and has a great way of teaching material in a digestible way. Thursdays he introduces a topic, which you read/post discussion about, and then do group discussion about it on Tuesdays. Discussions are 40%, final 30%, midterm 10%. Both exams open note, but tricky. Overall, a pretty easy and informative class.

He is a really knowledgeable professor who cares about his students. The class is structured in an interesting way: lecture on Thursday, a bunch of readings and a 500 ish word response due Monday, and discussion on Tuesday. It is a good class, but more history than theology.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: Bo is an excellent professor and an even more excellent person. He comes to class bringing the same energy without fail, is very understanding of personal matters, and is accessible outside of class. Bo clearly has an abundance of knowledge about Learning Analytics and Python. I can not recommend a professor more than I recommend Bo.

Bo is a great professor. He really cares about all of his students. He makes an effort and succeeds in forming a connection with all of his students. Bo is super kind and was always willing to help me with any questions I had in or outside of class.

Bo Pei was the best professor I had in 4 years at Notre Dame. His caring personality and unwavering support for students foster an incredible learning environment. He is willing to listen, and takes time to thoroughly answer every question. Finally, his Python teaching abilities are excellent. I would highly recommend any course taught by him.
Terrible lectures

Cell Bio is a hard course. You need to completely memorize the slides in class, which is a lot of slides and is very tough. You are graded on 4 tests, equally weighted and non cumulative. She does a great job explaining the material in lecture, and she is really helpful outside of class. Remember, you'll need to grind before tests, so be ready.

Prof D'Souza-Schorey is one of the best cell bio profs in the department and is very passionate about the field. The course is really dense and fact based. To do well you basically memorize everything on the hundreds of slides from lecture. Grade is from 4 exams equally weighted but are non-cumulative. She does well on explaining the material well.
Becker is an awesome professor for physics. His notes are very clear and THE most helpful material in this course. Esp his equation sheet overviews and lab paper guidelines.

BECKER IS THE BEST PROF AT ND

It is so clear that he will do anything to help his students. He prepares students well for the exam. He goes above and beyond in every way to help his students. 

he would probably do a backflip if it meant that it would make me understand the topic better. 

I would recommend you do anything to get in his class

I HIGHLY recommend this professor. I took his course during the summer and he has plenty of examples in-class, time to help with the homeworks, and in-class ungraded chapter quizzes. His exams also reflect what he teaches in class, unlike other professors' exams. Homeworks are long, but there are plenty of TA office hours where you can get help.

Would recommend! Examples in lecture are similar difficulty to exams, so read them over. I never read textbook and went through his organized PowerPoints and ended with an A. If attend office hours, will help you so much. Wants you to succeed.

Outside of class, he is a nice guy, but as a professor, he is awful. Went way too fast during the important parts, never asked for questions, and would just make us confused. If I had realized why he was put at the less-attended 8:20 am lecture, I wouldn't have registered for it.

Goes out of his way to help you. Great guy, better professor. Can sometimes be hard to understand, but if you just ask for clarification, he is more than happy to help. Make sure you do all the homework and understand it. Also, go to the lecture because he knows who shows up and helps you out in the end with your grade if you need it.

Professor Beatty was really nice to the entire class and really got to know all of us. Only issue I have is as an engineering student, I am used to being graded on a lot of assignments, and this class seemed very light, so I let it go for a while, especially the final project.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Ted Beatty is easily the best professor that I have had at Notre Dame. He is so nice and will help you out with anything. He knows everything about Latin American history. He will give you a long reading every class, but his lectures are so insightful. He is a great guy, take him.
Professor Beatty was one of the most intelligent, kind, and inspirational figures I have ever encountered in academia.  Really interesting lectures and insight

This was the class my first semester at ND that looked and felt the most like what I thought college courses would be like. We had really good "big picture" discussions of political and philosophical issues almost all the time. Really made you think.
Very good course and encouraging professor. I feel much more confident reading difficult texts and writing academic essays (both things I was weak on coming into college)

I struggled in this class in the early going, but I came to really enjoy it and I learned a lot. The prof. has a weird but very funny, sarcastic sense of humor and is good at getting everyone in the class to talk to one another about difficult material.

She's the best. She's really patient and I go to her office hours all the time. She's even available outside her office hours like every day all day. She never turns me away, and I see people meeting with her all the time. She's definitely helpful and nice and people obviously feel comfortable going to her with questions.
She's a terrible teacher. Rude, doesn't accept feedback well, and her tests don't match what she teaches.
Group work, no lectures. If she does have a power point there are so many typos it's not worth it.
Best algorithm class ever
he is one of the great teacher!
Master Yoda of the CSE Dept.
Ryan is the goat.  Very funny, loves math, great teacher.

Ryan is a really funny guy. He cracks jokes during lectures, but the math portion is difficult to understand. I found that he is so smart that he is almost unable to teach the basics of calculus. I would take another prof if you can. Highly recommend considering attending the Galvin only professors lectures and office hours.

Professor Contreras was not a good teacher for Calculus 1. He is a very smart guy who is incapable of teaching/“dumbing down” topics for his students. He would pause a lot for student questions but would struggle to answer them. I would avoid him at all costs. If you are taking Calculus for the first time, it is best to find another professor.
His lectures were terrible because he is clearly too advanced of a professor for calculus 1. If I had never taken calculus before I would not have done well.

Quite the character, one of those people who knows exactly what is going on mathematically in their head but cannot explain it to others in an understandable way.  Stopped attending his lectures and started watching Lim's recordings instead.  However, Ryan does greatly care for his students and their success, always paused to ask for questions.

Professor Donahue is a very knowledgeable professor. The course itself is not easy he does assigns quite a lot of readings. The course requires weekly 2-page papers which are mostly creative writings that connects to the weekly readings. There are also some discussion posts in place of the papers.The final is a 10-page paper on an in-class topic
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Prof. Donahue is good person, however, be aware. There is tons of reading and work to do. He is very unorganized and lacks time management skills. His lectures are interesting because he will ramble about things for way too long and rushes through the most important topics. Harsh grader and thinks that his class is the only class you take in Sem.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Donahue is a wonderful human being and a great professor. He demands and expects a lot from you, but he is always there to help you if needed. The week in Washington D.C. is a lot of fun, but Prof. Donahue holds everyone to a high standard. If you want to learn a lot and have a good time, this class is for you, just be ready to work!
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Group projects

comment: Great professor who cares about her students. Had her for CFR. She is a good lecturer who does her best to explain complicated concepts in a crammed course. She was helpful outside of class and always willing to help students. Difficulty of the course is not a product of her teaching but rather the course itself. Do the work and you will do well.

This is a class from hell. She throws at you nearly every single problem created by the the textbook, then she proceeds to give you excels, judgement cases, and quizzes. The class is horrible she just gives meaningless worksheets before you even learn the material and noone even does them. Then she gives test questions, that are barely discussed.

Professor Watkins is great! She is always very clear when explaining and gives time to work through and go over practice problems in class. She is very caring and really cares about all of her students. Definitely recommend!!
Hes a true gem.

Pierre in Spring 2020 was awful. No point to lectures and no organization. First exam was ridiculously hard. He did make the next couple assessments easier because we obviously weren't getting it, but, going online in March, he made the class torture. Scared of cheating, he made assignments impossible and exams were oral. didn't learn a thing

Calc A at Notre Dame has to be the easiest class I have ever taken in my entire life. Honestly it doesn't matter who your professor is because you could not show up to class once and still get an A. If you do care about the Prof then don't take Pierre he is confusing and his language barrier presents a heavy challenge.
He teaches how we approach proofs super well. He was our TA for the class and taught tutorials every week. It was really helpful for the honors class.
He explains things in a confusing way a lot of the time but if youve taken Calc BC or something similar already the class isnt that bad. You definitely dont need to show up for lectures.

The class was not too terrible but we learned literally nothing the entire time. Pretty sure I unlearned how to factor polynomials. He has a great fashion sense though. Basically just watch other lecture videos and use the practice another on the homework and you will be fine.

Professor Chiang excels at teaching complex topics to students who may or may not have had formal proof experience. He describes requirements for problems quite clearly and is quite friendly in class. His lectures are always a good time and should definitely be attended. He has a good demeanor and is very welcoming. Make sure you know content well.
Amazing professor! Teaches complex concepts in a really accessible way. I learned more from his class than from almost any other I've taken!
Talks too fast in class. Hard to understand whats being taught.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Tough grader

comment: I hated BLAW, but Professor Murphy made it generally easy to follow and understand.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Class is difficult with any prof. Take notes during reading to learn material, take notes based on her lecture for areas to focus on. Wants to see students succeed. Participation is worth 15% of entire grade, speak each class. Put in the work and you will be rewarded. Murphy is incredible
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Accessible outside class

comment: I really enjoyed Prof. Murphy's class and think she is a really solid option for business law. Class is graded from two exams (that she provides past exams for beforehand to study), a group paper, some participation/homework completion, and the final. A lot of reading (it is law) but manageable. Lectures are pretty good and she's really nice!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: I took this class for my Writing Intensive requirement to graduate and it did not disappoint. Two-page essays every two weeks + a 6-page essay final. As long as you take good notes during lecture, you'll be able to answer the prompts well. He is great at explaining material and is very well-liked. This is one of the best classes I've taken.

Professor Iffland is one of the best professors I've had a Notre Dame. He is very passionate about the material he teaches and take a lot of interest in the success of every student in the class. I haven't had any other professor who is as genuine and honest, and as engaging in lecture, as Professor Iffland. I would definitely recommend!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: God and Money was a 6 class course grading by one single assignment and attendance. Combination of business and religion. Hard topics but easy to pass.

Dr. Pfrender took over for another professor mid-course but made the class much more interesting and relevant, though some struggled to get through his morning lectures.

He is willing to work with the class in terms of grading and he tried to make the class interesting knowing most students were business majors. Great guy; brought in his cute dog
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment:
Calm voice. Very knowledgable of his field. Answers all the questions clearly and in a timely manner. Very accomodating to students and often responds quickly to emails. 
Gives take home exams.
Lots of reading and need to know time line of evolution.

TLDR: If you study and memorize this will be a breeze otherwise you'll fail.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Pfrender was very good to our class. The material was not something I was totally excited for, but he made it at least somewhat interesting for me. Try to go in with some energy because Pfrender has a very tiring voice, and some other students would nod off if he lectured too long without discussion time.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Corey is such a caring guy! He really wants us all to succeed and likes to joke around with all of his students. His lectures are all from the textbook so you don't really need to read it but you should be able to access it for some references for homework problems. Easy grader. Cares about our mental health. Con: goes on tangents in class a LOT.

Professor Pennycuff really cares about his students. You can see it in his lectures, his assignments, his exams, and his grading. Lectures are well-planned, funny, and he's willing to take time to explain things. Assignments and exams are well-specified, and he's never trying to trick you or get you for forgetting some edge case.

Overall a very entertaining professor. He did a good job running us through live examples of coding during lecture and directed us to useful resources. The primary drawback is that he tends to get stuck on tangents during class. Take home tests were awesome and reflective of what coding is actually like.

An S-tier metaphysician. He's funny, gives interesting lectures, and only grades on three papers. He's also really smart and helpful. I would highly recommend you take his courses if given the chance.

very interesting class if you pay attention, but paying attention isn't all that necessary. Daniel is very passionate about and great at philosophy, but since the grade is based mostly upon your 3 papers, class is really chill and you don't need to focus hard. He's a great professor overall I would highly recommend.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Lecture heavy--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: A pretty boring class. He had a tendency to ramble on. Grading was based on participation and 3, maybe 4, papers.

I LOVE Ethan. He is an incredibly kind, smart, and funny person. The class I took with him was probably my favorite class I've taken at ND so far. Be ready to laugh and participate in class. Always available for extra help or just to chat about movies. I loved how he would always start class by playing piano and serenading us.

Ethan was great! He lead the tutorial sessions for my film course, and he was always well prepared with things to discuss, but also very willing to allow for the conversation to go in a different direction. He really tried to get us to think. My favorite thing was his outfits. One time he showed up to class in a Philadelphia Mummers Parade costume.

Ethan Anderson was a wonderful professor! I had him for my Tutorial section of Basics of Film & Television. His class is enjoyable, and his personality is electric and infectious. I always looked forward to the freestyle raps he did for us at the end of each class, too.

Class is extremely hard, but Stiver's a great guy. Also actively tries to make class more enjoyable. He does say some non PC things but I appreciate the realness. Cares about his students and will help in every way he can.

I actually strongly disagree with the person below me -- Stiver was funny and went out of his way to make lectures engaging. He has a more monotone voice, but he is overall a nice guy and willing to help after class. The content is tough but not impossible to learn; helpful for real world too.
