Professor Stiver is quite disrespectful towards students--talking about inappropriate subjects in class (especially surprising at a Catholic school), saying politically incorrect things, and generally making students uncomfortable both in and out of the classroom. His class is full of lecture material, but he will only ask about the problem set Q's

I would highly recommend taking him as a physics professor. He is a good lecturer, but it does seem a bit slow. However, you do cover all the content necessary. He is always looking to improve and his lectures are quite entertaining at times.

Dafei is a kind and genuine professor who cares if you understand the material being taught. His lectures are entertaining and get a laugh out of most students, although occasionally they go a bit slow compared to the material that needs to be covered.

He is way too smart for Physics I. If you have never taken physics, a lot of the stuff will go right over your head and you will not understand. The readings sometimes help, but rarely. The examples he goes over in class are a lot more simple than the ones on the homework or on exams which does not help with studying for exams. Very hard
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lots of homework--Test heavy

comment: avoid at all costs; lots of issues here... would rather have taken lindley

Quantitative reasoning course. I really struggled in the class because any type of coding is really not my things. exams apply what you've learned in the class to a real world solution - felt like I could not adequately prepare for them (prac exams not like exams). The project is super important! She's available outside of class which saved me.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Test heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: She is one of the best professors that I have taken thus far! Her lectures are straightforward and the readings are interesting. She articulates clearly what a student should know about Congress in an unbiased way, and she makes the class engaged throughout the process. Take her!
Really enjoyed his Intro to Clinical Psychology course. I found him engaging and sometimes funny. Definitely not an easy "A". You have to work for your "A" but it's doable.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Professor Haeffel's Intro to Clinical Psychology course has been my favorite class that I have taken. He is an engaging lecturer and teaches you exactly what you need to know for exams. Attendances is not required but there is always the possibility for a pop quiz based on the assigned reading.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Prof. Haeffel has been the best teacher I have ever had. It was also the easiest class I took because he was so clear about what was required. There is a good amount of nightly reading, but if you skim and come up with a few talking points you will be fine. Essays are easy and there is only three of them.

Haeffel is by far my favorite professor so far. I took his first semester USEM and loved it. There was quite a bit of reading, mostly articles and scientific papers, but the topics were very interesting. The class is mostly discussions on the papers so be ready to participate. Extremely fun and would definitely take another class with
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: AMAZING professor-- absolutely one of the best teachers and people I've met here at Notre Dame. Class was a breeze to get through because of the way she lectured and brought in examples. Exams were incredibly fair and the semester long project was super engaging. Can't recommend enough!

Professor Ferguson is great! She really cares about her students and the class itself isn't too much work - just a semester-long group project with time in class to complete the assignments for it. Two exams which were not challenging - highly recommend!

Prof. Ferguson is the sweetest teacher and really cares about her students. Her class is engaging and super easy. She really just wants her students to succeed - definitely the best Foundations of Marketing professor.

Took him for Applied Math Methods I. Very difficult class due to the difficulty of the math but mostly because of the pace of the class. You learn difficult topics like Divergence Theorem and Green's Theorem in less than 3 weeks and move onto the next subject. Bei is a great lecturer and helpful teacher, just can be fast paced.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Bei goes over the practice exams every day-before the exams, and it saves all of us. He conveys the topics better and teaches with more clarity than the others.

Class material is fairly difficult, but exams are much easier. Standard avg 2~3 hours of homework each week. Not too difficult to get an A. He gives practice exams (that are very similar to the actual exams) and hosts review sessions where he goes through each problem. He is knowledgable and enthusiastic.

The sweetest human being ever. Fosters an inclusive and interesting seminar-style class. I highly recommend attending office hours for guidance on exams/essays since she can be a tough grader. Sex and Gender in Greco-Roman Antiquity was graded on 2 essays and 2 exams. I would take this prof again in a heartbeat.

She's a wonderful professor. She's a hard grader but she is happy to help you improve each time and to even just brainstorm ideas for where to start on each paper. There is a lot of reading and it's no big deal if you sometimes read sparksnotes instead of the actual pages but you *must* read whatever it is you're writing about for your essays.

Professor Mazurek is a good person and her USEM Myth of Troy class wasn't bad. Participation is key in this class and attending her class is also important. Go to office hours to get help on essays and show that you're trying. It's a lot of reading and class is all discussion but it can be done. Essay grading is a bit on the harder scale though.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Took Prof. Mazurek's USEM on The Myth of Troy. Lots of reading. About 50 pages of the Iliad or another book due for each class. Participation in the class discussions is important. The class material is very difficult, but the only assingments are 4 papers and few skits that make up your grade. Very knowledgeable prof overall and is engaging.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Very accessible and helpful when needed

Dr. Lyon is a really reasonable guy. The class itself can be a nightmare, but that's the case across all sections. He's clearly knowledgeable in all class concepts, and is very responsive at office hours. He can be a tough grader at times, but he also is patient in explaining his rationale and doesn't take pushback personally if inquired on it.

Awesome professor! Really cares about his students and makes an effort to help everyone. The grading is mostly done by TAs who are harsh. The curriculum is by the EG department, so Lyon only follows it. He does a good job of lecturing and was always accessible outside classroom hours. Recommend all freshmen engineering students to take him.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Great professor! Very caring and made an effort to learn everyone's names. Feedback was useful, and he was always available for questions in class, after class, or during office hours. The standardized curriculum was well-structured, and the projects and homework felt useful. TAs were also helpful and responsive. Highly recommend!

He is a great professor. The grading is mostly done by TAs, but is unforgiving. The curriculum is done by the department, so Professor Lyon is just following the curriculum; however, he understands excel, solidworks, and other class subjects well and is very good at teaching. Great guy and enjoyable class time.

Engineering Design is a filter class for engineers that is likely to break your GPA regardless of what professor you have. TAs do almost all of the grading, and they are harsh.

Lyon is really nice, very well-organized and responsive. Students are always trying to get into his sections. His lectures often seem as if he rehearsed them word-for-word.
Really good professor!!! He is just the best!
cooool!

He didn't seem to know very much about the course subject. I liked the class overall (was pretty interesting and it was an easy A) but his section was a waste of time. I also went to his office hours twice and both times he wasn't there, and he didn't tell us that he had cancelled. Ended up having to meet with the Prof. instead.

Prof. Soto is a nice man and was very friendly and helpful in office hours, but he was frequently late to class, took a long time to return essays, and didn't offer much feedback on papers. There was just a grade and a few vague sentences. Sometimes seemed like he was wing'n it in class.
One of my favorite classes last year

I was in his class on lit and conservative politics and really enjoyed it. There was a lot of reading, which was difficult late in the semester with other classes, but the in-class discussion sections were so interesting and actually kind of fun. Bryan is funny and very relatable and obviously cares a lot about the topic.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: He is a great professor.
Best PE teacher, he is a very cool dude
Amazing professor dedicated to seeing every student succeed. Establishes from the beginning clear guidelines for his course as well as a specific schedule for the entire semester.

Had Prof. Mellor for Drafting Class as a freshman. He really knows what he's talking about and truly cares strongly about the subject and his students. Class is project based so everyone is at their own pace but he is there to help you and the class was great!

BEST professor at the law school. Holds student's to high expectations and if you give him respect he will give it back. Destroys people who don't read closely and goes off if you're late. Great at explaining material and teaching how to attack real world and exam problems. Extremely helpful in office hours. Integrates real world concepts.
Fighting for justice.

Professor Wiest is an amazing person and a good teacher, but you have to make sure to read the textbook beforehand. He sometimes glosses over some things that the text helps at with. He is extremely supportive and will try to do all that he can to help his students understand.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Skip class? You won't pass.--Hilarious

comment: Professor Wiest is really good at explaining and helping you stay engaged in class, but Organic Chemistry is still challenging as it is. Go to tutorial, do the readings, and, if you ask him, professor Wiest will help you with extra tutoring outside of class. He wants students to succeed.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS

comment: TAKE HIM...great guy...super easy grader...loves to laugh
Father Coughlin is amazing, funny, a little scary at first, but genuinely cares about all his students.

Fr. Khaled is awesome professor. You definetly need to read the readings and pay attention to lectures. It is a hard class no doubt, but for any orthodox Catholic, it is a class worth taking. I appreciate Fr. spiritual and intellectual insights. He also gave students a chance for extra credit to buffer out test grades. Its work, but worth it!
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Wise Byzantine-priest and lecturer. Little hw but lots of reading. Must write short summary of readings. Five papers total, and grading is harsh (probably just the TA though). Only problem for me is he gets political at times, but if you hate Trump you'll be fine I guess. Wouldn't take again mainly bc I hate reading, but the discussions were nice.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Get ready to read--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: So much reading! I hate everything about leadership now!

Awesome professor. Teaches in an  engaging and progressive fashion. Has a lot of knowledge to share. My only regret was taking this during the summer for one week and not getting the full experience. Highly recommend taking him.
He's a really nice guy and rewards you for doing the homework with extra credit.
10/10 would take again; gives great lectures, really entertaining, wants to help you succeed
She was easy to learn from but it was also a bit like she was unsure of what she was teaching.

While the content of the class was interesting, she was very frustrating at times. She would not fix questions even if she knew she was wrong. She was not very helpful but the homework was pretty easy.
Had him for Calc II. Funny guy, but wasn't clear. Not like the math department at ND has many good professors anyways, but I wouldn't necessarily put him above anyone else.

His lectures were very unclear; he did not do a good job teaching the material. The only way I passed the class was with the help of my amazing TA and by learning the material on my own. There are a lot of online assignments.

Worst professor I've ever had. She could not finish any of her thoughts and continuously jumped around during lectures which made it impossible to follow. Her handwriting is also awful so you can't understand what she is saying, and can't copy her work on the board. Exams were extremely hard and she would openly lie about what was on it.

She assumed we all did the readings before class so she just jumped right into the materials without giving good definitions or examples. She did not set up the expectation of reading the textbook tho, so it was hard to follow at first. She was too excited about the topic which made learning incomprehensible. Her exams were hard too. Don't take her

Nice professor, but moves fast in lecture and assumes you understood everything that was discussed in the reading from the night before. The first few weeks were pretty tricky because she didn't define the key terms that she used often, but once I figured out the basic vocab it wasn't too bad. Most people went to Han Lu's lecture.

One of those profs who treated the lectures as a review of what you read (which I usually did not until right before the homework), so basically she just breezes through the topics. I stopped going to class after a couple weeks.

Awful experience with her. She loves to hear her self talk. Not an enjoyable class in the slightest because she makes something that is supposed to be fun and engaging so technical and puts every concept in a box. Has a selfishly dictated standard that obviously no one can reach. Never again.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Kennell will not make this an easy class. However, by the time the semester is over, I can guarantee you will have improved as a writer. She makes attendance to a few of her individual sessions mandatory. Nevertheless, if you want to improve, be ready to show up VERY often. Overall, she is a great person, and a great professor.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Terrible experience. A class like this should never have been difficult. Professor has no sympathy and is an awful communicator. If you're in her class right now, DROP ASAP!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Worse class ever, lots of writing, would not recommend

Worse prof ever, Seeing Anime is possibly the worse class that I have taken. The exams were graded really harshly, an simple core requirement class should not be this hard, she takes everything so seriously.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--So many papers

comment: Great professor, inspirational, funny, a real Italian guy. One of the best in the Italian department.

Every class, he would give a structured lesson, have us practice what we learned with a partner, and then finish with an interactive activity (I.e. Speed dating) or Jeopardy. He would incorporate culture, contemporary and classical,  into classes. It helped to learn from an authentic Italian who relates to us so well.

Reads off of the lecture slides almost verbatim and she posts the lecture slides to Canvas so lectures are somewhat pointless to attend. The homework are very similar to the exams. Guo is nice and its clear she is passionate about helping students understand the material. Easy course but I wish it hadn't been so boring.

She teaches very quickly and can be difficult to understand. Exams are worth 25% of your grade. Lectures and homeworks do not really match, and the exams don't match the homeworks either. Doesn't give practice exams. Not the worst prof I've ever had, but not the best. If I had to take her again, I would, but she wouldn't be my first choice.

Hobbins is really passionate about his subject matter and greatly appreciates when you show interest. He will have you READ!! So be prepared. Don't expect to be able to write a paper the day of and get an A…don't expect to show up to class unprepared and get an A. Overall he just seems to be a nice history nerd with a LOT to say.

Hobbins was genuienly a sweet guy who clearly loved history and teaching history. Our class was discussion based and sometimes extremely boring, but he tried his best. There was a lot of reading outside of class and a fair amount of essays. He is a fair grader, but don't expect all A's on your papers. Overall not a bad option for a history class.
Professor Hobbins is a really sweet guy who loves history. The class is purely lecture based and is pretty boring. But it's easy if you do the readings.

Professor Hobbins explains concepts very well and is passionate about the subject material, but could be a little dry on the topics that weren't as interesting to him. Quite a bit of work, but you gain a lot of understanding of history from his lectures

I really loved Professor Dinkelman. I think she understands that metrics is a hard class and everyone is just trying to get through it. She was pretty light on grading, I thought at least. I tried hard to understand the material but I don't think I really got there. It was pretty dull. Nevertheless, I would highly recommend her for metrics.

Dinkelman is amazing at explaining concepts, but there is some disconnect between the lectures and the homework. Dinkelman seems very passionate about the subject which helps make econometrics slightly better. Her class was structured different from other metrics classes that I've heard of in that she assigns a group paper.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: He is a really good professor. I took him at Binghamton where he teaches now. Pretty good lecturer. Gives rewrites for homework, at least for this class. Exams for this course can be difficult, but he is on the easier end of the exams. He taught the material really well, especially during a pandemic. Very much would recommend.

He is always focused on giving you an overall understanding of calculus and is excited to teach it. He is an interesting lecturer and always has funny comments about certain things that make you laugh. Recommend for Calc 1.

Hard class, but his humor and dedication made it an exciting challenge rather than a slog. Attendance isn't mandatory, but might as well be since the lectures are crucial to understanding, and the textbook is only used as a source for homeworks.

A very difficult yet rewarding professor. He is very passionate about circuits and does a great job getting to know individual students. Although this was one of the hardest courses I took, his humor and support helped me through it. Also, the homework and weekly quizes make this more like a 3 credit course than a 2 credit.

강선생님 is the best language teacher I've had in my life!

We made tons of progress in just one semester, and while the workload is considerable, it was all relevant. Prof. Kang is very kind and she really cares about her students learning. She goes the extra mile making sure we also engage with Korean culture!

Professor Kang is a wonderful instructor. I took her Elementary Korean class and I have made so much progress. The workload is manageable, the assignments are always relevant, and she is a very kind, funny, and sweet person. She encourages students to learn in various ways.

Professor Kang is a very kind woman and is genuinely trying to help her students learn Korean. She just wants more people to appreciate her language and culture and is very caring in class and outside of it because of that. I wish more students would take Korean because it's not super hard to learn. The Korean professors are all so helpful.
Very nice, very funny. He did a great job at teaching the Physics for Life Sciences material. 10/10.

Physics Two for Life Sciences is a hard course, especially if you have never taken physics. Out of the teachers that taught this course at ND, he was by far the best lecturer and was the funniest and nicest. This is a hard course and you will have to study and prepare out of class, but he was an amazing teacher that I would recommend taking.

This class requires a lot of reading; prepare for about 100-200 pages a week. Prof. Bordogna is a fair teacher and considers the effort that you put in. I never thought of myself as a great writer but after several meetings with Prof., I was able to get a good grade on both of my papers. If you put in effort in this course, you will do fine.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Great professor. It's a difficult class for a freshman; she is very picky about grammar but gives good feedback. There is a ton of reading
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Bordogna was very passionate about the subject material, but as a first semester freshman, the quantity of work for this class was insane. She was a stickler on grammar and very picky with papers, but she would let you redo them sometimes and would always be willing to meet to discuss. Participation was a large factor of the grade.

Prof Bordogna is caring and takes participation into account heavily when determining grades. Lots of reading outside of class but are fairly interesting. Classes are student lead discussions. Harsh grader on writing but gives helpful, specific feedback. Encourages you to share your opinion and curves final grade if you show you put in the effort.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: Easily one of the best professors I have had. His teaching style is great and he prioritizes learning. He is a realllly good person, very kind and patient. Take him. He makes the class very easy and the tests are open note.

Nice guy, solid teacher. M&D isn't very interesting but he definitely cares about teaching. His lectures plus HW should leave you prepared for tests but tends to throw in some tricks to the concepts. Big fan of corny jokes and inspirational quotes

I thought this class was pretty stupid and self-explanatory. She was super nice but it was curved pretty harshly to get an A. More opportunities for points compared to other 1.5 credit options, but also means some random assignments that feel useless and can be difficult. If you listen in class you don't need to bother doing the readings.

Prof McManus Warnell is lovely and I enjoyed the class discussions. However, this class has a very steep curve since it is a 1.5 credit so it is difficult to get an A. The class does go over interesting content, but some of the assignments were redundant. Grades were made up of a few writing assignments, quizzes, a group project, and a final exam.

She is an absolute angel and is so nice but the class sucks The class is all common sense and is extremely boring. She mandates attendance Its not much work but is highly curved so only a handful of students receive an A grade

I really liked Prof. McManus' ethics class. She does a great job getting everyone to participate, and she facilitates class discussions well. However, you have to participate and show up to class to do well. The only issue I had with her ethics class is that it is HEAVILY curved, so don't expect to get an A or an A- unless you do outstanding work.
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: This guy is amazing. I took VFX and Advanced VFX with him and loved it. His lessons are available online and all your homework can be done through them. If you try, you'll get an A. He cares a lot about teaching and jokes a lot in class. Super casual. Will respond to emails quickly about anything, even late at night sometimes.

Clearly passionate about his work and it is reflected in the courses he teaches. Funny, compassionate, and understanding about a lot of things. Homework is informative and has very few tough points due to the clarity of the provided lectures/videos. If he is teaching a class, I would take it again and again if I could.
almost impressively bad at teaching.
He makes me confused about topics I've already learned. I'm not sure how. Seems like a nice guy but isn't assertive with his teaching.

One of the best physics professors I have ever had. Very insightful, and makes lectures very fun. I am not good at physics by any stretch, but his lectures were very useful. The questions he solved during lectures were similar to the exam questions. Would take again!

Physics 10310 isn't overly difficult, especially if you've taken AP Physics C in high school. Just do all of the homework and do the labs, free points. The test questions are way easier than anything on the HW. Lannon just goes through practice questions in lectures. Cares about his students, tries to keep things comical, but gets boring at times.

Lannon is probably your best bet for the engineering physics courses! The examples Lannon went through in class were often similar to the exams. My exam grades took a huge dip halfway through the semester, and he was willing to meet with me to discuss study strategies. I went from getting a C on the midterm to an A in the class!

I took Prof Gondoli's USEM and really liked it. It's an interesting topic, and she makes the class really easy-- you revise one paper that uses the readings for class, and she goes into depth and explains them well. There are some 4pt quizzes, but the answers are on Quizlet. You don't need to buy the textbook because she gives you all the readings.

Professor Gondoli is the absolute sweetest. She is really understanding and moves deadlines based on how the class feels. She also cancels class sometimes. As long as you submit your paper drafts for this class, you will do well. One suggestion I have is not to buy the textbook because she posts all the files so I spent $70 for no reason.

Maria Rosa is very knowledgeable and passionate about what she teaches. Her lectures are group discussions about the texts you read. She's the kindest person and gives great feedback on essays. Homework is discussion posts but you can get away with missing a few. Take notes during class to use for your essays. Interesting readings, loved her class!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Caring

comment: She's really great. You can get away with not doing the readings, but it makes it hard to participate in class and screws you over for the exam. Some presentations, but very kind grader. Just talks - no PowerPoints.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment:
Eric Jumper is an absolutely brilliant man.  Unfortunately none of that translates into being a good teacher.  The man lacks empathy towards others and is incredibly arrogant.  

He is much more interested in research and publishing.  Students are an unwelcome distraction to his other interests.

Absolutely the worst professor I have had.  Unable to communicate basic principles of aerospace engineering.

He has absolutely no patience for students who cannot learn his material and will launch personal attacks against you in his office.

By far the nicest professor I have come across at Notre Dame, Shane takes time to know each of the students in his class and teach the material in an intuitive way. Many many options for extra credit and test averages are consistently high. He truly wants the best for his students and it is clearly seen in his personality and teaching style.

Shane is awesome, probably the best professor I have had at ND. He is focused on the actuarial science discipline, which is helpful if you want to be an actuary. Probability is tough material, but he grades tests leniently, and offers extra credit on each of them. Shane is truly just a nice guy, always available and willing to get to know students.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Excellent prof. Super articulate, insightful, caring. Class is super interesting. Also he's pretty cute

Awesome class and instructor. Felt like I learned a ton and enjoyed going to class. Really funny guy as well. Not sure if he is teaching again in future, but this was one of my favorite classes at ND. Come to class, go to office hours, and submit good work and you will get a good grade and enjoy the class tremendously. Also he is super funny.

I enjoyed this class so much, I had her for Introduction to Latino studies and I feel like this class is so useful when wanting to learn more about Latinos from all parts of South America. If you have the time, I would definitely recommend doing the CEL component and volunteering in La Casa de Amistad!!

funny and incredibly caring. took Latino studies and loved it so much because of how she teaches. It's basically 80% discussion based and 20% notes. highly recommend doing her service-based learning if you can, it's so wholesome. love moreno so much!!

She is genuinely the best professor I've had on campus yet. She's incredibly caring and truly treats her class as well as she would her own kids. She is quite picky with grammar, but it does not affect your grade much. She offers paper revisions for students who volunteer at La Casa once a week. Most students were convinced by her to continue ILS.

Professor Kaplan was a great teacher and made me a better writer. She gives more feedback than any teacher I have ever had, and she is a tough grader. I was able to barely get an A, even though I had a B headed into midterm break. Hard work will pay off in this class if you stick with it.

The best writing teacher I've ever had. She was a tough grader but by the end of the semester, I had improved a lot. She didn't care about deadlines as long as you turn. it in by the time you tell her. Also, we could revise the first two papers if we wanted to get a better grade. She was extremely nice, understanding, and willing to help.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Tough grader

comment: Professor Zhang is so so so kind, and clearly cares so much about student success. She will go to great lengths to make sure that class is conducted fairly, and that everyone's on the same page in class. Exams were a little difficult, but nothing unreasonable.
Had her for stats for sociology... really just wants students to learn and do well! exams and problem sets were not super easy but not hard at all and the workload was manageable!!!!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Online Savvy--Clear grading criteria

comment: This professor is extremely kind-hearted, very helpful in answering doubts and always comes to class prepared. She answers questions with patience and stays back after class to help you. Highly recommend, but don't expect to do well if you don't pay attention in class.

It was a pleasure to have Xiyan for Calculus A. As long as you pay attention and ask questions, you will be fine. Xiyan is more than willing to help, and I would take her class again if I could. Xiyan approaches everything with a good attitude and has a good heart. She is probably one of the nicest and most accessible instructors.

it would be a waste of time to take this class. learn little to nothing, and there is no grading criteria whatsoever. its all subjective. i got an A and a A- on my 2 papers and finished with a B+. don't know how that works. professor does not equally grade projects and each class is just story time for 75 mins

Good guy, easy class but would steer clear of him overall though. Very lackluster class that he obviously only teaches because he has to. Three six page papers and a final project but no assignments other than that. Not sure if he evens looks at the assignments, I think he just randomly assigns a grade which might come back to bite you- or help you
rating_tags: So many papers--Graded by few things

comment: The class is graded off of 4 labs and 2 one page papers. The papers are very easy but make sure to follow every direction on the lab assignments closely or he will take points off. There are daily readings but they are somewhat optional and only occasionally directly referenced in class.

Easy class, but I'm not confident that I learned a whole lot about Archaeology. The class was hyper-focused on cult archaeology and the professor's own research (which is understandable to an extent). The only grades are the papers you submit, so make sure to follow the guidelines for each one. As long as you do that, you'll earn a good grade.

My main concern with this class is that the required films were not always easy to access. A lot of them were not available for free online. Supposedly, the library has CDs of all of them, but I heard they weren't the best audio quality. The lectures are a little bland, but Prof Reed is nice and willing to work with you if you reach out to her.

Tessa is a young professor and definitely grades harsher than a seasoned professor would. Her lectures are bland and oftentimes don't relate to the subject we are meant to be studying. She gives out very few A's, however doesn't give good feedback on assignments.

She was the worst lecturer I have ever had. Bar none. She also stole another professor's course material (assignments, quizzes, and exams) for the majority of the course. Additionally, she admitted to us that she didn't know how to write Python code, despite the fact that she was the professor for a class taught mostly in Python.

During lecture she would constantly struggle to write code, even when copying it, and failed to demonstrate any understanding of the material. She would constantly say "I'll get back to you" when someone would ask a question about why she did something, but she would never actually get back to you. I would not recommend taking her class.

Know at least some of the texts coming in. Staud is very enjoyable to talk and listen to and is very knowledgeable about the subject. He definitely cares about his students. The structure of points in the class and the easiness in losing points makes it extremely difficult to earn an A. Papers, while short, are assigned randomly and due shortly.

Staud is my favorite professor on this campus. I highly recommend taking his USEM class. He's easy to talk to and is super understanding when you need extensions. He gets so excited when we discuss the reading material. One day he got so excited he jumped out of his chair. It's wholesome and contagious, as we often will feel more engaged.

Truly a great prof and super nice guy. Exams are TOUGH and lectures packed with info. Take good notes and pay attention, a lot of things on the exams come from what he emphasizes in class. Great class for premeds/med school, and lots of good MCAT info. Your grade is 90% exams, 10% between a presentation (easy) and reading questions (not easy).

While the class was a lot of work, this class is a must for anyone looking to attend med school. My advice, memorize everything he presents on the slides, even if it seems insignificant. The class was graded on quizzes on the textbook reading (worth very little), exams, and one project. His lectures were interesting, but full of information.

Professor Seida is excellent and explains the material very clearly. However, the course content is Very extensive, and there is a LOT to review before and after class. The "quizzes" are generally simple, and most of the exam questions are similar to the examples discussed in class.

If you take TBS as a MSA student you will question every ounce of education till this point. This professor talks in circles about stuff you did not learn. I hope you aren't one of his victims because he will call on you all day everyday. He will come close to you start a sentence, fall asleep, then revive and expect an answer.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Cannot get ahold of them outside of class. Gives super unclear instructions and no rubrics. Very subjective when grading.
Terrible DO NOT TAKE

I took Video Game Development with Professor Villano. He had options for projects for those with limited coding experience, which I appreciated. He is very helpful in office hours and makes time to meet with students when needed. He is not that helpful in class, but that's mostly due too many students to tend to at times.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Programming for Video Game Development with Villano is a fun and laid back class for someone who does not have much programming experience. Professor Villano gives a lot of clear instructions and code to copy, however I would not say this class will teach you to code if you did not already have some background knowledge.
Dr. McShane is a wonderful director of the Notre Dame Liturgical Choir. Without Andy, the choir would not be what it is today.

Andy is a great director and teacher for Liturgical Choir. I really can't imagine it with someone else. I am about to graduate in a few months at the end of my 5th year (dual-degree program) and I took this as a course for credit my Freshman year and then have stayed in the choir since. Definitely one of my most meaningful experiences at Notre Dame
This professor is absolutely atrocious. Completely full of himself and absolutely painful to listen to.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: He is pretty funny, and very good at explaining the material.
Very passionate about his work and it shows in his lectures.
Very little homework, tests are take home short response, interesting lectures.

She is very smart and she cares about her students but holy cow she is a tough grader. DO NOT TAKE if you can help it it is impossible to get an A in her class. Free As for other teachers would be a hard B for her. Our class average was at least 3 points below the others I had heard of, which is the difference between an A- and a B
She went very fast during lecture, but the materials on canvas made it easier to keep up during lecture. She was a tough grader and very detail oriented.

I enjoyed taking Engineering Design with Myia Dickens. She can be a pretty tough grader at times, but one of the nicest parts about taking this class with her was that she makes herself very available outside of class hours. It is clear that she wants everyone to succeed, and she makes an effort to get to know her students.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Good class. I found it really interesting and he's a good teacher.
very hard. took a lot of time and still didn't understand the material or get a good grade.

Caponigri was the greatest prof. i've had at Notre Dame.  She is really laid back, really funny, and you actually enjoy class.  This'll sound cliche, but she makes learning fun.  Honestly, I learned a lot in her class and had a lot of fun.
No Comments
It was ok.
She is very helpful.
One of ND's finest professors. He's amazing - if poetry were written about dirty socks that man could find a deep meaning behind it. Not to mention hearing him read Italian...swoon.
Christian is amazing! Take his classes, they will change your life!

Professor Young is a great choice for your gen chem professor. She is very good at lecture, writes clearly and largely on the board so you can copy notes, and always answers any question. She is also very down to earth and kind, so she brightens up class. She cracks jokes and says thing that make the dry material of gen chem a little more fun.

Gen chem is brutal no matter who you take, and you can't avoid it if you're in STEM, but take it with Dr. Young if you have a choice. She understands how difficult the material is, relates to the class, and is very kind. She made the class bearable despite its difficulty and size.
Great guy, highly recommend

I'm an ME who took his CE Fluid Mechanics. He is clear and to-the-point, and really simplifies complex topics. Hw: 4-7 textbook problems each week, and it never took me more than 3 hours to finish. You'll feel like you're in high school again! Not saying it's an easy class, but seemingly much-easier than the other alternative we had.
She's awesome. She tells you exactly what you need to do to succeed. I wish I could take her class again.
Good-nature, super itelligent but hard to follow at times.
Alex is the best!!!  I loved Chorale and miss it very much.  We were very lucky to have him.
Excellent professor. Very enthusiastic about the course material, helps students learn and makes it easy to get into the course.
She's super cool and it's easy A. The exams are super easy, all mcqs, and the answers are all basically written on study guide
Great Foundations of Theo course. Teaches/lectures well, and is an engaging professor. Very adaptable. Short readings for each class.

Prof Kourany obviously knows her stuff. While the class was mostly student-led, she would often jump in to explain concepts or challenge us. She had high expectations but let us shape the class to fit our interests. She was difficult to contact outside of class but was very willing to help if you caught her after class. Classes often ran over time.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Kourany's class was structured so that it was mostly student-led, reducing her role solely to picking out readings for class. She failed to help guide discussion, yet somehow managed to consistently hold us up to 20 minutes past class. Her feedback was unclear and extremely unhelpful. She did not respect students or their time and it showed.

Professor McLachlan relies heavily on his lectures for his tests. He will frequently have questions on tests that directly come form slides. DO THE READING prior to class as he expects you to do so. Tests are 1 hr. 15 min. With 21 questions (5 multiple choice, 16 free response). study ahead of time, utilize recorded lectures posted onto canvas.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Accessible outside class

comment: Do not take this class if you can avoid it. There was little instruction, tutorials were very hard, class was extremely disorganized and I felt as if I learned absolutely nothing.
Don't take him for Elements of Calc, he does not care about the class at all. He makes fun of the material every class and isn't helpful in the assignments. Take Mulholland or really anyone else.

Very good at teaching difficult concepts. He's very passionate about what he teaches, and it shows. Whenever I had a question, he gave great explanations. WARNING: If you are not looking for a rigorous proof-based calculus course, DO NOT take this class. This is the hardest class I have ever taken, by far. But if math is your thing, go for it!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: sometimes goes off on tangents and talks a lot but overall this class was very discussion based which is engaging. He likes to press students for deeper answers--sometimes it feels like he's putting you on the spot and trying to embarrass you, but its probably because he wants you to reach your potential of developing thoughts.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Do not expect an easy humanities class from him. Knows his stuff, and expects you to know it, too. Doesn't seem like too bad a guy but research rather than teaching seems to be his forte. Essays are on complex topics and force you to do stuff you'd expect from actual history majors

Brian is a good teacher overall. Struggles to explain harder topics and keep the class engaging. Will always answer questions. I didn't think the class was too hard, but if you really struggle with calc, Lim is probably the best professor to take. Brian was good for me though!

Knows how to do math but struggles to explain it well to the class. Will happily answer questions and help until you're satisfied. If you have taken Calc. I before this class is easy, otherwise you may struggle with some of his explanations. You have to do the homework and practice questions, its a math class after all. Makes an effort to be kind.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: Open communication and interest in student growth are vital in teaching. Regrettably, my experience in his course wasn't positive. Delays in responses and a seeming disinterest in student development made me question my decision to enroll. Such delays and lack of concern hinder academic progress and degrade the overall learning experience.

Awesome professor, horrible class. He is a very caring professor, very very willing to work with students. Tasked with teaching an unteachable class. Homeworks were very hard as were exams. I would say if this class applies to his others, he challenges students but works to make sure they succeed if the effort is put in. Would recommend

Dr. Anderson is incredibly passionate and knowledgeable the content. As a result of her dedication to theology, I came out of her class with a very strong foundational understanding of the Judeo-Christian religion. That being said, her class is more difficult than other foundation classes--lots of reading, tough grader, and participation matters.

Anderson's foundations class is pretty much entirely discussion based; participate like 1-2 times a class and you'll get full participation points. There are a TON of readings and 3-4 HW questions a night based on the readings. Some readings are interesting, some not so much. Strict grader for papers but exams aren't bad. Tough class overall.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Professor Johnson-Roullier was the most disorganized and frustrating professor that I have had here during my time at Notre Dame. She rearranged the syllabus and due dates so frequently that it was nearly a weekly basis and generally had to have many classes online, including our first class of the semester. Overall nice, but very confusing.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lots of homework

comment: Super sweet and knowledgeable woman! Assigned 9 books (many 350+ pages) for one semester, which was unmanageable and hard to work around. Slightly disorganized and chaotic classroom setting. Not my preferred style of learning, but a great, funny person.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Bohrer is great! She makes lectures very engaging and explains difficult topics well. She is also very flexible, and clearly cares about her students. I highly recommend taking her classes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Bohrer is a great lecturer! She chose very interesting readings and explained them well at an introductory level. Make sure to do the readings and you should do well in her class.
Very sweet and communicative prof for Design Tools 1. Extremely understanding and consistent. Queen

Professor Wang is a solid professor (pun intended). For Design Tools II she does a good job of working with students on their homework and projects and is pretty funny too. Overall a great professor to have.

Mileski changed the class so it's near impossible to get an A. She curves the median test grades to a B+ even though the class should be curved to a 3.6. She does not teach any of the math/stats in the textbook and focuses more on concepts that are intuitive. Half of the class time is spent on unhelpful discussions. Difficult class to sit through.

The class is easy. She's easy-going and lets you decide the format of the exams. My course consisted of 2 exams (one open-note and one take-home) and easy-graded discussion questions. A lot of the exam material is found in the textbook, but some class material is still on it. Problems are more conceptual based than calculation.

As someone who worried heavily about adapting to college-level writing, Professor Want sure was very helpful and patient. She gave amazing feedback and always made herself accessible outside of class time. The workload is fair and not very overwhelming as long as you do everything within a given period of time. I wouldn't want any other professor.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Want somehow made me enjoy a writing class and that is amazing. Yes, there is a decent amount of work but I never felt annoyed by it and would definitely recommend this class if you want to learn various styles of writing in a new way.

This is the prof you want for Writing & Rhetoric. Class was easy as long as you put in some effort and do the assignments. A decent amount of homework and a few very manageable essays (it's a writing course after all). She's extremely caring and really accessible. Even if you aren't the best writer, getting an A is pretty easy.

Professor McKenna is very passionate about what she teaches. I took her CSEM class on renaissance feminism, I thought there was too much work assigned for a class that doesn't count towards your major but still interesting nonetheless. Grading is fair, lots of participation needed. Very clear about her expectations.

Loved her as a professor! Super passionate and understanding. Wouldn't consider the class an easy A - lots of readings (some of which were quite long/tedious) and a discussion-based class so you are graded on participation. If that's not your thing then maybe avoid. Still, class was interesting and she grades fairly if you put in some effort.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: So nice, super easy, trust me this class its hard to get under an A.

She is great, really caring and overall a good person. Funny, engaging, and cares about your learning. Daily readings, but nothing super hard. 5 short, easy quizzes, and if you miss one you have to write an essay. Always available outside class. You will literally learn how to be a better person.

Dan is truly an amazing teacher and really engaging in lectures and outside of class. The class is definitely not an easy one as tests and homework can be very challenging but he is very helpful outside of class and truly wants you to succeed so if you give the effort you will do fine and really learn a lot.

He is terrible, changes the course all the time, genuinely has no idea how to teach. When he starts the class he has this grand plan then goes on too many tangents and never actually gets through any material. If you already know how to code with python then just take him and never go to class. Annoying to listen to, good guy not a good teacher
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Accessible outside class

comment: The class was really challenging for me but also interesting. Dan is awesome and somehow always available outside of class. So while it's super hard he gives lots of opportunities to get extra help. The problem sets took me forever every week though. Go to his office hours, they were so helpful for the homework

Really energetic and passionate but it's almost to a fault. She sometimes goes a little fast, but I do like that she has higher expectations for a fresh level class. Also very understanding and gets know to everyone's name which is nice.

Dr. Levis is very nice and tries to help students through lectures. She also tries to make her lectures engaging and the class isn't boring. Make sure to pay attention to ALL lectures and although she does tend to go a little fast through lectures, the TA will help you catch up if you fall behind.

Professor Aguilar was incredibly kind. His office was open to all students at almost any time and he would personally go out of his way to ensure students understood his subjects. When it came to writing paper, professor Aguilar always broke down how we could improve our writing and was very fair. He also gives out candy. 10/10
Great professor. His lectures were very informative and engaging.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback

comment: I would highly recommend this class! I took him for U.S. Latina/o History and do not regret it. He was very generous with grading for the first two papers and then became stricter. However, he provides great feedback before each essay is due and sets aside time to help students with their writing. One of my favorite professors thus far.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: Amazing professor overall. He truly loves what he does and grades very fairly.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Profe Navia is the best Spanish prof. at ND! He is super understanding that learning a new language is hard and wants his students to do the best they can and to succeed. He was very generous with credit, and often simplified assignments to ensure that most students would do well. I certainly recommend him.

Professor Navia wants each of his students to suceed! The course is challenging, but he structures it so you can succeed. It is easy to get participation points because he goes around the room one at a time and has students answer questions. He took the stress out of learning Spanish, and I'll love him forever. Take him if you can!

Prof. Navia is the only reason I survived the arts & letters language requirement! I am not good at Spanish at all, but his grading was very transparent and he understood that each student has a different level of Spanish proficiency. If you work hard you can succeed in this course. It is very straightforward, and he is a funny!

Candida is just not pleasant. There's just something about her that gives off a bad vibe. Her teaching is okay but didn't really help when it came to outside of class. I recommend trying to get a different professor if you can.
Candida is so smart and knows everything about the Bible. She is hilarious, British, and smoking hot.
History of Business in American was such a unique and interesting class I would definitely recommend. Prof. Specht is very chill and caring and made the class enjoyable
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: Not too much work. Lectures are interesting and Prof. Specht is very entertaining. Highly recommend American Business History. Almost all grading is done by TAs.
Graded mostly by TAs
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Specht is an amazing professor. He makes lectures very interesting and relevant to real life. The class is not too much work and the work there is is interesting. He makes assignment creative and fun. I would strongly recommend him and his classes.
Tom Nowak has very challenging tests, but will be reasonable with grades. He is very supportive and intelligent and always willing to help.  One of the strongest instructors I've had.
Just terrible. Period.

HIST10606 - Boxing in America. Super cool class but A LOT MORE WORK THAN ANTICIPATED. 5 books for 5 3-page essays (TA graded), 2 exams - need to know everything about specific boxers, 1 final paper (5-7 pages). Many readings for Friday discussions. Lectures themselves super interesting - he is so passionate about the topic. Beware of amount of work
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Griffin is absolutely fantastic. Not only is he the best lecturer I have had in my time at Notre Dame, he makes an effort to get to know his students by buying every student lunch to get to know them in a one on one setting. His class is not too much work, just a little bit of reading. Definitely would recommend him to anyone.

Lectures are a lot of fun and interactive. Homework is difficult. I recommend taking this class, it made me really excited about majoring in physics. Really teaches you problem-solving and thinking creatively. Go to office hours, put in the effort, and you'll do well.

Prof Surman is an excellent Physics professor. I took her for E&M, with no exposure to it in high school. Teaches in a well-structured, logical way that made sense to me. She is relaxed and very approachable. Learned a ton and thoroughly enjoyed her class. Exams are hard, but all material is covered well and you'll score well if you pay attention.

If you study for your exams and pay attention to the material then you will succeed. She offered a lot of chances for extra credit as well. Just gave unnecessary busy work a lot of the time, and while the rubric for grading was clear, her choice of grading alongside that rubric was not.

Genuinely one of the best professors I've ever had! She is so kind and takes the extra time to make sure that all of her students fully understand the lesson. She offers lots of different opportunities for extra credit, but you do have to put in the work for it. Super engaging class, I loved it!

Prof Botero is one of my all-time favorite professors at ND. She cares so much for her students and their success. I learned so much about Spanish culture in this class, but it never felt like schoolwork. 10/10 class and professor!
Take his course! An incredible, inspirational man and a great prof.
Great Class! a must in ND Law School

Very difficult class, but Dr. Taylor made it worth it. He is really passionate about the subject and wants you to learn/understand the material. He is very accessible outside of class. He really cares about his students. Lots of homework and difficult exams. I hated the class, but he made me want to go each day.

This class was very hard and I didn't do that great in it - but Professor Taylor made lectures interesting and worth going to even though I hated the class as a whole. He is extremely knowledgable and cares about his students a lot.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Test heavy

comment: This has been more a class on practicing math methods rather than learning any E n M that is not known at undergrad level.I am very disappointed.

Frauendorf is a horrible teacher. He mutters, he's incoherent, All your time will be spent repeating things you already know by heart. It is week 8 of a year long(32 week) graduate class. We have made it to chapter 3 of 24 in the book. Everything from chapters 1-8 is high school material, and despite telling him this, He refuses to change.
One of the best profs I've had at ND. Really cares about his students. Class was interactive and assignments were interesting.
His nickname is "Mr. Cool Guy." That pretty much sums him up.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: He makes me angry!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Looks just like Shakespeare, including the bad hair, and has great accent -- what more do you want in a hot Shakespeare expert?

He's a Grad student; taught Intro to Philo. Fun teacher; really down to earth and pretty flexible when it comes to assignments.  That said, he doesn't assign much to begin with. Four-question quizzes on readings, a few short papers, and two exams.  Makes a pretty tricky subject interesting, and you can tell he really loves the material.
hard grader, but awesome TA, he really cares about this stuff!
Jens is solid in a world of TAs who are usually not good. Not enough of Jens to go around.
Very funny and good professor.

really interesting lecturer, but assigns absurd amounts of readings (that you don't really need to do because he explains them in class anyways); a little intimidating; also, gives RIDICULOUSLY long final take home exams
No Comments
Great prof! Panel system.

Class was fun,  Garnett is very entertaining and she makes the material seem easy in class. However it turns out she is actually just blowing off all of the hard things. The exam is totally killer, hardest one I've ever taken in my life. Friends who had other professors learned WAY more than our class and had a better understanding of the material.

Professor Garbinsky was wonderful! She clearly sets guidelines and makes sure you know exactly what to expect. Her lectures are so easy to follow, and she really makes learning the material easy. No textbook use at all, but prepare to work a lot with the group you are placed into for the semester. I would highly recommend for marketing!

She's super straightforward, so you know exactly what to expect - w her classes, tests, projects. Ur in a group for the whole semester, and she definitely makes u work for ur grade, but tells u exactly what she wants so i appreciated that. and her lectures were actually informative and interesting. and no hw
rating_tags: Respected--Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria

comment: Took him for Sustainability. Doesn't stop laughing at his own jokes and talking about how he worked at NASA. He doesn't really know how to be helpful to students and gives criticism rather than actual constructive criticism. Basically your classic tenured professor that is too comfortable in their own position to put any real effort into helping.
Very professional and kind. Expects a lot out of his students.

It is a hard class but his lectures were so helpful in learning a hard topic. 

If you work hard you can succeed in this class

Peaslee has a reputation that isn't the greatest, but he's very accessible 1 on 1 and tries very hard to be helpful during lectures. He rarely stops talking during lecture, so it sometimes gets overwhelming, especially with the topics in 2nd semester physicd.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: I know this is a req for CHEGs, but it was really bad. It was his first time teaching the course, but the material was well organized. Positive attitude and respect for his students, however, was majorly lacking.
Exams are tough but not graded terribly hard. The projects and homeworks are very time consuming yet worthwhile.
Great professor. Had a great time with him in Honors Calc 3. Initially very reserved, he turned out to be very funny and lovable!

Mnev presented all the content in Honors Calculus 3 thoroughly and clearly, closely following our textbook. We were allowed to work on the homework in small groups, which makes it significantly easier. He usually just gives lectures (which seems effective for math), and makes sure to occasionally ask if there are any questions.

The material for linear algebra is incredibly difficult, so unfortunately it looks bad on Mnev. But really, I think he's a fine teacher. I'd recommend sitting closer to the front to get the most from class. Unexceptional teacher but he goes through all the material and does a decent job of explaining and posting his notes online.
Best accounting professor at this school.
never gives relevant practice for the exam.
Best professor I've had at ND. Super engaging and interesting. Will always help outside of class time. Would recommend taking any class he is teaching.

Barron's sports analytics class was ok. I personally didn't have a ton of sports knowledge going into the class, and I was unable to understand a lot of the analysis. The lectures felt like he was just showing us a cool project he did, but we didn't actually learn the skills. Little homework + big project where you can work in group or by yourself.

She uses an iPad to project her steps to solve the skeleton example sheets. She is very organized in how she goes through problems using colors and numbers to make each sequential step clear. However, she can over-explain some things, making simple topics seem complex at first. Overall a good experience though.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Online Savvy

comment: Had her for Calc A which I took in High School. Class itself was relatively easy, but she just isn't a good teacher. If it's your first time taking Calc, I'd go with another prof. She rambles on about pointless concepts and is unable to explain the necessary concepts in simple terms. Class is boring and entirely lectures.

I LOVE Professor Shelton. I couldn't have asked for a better W&R teacher. Her class really forced me to break down my writing, and I improved SO much. Shelton always makes class interesting, and she never fails to make me laugh. She's hip but also has an old soul. I have zero complaints about her class. I couldn't recommend her more!

She was an absolutely amazing TA for my Intro to American Studies class. She always took the time to make sure we understood the concepts; she also never hesitated to quickly answer questions. If you just show her your outlines and papers before submitting them, you'll get an A!

Democracy in Crisis: Really great guy. New lecturer, but so likable. Few pop quizzes on daily readings, so skim before each class. Maybe 2 papers, final, present on country's democracy history. Interesting graphs, kinda dense but cool to see the trends. Small, discussion based, but open environment to share whatever thoughts.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Beware of pop quizzes--Caring

comment: Paul is a new lecturer and could definitely use some practice, but overall he's a great professor. I had him for African Politics and he made the topic very interesting and easy to understand. He's a fairly easy grader as well.

I really liked Professor Spiess! She is very sweet and knows a lot about M&A. She was always very helpful in office hours and her tests were very fair. There were a fair amount of group projects but they were very manageable. Super interesting class overall - definitely recommend taking M&A if you're looking for a Finance elective!

I'm in grad school at ND and Spiess is BY FAR one of the best professors I've ever had. She explains intricate and confusing concepts extremely well and is incredibly helpful outside of class. I learned a ton and you know exactly what you need to do to get an A. AMAZING professor
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: Great teacher. Teaches complex concepts in ways that are easy to understand. Very helpful during office hours.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Calc 2 is a pretty tough class, but Professor Mulholland made it exponentially easier. She was so clear in her lectures. She does move quite fast, but I think this is offset by her stopping for questions very frequently. She was very accessible and willing to help in office hours.

If you are taking calc 2, take Professor Muholland. Trust me she is the best calculus professor here. She is caring, and her lectures are the most engaging out of all of the other professors. She is extremely welcoming and helpful, and easy to talk to.

Professor Riedl is a very good professor. He ensures that students understand the material and is always available to help students outside of class. He is very enthusiastic about teaching and is easy to talk to. He is always open to questions. The course itself is very exam heavy so it is important to attend lectures and take many practice exams.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Riedl clearly cared about what he was teaching, but was rather dull in teaching it. He was available outside of class and was helpful and responsive overall, but if you're prone to falling asleep in class Professor Riedl is not the professor for you.

Logan is an amazing professor, keeps the topics interesting, and allows you to change the prompt to something you enjoy for projects. For projects, you would tell him the grade you thought you deserved, and he would usually give you that. I'm not sure if he does this for all classes, but he is extremely nice with extensions and very assessable.

By far the best professor at this university. He is such a caring individual and wants to ensure that not only does everyone in the class pass but that they all are able to grow and prosper as writers. His four assignments are actually enjoyable, too! If you are going to take any Writing & Rhetoric class here, you HAVE to take it with Logan!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Amazing lectures

comment: Professor Cole is a good guy who does not give out much work. For my class, we rarely had to actual complete an engagement about the film, but you only have to be prepared to talk about a topic he gives to you before class. I do think he is retiring this year but was a great professor and easy grader.

ARS Robotica is great because it is easier than a lot of other literature USEMs. There is not too much work and he does not grade super harshly but he can be weirdly picky about certain things which is annoying but he doesn't take too many points off. The classes were fine but I didn't really learn a lot. Definitely would recommend as a USEM

ARS Robotica is one of the best USEM's offered by the school. The course consists of 2 short stories and 1 book along with about 12 movies. You are given a book/movie each week to watch and write a 2 page response to a prompt he emails you. You don't do any research and he only looks to see that you thoughtfully analyzed. Much less work than others

The absolute worst professor on campus. Avoid at all costs. You are only graded by the midterm and final. I thought I got a 100 on the midterm and he gave me a C- and I was forced to drop the class. He is absolutely crazy as well and irrational. His lectures make no sense at times and he is very mean. I do not know how he is a professor here.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Davis is one of the best professors at Notre Dame. His course is challenging, but he is extremely passionate about what he's teaching and he cares about his students. He is hilarious and some of the stories he tells in class are legendary! Take this course if you can! You won't regret it, just be ready to work hard.

Overall amazing professor. Though he indicates he makes his own political leanings clear, he encourages students to disagree with him and actively takes opposing viewpoints into consideration as the course focuses on the social dynamics of American History. Good amount of reading that you do not have to do but I recommend.

Cajka is an awesome prof who is very passionate about his work. There are many readings outside of class but you do not really need to do them. Grades are based on a few papers, the midterm, and the final. Overall a very easy course would definitely recommend.

Prof. Cajka is such an incredible professor. He is very passionate about the subject he teaches on and is always willing to take other people's points of view into question. I took Witnessing the Sixties with him, and the papers were difficult but he is always willing to help during office hours. Readings are interesting if you like history.

Professor Cajka was amazing. His lectures were super engaging, and he's super passionate about the subject. Discussions were really interesting, and he let students guide the direction of the class. It was easily the most interesting course of my semester. Pay attention to lectures and you will succeed.

Dr. Marvin is incredibly kind and helpful. She makes class very entertaining and engaging, and I learned a lot. My writing improved greatly with her assistance, and she gives you many many opportunities to improve your work for extra points back on assignments.
Hidden gem. Definitely should take for W&R.

She is the kindest professor on this campus! Highly Highly recommend Advanced Writing Rhet for anyone of any grade level. It sounds hard but it's actually relatively easy and soooo helpful for building life/career skills

If you're taking multimedia writing and rhetoric, PLEASE sign up for Professor Marvin's course. She is literally the kindest professor you will ever have, and her assignments are not super difficult. She gives you plenty of time to work on assignments as well. She is super good at lecturing and makes the class interesting! Literally is amazing!

Took Professor Lu for cell bio and loved him. Tests were hard, but there was a lot of extra credit to balance it out and he so obviously really cared about students and always listened to feedback. If you want to really learn the gritty details of cell bio and get into the subject without a ton of stress, take him.

Lectures were pretty boring, but the material is interesting and not difficult. Final grade is mostly based on tests with a few points coming from completion-based homeworks and one project. He is absolutely available and willing to meet one-on-one for a review session before exams, which I found extremely useful. Overall, not a difficult course.

Akosa has a very thick accent and reads off the slideshow for the most part. The class is fairly easy with little homework and she allows a cheat sheet for the tests as to write all the formulas down. If you go to the lectures and understand the calculations you will be fine but the MC on the test are very hard as it is about theory we do not learn

She is nice and very willing to help out when you don't understand something. She has a very thick accent and spends too much time on easy material which makes class very monotonous. Free response on Exams are very similar to the practice exams, but the multiple choice contains some new, very challenging questions.

You have to be extremely focused in class to get anything out of the lectures. Akosa has a thick accent which is difficult to understand, and it can frequently be hard to follow what she is saying. Attendance is optional though which is nice, and sometimes I've heard of people teaching themselves the material instead of going to class.

Prof. Akosa's class was extremely challenging, and she often took off points without clear reasons. She was difficult to reach outside of class, making it hard to get assistance. As a Mendoza College senior, I've had many supportive professors, but unfortunately, she wasn't one of them. If possible, consider other instructors.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Graded by few things

comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS PROFESSOR! Sitting through her lectures was pure torture as she scream lectures and speaks in a monotone voice. She spends the whole class on the easy part of the lecture and leaves 5 minutes for the difficult material. I had to teach myself the whole course. Save yourself, and pick a different professor.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Took him for Intro to Christian Ethics and had a great time. Taking his class helped me to deeper understand the foundations of my faith, classical ethics, and the application of my faith to difficult decisions and hot topics in current events. Great speaker, would recommend.

Terribly organized. No guidelines or rubric is provided for written assignments, making it very difficult to understand what he wants you to write about. Feedback on assignments is useless and does not explain grades. Lectures are monotonous, repetitive, and do not stimulate interest in the subject. I would not wish this class upon my worst enemy.

Super caring professor who genuinely wanted to get to know all of his students. The main assignments were two papers, one based solely on the readings and one cumulative project, and the workload was not too bad.

One of the easier theology teachers. Homeworks are readings that can range from 20-75 minutes, usually around 30-35 minutes a night. Only two papers all year (one midterm and one final). Class is all discussion very little lecture.  Essays are graded fairly so just put in the work for those two assignments and you will be fine
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: A kindred soul and good man. Took abnormal, prioritizes students and genuinely wants to get to know you as people. Lectures are heavy but he makes them incredibly manageable and engaging, never bored in class. Readings supplement material well in addition to projects; bona fide good prof that very few people have quarreled with, recommend 24/7.
I never went to class but it was easy, only two exams about 23 questions each

Prof. Powers has one of the hardest USEMs- he's a tough grader and assigns lots of essays but he gives feedback. He lets the class pick some topics to study based on what we care about. Lectures are dull sometimes but he's knowledgeable and has a ton of connections. I'd recommend if you want a challenging class/genuinely care about peacebuilding.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--So many papers

comment: I really enjoyed having Professor Powers for my peace studies senior seminar. He is very kind. Lectures can be dull at times, but he really puts effort into knowing all of his students and asking us what topics we are interested in learning more about. I would highly recommend him!

Took class fall 2024 so it is easier compared to previous years. His lectures are flipped so you learn topics through online lectures then attend in person (which is optional) for questions / more application. He does not help on homework questions. two exams, one final. one-sided cheat sheet allowed for each exam. go to ACES for homework help.

Quiz every day. Not too much homework -- just 1 packet a week with about 7 questions. Only 1 hour of office hours a week, in which he discourages you from asking to walk through homework problems and instead will only give "hints". Exams are okay, you get a cheat sheet. He's not the most respectful when you're confused on the material.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: He does a very good job providing an overview of the different parts of electrical engineering, which is helpful as an introduction to the major. His lectures are overall pretty decent, but not spectacular. The prelabs and lab reports are also brutal, taking many hours to complete and including lots of dense reading that you must go through.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read

comment: Prof Juan is very passionate. He cares a lot about his class but expects it to be a priority. Would definitely take again if I did not have a heavy class load.

He is VERY passionate about what he does. His main goal is to get students to think creatively and step outside of their comfort zone. He really believes in his students and sees the virtues of their creative projects while offering ideas for improvement. My only critique is that he sometimes loses track of time.
