Prof Flenner is good at explaining the material, but some of the concepts themselves are just difficult to understand. He is very accessible outside of class for extra help and gives partial credit on quizzes and exams. There is a homework and quiz each week. 2 section exams and 1 cumulative final.
"Here's another fact...well, it's not much of a fact. It's more like an antifact..."

Sets unrealistically high standards for engaging with the material to succeed (focus questions, must reread, pop quizzes). Exams are doable but he tells you nothing about how they'll be formatted. Papers are long and scheduled so that the brunt of writing must happen over breaks. Great guy & really cares about the content, but I wouldn't recommend.
Professor Newlands really values helping his students learn and seeing them grow.
rating_tags: Respected--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Sebastian is by far the best professor I've had here at ND. He truly makes learning fun, even when the subject material is a bit bland. If you have the chance to take him, do it!
He's awesome. Class i

Smart professor who has some extremely engaging lectures, but he does not know how to teach an undergraduate course... Also quite biased, and plays favorites with students. Most of the readings are unnecessary. Still learned a lot from him

From the second you walk in this class you know where this guys bias lies. Super hard the whole class, only gives biased information and readings for class. Surface level stuff as well. Kind of a joke: you just gotta play the game.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--So many papers

comment: Dr. Merluzzi is very thorough with his feedback. This class is excellent if you are planning on going to graduate school. Everyone in my class got into grad school. He wrote me an excellent letter of rec, and he really cares about your success beyond undergrad.
No Comments
Boring.
Educating in Faith:  Great course! Favorite Teacher at ND, hands down!

Prof. Smyth is a good teacher. He can be very humorous and tends to balance out serious topics with some levity. Tough grader and demands a lot of your writing. He has a divisive personality (I know some people were put off by him) but I never had any problems

Jim is a great and funnyirascible teacher. Tends to be lecture oriented but he does like to speak to students outside of seminar to hear about their work and interests. For women, do be cognizant, however, that he is of a certain vintage and does feel entitled acting a certain way. He is probably harmless, but just know what you're in for.

Professor Kandel is a wonderful teacher- he teaches you how to think about issues chemically and understand concepts rather than just solve problems. As long as you make an effort, he will be more than willing to help you succeed. Also, he makes funny chemistry jokes on the regular
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--ACCESSIBLE OUTSIDE CLASS--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Kandel genuinely cares about his students. I've never seen a professor who gave as much of an effort to make sure that everyone understood the material. He wasn't always very clear during lecture, but if you went to office hours he would clear up anything you were confused about. Very funny, great guy, but you definitely have to work.

I HATE writing but prof Jansen is AMAZNIG. We talked about music videos a lot and I literally wrote a paper on the Weeknd but he is not an easIy grader.. If u want a A or B be reayd to spend ALOT of time on revising ur papers.
Professor Jansen was a tough grader but his class was awesome! Take his class. There was a lot of work but he was very helpful.
Tormey is sooooo hot.  I really want to have his babies.  I wish this guy would come back to ND.  But I do not know where he went.  Mike come back!  For both our sake.
Made a hard stats class actually enjoyable

Took stats. SO EASY if you've taken any intro stats class before (I took AP in highschool). He really wanted to make sure everyone understood. He also tries to engage class but sometimes class isn't very receptive at 830 in the morning. Nice guy. I did very well.
Super helpful teacher. Always available for meetings. He reminds me of an absent minded professor. You can tell he really loves math.
He's the best prof
Garrett is the best professor ever, and he is SO dreamy. He's so talented and helpful!
Good teacher, can be a little conceited. Overall great teacher though, really knows his stuff and knows how to make you learn it.
Definitely seems to talk down to students. Could do well to come across as more respectful of students' effort in his class. Tends to remind class of his intellectual stature.

E. Capdevielle's W&R is okay. It has an environment/community theme that doesn't appeal to all, but it was somewhat interesting. As long as you are engaged and keep up on writing assignments, you will be fine. She has opportunities to revise and re-submit essays. She is also understanding about extending deadlines as long as you communicate.

Prof. Capdeville is such a great professor and very passionate about writing. Lessons are very engaging and clear. There are 3 main papers, including a 10-15 page research paper, and you get to choose your topics. She is very caring and will meet with you outside of class as much as you want. Not an easy A, but definitely worthwhile.
The Arabic professors at Notre Dame are phenomenal and so caring and helpful.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria

comment: Professor Bronson is excellent, probably the best I've had. I learned more in her class than I did in my other four combined. My interest in the Arabic language has grown over my three semesters with her and I plan to continue. The only negative is the unclear book which the professor supplements with her own handouts.

Dr. Radcliff is such a unique professor. His lectures are incredibly boring, but he is such a funny man. It defies logic. Regardless, his exams are really easy and are usually open notes, so as long as you put in any effort, you are basically guaranteed a high grade. If you're looking for an engaging course, this is not the one to take.

Prof. Radcliff is a really nice guy and really cares about his students, but he's not the most organized professor ever. I took Applied Quantitative Methods with him and it seemed like he had no idea what he was doing, or if he did, he just didn't know how to explain it. That being said, he's a really easy grader.

There is a lot of reading for this class, but the reading is always very interesting. Make sure to attend the lectures. As long as you are attending class regularly you will ace every quiz and test. Theres no trick questions. His class is very interesting and I would 100% take again
very interesting

Prof. Baglow was a great Foundations of Theo teacher! We had a lot of group work which was nice because we got to know our classmates and discuss key concepts together. His tests weren't too bad and he was available to answer questions if you were confused. He's a very nice guy and really wants his students to be interested in what he's teaching.

Dr. Baglow is a great Theo prof if you're interested in science at all. He does his best to rationalize religion in light of science, and makes it more digestible for those of us who think scientifically. Only one big paper and a few tests, which are just questions from the lectures. Great guy, good and prepared lecturer, overall solid choice.

Great professor and a useful class for learning the basics of designing computer interfaces! There is a semester-long group project where we work on understanding user needs, designing, and evaluating an app in an application domain of choice. Professor Li is very engaging and gave great feedback on our projects.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: This class involves a lot of readings, writing reflections, and discussions on these readings. Professor Li is very knowledgeable about HCI research and provides great individual feedback to each student. I highly recommend this class to any CS grad student. Topics covered in this class are useful and practical, even for those outside HCI.

Donovan is a great professor. Graded mostly off of three exams, one group case, and one individual case. There is a lot of material, but he does his best to get through everything and gives good examples. Exams aren't easy, but are pretty straight forward. He tries to make himself very accessible to students and seems very accommodating.

John is awesome! Would 100% take this class again. He's chill and the lectures are helpful/make sense with reference slides that are clear so you can go back and understand if you happen to miss something. And super engaging!
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: John is a fantastic dude. Really helpful and knowledgeable if you have questions. Also gives really good in-class problems that prepare you for the exam and real-world examples that really help contextualize the material. The King of Partial Credit.
I love Professor Hall as his lectures are humorous and well organized. He offers reasoning for every concept covered, which was super helpful for me to understand.
The best math teacher I have had in my time at ND, will be taking more of his classes in the future

Good funny professor, sure he does not hang around class after it is over but you have a tutorial for an hour to ask questions. Certainly learned more from him than anyone else in the math department. Shows you easiest ways to do problems on exams, not just the "textbook" way. Great exam prep too.

Professor showed up to class at exact minute class starts, left at exact minute it ended. If you get confused, you can try asking him, but he simply repeats what he said before in lecture, which is often what got me confused to begin with. Form a study group for this class because maybe someone understands it better and can simplify better.

Really easy elective. Content is pretty interesting. Covers a lot of research design which is cool. Only 4 problem sets which take ~1 hour and are very easy. Midterm and final exam which were both pretty easy. My advice is never read the textbook and you don't have to read every single word of the research papers. You can get away with skimming.

Professor Gibbs' Economics of Education class was super interesting. Readings for every class, but you can mostly skim or just read the important parts an be fine. Only hw is 4 problem sets each worth 10% of grade, but not difficult. Exams are straightforward and not too difficult. Participation is a decent part of the grade.
Fantastic professor. She is very knowledgeable and is very willing to clarify any doubts that you have. She's also very accessible outside of class!

I really liked Gibbs' Economics of Education class. I thought that her lectures and the subject matter was very interesting, and Prof. Gibbs was very flexible and understanding throughout the semester. There isn't a lot of homework, and the tests are pretty easy.

Not for the faint of heart. Will put you on the spot and tell you you're wrong and he will be right about it. But if you're ready to learn his is a great class. Interesting guy whom you get to know as an individual. Focused reader, will give specific pointers on papers. Builds a good community, I was usually excited to attend his class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Norton is a good professor. His class is a little disorganized with no Canvas and how he emails you the homework sometimes just 18 hours in advance. There is a lot of reading but you just needed surface level understanding. A LOT of grammar homework. 3 papers. Never knew my grade throughout semester which was interesting. Cold Calls!

Soooooo much reading, I almost was never able to finish the readings on top of my other coursework. Discussion based class for USEM, so be ready for him to call on you. Organization is okay, but sometimes his expectations are unclear and he expects you to be super interested in his course. Great person, but I wasn't the biggest fan of the class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: He is very passionate about the topics he teaches and is pretty engaging. Gives large chunks to read, but otherwise there were only 2 written assignments. Grades fairly-- if you put in the effort and thought, you will earn a solid grade on it. Take this Professor if you like reading-- he assigns good books pertaining to the class topics.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: I loved Professor Capdevielle and the structure of his class. No final drafts are due until the end of the semester, and he provides excellent feedback. Your grade is primarily comprised of four papers, one of them being an audio essay. I definitely recommend him for Writing and Rhetoric.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: By far, he's the best professor in the Writing & Rhetoric department. He does not grade harshly, yet simultaneously he gives extremely good feedback. Please take him, he's great!

He ran his classroom in a really cool format. He would have us write drafts and bring them in to talk about in groups. Also he required one on one meetings with him to discuss our drafts. It helped a lot to know what to fix, final portfolio consisted of all the papers written throughout the semester. He definitely wasn't as easy compared to others.
Dr. V is awesome. The labs are super chill, you get snacks every week and overall the lab is a really relaxing environment, a lot of fun and will add no stress to your semester. Take it if you can.

Dr. V is the best! I had him for cell bio lab and he is the best. Snacks and music every week. He is such a funny dude and makes lab great. We rarely stayed the whole time and the work was easy. The presentation at the end was a little annoying but manageable. Easiest bio lab.

We were able to pick our own grade based on a contract where we had to fulfill certain requirements such as submitting X/X homework assignments on time, only missing 2 classes, etc. Attendance was technically mandatory but was not really tracked, at least in the class I took. Would definitely recommend!

Her class was very casual and I am so happy I get to have her again next semester. Never took Python before and was fine. Each assignment was pass/fail and you get two tries per assignment with feedback from the TAs. The number of "fails" you have at the end of the semester determines your grade. Sometimes she brings her dog to class too.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: A good seminar leader, but spent the first half hour of every class essentially repeating what we had said in the prior class in a very dry and uninteresting tone. A poor lecturer. But the material was very interesting, and she gave a good amount of freedom on what you wrote about.

"Sociology of Culture" USEM: Attendance and participation are required. 2 papers + daily readings and one-page journal entries. Class is entirely discussion-based. Overall interesting and age-appropriate discussion topics. No exams. She lets discussion flow naturally and does not mind if we get slightly off-topic occasionally. A good USEM!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: This class seemed interesting and fit my Art History major requirements, and it was regretful from the start. Lectures were dreadfully boring, and the entire grade is based off of 3 written exams. He is an extremely tough grader with no clear direction, and I saw no grade improvement after many office hours visits.

Robin Rhodes so far in my career at Notre Dame has been one of the worst professors I have taken a class from. I took this class as a USEM fine arts credit and boy do I regret it. He was extremely dull in class and graded extremely harshly. He preferred essays that showed a low level of writing. Awful awful awful. Avoid at all costs.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Tough grader

comment: While I got an A in the course, I received zero feedback as to why, and the entire grade was based on a single paper. So do that paper well I guess. There was a lot of assigned reading but it didn't really have much incentive without any tie to a grade, and to me it was quite repetitive and pushed a lot of the same recurring themes over and over.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Respected--Graded by few things

comment: Prof. Omar truly cares about each of his students and is so passionate about peace studies. He made the 15 page paper very manageable by having a 5 page draft due in March then a 12 page draft in April. This was super helpful because we got his feedback to incorporate into the final paper. He gives great lectures and assigns interesting readings
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Accessible outside class

comment: Sehnert is amazing! His lectures were very well-structured and easy to follow. He was very in tune with what the class did not understand and explained these topics more thoroughly. He is very smart and funny! His class had a good balance between lecture time and small group discussion. Overall, this was a very laidback yet informative class!

Professor Sehnert is a good professor. The course consists of reading roughly 20-30 pages per class, and then a brief lecture at the beginning of class followed by a student presentation and general discussion. The work in the class in minimal. If you need to take a political theory course, this is an easy but interesting option.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Accessible outside class

comment: Bechler was bomb!!! His class was super straight forward and most of his exams was just vocab from lectures. Make quizlets and you'll ace the class. He's a young guy who's relateable and funny. If you take this class with anyone else you aren't doing it right--- it's Bechler or nothing.
I loved Prof Bechler. He was relatable and made lectures fun with good examples. He seems very excited to work in this topic which adds value to his lectures. Very manageable class and work load.

Witnessing Climate Change is an interesting and relevant class. It doesn't require a crazy amount of work. Not too tough of a grader, and you get a point of extra credit for every climate/writing event you go to. I enjoyed how the class was structured: lectures once a week & smaller discussions twice a week. The assignments were interesting too.

Witnessing Climate Change is one of the best courses you could take at ND. You'll learn a ton about climate change and grow immensely as a writer. You can get away with not doing some of the readings but they're really interesting and informative. As long as you put in the work, you'll most likely get an A (it's also easy to get extra credit).
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Gives good feedback

comment: Prof. Miller is by far the best Orgo professor at ND. You're giving yourself the best shot at succeeding by choosing to go to his lectures. I'm sure other professors are fine, but Prof. Miller is extremely knowledgeable about the topic, and you can tell he really cares. He's great about answering questions over email and during class.

Prof. Miller is great! As good as an orgo professor can get. Lecture is not mandatory but you should attend to do well, you might not even have to read the textbook. He explains the concepts and mechanisms really well and is very accessible outside of class. Do the problem sets and quizzes, they do help your grade. You can tell he loves teaching.

Lorenzo Riva is a good professor overall. You can tell that he cares about what he teaches and is passionate about the subject. As a student entering the class with no prior experience on the course's topics, his way of teaching did not work well for me though.

Lorenzo is very thorough with his notation and verbose in his lectures, so be mindful of that before taking his class. He's got great handwriting and uses colored chalk often, which helps a lot with notetaking. He's got a good sense of humor and is very helpful in office hours. He's also pretty patient when it comes to homework extensions.

Dr. Mclaughlin is a great professor. Always available for any advice needed. Her classes are very fun and the topics talked about are very interesting. At first, there are a lot of readings but, later in the semester, it gets a little more chill.

Dr. McLaughlin is a very respectable instructor. If you need to take W&R, you can't go wrong with her class. Dr. McLaughlin gives great feedback and makes herself readily available. I also feel that I learned in her class, which not many people can say about other courses. Overall, great instructor. Just work, ask questions, and you'll be fine!
difficult but rewarding
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: The Black horror class was interesting but a lot of reading and writing. Sometimes he expects students to know about difficult literary theory or political history so I felt a bit out of place at times. We wrote a lot but it was all done in small portions so it wasn't that bad. He was accessible for office hours and gives harsh but good feedback.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: George is actually an unreal professor. He is an incredibly professional person and has the real world experience in the film and writing industry to back up his course load. His assignments are tailored towards creatives, and they are not incredibly difficult if you like to write/make short film exercises. Overall, my favorite professor at ND.
George was a fantastic professor and his insight really helped me grow as a student. He gives great feedback and wants to see you perform better.

Br. Jacob is my favorite prof I have taken so far! He is super funny, encouraging, and accessible outside of class! He cares about each of his students and keeps his lectures entertaining! He is a tough grader but you can tell it is only because he wants us to master French. Would 100% recommend to take him, he is the best!

Great professor and very helpful in building your confidence to speak in French. Was extremely understanding and would grant extensions or offer help if you were struggling in class. Would definitely recommend Brother Jacob Eifrid!

I took Bernel for Strategy and I would not take him again. He was "fine" but frequently confused our class for his other Leadership class. Questions on Leadership topics would make it on our Strategy exams and vis versa. I attended every class with occasional participation and got a 1/5 on participation, taking me from an A to A-. Would avoid.

Incredibly arbitrary professor. Class was honestly horrific to get through. Least favorite Foundations class by far. I was supposed to get an A in the class, but he gave me a 1/5 on participation even though I spoke to him consistently before and after class. I'd avoid at all costs. He keeps telling the same stories too, and has no concept of tech.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Very boring lecturer. Lecture material not very useful to labs or tests. Homework and labs were tough, especially the coding in labs. Overall a poorly designed and ran class (not all his fault), but just kind of a waste unfortunately. He is not the worst professor I have had, but he made no impact on my life whatsoever. Not a grade killer though
Easy class, show up and fall asleep. If you have a brain in your head you will pass.

This is the hardest class I've taken in my life. I am not at all a history person and it really showed when I was graded in this class. I got torn apart. That being said, I love prof. Thomas and learned so much in her class. Expect to be taught by a professor who is passionate and well-versed in the subject of the course. Highest praise for her.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: Such a nice prof who really cares about all of her students. She's passionate about her work and it shows. She does want you to conform to her favored writing and conduct styles, but if you do that and make a genuine effort to connect to the material, you will succeed. Probably the best personal connection I've made with a teacher. Recommended!

Fundamentally changed how I viewed the Catholic position on service. The volunteering required for the course was very impactful for me, and made the class a huge bonus for my semester. Only class I really looked forward to going to. The due dates for things are super flexible. I wish she taught more classes I could take, she's the best.

She is so sweet, she gives religious sister vibes. A lot of reading & writing to prepare for class but it's interesting. Easy grader, very forgiving regarding late work. Service work is really nice. Discussions in class about important social issues, very respectful and insightful. Would definitely recommend if you enjoy CST.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Inspirational--Lots of homework

comment: Professor Kleiser is a great person, and cares about her students. However, her grades are very difficult, they're hard to study for and very unpredictable. She's definitely a difficult professor and makes you work for your grade. But she will make sure you do not fail, and is helpful during office hours.

She is a great person, but her teaching style is reading off of slides during class and giving some real-life examples. Somewhat difficult to fully grasp the concepts she teaches, but the tests aren't ridiculously hard. Tests do somewhat have random questions but if you review the slides a little bit before the test you'll be fine

Kleiser's midterms and finals are pretty hard compared to the rest of intro to marketing classes. Take another easier professor to get the marketing requirement out of the way. However, she's pretty knowledgeable, and I did learn quite a lot in one semester. She takes attendance periodically, especially in the beginning of the semester.
Wasn't really sympathetic. I didn't understand the way he graded. Lectures were tangential and Eurocentric (even in World Cinema). He seemed like he had good intentions...
All around great professor in a department that is really struggling right now. Had him for American Television History, he was really funny and was always open to people's points of view.
I had Professor Krier and I graduated in 1978.  He taught me how to read, dissect and appreciate a novel.  I'm thrilled to see that he is still teaching and that our son can have the same experience.
You will learn a ton. I took him seven years ago and still think about his class often.
Amazing professor - she told us about her fieldwork frequently and was genuinely interested in what students thought during lectures. I would take this class again!!!
She's a very knowledgeable professor but more importantly, she actually practices her field. Its an honor to be in her classroom.

Professor refuses to answer questions, just responds with useless questions that leave you more confused. Has an ego and gets frustrated easily when students don't understand his tasks. Talks to the class like you are already supposed to know the things that he is saying, never really teaches. I would avoid his classes if possible.

Takes off too much points for homework. Make students think it's better to not even be spending that much time doing homework when the points taken off are just ridiculous. Need to start thinking that students are actually trying to learn and taking that many points off will not encourage them at all.

Recommend for non-humanities majors. I didn't expect the best class I took at Notre Dame to be a required core course, last semester of senior year. I have zero interest in religion and picked the class for the time slot. Romero combines theory with practical stories, which I liked. I wish he had returned our exams more quickly. Nice guy.

Dr. Romero's Theology and Disability course is a good class: highly recommended. I signed up for the class as my second theology requirement because it looked interesting. He made we want to change my minor to theology. The class was a little harder than I expected, but it was worth it. He only had us buy two novels and everything else was PDF.

Katherine Novey taught me when she was a PhD student, and was amazing at breaking down the most complex of topics. She is extremely organised, with notes being sent out prior to the start of every class so that everybody was on the same page about the content that was being covered. She is also extremely accessible outside of class. She is amazing!

Taught my course as a 4th yr PhD student. Easy class to pass if you do your hw and study diligently before the tutorials (quizzes never during the class per). Tests the same for all calc students-were pretty chill. Seemed to be reviewing herself > teaching the course. Emails organized notes despite solely using a chalkboard and yolo-ing lessons.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: A literal queen. I took her summer class that condensed the semester into 4 weeks and still feel like I learned so much about the language with no problem. Also super approachable even for someone with no Italian background. 10/10 recommend.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Clear grading criteria--Gives good feedback

comment: The best

Pat is probably the best math professor I've ever had. For brief periods of time, his explanations of concepts could make me understand why someone would want to be a math major. In a course with some seriously tough material, he did a great job of helping us all to understand well enough to succeed. His office hours are great, too.

Prof. Heslin brought an unexpected amount of positive energy to calculus 1. His explainations were clear and accurate. Having taken the class before in high school, I thought I didn't have much to learn. But Heslin eaily provided new, often easier ways to think about things. Very clear and often makes good jokes.

Professor Johnson is awesome! I took his class for Foundations and really enjoyed it. Your grade is mostly based on papers and the tests (which 75% of the test grade is an essay). He shows up to class every day excited to teach and wants everyone to learn. I definitely worked harder than my friends in other foundations but got a lot more out of it.

Very good! He clearly cares for his students and is dedicated to the course. There is an above-average level of reading, but it is a Theology class. Essays are vital but you'll do well once you realize what analysis he's looking for. Not an easy A, but not your hardest class, take if interested in getting something from class past the requirement.
Lectures were a bit unorganized and slightly dull. Nice guy and cares about his students. Overall a good class.
rating_tags: Participation matters--Graded by few things--Group projects

comment: Dr. Joe is an incredibly knowledgeable professor who treats his students with the utmost respect. Although I believe this was his first semester at ND, he did a great job getting know everyone (he had memorized everyone's names and "fun facts" by the third week) and engaging us in interesting marketing discussions. I would highly recommend him!
Unethical and deeply unlikable professor. Avoid!

If you are going to take geographic information systems, it will be from Matt. Good thing he is awesome! His class was incredibly useful and well-organized. He is approachable and his dry humor is perfect.

The class material itself was pretty boring but Torrance is very passionate about what he's teaching which makes the lectures more bearable. He is a pretty easy grader and there's not much work besides readings (which you can get away with not doing) and a few big papers.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--So many papers

comment: I thought Theology class would be a drag, but it isn't that bad with this professor.

My Class experience was not pleasant. Professor seemed to wander off topic at least once every class. She interjected unhinged tangents into the curriculum regarding abortion. All together a weird class.

Her course is not necessarily the hardest (or most interesting), but definitely this is the most frustrating and confusing course I've ever taken - because she gave you the misperception that you will get an A for the whole damn semester and then you get a much much worse grade that doesn't reflect your real effort and performance at all!!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment:
-Disorganized class
-Interesting material
-Not difficult but lots of reading and typing
-Unclear grading criteria on hwk
-interesting readings and videos
-good elective for the entrepreneurship minor

Hurst's class is not hard at all, but she is a tough grader and difficult to please for your assignments/submissions. She's not afraid to give out bad grades if she doesn't receive what she wants. The class was easy and interesting itself but difficult to get an A in.
rating_tags: Graded by few things--Group projects--Tough grader

comment: Class lacks substance. Monotonous. No guidance. He roughly edits papers but does not explain what is wrong/ how to fix it. Whole class based on one paper.

Prof Barber is a highly respected scholar in constitutional studies. His lectures are incredibly interesting, but your attendance has little bearing on class grade. Your grade is solely based on a midterm and final exam.
She is truly a wonderful professor. She is very understanding and adaptable. I always looked forward to her class. Definitely take one of her classes if possible.
She is a true gem. Super enthusiastic and loves what she is teaching. If given the opportunity, take her class!

This was an enjoyable USEM, but he did not give us back our papers until the very end of the year. I don't know how I ended up with the grades I got, but his classes were enjoyable enough that I would go through it again. Intimidating the first couple weeks for an incoming freshman, but after a bit you get used to it and enjoy Campbell.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Campbell makes each class very engaging. Hes really into discussions and requires some papers, but as long as you do the readings youll be fine. Its really a great space to express your opinions and learn how to think like an economist.

Professor Howard is a great guy and he is really passionate about the topic. He talks pretty fast in lectures so sometimes you might have to review some topics on your own if you missed them in class. The class itself was very interesting although I found it to be kind of difficult. Homework wasn't too crazy but took forever
Nice lectures. group projects.

Professor Mclean is great. While his class is lecture heavy, he provides note guides that are very helpful. As long as you pat attention in class, engage in the assigned readings, and complete the minimal homework, you will succeed.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: Great professor! Very knowledgable of the subject. Kind and patient, will expand your knowledge of the Bible. Lots of reading, but manageable and worth it!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Overall, I did not find Professor Niebur engaging during lectures, maybe due to the pandemic. However, he knows what he is talking about. If you go to lectures and pay attention, you will do fine on the exams. Go to class because there are weekly quizzes. Was old-fashioned when it came to picking up graded assignments.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Professor Niebur was a good lecturer who was extremely nice and fair in how he handled the class. The grade was mostly determined by a few tests and the final, but the homework and in class exercises prepare you well for it. If you pay attention in lecture and do homework the rest is easy, and Glen makes it fun and worthwhile.
Very unimpressive.

Gaski’s class is not a lot of work and the tests are not too difficult. No homework, just readings and exams. However, as a person he is extremely difficult and condescending. Be aware, if you use your phone in class (he has his TA spying from the back of the room), he lowers your final grade an entire letter grade.
Prof. Meserve is highly knowledgeable and clearly cares about the subject and her students. She assigns a lot of reading but that's par for this course.

Professor Meserve cares about her students and makes herself available to discuss class matters with them. She is approachable. However, she does not clearly communicate assignment expectations. Her grades on papers seem based more upon her subjective opinions about the arguments expressed within instead of the qualities of the papers themselves.

Schmuhl is a super nice guy, even if he's pretty old. Lectures can get boring, but he always has some funny jokes when class starts. Exams were super manageable if you keep up with the readings and optional practice problems. Not much out of class work and the online excel assignments were easy to knock out if you worked with someone else.

Super nice guy. Does his best to make the class interesting and always puts a joke up before class. Marks attendance. Lectures can be a bit dry and some days it takes a lot of effort to keep from zoning out. Overall a really great professor and would recommend!

Bill is such a great guy and is really passionate about accounting. He always starts the class off by giving a few jokes. However, he is very soft-spoken so sometimes he will put you to sleep during lecture. I would suggest reading the textbook prior to lecture to get a better understanding. But other than that, I highly recommend
By far least enjoyable class at ND. Topics were extremely irrelevant and outdated, and lectures were boring. Attendance was on a contingent basis
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Doesn't tell u the exam score averages or post grades on Canvas. Exams are so poorly worded & by no means test ur level of understanding. Makes objective answers to subjective questions & leaves no room for contrary cases.feels more like an indoctrination rather than a lecture. Unbelievably boring, dreaded going every day. gives vague anwrs unfunny

Professor Raiha is one of the coolest professors I've ever had at ND. His lectures for sports economics were really great. We had a final capstone for the class, but he gave us a lot of support throughout the semester and many options to complete, with varying degrees of difficulty. He is honestly a great guy. I would easily take the class again.

Professor Raiha is among the mosted skilled and gifted lecturers at Notre Dame, and you truly feel that you have walked away from each lecture having learned something. His Money, Banking, and Mortgage Markets class is incredibly well-structured, and it integrates much of what I have learned in other finance and economics classes.
I really enjoyed this class. He goes through slides fairly quickly, but honestly I felt that kept me engaged because I knew I had to be paying attention.

He speaks fast and goes through about 60 slides/ class. There's a midterm, a final, a few psets, and a project. He takes forever to grade homework, and goes so fast that we often had to cover the same material in the next class cause he went too fast. He seems like a good guy though, and exams aren't that tough  if you have time to study for them.

Prof. Chimal Dzul wasn't actually the professor I signed up with for intro to Linear Algebra and Diff Eq., but I ended up attending his lectures all semester long because he was the best explainer in the department. He's very responsive to student questions during lecture, and I would highly recommend taking him for MATH 20580

He was a great professor. Very clear explanations, gave lots of helpful examples and did great review sessions before the exams which helped a ton. He is also super funny and cares about his students a lot. The class overall was pretty hard in my opinion, the content itself wasn't too bad but the exams were very tricky and difficult.

I took MUS 13182 and my USEM, and it was much harder than expected. Prof. Bullock is clearly very knowledgeable and passionate about the class, and he was very willing to allow us to pursue our own musical interests in our final paper, but the readings/reflection papers, especially at the beginning of the semester, were quite time-consuming.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Accessible outside class

comment: Prof. Bullock was a super caring and passionate professor. He has done a lot of service and worked in kids hospitals - it really shows through in how he wants each person to feel valued. However, he is a super tough grader. He is always willing to chat about how you can improve and even restructure the course for the class. Harder than expected.

Ridiculously graded considering it is an elective. She's the kind of professor to only give 1 or 2 A's out of principle. Grade based on 3 essays (2 in class), & her writing style/structure expectations are never communicated clearly. Heard her TA was an unfair/contradictory/rude grader. She is a nice person, but I don't recommend the class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment:
This class had 95% of the final grade split between 3 papers. Two of those papers were in class exams, and the other was a 10-12 page paper. She graded all three of these very difficultly, especially for an elective class. Class was super boring, and readings were very long. Don't take. 

She seems like a nice person though

I enjoyed this class at the beginning: the perfect balance of challenge while still being doable. However, in the literal Civil War history class, I find it HIGHLY unacceptable for the teacher to be quoting the N-word!! (Yes, in class, out loud!) multiple times. I wouldn't take any courses taught by this professor and find her behavior deplorable.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Avoid this class unless absolutely necessary. Drop rate is very high, only 3 total grades. Midterm (writing a paper during class time), 10-12 page paper, and final (same as midterm). Grades extremely harshly and states incorrect facts in class (I checked). Feels like a masters or PHD level class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: She is the sweetest! She is very passionate about the subject and makes the coursework engaging even when the readings aren't. Some of the material is not very exciting, but Barbara makes up for it. Grades are made up of 2-3 papers, but she is not a harsh grader. It takes her a little bit to get out feedback, but the comments she gives are helpful.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: The class was one of my favorites because Prof. Green is really sweet and clearly passionate about the topic. I found the beginning readings to be a bore, but they were more fun towards the end. She gives you the option to turn in a rough draft and edit it to turn in. She's a tough grader on originality, but everything else is normal. I love her.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: Very eager and caring yet new professor (earned PhD may 2024). Room to improve with communication/clarity however, which is often lacking. He's a non-native English speaker so there's a slight language barrier. Lectures are sometimes dull. Grade based on time consuming weekly homework, a group project, and 2 exams which were manageable.

It was his first semester teaching so I'll cut him some slack but it was not a great intro to Spanish experience. Tests were super easy but class was rlly boring and grading on writing/speaking assignments was so quite harsh — taking off full rubric points for a handful of mistakes. Was not super personable but definitely think he can/will improve!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Lots of homework

comment: Incredibly hard grader that would not take into consideration the fact this is a beginning level Spanish class. I would do schedule your classes around NOT taking this prof.

Do not take his class! Possibly the WORST teacher for a beginner 2 class. He has no consideration for it being an intro course and cares more about his own studies than about teaching you the material well. He is unwilling to work with you to get better in the course and just expects you to do everything on your own. HARSH GRADER!! Condescending!

Grobien is a very dry lecturer, and even at the end of the semester, I have no idea what he's looking for in the responses and term paper. His tests (2 + final) were okay. The first was fine, but then he got really specific and I swear I don't remember him talking about half the things on the exam. I did the reading and showed up to class everyday.

John Sherry was way to liberal for me and I feel my conservative views affected my grade.  He could not explain why I received a low grade on my final project (he gave no direction), other than to say that it was not what he was looking for. Even after he reviewed our projects a week earlier with no comment.  Very unprofessional.
No Comments
Reading and writing intensive. Tough class but prof gives lots of feedback. She really cares about helping us.

The course itself isn't too bad as long as you attend lecture and do homework, but Dr. Shaw isn't the best at lectures. She spends them talking at the class as she does a problem on the board. It isn't very engaging, but you need the lectures to understand the material. I'd opt for a different professor, but avoiding the 8:20 section was worth her.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS

comment: nice guy. lots of readings. cheap textbook.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Respected--Get ready to read

comment: While Linh Nguyen's class was quite boring, she did a good job of teaching and explaining the material. The class was pretty easy overall. The problem sets were based on a previous professor's homework, and the answers were online. Also, the tests were pretty easy with the class average being an A I think.
Loved her class!  Thought-provoking topics, interesting discussions, super down to earth (and smart) professor.  10/10 would take again.

Philosophy as a concept is pretty challenging but if you show up and pay attention, you'll be fine. Participation is important so he learns your name. Lots of reading assigned but you can easily get by without doing it because his lectures summarize the readings. Online quizzes randomly assigned based on readings can be done with Sparknotes.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: The class child and adolescent psychopathology was an interesting class but a little boring at times, just lectures with powerpoints. Professor Miller-Graff is one of my favorite professors I've had. She's such a nice person and you can tell she really cares about what she's teaching. Great, interesting professor!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: Does not explain thing very clearly, does not explain the process, just does it. Not very approachable.

Honestly, she is just the sweetest prof I have had at ND (but also I am a frosh so….) If you are looking for a Moreau class, no matter what time, you can NEVER go wrong with her. She genuinely cares for her students, is super understanding, and only wants you to succeed and have a chill semester. (S/O to her weekly snack pile for her students)

Prof Ghosh is caring and willing to answer all questions before,during, or after class! I came into the class with a calc background but if I hadn't I'm not sure how well I would have done. He is easy to understand but sometimes he fails to adequately explain concepts/connect them to the real world. Fine w background in calc might be hard without.

Professor Barone* is a kind and intelligent professor. She is approachable and really cares about her students. She really tries to break down topics and simplify things for us. The course is quite difficult however she makes it worthwhile. She gives so much material to practice for exams. I cannot praise her enough.She is also very fair with exams

Terrific guy and a great resource to have but he's not the best professor. Everyone seemed to always be confused and struggling and grades were extremely low. If I took the class again I wouldn't attend a lecture and would just read the textbook and do homework problems to learn. Got a B- in MD1 but an A in MD2
Easily the worst professor I had at Notre Dame. He somehow managed to make the content impossible to understand, making lectures useless. Would never take again.

One of my favorite professors at Notre Dame. Was worried as a double STEM major taking a history class, but she makes it really accessible and engaging for people who don't have much prior knowledge in current events. I can tell she really cares about the students. 10/10 class and prof, would absolutely take again. No papers, just 3 exams.

Professor Keys is such a sweet lady! She cares for all her students, and is also very good at explaining difficult concepts in simpler terms. If you want to succeed in the Justice Seminar, going to her office hours is a must! If you ever get the chance to take a course with Keys, don't pass up the opportunity! She is one of the best Notre Dame has!

Prof Johnson is a super good guy... He is very knowledgeable about theology. I would however recommend you take a different theology for your THEO 2 requirement. He is extremely boring and unless you are passionate about this topic like him, you will be falling asleep and lost. The only grades in his class are 6 essays.

Wern gives decent lectures with good explanations of concepts. She also holds multiple weekly office hours and is easy to reach out of class. Dont buy the textbook. Though this class curriculum is standardized irrespective of which calculus professor you take, Calc 10360 has a lot of homework.
rating_tags: Lecture heavy--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: This class felt somewhat like a generic economics class with some present-day literature on the developing world. The amount of homework is very manageable - and Professor Firth is accessible outside of class for any help you need. Tests are not difficult if you do the homework.

Professor Brown is a solid 2nd theo professor. You won't quite be able to coast to an automatic A, but if you put in a reasonable amount of work you won't have a hard time in the course. I took it online and still found the material reasonably interesting, and Brown approaches it with a pretty open mind.

Strebinger can be funny/interesting as a professor. The layout of the class makes it enjoyable with a short lesson then free time to do your work. This is useful because the TA's are there during class to help with daily assignments. The class is pretty time consuming but it can be enjoyable working with CAD once you get used to it.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Group projects--Clear grading criteria

comment: Taeho is an amazing professor, and it's always really clear how much he cares about his students. As long as you communicate with him when you need to be absent, etc., and are prepared to go to office hours for help with homework, it's not too hard to get a decent grade in the class. The homeworks do take a while, but he's crazy helpful if you ask.

The class is all about a research project. There are no exams and weekly one page blog posts. Professor Beatty is very caring and kind and an overall great professor. Class material can be a little dry at times if you do not enjoy engineering history. You can send Professor Beatty drafts of your blog posts to get feedback before submission.

McWill is super old and the class is a little slow because of it. He basically just reads off a slide and that's it. He's a really nice guy and a funny guy, but in terms of course material he's useless. It feels like he has no idea what he's talking about. The class is really an easy A though.

Phenomenal professor. Did a really good job teaching Foundations. She made the information easy to learn, assignments were reasonable, and her outlines really made lectures easy to follow. Only negative is a high grading scale

Zaira is so caring and sweet. She made Spanish super fun, easy, and exciting. I enjoyed going to her class every day because she always had something fun planned for our class! I wish I could take her for the intermediate level courses!

Professor Champion is a really great professor with a lot of interesting things. He gets distracted a lot, but it made the 75 minute classes in the morning more bearable. He took forever to get us quiz grades back, but HW and tests were quick. Quizzes are worth more than he led on, as those were the deciding factor between me getting an A and A-.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.--Amazing lectures

comment: Nicest person ever. Allows you to choose your final mark.. easy A if you complete all your work. Also allows you to rewrite all of your assignments. Also actually covers interesting topics. Best writing and rhetoric class.

Had her for principles of marketing. Almost every class is a lecture. A lot of it can get repetitive but if you make a quizlet of all the vocab for each exam you're basically learning all the material. Can get a little boring in class but if you read the book like you're supposed to, it makes class like a reinforcement exercise

I really enjoyed taking the University seminar with Professor Abram. I took Post-Apocalyptic literature with him. We read around 5 books throughout the semester. It was an easy class with reverse grading and I genuinely enjoyed the discussions we had.

Took Professor Zimmermann for intro to Soc. Very easy grader, don't think I missed a single point throughout the semester, including on papers. However, his lectures are very insightful and you will never be bored---Ever.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Clear grading criteria--Accessible outside class

comment: Professor Mainwaring is one of the best professors I've ever had. He is brilliant and his lectures are engaging and worthwhile. He truly cares about you and wants everyone to succeed. Get ready to read and write, but I always found the content to be interesting. If you need to take a comparative politics course, take Latin American Politics!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Amazing lectures --So many papers

comment: Professor Kellenberg is an AMAZING person and instructor. He facilitates engaging discussions and cares for all his students. His class isn't difficult as long as you put in the effort. I can honestly say that he is one of ND's best. Additionally, you will learn a lot in the class that will help you better understand the world we live in.

Very good professor, but he just speaks fast and goes through his lectures fast. He is always willing to help students out, outside of class, and wants you to succeed. If you ask questions about the problem sets, do not expect clear answers.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: Everyone loves Professor Kilbane. He is the most caring, interesting, and engaging professor I have had. He truly cares about his students and wants us to learn. I looked forwards to going to his class every day. The lectures are cool, projects are fun, and I learned a lot. He created a great environment and would take his class in a heartbeat.

Great professor that really cares about his students; he goes above and beyond to help us outside of class. One of the easiest second Theo courses at Notre Dame. He teaches quite well, and his discussions are always engaging. Light workload.
Great professor that makes a subject most of us are unfamiliar with really digestible. She actually cares about her students, and goes the extra mile to make sure we're going to do well on the tests.

I would not recommend taking him. His lectures were very disorganized and you just ended up listening to other students talk for the entire class period. He does not use slides or go over the readings. Also, he did not put any grades in for the entire semester so I had no idea what my final grade would be.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: Awesome professor, great teaching style. Explains content well. Willing to be flexible with office hours. Tests can be difficult, but he lets you make up points.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lots of homework--Accessible outside class

comment: Grade comes from short daily reader responses, a few quizzes, 2 papers, midterm, and final. He provides guided note-taking handouts so studying is easier. Loved the small discussion sections. Reader responses are basically a completion grade. Interesting readings. A great first Theo no matter how much you know/don't know about Catholicism.
rating_tags: Amazing lectures --Gives good feedback--Accessible outside class

comment: This was my favorite class ever taken. It was so fun, interesting, and easy. Participation matters but he makes sure everyone succeeds. He does cold call, but he lets you talk over discussions with your table partners first which makes it easy. I recommend this class to everyone!

Her seminar class was very tough and definitely one of the harder USEMS, but definitely the most rewarding. She was incredibly knowledgeable about each work and author, and she had very high standards for our own work. Very accessible at office hours. She cared deeply about what each of us was interested in ourselves.

Jonathan Boulos is both an excellent teacher and human. He cares about his students and was extremely understanding of personal extenuating circumstances. His lectures are short and sweet with an emphasis on their application to the real world, in which he has had a detailed career in accounting.

Prof Coleman is a pretty caring prof whose passion pulls you into interest of the subject as well. I did not care much for environmental history at first but Coleman's lectures got me pretty interested in the subject. His lectures are pretty straightforward however expect to read multiple 300+ pg books in essay writing weeks (only 4 essays tho).

Willie is amazing. Great at starting conversations and genuinely cares for his students. Like most (but not all) Moreau teachers, you can get an A just by showing up and reaching the word count on all of the assignments. If you are between him and a section with a prof you don't know I would highly recommend.

Prof Guo taught a fun CSEM about Arabian Nights! I learned a lot, but I never felt like the course was too much. We watched some short films and read 3 books, but the reading was split up well throughout the course. I liked the class, and the presentations were very low-pressure. Enjoyed the course!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: She made sure we cared about Moreau. She followed Moreau's coursework by the book. She lengthened her classes to get to 50 minutes. Most thought it was boring, but it is an easy A, and she is not a very bad teacher.
learned a lot, recommend to everyone

This class forces you into a dilemma: sacrifice your academic integrity or fall behind. Professor Riley creates an environment where undergrads feel pressured to compete with others blatantly breaking the honor code. It's unacceptable and reflects poorly on ND to allow someone like her to teach here. She doesn't deserve to represent this university

TERRIBLE! By far the worst professor I've had. Lectures are mind-numbing and unclear. Grading is a joke—few assignments, a brutal curve, and grades based purely on luck. The open-note exam jacked up the curve, and the final was completely unfair and irrelevant. Participation is pointless. Stay far away—if you're stuck with her, RUN FAST.

I really enjoyed Professor Riley's class! The first test was open note/ not in class so I was quite scared of the curve, however things picked up in the second half with the exam being a lot more challenging. Her class was super interesting and fair, would recommend!

She's extremely into what she does, but I think that makes her get a little carried away sometimes in stuff that we don't really care about. Class environment was very informal and many got away with not paying attention or just straight skipping class. Tests are open-book so very low pressure. Would recommend for easy A for non-marketing majors

Very knowledgeable and passionate about "sanctity & society," has even written a book in her field of study. 
Expect daily readings (sometimes quite lengthy), 5 papers, & mandatory participation (which is graded rather harshly, volunteer a "question, critique, or comment" at least 2-3 times per class). Overall a very interesting professor & class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Graded by few things

comment: I took her for calc II. She gave good lectures and was clear about the topics; I just really didn't like calculus, and I'm terrible at it. I would recommend her, though; she's straightforward and clear.
The class is very lecture heavy. Lectures about 80% of the class then some discussion on the readings. There are very few assignments outside of the reading. I would recommend.
No extra credit and made midterm and final way harder than in class and homework. Nice lecturer and available outside classroom, though.

Professor Dochuk demonstrates great knowledge of the material he teaches, and he is very passionate about the course content. He makes it clear that he wants you to learn and engage in the material, which is very refreshing. Cares about students' well-being and interest in the material. Class is mostly essay and presentation based.

Super cool guy, very smart, and tries his hardest to make classes enjoyable. Always available and willing to talk about the class or whatever you desire. The class is hard though. Put a lot of effort into the homeworks, they prepare you for the exams.
Professor Kelly is a great guy and makes class fun. He lectures a lot but throws in games so it isnt boring. Highly recommend taking him if you get the chance.

Recommend! Practice exams are true to the actual ones, you're allowed a sheet of info for every exam, and studying the material 100% lets you perform well on the exam. The 2-person final group project is both very reasonable and great experience for freshman year. Great ease into EE, but highly recommend using office hours for weekly homeworks.

Professor Johnson is very nice and approachable. His lectures can be convoluted and confusing. His midterms are difficult and he doesn't give enough material to practice for the exams. For our final, we didn't get any practice material and he canceled the last class before the final. Despite this, I still would take more of his classes.

Terrible lecturer. Her notes are all over the place and there is no clear logic or line of reasoning throughout the lecture. And she doesn't post the notes online. Also impossible to reach outside of class. I would email her 4-5 days before an exam with a question and she wouldn't respond until after the exam took place. TERRIBLE!!! DO NOT TAKE!!!!
She's new but very fun and cool. Not a fan of her lecturing style but some people love it.

Professor Grillo is a nice person and her lectures are interesting, however, Honors Theo is out of 100 points. She assumes her students have a knowledge of Christianity and Judaism that people who did not grow up religious and do not have an interest in those subjects do not possess. Reliant on TA to grade papers and expects too much in them.
Horrible organization of the course. Harsh grader, takes points off for unnecessary reasons.
Father Mike is a legendary Moreau professor. Class is easy and he is a really nice and funny.
PROFESSOR BECHLER IS AWESOME. Test right off powerpoints. He cares so much and his class is actually so interesting. Best marketing class at ND.

I loved having Professor Robson for my discussion section of "Why Business?" Professor Robson is incredibly kind and has very interesting conversation starters prepared for each meeting. I was never in a position where I needed to seek extra help, but he was available outside of meeting times for anyone who needed feedback.

Don't take. Class is extremely boring due to both material and lecture style. Graded on very few things in which are graded extremely strict. The final exam was long and asked a lot of unimportant things in comparison to the big pictures of the class. As a positive, there wasn't much work involved in the class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Great, funny professor. Weekly problem sets. Two midterms + final exam
Very good professor, explains concepts pretty well
No Comments

This guy gets it. Great teacher and a very charismatic classroom personality. Has helped my writing so, so much. His being an ND man helps. He relates to what we are going through as freshmen and is real with us. The best class I had this first semester of college.

Professor Khan is a really great teacher. I had him for Topology, and he made the subject quite approachable. His lectures were clear and well-prepared, and he included many instructive examples, which I think is essential to bring the abstract concepts of topology down to earth. He holds lots of office hours, and he keeps an updated website.
His class is nothing like the homework which is nothing like the tests. Its really easy math that he teaches but he is very abstract and makes simple concepts much harder than they need to be.
Zach is a really good instructor. He does a good job of explaining the process of building pieces and gives good feedback. He is really laidback and very funny.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Clear grading criteria--Hilarious

comment: Professor Nguyen is pretty average professor. He clearly knows the material and greatly cares about the students, being constantly available for them, but his lectures are mediocre. If you need to take a class taught by him, he won't be your favorite professor, but he will get you through the class with a decent understanding of the material.

His assignments are impossibly vague  we had to request a rubric that wasn't helpful, and I asked four times if our "second paper" was supposed to be a revision or a new paper and didn't get a helpful answer; smart but arrogant, gives same lecture almost every class
I hate music theory.  I love Professor Johnson's classes.
Just a great guy.
Very unique way to learn about the English language.
BEST professor in the law school. Panel system.

Great guy! Very funny and entertaining, very helpful both inside and outside the classroom. A few group projects but they're very straightforward. Everyone loves him and he makes sure everyone's engaged and understands. If you show up and pay attention, studying for tests is easy. Assignments are easy (took me less than an hour usually). Love him!

Sara is an amazing professor! She is hilarious and is a total genius  she is by far the smartest person I have ever met. She is incredibly knowledgeable and always has a quick response to questions, and can always dream up different unique thought experiments for the class. Her time travel course has a lot of reading, but it was manageable and fun

Great professor for Moreau, not a lot of work but Moreau is kind of the same everywhere so that does not really matter. Not a harsh grader, just show a little effort. He likes to cold call. Understanding.

Professor Grillo is incredibly knowledgeable and passionate about Latin and will do his best to increase your knowledge of Latin. However, the course (intermediate latin) was very difficult and involved a ton of work. Great for classics majors and will definitely make you better at Latin, but non-majors beware.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--LOTS OF HOMEWORK

comment: Bright guy, very helpful and understanding. When you have an issue he is extremely reasonable. Brings energy to the classroom, makes some good jokes and does a great job teaching the content of the course. He really understands how to meet each student at the level they are at and teach them from there.
Although he means well, he is not the best professor. He gets frustrated when students don't understand the material like he does. The content is really fuzzy and the tests are extremely challenging.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--GROUP PROJECTS--LECTURE HEAVY

comment: Professor Rowland is great. A real Italian woman who knows everything about Rome that you could ever imagine. She is very caring for her students and is more than willing to help on any paper or research. She is also a great mentor and a person who can help you along the way on your college iist

Great Macro class, he makes it very simple to pass. Homework assignments due each class and three exams. He gives very comprehensive study guides for each test, some of the questions are even the same. His lectures are not mandatory but are interesting.
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Clear grading criteria--Lecture heavy

comment: What he writes on board is just exactly copied from the textbook. Don't think he truly understands what he is teaching. Can't answer student questions.
The teacher is nice but give a decent amount of homework, she also accepts late work but deducts points off.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Participation matters

comment: I took one of Dr. Quesadas university seminar and hands down it was my favorite class freshman year. She is very passionate about her teachings and she always makes lectures interesting somehow. The books I read in her class are probably ones that Ill always remember because of how unique and amusing they are.

Professor Mathieu is a very nice man, but he is hard to learn from. I will also say that he is very accessible, but his teaching is bland and way too theoretical. I had to watch the lectures of another professor teaching the same class because his lectures were awful. Avoid him if you can, but if you get him try and get notes somewhere else.

Seth is a godsend, he takes his time to make sure everyone is understanding the material, and gives ample time during class to ask questions on homework or tests. Super engaging lectures, you will never be bored or lost.

Mast is one of the best professors I have had at ND. He is so knowledgable about urban econ, which makes the lectures super interesting. The things you learn are applicable outside of class. Exams are not easy but doable if you study the problem sets and pay attention in lecture. This is one of the best econ electives you can take.

I had her for THEO 13183, a USEM. There are a lot of readings for the course, but overall everything is discussion based and she definitely meets you where you are. 10/10 would always recommend. Oh wait, sometimes she's a little slow to grade and post assignments, but they're not too difficult and you have nothing to worry about.

Kim is a very nice professor. She's kind of strange and laughs at her own jokes a lot. Her class is easy though. Would recommend. The class itself was fairly boring but she allowed computers so I just went on my computer the whole time and got an A still. You had to go to 4 liturgies outside of class. She did not give a compensating day off.

She gave a good effort in teaching but I would never take this teacher again. She is very hard to understand and follow, if I hadn't taken high school AP calculus I would suffer greatly in this class. Definitely take a different teacher if you want to get an A in this class.

He was my TA in intro philo. Always accessible via office hours and email/Slack. Awesome feedback on rough drafts and papers. Philosophy makes a lot of sense to him and he will expect a lot of you (grades pretty harshly) but he'll help as much as he can to make your papers good before you turn them in. Highly recommend him, you'll learn a lot.

I took Intro to Public Policy and it was great! Mueller is well versed on current events and has political experience which made lecture super interesting. Reading is long but keep up with it as it is relevant for midterm and final. Study for the midterm; it is pretty tough. The rest of the assignments were quite easy. Great class!!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Group projects--Lecture heavy

comment: Professor Webber makes a difficult class seem manageable. The individual processes are simple, almost obvious sometimes, but the problems can be so time consuming and difficult to read that the hardest part about the class is time management. Do every practice problem, test, anything as many times as you can to get used to doing algebra so fast.
rating_tags: Respected--Accessible outside class--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: Amazing professor! He's great at starting class discussions and makes you think about the texts you're reading from multiple perspectives. The workload was reasonable and the tests/papers were focused on making you think about prominent themes rather than memorization. He's an engaging lecturer and values student input.
Love her so much! Such a caring person and wants you to actually learn the content. Put in the work and you will succeed. Also, a super interesting person and very caring

The best professor and class Ive ever taken at notre dame. He is so knowledgeable and accessible. I truly enjoyed coming to class and discussing the films. He really cares about his students and will do anything to help. AMAZING PROFESSOR, EVEN BETTER PERSON

Professor Pinderhughes is pretty nice and the material for the course is interesting. She does tend to go off on tangents for an unreasonable amount of time, but she's clearly very knowledgeable in her field. I'd recommend anyone with an interest in race take her USEM (Black politics after the civil-rights era)
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--So many papers

comment: Prof. Pinderhughes runs a very discussion heavy class and values student voice/input. To do well in this class, participate! Show her that you are engaging with the texts she is assigning.
rating_tags: Respected--Graded by few things--Clear grading criteria

comment: Prof. Estefan is committed to his teaching. He spends time during his lectures to make sure the students understand the subject matter. He also makes himself available for office hours, so make sure to take advantage of those if economics is not your thing or you are having trouble grasping a particular topic.

Professor Macdonald was an ok professor. The class is difficult, and the lectures can be quite boring. The one highlight of the class was the guest speakers. You MUST participate a ton in the class otherwise he will heavily take off your participation grade. He is very accessible outside of class, and does seem to care for his students.

One of the coolest professors you'll ever have. His expertise in Theology is evident but he is also a great lecturer and really entertaining. He's super accessible and helpful outside of class and honestly, as long as you put in some effort you'll get a good grade. Often lets class out early once he's covered all his material. Overall a great guy.

He is very knowledgeable. However, I found his lectures very hard to follow. He doesn't use slides and he assumes that his students have a high level of background knowledge. You must do all the readings to do well, but I feel like his readings weren't introductory level, and would've been more appropriate to assign to an intermediate class.

For PHYS 20065, His lectures are extremely informational and he explains everything very clearly. Class is graded off of daily quizzes (very easy), 4 homework sets, and three exams. The concepts are tough, but an A is very obtainable. Overall he is a great and funny guy, definitely recommend if you are interested in the subject.

Class went super in-depth on random facts and tests did not cover major themes at all - just random bullet points from slides. Desch was a cool lecturer and is a nice guy, but also assigns an absurd amount of reading for the days he teaches the class. Pretty hard tests but some easy points from take-home and check-in quizzes each day.

This review applies only for The Science and Strategy of Nuclear War. This class was terrible. It was the information for 4 classes (history, chemistry, physics, strategy) in one. Tests are a mix of complicated physics and obscure history /poli sci facts from the lecture, but never about main ideas. Readings can be over 100 pages per class period.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Prof. Desch is great! He is very good at leading a seminar. He helps summarize the key points of the reading for the first 20 minutes of the class, then moves into a structured discussion of the reading. He is very kind and loves to joke around. He is also very passionate and knowledgeable
This is my dad. He is a good teacher. I did not actually take this class but he's been lecturing me my whole life. You should his class. It would be funny.

Professor Morris is what I imagined college professors being like. He's pretty funny, very knowledgeable, and works with students by caring about their opinions. However, his class is not easy. In order to get the most out of lecture and understand the material, you NEED to read the book. Otherwise you are screwed for his hard tests.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Test heavy

comment: Professor Bentley spent most of the time doing practice problems instead of lecturing/describing the material. In physics, you need a good balance of describing and practicing, and he was one extreme. Although we did a lot of problems, they did not seem to help with weekly problem set or tests.

Professor Rossiter was my favorite professor last semester! I really enjoyed her seminar and learned a lot from it, and on top of that she was a pretty easy grader and really worked with her students when they needed it. Can't recommend enough.

Professor Toumayan is really patient and offers many opportunities for extra credit. He always gives essay extensions if needed. Participation is worth 25% of the final grade, but you don't need to speak in every lecture.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: Writing this review to ensure Blado never gets full professorship. He is an incredibly hard-headed individual, and incredibly unhelpful when it comes to giving advice. He has a robotic personality and is unable to connect with students. He turned GGL from a fun introductory philosophy class into a struggle to get a halfway decent grade. Avoid!!

Very interesting class. Wonderful lecturer. I never quite knew how I was doing in the class. Reading responses were required for homework before every class. No exams, just essays. One 15 minute presentation for each student to teach a chapter of the book we read in class.
