Professor Dingler is my favorite professor I have had so far at ND. Tests are extremely fair as are homework. Really accommodating and accessible outside of class.

The professor encourages participation and has created a relaxed and non-judgmental environment. She wants everyone to speak as much as possible and provides many opportunities for extracredit. She is open to hearing our ideas. Perhaps more English at the beginning would have been better because it was hard to follow during the first two weeks.

The content she teaches is pretty hard and when you ask questions, she's resistant to answering fully & tells you to find the answer independently. Not very organized, very few things are graded, grading on exams is harsh and arbitrary for essay questions, suddenly and often cancels classes. Grading for participation is entirely unfair and random!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Professor Morrell was by far my favorite professor this semester. You can tell she genuinely cares about each of her students. You do have to read a lot for this class but the books are very interesting and easy to read. There is a final annotated bibliography and a research paper worth most of your grade, but they weren't hard to do.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Caring

comment: Prof is hilarious, passionate, and knowledgeable about all things Tudor England and beyond. You have 15 pages of reading paired with reading reports due before every class and two essays with min. 2,000 words each. Everything is due by email, which he never answers, so it's difficult to get in touch with him. Overall, lax class but you have to work
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: One of the most unprofessional professors you'll ever have. She doesn't answer questions well, and she's quick to cut you off.

Lectures are pretty boring. Part of that is the material itself is very dry and Creighton doesn't bring much energy either. She is effective at instructing though. There is not much homework and exams are departmental. Easy option for acct 2 but it is not very exciting
Very poor at explaining. Not helpful to students at all.
I loved her. Very compassionate and genuinely cares about her students. 10/10 TAKE HER.

I enjoyed taking the USEM with Professor Burman. He is a tough grader on papers who pays close attention to language and details, but he explains his grading. He is very knowledgable about Islamic history, and it shows in his lectures. However, the class discussions can get boring at times.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: I took Prof. Burman for USEM and I enjoyed it. He is an extremely tough grader on the papers but he will explain his grading. He is very knowledgeable about the history of Islam and it shows. The class was all discussion about the previous nights readings, which can be long. Take notes on the readings, it will help with the three papers you write.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Gives good feedback

comment: Sims is a fantastic person. Lectures were funny and knows what it is like to be a student and cares about them. Int Macro was very hard. Going to lecture, office hours, and paying attention is a must. HW is moderate (5 problem sets) Study for exams multiple days in advance; you cannot wing them. Funny prof and would recommend but be ready to study.
Dr. Peterson was an amazing professor and would 10/10 take any of his classes again!

Dr. A is a great professor. She prepares you well for the exams while also being super friendly and approachable. Definitely take her class if you have the chance. Just remember to ask her about her 2024-25 fantasy football championship game. She loves talking about it.

Dr. A is entertaining and cares about students. Extremely approachable, covered a lot of ground. Only downside is that she didn't spend a lot of time developing deep understanding of the material. A lot of process memorization.

Class concepts are sometimes challenging but Dr. Adamo is great at explaining them and provides great notes.Tutorial Quizzes and labs (coding) are open book, homeworks are probably the hardest part of the class and can take up to 3-4 hours a week if done properly, but they can set you up really well for exams which are easier than practice ones.

The class is super fast and covers a lot of things within limited time -- and the test covers everything taught in class, the entire textbook (that did not talk about in class), quizzes, and homework. The test questions are SUPER HARD. This class took me the longest to review—both the tests and quizzes were tough!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Lecture heavy--Test heavy

comment: Lectures were sometimes boring but attendance was crucial to understanding the material and doing well on exams and quizzes. Quizzes were unnecessarily hard even if you study, exams were ok. I learned a lot and the course is required so I don't regret taking it but Ryngaert is probably a little harder than the other professors, especially Sims.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Lecture heavy--Accessible outside class

comment: The topics covered in this class were very interesting and Qiong did a very good job lecturing on them and facilitating discussion in class. I typically get bored with long readings in philosophy and politics classes, but I found this class fun.
Came to class everyday with great energy. Taught material well, with shortcuts to while making sure we understood the keys underlying concepts

Took him for Calc 1. He is a grad student. He was a great professor--lectures were clear and chalkboard was used to give notes. He was particularly accessible outside of class, often hosting extra office hours before exams. He also went through the trouble of learning the name of everyone in our section--he clearly cares about his students a lot.
